this very quickly made it into maybe my top 3 favorite video games of all time. i got 100% completion on my first playthrough.

if you like star wars like i do, youll love this games story and characters. its fantastic, and very refreshing considering they dont make good star wars movies anymore. this game plays out like a very slow star wars movie. the plot genuinely moved me, and there is so much cinematic creativity throughout

the combat is good. its closer to sekiro than a souls game, with a strong emphasis on parrying and a much faster pace, and neat abilities and powerups to get, but boss fights feel pretty aimless and random

the exploration is neat. i enjoyed getting 100%, mostly because i really love the cosmetics. the cosmetic customization in this game is just great btw. lightsaber parts, jackets, droid skins, and ship skins. any puzzles are simple enough to be pleasant, and nothing is TOO out of the way with thorough exploration and a little creativity.

the soundtrack is very nice. nothing id listen to out of context, but it brings great flavor and tone in the moment. the graphics are just incredible. i really didnt think it would be possible for facial animation to be at this level, not just for the human characters, but the aliens too.

Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order is a tour de force in the gaming universe, seamlessly blending the rich lore of the Star Wars universe with captivating gameplay and a compelling narrative. Developed by Respawn Entertainment and published by Electronic Arts, this action-adventure game manages to capture the essence of what makes the Star Wars saga so beloved while delivering an engaging and immersive experience. The storyline follows Cal Kestis, a young Jedi Padawan who narrowly escaped the events of Order 66 and is now trying to survive in a galaxy ruled by the oppressive Galactic Empire. As players guide Cal through various planets, each meticulously crafted with attention to detail, they unravel a gripping tale filled with twists, turns, and moments that truly feel like they belong in the Star Wars canon. One of the standout features of Fallen Order is its lightsaber combat system. Respawn has meticulously designed the combat mechanics, making lightsaber battles feel authentic and rewarding. The parrying, dodging, and strategic use of Force powers create a ballet of combat that mirrors the elegance and intensity of lightsaber duels from the films. As players progress, they can unlock new abilities, enhancing both the combat and exploration aspects of the game. The level design in Fallen Order deserves special commendation. Each planet offers a distinct atmosphere, from the dense forests of Kashyyyk to the industrial landscapes of Zeffo. The interconnected world design encourages exploration, with secrets hidden in every nook and cranny. Solving puzzles and overcoming environmental challenges adds depth to the gameplay, providing a satisfying balance between action and cerebral engagement. The attention to detail in Fallen Order extends beyond the visuals. The score, composed by Stephen Barton, complements the epic nature of the Star Wars universe, enhancing the emotional impact of key moments. The voice acting, particularly by Cameron Monaghan as Cal Kestis, is superb, adding authenticity and depth to the characters. While the game is not without its minor flaws, such as occasional frame rate drops and texture pop-ins, these issues are overshadowed by the overall excellence of the experience. Respawn's commitment to patching and improving the game post-launch also demonstrates their dedication to delivering a polished and enjoyable product.

In conclusion, Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order is a masterful addition to the Star Wars gaming legacy. It successfully captures the magic of the franchise, offering a captivating narrative, exhilarating lightsaber combat, and a galaxy waiting to be explored. Whether you're a die-hard Star Wars fan or a newcomer to the series, Fallen Order is a must-play, proving that the force is indeed strong with this exceptional game.

As someone who loves puzzles, story, collectables and has never touched the Star Wars franchise at all this game is a solid 8.5-9/10 for me. The characters are great, as well as the story and even the action. You definitely do not need prior knowledge of the lore of Star Wars to enjoy this game and would recommend to anyone. 
(Also definitely got me hooked into the franchise as a whole.)

Probably the best Star Wars game in like 2 decades, possibly ever.
Only downsides is once you'r done you probably want more... but there is nothing. (At least if your like me and got all locations at around 93-100% completion already by then, and the final mission which was my favourite is not replayable)... and also it needs Origin to run as written on the side of the steam page.

As for a more useful review.
Plays a lot like adventure games like Tomb Raider and Uncharted, so exploration and a bit of puzzle solving (mostly for side items and upgrades, less so for the main story) with a bit of Souls-like combat and enemy respawn-system thrown in.
It's hardest in the beginning and then feels easier as you progress, with fits with Cals journey from failed padawan to a jedi knight.
So difficulty wise it's easier to get into than other souls-likes since you got the difficulty options to choose from and the easiest one looks like it's a large step down from the others. Likewise for people wanting more of a challenge, the highest seams to be a huge step up from the middle 2 so all in all they could probably be summarized as:
Story (very easy)
Jedi Knight (normal)
Jedi Master (Hard)(I played on this)
Jedi Grand Master (Souls-like?)
(With the difficulty having sliders showing the damage taken, parry windows and enemy aggression when selecting, hence i saw that the bottom and top ones are quite a bit apart from the middle two).

Another thing i kinda like about it was while being linear, often when faced with a fork in the road i had no idea which was the correct route and which was the one hiding a puzzle for a side-secret, which is something that's very rare, usually in games i can just tell "this is the right way, so i'll go into that side path to collect the thing).

Picked it up now on a sale, got to 96% completion in 22h (according to steam) in just over 2 days, But i still feel like this was money well spent.
Overall i say if you see it on a sale or think you can afford it, it's worth a try.
Hopefully the greatness of this game gives us some new direction from EA when comparing it's good publicity to their Battlefront remakes publicity...

I have been a huge star wars fan for many years now, for some reason I never thought of buying Jedi Fallen order until my recent star wars binge.
I decided to give the game a try and here is how my journey was, SPOILERS AHEAD! :

I started the game with no expectations as games in today's climate are either over hyped or underwhelming.
The story did not disappoint and it kept me on the edge of my seat since the very beginning as I started playing as Cal. The cinematics  and music is encapsulating. If you want to grind the game and explore 100% of every planet and find every secret + crates it might take you 20 hours+ but I went straight in and focused mainly on the story. 
In some areas the game took long to get to the point or it felt like it was dragging. The enemies as you progressed felt good as you got stronger they start to feel on your level or a bit easier to challenge. Specifically the boss fights felt difficult as the parry system took a while to master but once you get the hang of it - its a blast. The game mentions its ' soul like' and I personally feel that is far from the truth - yes some aspects such as the adventure or waves of enemies plus  the save station but other than that not much of a soul like game.
This game made me want to come back each time and finish it even after hours of not playing, I think a game+ would be great in a few weeks/months but right after completion not really.

I would of loved the game more if the travelling system were more open world where you could be in space for example and visit more planets, in total there are 7 but only 5 that are completely free to explore and it can become a bit boring once you have completed everything. 

The combat does take a while to get use it, I loved the fact to that you could build onto Cal and choose what abilities to master, as you progress it feels as if the Padawan actually is turning into the Jedi Knight.

The bounty hunters were the one thing I disliked, they would respawn in very difficult times just before you have a boss fight or you don't have a save station nearby, this was a mechanic I disliked but once you cleared them they never respawn again.

Overall the feel of the game is amazing - the story is great. I personally was gobsmacked right at the end of the game, the whole premise of the game was to find the Holocrom and "restore the Jedi" just for Cal to break it. Other than that I still think this game takes you on a ride and I mean who wouldn't want to see the Sith Lord Dark Vader himself.
I think this is a must have for any star wars fan - I would rate the game a 8/10 and would recommend others to give it a try.

Tough to recommend unless you're a fan of Star Wars already, the game is carried a lot by its references to its universe and other events. There's some fan service in there too, for good measure, and the story is mostly convincing and conveniently wrapped at the end. 

The game starts off pretty good, and the ending level is really great, but the middle is a slog. They could have just cut the three planets in between and sell it as a 4 hour masterpiece. 

The absence of any sort of fast travel (save for jumping planet to planet on your ship, thankfully) is pretty bad for a modern game, but abysmal and frustrating for a game that gates functional elements (health packs) behind exploration and secrets. You're either doomed to finish most of the game with just two, or spend a quarter of the game backtracking in search of secrets. 

Some of the environments are good, and some of the exploration is pretty neat, but there are plenty of stages that are uninspired and with frustrating level design. The progression of getting your skills 'back' makes sense narratively, but it means you're only spending a small fraction with the full arsenal, and this feels bad. 

Enemy variety is probably as low as it gets, and it's not an issue with stormtroopers - after all, how many ranks can there be - but wildlife could have afforded to be more varied throughout the vast galaxy. Combat is fine but never as engaging as the souls-like formula would expect it to be; bosses are thankfully easy enough to make up for the lack of finesse. Again, apart from the last level, where density and variety finally clicked, most of it feels off. 

There's still plenty of bugs in the game, even after the sequel got some fixes already, but nothing overly disturbing. You can feel like a speedrunner hacking through walls and invisible ropes even just playing normal! The most game breaking part is the EA launcher not launching the game at all, especially on Steam Deck (where it's decent once/if it starts).

I did enjoy the cast a lot, and the story too, but I just wish they gave them a better game to star in.

The game is easily forgotten. I don't believe i would want to replay this game for a few reasons. The mechanics are extremely clunky as there has been too many times where i jump for an objective and i constantly miss or am 95% there and the character doesn't execute. The story is predictable and the story line is kind of dumb, just because the main character some how forgets all his training. The game puts in you a memory of training during game play. I absolutely hated having to go back to previous planets just to get that ONE chest, or that ONE path i couldn't reach because, and again, you forget your training. The game constantly has you looking for chests that only give you cosmetics and are useless. The saber/bd1 character get absolutely random upgrades throughout the game which makes you feel like no matter how many enemies you kill, or objectives you complete, it doesn't matter because there's a random work bench around the corner. Leveling is arbitrary as you never get a consistent amount of experience. I loved how in the beginning there is a bunch of puzzles but is quickly diminished as you progress and feel like the developers were rushed and tried to complete the game on a deadline. 

I will say the graphics are really good and realistic. Voice acting is top notch as well. I also didn't spend a lot of money buying the game as well so i win in the end.

I'm a little puzzled playing this game, how it can be this unplayable simply due to the horrible gameplay, bugs and save points.

Graphics look good, really good for it's age, runs easy too. But I am now at a point where I have to stop playing because the gameplay is just too broken to keep going, there is zero fun in this. I only spent ¬£4 on this game and the hours I've played so far are 80% just repeating the same shit over and over.

I had several game breaking bugs of things not moving or moving without me, blocking progression forcing me to kill myself.

The controls are a nightmare, literally broken on PC where the dodge is on Y, lol? And on controller the triggers aren't even used for anything in combat. The controls couldn't have been done more unintuitive...

95% of the gameplay is figthing animals and climbing ledges 3 hours in....

Movement feels too slow for half of the mechanics, dodging to short, jumping too short, some attacks take forever until your movement is unblocked again. Running freely on the other hand is super quick as well as turning around and jumping up

In fights against bosses the camera non stops gets pushed away due to walls or dodging making it super difficult to keep track of enemies, the supposed "tracking/focus" function straight up doesn't work for me.

For some dumb reason they've used fixed save point location in the linear levels. When you die fighting a boss you have to spent minutes each time running back for another try. The most frustrating thing in the game if you want to play on hard

The fighting should be fun, but for some reason the blocking/dodging/attack feels clonky and just not triggering correctly

Since the gameplay relies completely on the blocking and dodging mechanics, this breaks the game further since it's done so badly that the difficulty levels are either relying completely on executing the combat to perfection or it makes it so easy that there is no combat gameplay left. No inbetween... I started on hard but the issues with the camera and controls overshadows the actual gameplay. Going down even to normal pretty much removes the combat since you just press A to kill everything. On the easy mode/Game Journo mode it's pretty much just walk through the levels

Idk if I come back to this again later, but for now I'm so fed up with this shit trying to make it work to at least see the story, let alone "enjoy" the game

Edit: EDIT: I FINALLY got help from a Steam Agent that read and comprehended the issue.

If you are having this issue, try the following: 

1. hit your windows key and search for "regedit"
2. go to "Computer\HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Respawn\Jedi Fallen Order"
3. Change the value of the variable "Install Dir" to whatever your install directory is for the game in steam.

Original review: I am leaving this here because the process to get this issue resolved gave me an extreme headache for way too long and it might be better just to not deal with it.

Enjoyable story and good graphics. You definitely feel like a Padawan to begin with but you start to feel stronger towards the end of the game. It's a good feeling of progress. If you expect to be Starkiller you will be disappointed. 

I'm not a fan of the combat and map system. The combat timing can be very tricky and really punishes button mashing or mistakenly pressed buttons. The map system is not clear and could be larger... Maybe my old age is starting to set in?

Overall an enjoyable experience. Probably better for Star Wars fans. I won't be 100% the secrets any time soon...Unlike the Batman Arkham series.

[b]TLDR[/b]
An awful journey+good end game type of experience from the era of Dark Souls

***

I have played through this on Jedi Grandmaster with two stems and one late game accidental health improvement and
[h1]Cauliflower Broflovski I : Cosplay Survivor[/h1]
Is not a jedi game.

You are a former jedi temple trainee and a welder from Bracca, yet you can't Qui-Gon a door.
Slash a naked person 4-5 times with a lightsaber, and they are still alive, yet, if they touch you two times with what looks like a stone club, you are dead. 
Opponents [b]parry[/b] your saber with a club.
You use the improved force push/pull on purge troopers and the only damage troopers take is cringe.

In other words, in this game you are less of a jedi and more of a random person from SWcon with some prince of persia level acrobatic skills.

So roll and dodge and roll and dodge and roll and dodge to the end titles as you chip away at the enemies big D health bar, while you pretend it's not just another Dark Souls evening.

Now, to be objective, after the titles, it [b]does[/b] get much much better. 
Every ability is unlocked, so you can finally explore the locations, which have some good music and art. 
Additionally, a game feature is unlocked, that allows you to design and stage great battles against the AI, basically set up your own arena.

Which is some good gameplay, but why the 40+ hours wait, though?

This game should probably be taken to Bracca for refitting, as it has a very solid artistic and fight system core, rendered completely unenjoyable by the decision to time gate everything and buff up endless waves of trash, that nobody asked for in the first place.

Fantastic polished piece. Love that i got it for very cheap. Make sure to play on grandmaster. Loved the story, although you should have the ability to skip cut scenes of course, like with any game, with cutscenes. What is done with this masterpiece, is that the difference between difficulty, is enemy damage, aggression and parry timing. Rather, the player is benefited with more exciting on the wire combat with higher difficulties, no time wasting high hp enemies bs, that almost every game seems to pull to horribly bloat run times. Also the amount of collectibles to grab, the battle grid, and the sick as hell combat challenges pushes your value for money.

Jedi: Fallen Order is short, but sweet!

I'm typically a fan of games with tons of open-world exploration, but Fallen Order really only has about 5 hours of it. I wish there was more to do on each of the planets you explore throughout the main story, but the quality of what we do get is definitely the highlight of this game. The story/characters are really well written, as is the soundtrack. I found myself emotionally attached to multiple characters by the end, and am definitely looking forward to playing the sequel.

There wasn't too much in terms of character customization, as there were only 5 base different outfits to choose from, but thankfully there were tons of ponchos and jackets to unlock that covered the base outfits, keeping the MC's appearance exciting. I loved the amount of lightsaber customization as well, though I wish we could make more subtle changes rather than only being allowed to change full sections, but like I said I loved the options we were given, so I'm not too disappointed.

Oh, and I shouldn't fail to mention that the combat in the game is slow to unlock, but incredibly fun once you level up enough.

Overall, an 8/10, would recommend.

TL;DR - If you like story games with a decent amount of character customization, a fun combat experience, a great soundtrack, and the familiar Star Wars universe, then this is the game for you!

If you ever wanted to play as the galaxy's weakest Jedi, this is the game for you. Even though the main character is a padawan, there is no excuse for how weak lightsabers feel or how there is barely any flow to the combat. Combat feels simultaneously stiff and floaty because of how this game prioritizes being "cinematic" to the detriment of everything else.

If I could describe this game in one word it would be: jank. This is the jankiest AAA game I have ever played and I can't believe the review scores it got from mainstream outlets.

This game plays like a worse version of Tomb Raider 2016 with a much worse version of Sekiro's combat. For those who have played FF7R and were annoyed by the amount of gaps you had to squeeze through, be prepared for quadruple that amount in this game, plus lots of climbing sections and "exciting" scripted sequences where you slide down collapsing terrain or have control taken away from you to watch pointless bullshit. There are a couple sequences in particular where you watch NPCs from a control room as they kill a bunch of enemies. These were supposed to make the NPCs look badass but they were animated so poorly it just made me laugh.

Putting all that aside, I think the decision to try and implement a weighty combat system where you have to commit to your attacks via animation locking was a bad choice. That makes sense in a Fromsoft game but in Star Wars, lightsabers are just metal rods with plasma beams shooting out. There is no weight there.

This game does have some decent story moments and the human characters were fine. Debra Wilson was a good character and she's basically shifted her career into being a video game character at this point so she didn't bother me. However, Forest Whitaker shows up as a rebel leader on one of the planets which was a very wtf immersion-breaking moment [edit: apparently he is reprising his role from Rogue One which doesn't change my opinion that he isn't a very good actor]. I don't really care to list the few good things I have to say about this game because they don't make up for the amount of bad.

Don't waste your time with this game. If you like cinematic games go play Tomb Raider or God of War or TLOU. If you like good action combat games go play Sekiro, which does everything this game does but much much better.

The game design is poor. This is a "story" game in which nothing is plausible. It feels like playing a trashy arcade game. Instead of a Jedi we could as well control a soap bubble. What a waste for the good graphics, characters and animations.

Biggest pain point: the mechanic of dying and respawning is awful. All enemies are respawned at exact static positions if you "meditate" (refill energy etc.), but things like opened doors etc. are rememberd even after you died. This does not make any sense in a linear story game. Why not a normal save, die, reset-to-saved-state mechanic?

Second pain point: the level design is horrible. Better don't ask how enemies got to the place where they are. Don't ask why every path or building is an obstacle course. Don't ask why you can climb the craziest things but then suddenly can't grab a 3m high edge. Don't ask why you can do craziest jumps, where it was intended by the level designer, but hit an invisible wall in other places.

Third pain point: the poor balancing. 80% of the game were manageable on difficulty "jedi master" (3/4) without any problems, But in some cases I had to change it to "story mode" (1/4). It seemed impossible even on "jedi knight" (2/4). On the lowest difficulty, however, it was way too easy.

Positive points: The story was OK. Atmosphere, characters, dialogs etc. are actually pretty good. But the fact that you have absolutely no influence on the story (choice for the dark side maybe?) means that I can't really make a recommendation here either.

In the end, I'm just glad that I can free up the disk space again.

When I first started this game I hated it.  The re-spawn save mechanic lead to a ton of backtracking on death.  This and no ability to quick travel was annoying AF.  However, the story, the characters, the graphics kept me engaged long enough to win me over.  I played on Jedi Master mode and there were a few times during boss encounters where my controller was about to go flying across the room, but i kept at it and was able to progress.  Though, I do suspect that the game got bored with me during the final encounter with Trilla and just gave it to me.  Frustration level was highest at the beginning and as I progressed through the game, it became less so (not counting final battle).  Anyway, overall the experience was worth it because of the characters, the story and the Lore revealed.  I would recommend, though maybe not at Jedi Master for first play through.

If your a full on fan of the Star Wars genre then you will probably enjoy this one.
While I personally enjoyed the original movie trilogy, I've never been fond of the more recent movies and lore etc. So, these are my unbiased opinions based just on the game itself.

Visually, it's quite stunning with with good voice acting and competent cinematic's etc.
Running on the PC I had no errors, lock-ups or crashes etc, but did encounter the occasional camera glitch that did some funky things but this only happened a couple of times through my entire 40+ hr play through. The audio sound effects and music are well done and with no noticeable issues either.

As for the story, I just couldn't get into it at all really, and I found it somewhat of a chore to stick at it and complete which should speak volumes.

My biggest gripe though is with the game play itself.
I was hoping for a more traditional type of Star Wars game along the lines of the Dark Forces series but this game felt more like Tomb Raider with a light sabre and with no gun-play whatsoever.

I despise platforming type games in general, which this one is chock full of which just annoyed the hell out of me. I play solely for entertainment... not to be repeatedly pissed off. 

The encounters with enemy AI and bosses are reasonably good, with a good variety of different opponents (and wildlife) and the acquired force powers are quite satisfying when pulled off. But the combat ends up being all too brief and quickly forgotten due to yet another irritating section of platforming. 

I pumped more hours into this one just trying to find all the collectables on each level but after completing the story I just found no desire to want to go back and try to 100% it, or start a New Game+ play through. Many of the collectables require force abilities to reach that you don't acquire until the later stages of the game which will require a TON of back tracking.

All up, if your a fan of the Star Wars universe in general, you probably will get some enjoyment out of it, but if your on the fringe like myself (or despise platforming) then I'd only recommend purchasing if on sale or avoid completely.

I was about to give up until I saw a guide on the community hub that explained how to instead force use the older origin app of EA and disable the demon that is EA play. I fresh installed origin and used the installer for a patch mentioned in guide from github. I am now free. I can use the steam overlay as I should and am free of the demon's grasp.

Tried all the suggested fixes and also Vsync on and off, frame rate setting same as the monitors rate, lower resolution with "Epic" settings except shadow quality, lowered to medium even, etc. The game is still crashing every time that I play, only allowing me to get more and more frustrating with it as crashes are very random, can be 10 minutes play or 2min or sometimes 15 min (rarely), but it must crash. I love the games balance between challenging and interesting combat, good level design with some puzzles and easter eggs, and compelling narrative.

"To casuals like myself its been a gentle intro to the souls-like genre"

The dialogue is not too heavy, its enough to keep the story moving and not bogg you down with those long strings of dialogue that ultimately don't really matter. (mass effect series, any old republic game for example"

The combat is exciting and just challenging enough but not too punishing, and the adjustable difficulty level is a nice feature if you don't want the added challenge. (I've played halfway through the game at Jedi Master dificulty and have had to make at most 5-20 attempts at the harder bosses...by "souls-like" standards this is a walk in the park...but to casuals like like myself its been a gentle intro to the souls-like genre.

[h1]This would have been amazing if it had come out in, like, 2005.[/h1]

[h2]Technical Issues[/h2]
Like most Unreal Engine 4 and 5 games using DX12 backend, this game comes packed with random hitching and performance problems that occasionally caused a fall or death. These were annoying, but not so severe that they ruined the game experience entirely. What did nearly ruin the experience was the fact that I almost didn't get to play the game at all, as the EA launcher was outright preventing me from launching the game for some inexplicable reason (as other reviews have mentioned). I only managed to work-around by circumventing the launcher entirely, and that by itself is a non-starter and should be reason enough to avoid the game entirely, but I'll go on to detail the rest of my complaints.

[h2]Souls-like...?[/h2]
Though it's billed as a souls-like game, in actuality Jedi: Fallen Order has very little in common with the souls-like genre and far more in common with a metroidvania. The only aspect that it shares with a souls title is the ability to permanently lose XP if you die twice without regaining it. However, you only need to land one hit on the enemy that killed you to regain your XP, which is generally super easy to do. On top of that, your XP can only be spent on acquiring new skills and there are no RPG stats to speak of, and the most any skill costs is 3 full bars, so it's rare to ever be running around with a meaningful amount of XP to lose in the first place. The addition of this bloodstain-like system serves no real functional purpose in the game, but it's mostly harmless in its implementation.

[h2]Dated Gameplay[/h2]
This game is a hair's-breadth away from being an on-rails experience (again in spite of being marketed as a souls-like). The vast majority of your time will be spent climbing fixed paths up walls, or going down fixed paths on giant slides, or swinging along fixed paths from ropes, or squeezing dreadfully slowly through nonsensically placed gaps in walls. The game makes a point of showing you all these mechanics during the tutorial and then proceeds to use them ad-nauseum throughout the rest of the game. These are the kinds of mechanics that give the superficial appearance of gameplay, but in actuality provide zero challenge and next to zero ability to explore or play. In 2005 this would have been acceptable, but in 2019 this is just sad. It doesn't help that the combat feels incredibly clunky and inconsistent, making the only real "gameplay" part of this game pretty miserable to play.

[h2]Half-baked Animations[/h2]
The in-game character animation in this game is so laughably bad that I'd normally have a hard time believing this was a major studio title... if it weren't for the fact that this is pretty much in line come to expect from major studios over the last decade. The animations combined with constant clipping problems on both characters and world geometry makes the game look incredibly amateur and/or unfinished, depending on what spin you wanna take. Cutscene animations look fine, but it's clear to me that this product was rushed out to the door to meet a release deadline.

[h2]No-bake Plot[/h2]
You know that one RedLetterMedia video about how they love Rogue One? That was all I could think about while playing this game. The story and writing attempts to hit all of the major beats that a typical post-Disney Star Wars product tries to hit, but it does it in a way that feels jumbled, contrived, and incredibly forced (no pun intended). No one in this game has any kind of appeal as a character, and everyone talks exactly how real people don't. Our protagonist is visually intended to evoke the idea of a cowboy, but he looks and acts like an innocent child and sounds like the most boring man you've ever met. Plot beats and character moments happen with almost no setup or coherence, but then everyone will bring them up constantly afterwards as if trying to brainwash you into caring about it happening. This feels to me like a rough-draft of a story, and one that even at its best would be incredibly by-the-numbers.

[h2]TL;DR[/h2]
This is a really mediocre metroidvania that feels like you're playing a shitty Tomb Raider game. Skip it.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

Prince of Persia exploration and puzzles plus Dark Souls combat minus RPG mechanics plus Star Wars environments and story equals Jedi Fallen Order. This game is a wonderful fusion of ideas that works wonders in all areas. Gives some cool insight into the period between Episode 3 and 4, putting it on a scale going back and forth between light-hearted and gritty. Introduces a new cast and story while incorporating some parts of the Clone Wars show as well. Great acting, writing, wonderful characters, immersive design and beautiful environments. The Force Unleashed ran so this game could walk, but it does it amazingly well. It's a far cry from the breakneck speed power fantasy of Starkiller's story, but manages to work with its more limited gameplay by focusing more on story and exploration as well as making combat more balanced and tough, but fair. Combat comes down to evasion, blocking, parrying, and knowing when to attack. Force powers and upgrades can help, but usually can't decide the outcome. Overall I'd say this is an excellent game for all kinds of players, whether you're a Star Wars fan or not.

This game is an outstanding adventurous single player game that not only includes your basic star wars elements such as (Space travel, planet exploring, light-sabers and the empire as the enemy) but it also features puzzles that you have to solve, that can be tedious and a annoying but once you get past them its a relief. A great story that is canon to the Star-Wars universe (In-between episodes 3 and 4) with great world building and character story arcs, backstory of each planet with hidden artifacts you have to find exploring the world and outstanding graphics for a game that is released in 2019, which is further improved in the second game Jedi Survivor (2023) alongside its game-play and much more.

[h1] TLDR: As a game it's fine. As a star wars game? [u] No [/u] [/h1]

I managed to stay away from spoilers all these years. Never had the time to really sit down and play it. I had no idea it was a souls-like. I absolutely despise souls-like games and how they deal with difficulty. Instead of creating difficulty through mechanics this game uses seer damage against you and the fact that enemies come back to file after you meditate. Maybe in some settings it makes sense, but not in the scope of this game. It would make sense if enemies would respawn after you leave a planet and come back. Given the amount of back tracking you have to do this quickly becomes very very tiring and, at least for me, completely tedious. It is good how they walled off areas according to what skills you have but going through the same area more than twice is something I personally consider lazy development and lazy design. 
The back tracking also kills the pacing of the story.
The game's score is amazing and along with the story are just about everything that I liked about the game.
The lightsaber feels like a glorified shiny club, with a few race exceptions where it actually feels like a lightsaber but this is limited to cutscenes and a handful of enemies. It looks amazing though, it just feels silly that it can cut through blaster proof metal but struggle with a giant bi-pedal troll all the while in the same trolls killing animation shows the lightsaber cutting effortlessly through it.


[h3] <u] Pros: [/u] [/h3]
[ul]
[li] Saber animations look very cool. [/li]
[li] Story is very good, it pulls you in immediately. [/li]
[li] Music is beyond amazing. [/li]
[li] It is good to see a star wars game with this modern technology. [/li]
[li] The story's antagonists, when not part of the wildlife, are very good. [/li]
[li] The action sequences are very intense. [/li]
[li] The game's environment's, when not going through them for the 20th time, are stunning and feel real. [/li]
[/ul]

[h3] [u] Cons: [/u] [/h3]
[ul]
[li] For a Jedi you seem to enjoy killing animals a lot. [/li]
[li] Throughout a great deal of the game you are mostly fighting wildlife. [/li]
[li] Some of the game's most difficult enemies are, again, wildlife. [/li]
[li] The whole skill tree system feels unnecessary, included just because it's impossible to not have skill trees these days. [/li]
[li] The amount of paths in a level makes them feel open, but you quickly run into impassable obstacles if you are not meant to go that way yet and it feels lazy, not to mention that you then have to go back the way you came again. [/li]
[li] The amount of backtracking is atrocious. Going through the same platforming sections again and again, fighting the same enemies again and again feels mindbogglingly boring or forced upon the player. [/li]
[li] Hiding upgrade collectibles (increase HP or Force) behind skill-locked areas makes the idea to include the same functionality within the skill tree weird and vice versa. Yet another badly implemented souls-like mechanic. [/li]
[/ul]

All in all the game suffers from some badly implemented ideas just to ride the souls-like train. The whole pacing of the gameplay takes away from the overall story and very good and interesting characters. You spend far more time dealing with pestering wildlife and massacring natives than a jedi game should, not to mention that as a star wars game there should at least be some degree of choice weather you are more inclined towards the light or the dark. In general, future installments should draw more inspiration from the star killer saga than other souls-like games.

I have owned this game since release and have tried so many times to get into this game.  I love Star wars as much as the next person and I like Cal and the characters in this game.
The first 20 mins or so of the game are almost breath taking with the quality of graphics and how the environment is so impressive.   
However about an hour in you realise that once you strip the initial wow factor away and the story is now held back between long map sections of repetitive boring content.   The biggest problems are that the game tries to be a Tomb raider clone and fails quiet hard at it.  It also tries to add Dark souls elements to the combat and saving system which the game just doesn't want or need.   The combat is good at first but then just adds stupid enemies for the sake of it which just messes the combat and camera into a frustrating experience.
This review has been written on my failed 4th attempt at getting into this game and I just can't its not good enough to demand my time so want to warn others.
Personally I will be watching the story on YouTube and missing the frustration of this half baked game and will try Survivor.......

Positive:
1. Graphic is good.
2. MC and others voice acting are suitable.
3. Middle to end cutscenes and story are intense and entertaining.
4. Late gameplay with upgrades make combat smoother although not exactly reach the right point.

Negative:
1. The general star wars story regarding the Empire vs lone Jedi with rebels is already too overused. Boring.
2. The gameplay from start to middle is Awful and Boring. Parkour and dull light saber fighting. I mean at this point I can see why George Lucas make trooper rifle to be slow laser beam, if they are fast as bullets, Jedi would not be main character. Map puzzle feels not as logical as tomb raider, instead more like fantasy like sonic hedgehog map.
3. Back to how this game tries to combine tomb raider and souls like but somehow it couldnt, plus its early gameplay feels terrible, clunky and not smooth.
4. Camera is not perfect and no fast travel in planet.

PS: I wish instead of developing this mediocre star wars product, that Respawn continue developing Titanfall 3. Titanfall universe has greater potential than this.

The planets are beautiful, the world is not too open, more linear, but with perfect amount of exploration. Lots of action-adventure moments, at times you feel like you're in an interactive movie. Combat is amazing, everything you'd want from lightsaber combat. It's challenging yet satisfying on Jedi Master difficulty (2nd hardest), it takes some time to learn your boundaries of how aggressive you can get and how to incorporate force moves in it.

Story is pretty good, especially the final third that leaves you with a desire for a sequel (which is out). As a fan of KOTOR I'd like if there was more dialogue and depth to characters, as they hold a lot of potential. Maybe it is done properly in the sequel.
Overall a good hack and slash game, linear story, quite the slog to gather up all the collectibles (back and forth on certain areas).

It's a lot of fun (light saber combat/force abilities)  but rather short on playtime. The sale price is more than generous. 

I'm surprised Respawn Entertainment didn't add SBMM to this, following their apex model.

Hands down, the BEST thing to come out of Disney Star Wars that ISN'T named "Rogue One" or "LEGO Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga".
This game is some of the most fun I've had with a Star Wars game. Although the combat lacks dismemberment like earlier SW efforts like Jedi Outcast and Force Unleashed, it still feels fun, easy to learn and hard to master. The puzzles are successful brainteasers, controls feel smooth, and level design sprawling yet easy to navigate around thanks to shortcuts and a handy-dandy map.

And writing/plot-wise? It might appear to be a generic macguffin hunt a la Rise of Skywalker, but unlike Rise, the story is actually fun with characters who you care about and some actually good concepts that are built on throughout the game. Cal's relationship with BD in particular is the highlight of the entire game for me, as is how his character arc progresses overtime. It all culminates in one of the best endings of all time, a climax so intense and gratifying, that I'd dare not spoil because I want you to experience it for yourself.

Overall, with fantastic writing and characters, exquisite action-adventure gameplay and combat, and even solid sound design, voice acting and music, Jedi: Fallen Order is a must-play for any true fan of that Galaxy Far, Far Away.

10.... out of 10

NOT A SPOILER... just a warning for you who want to have 100% complete at the end of the game... You can't go back to the Last level after you beat it. So get your stuff while there... but if you don't you will only be missing out on side story content, not boosters for stats or skins or anything like that, but they are pretty easy to find on the last level.

You only get to play this for the first time once so do yourself a favor and just play it! Don't worry about walkthroughs or any of that. Or do... it's your life... go ahead and ruin it one game at a time!

DON'T WORRY! I know you emotionally torn Dark Souls, Sekiro, and Elden Ring survivors... this isn't the abusive lover you're afraid it might be!!! 

There's 3 difficulty settings... even on the hardest one my first time through I maybe died 30 times... as apposed to 100s of times on dark souls or Sekiro... Let's just call it an even thousand. If you just want to run through and decimate then go on Story mode and it's still a freaking awesome ride and not really challenging.. just fun, and you still have to solve those puzzles. AND IF YOU DIE The guy who killed you holds onto your xp just for that level,,, and if you die again... HE STILL HOLDS ONTO THAT XP... you never lose your xp. You just go tickle him, not even kill him, just hit him once or force sneeze in their direction and they give you all your lost xp back. 

It's meant to be enjoyed... not train you for a POW camp when they torture you.

LASTLY:
BONUS CONTENT!!! I personally loved the 3-4 hours worth of behind the scenes and the making of Since I'm an aspiring indi-game developer, so that alone was worth more than full price of the game on release day (for me personally). I took like 10 pages of notes.

Enjoy ;)

I need to start by acknowledging I only played for 30 minutes. The reason I only played for 30 minutes is that I don't have a controller, and at a certain scene I was told I had to switch targets by pressing a button on my mouse that doesn't exist. I tried reallocating controls in the settings, but it wouldn't let me assign this function to another key.
There may well be a solution to this, but the I gave up pretty quickly because the game seemed pretty crap anyway. I got it because I wanted something mindless and fun where I could jump around and hit stuff with my lightsaber, but I spent most of those thirty minutes watching cutscenes or moving in the strict, linear path the game had laid down for me. Why is it that so many games designed for console seem to be barely interactive and don't like giving players options?
There must be a target audience for this game, since others clearly like it, but if you're like me and you want to control what's going on in a game, give this one a miss.

Imagine Tomb Raider and Uncharted had a bastard child which was born retarded and it was set in the Star Wars universe. Have you imagined it? Good.  The result is Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order.

Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order is nothing more than a blatant attempt to cash in on the Star Wars franchise with a subpar game that wouldn't be able to stand on its own if it were not part for the use of the Star Wars name. Overall the game is a solid C- or D+ at best. The mechanics are clunky, the plot is disjointed, the character development is minimal, and you spend an absurd amount of time bouncing around doing parkour type nonsense and cave exploration instead of actually being immersed in a Star Wars plot.

The game is a miscarriage best avoided.

Barely playable. its either stuttering or crashing even though my system is above the recommended requirement for the game, took me almost 5 hours to fix it but there's nothing. Really solid game, had lots of fun playing. Could benefit from a fast travel feature as the backtracking you need to do on maps like Zeffo to get to the end of the map is quite annoying. The holo-map could also use a rework as the layers can get a bit overwhelming for beginners. Im pretty sure most of these issues are fixed in the sequel which i have yet to play.

[8/10] STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order is great game filled with interesting combat and characters. This game is a treat and truly makes yourself feel immersed in the world that players no matter the level of knowledge of the IP can enjoy.

The story is mostly self contained within the universe but it never makes you feel as if this isn't a story worth telling. The combat is fluid and fun which allows you to tackle combat encounters in many different ways. Exploration is heavily encouraged and is always rewarding with many collectables and upgrades. There are many ways to also interact with the world from movement and force abilities that constantly increase through the story and make revisiting areas enjoyably and picking up bits of lore and world building you may have missed. The game is decently lengthy but never pads for time. Though when trying to go for all achievements it isn't so helpful as to showing you where to find items and makes some areas require really long treks without shortcuts to revisit.

This is an overall great game and a enjoyable experience throughout with great lore and gameplay. It is well worth picking up on sale or alone if you are so inclined.

No, if we eliminate the lightsaber, the force powers and the Star Wars universe we have an average game with nothing to say to the gaming industry.[/i]

This game nails what makes Star Wars...Star Wars, While there aren't any space battles or massive engagements, the atmosphere and level design are truly remarkable. The base concept of the story was simple and easy to follow, but the interesting characters within made it memorable. 

Gameplay was fun, but sometimes I did have some issues with targeting the right enemy. Difficulty felt just right without being too overwhelming. I played on Normal, for reference. Getting to customize my character and lightsaber were also fun little things to help make me feel like a part of the game.

Overall, if you're looking for a straightforward, fun Star Wars game with engaging combat and you really want that grungy, authentic atmosphere with a cast of memorable characters and awesome locations, I recommend Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order. Can't wait to try out Survivor.

This game is one of the best games I have played. Since its big brother Jedi Survivor was released you can get this amazing game for 5 dollars and tons of hours. The graphics are really nice and every planet has an amazing atmosphere. The story you undertake through the game is awesome and keeps expanding with twists and turns, and there is good character development. I love how the skill tree / force skills are progressed slowly and evenly through the game so it is balance and it is like Cal is actually learning through his journey, as he is supposed to be a padawan at the beginning of the story.

Then there is the game play. The game play is amazing. I really enjoy the combat in this game, which is a parry combat system, where you heavily rely on blocking and counter attacking to kill you enemy's. While some people might not like this, as you play on, you earn more skills, attacks and even a weapon upgrade. I love this as it allows you to keep refining how you like to fight, especially if you one who doesn't like the parry mechanics as it offers other ways to take out your enemy's, and just keeps the combat fresh.

I also want to bring up BD-1, as he is your awesome companion with some awesome mechanics. I really like how he carry's all the stims ( healing ) and how you can find and collect more through your play through. As you go on you can also find upgrades that allow BD-1 to unlock doors and pathways that you could never get through yourself. What I really wanted to bring up was his map. The holomap that BD-1 has is the most helpful map I have ever seen in a game. I love how it shows you every path, and tells you where you can explore, what is locked, and what locked paths can be oped using a force power or solving a puzzle. I just find this so useful when exploring or trying to find my way to the objective.

The other game play mechanics like the puzzles and parkour are really fun as well. You can wall run, climb, swing, double jump, slide down slopes, all of which help you move through the game. and just like everything else, you slowly learn more of these skills as you play, unlocking new areas and secrets to be discovered. The puzzles are a good break from combat as you have to use if to unlock doors, solve the tombs, or just get a secrete. 

So, if your looking for a great story driven action combat star wars game, this is for you. I really recommend this game anyone and everyone, as it goes on sale for 5 dollars when it is really worth all 40 dollars. There is tons of constant, places to explore, puzzles to solve, and enemy's to fight. When in doubt if you hate the game refund it, but you should definitely give it a try. 10/10 would play again.

The story was okay, and the graphics were fine, though some character movements were a bit weird like the running on the wall bs. One major drawback for me was the extensive and repetitive terrains. And the map? Instead of helping, it made things way harder, turning the game into a struggle 

Despite the said downsides, I'd still recommend giving it a go. There are some redeeming qualities that make it worthwhile. And hey, it's STAR WARS.

[h1]The Fire Still Burns. Hope Still Burns. The Jedi Are Not Yet Lost. We Are Not Yet Lost[/h1]

[table]
[tr]
	[th]Don't forget to visit my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/44750396/] Curator's page [/url]for more recommendations![/th]
[/tr]
[/table]

Being a Star Wars fan in recent years is not an easy path. Accepting failure after failure of what has been done with the amazing story is quite tough. However, as Saw Gerrera said - Hope still Burns. And I am writing here not to complain but instead to praise.

[b]Jedi: Fallen Order[/b] is an amazing action adventure story which takes place after the horrible events after Order 66. The  main character ‚Äì Cal Kestis was a padawan when the Clones betrayed the Jedi. Now ‚Äì Kestis is a young man and probably one of the few Jedi left and he is on his path to do whatever it takes to complete his own apprenticeship and to re-establish the Jedi Order.

The game combines a few genres: it is a story adventure, full of amazing cinematic cutscenes; it could be one of the sequels of [b]Tomb Raider[/b] or simply a parkour simulator.

In my opinion, the scenario of the game is very well written especially when it comes to flashbacks, revealing the times when Cal Kestis was a padawan before the Empire. No spoiler alert, but we can actually see how Cal Kestis matures and becomes a better person and a more skilled Jedi.


 [h1]We Will Always Struggle, But That Is The Test. It's The Choice To Keep Fighting That Makes Us Who We Are [/h1]

Of course, the game is not perfect. On my first play though the game was a pain. I remember I was stuck on some points for ages as I couldn‚Äôt perfectly calculate the appropriate amount of time when I‚Äôd need to jump or grab or jump and grab or jump jump and grab. 
The main disadvantage for me was lack of quick travel between the ‚Äúsafe points‚Äù or a proper navigation on the planets which made the greedy part of me stop chasing achievements. It was so frustrating when I‚Äôd get to a faraway place and then by accident would step on a slide which would lead to the very beginning. 

There are no side quests however I believe it is quite justified. Come on guys, we are trying to be secret, the Jedi are dead, etc‚Ä¶
So it is quite alright that the game focuses on the main quest and solo explorations.
What I loved instead is that the Force Echoes tells us more of the story behind the beautiful landscapes. It makes perfect sense and reveals a bit of the tragedy of the Jedi (and not Darth Plagueis the wise).
Customization is one of the disappointing things in the game. After 10 open chests it became extremely boring to  discover more customizations for your lightsaber. But OK it is more or less alright. But who the hell would hide around these planets 20 different (not really) kinds of poncho? Zeffo? The Night Sisters have a new fashion designer? I‚Äôd understand if the chests would contain some planet-inspired costumes, but please no 100500 shades of brown-green poncho. It is absolutely ridiculous when you think about the game and its story. 



 [h1]Keep Failing. Keep Getting Back Up. That Is The Only Way To Succeed [/h1]

But despite all the disadvantages and my nitpicking, the  [b]Jedi: Fallen Order [/b] is able to provide a great experience not only to Star Wars fans, but I‚Äôm sure it will be interesting to anyone who is curious about Lara Croft-like games and on top of that I actually would have a real story. 
I really see and hope that the potential of the story will be open In all its beauty, connecting the games and the TV shows. I really hope it won‚Äôt be wasted.

P.S. To have a saberstaff and do whoosh whoosh ‚Äì is actually an incredible feeling!
P.S.S. To reflect the stormtroopers' shots with a saberstaff doing whoosh whoosh is actually cooler!

fun

You have to understand that game is AAA first and Star Wars at a distant second. Its chock full of repetitive, generic AAA stuff we've seen in hundreds of other games. Stuff like platforming, pointless collectibles designed to pad out progression, janky combat, surface deep pseudo RPG systems, and a terrible story. I'm surprised there weren't hacking minigames and stealth added as well. 

To start with, the platforming gets old very quickly. Its got wall running, jumping, sliding, etc. but to such an extent it feels more like a Tomb Raider game. Or a Disneyland amusement park. Its a bit hard to take a game seriously when you're bouncing all around the place like fun house and doing stuff that would be impossible even for jedi. And to make matters worse, it sometimes doesn't work: Cal lets go of an edge for no reason, doesn't grab it at all, etc.

Combat has a similar issue. Its not responsive, Cal often doesn't do what you want him to. But I think it was actually by design. If you take any amount of damage, Cal gets stun and loses his action. Even if you spent force points on it. You still lose the points, but the action doesn't connect. And he gets stunned for so long that by the time you recover, you get hit by another attack. Its essentially "dodge every attack perfectly, or get stunlocked" just like Dark Souls. This is what made me hate the combat. Its 5 minutes of rolling and blocking, make 1 attack, then repeat. Combine this with how ridiculously tanky bosses and certain elite enemies are (having a second healthbar you have to damage just to open them up for 1 hit at a time) and it makes combat feel like a slog. Fortunately, you can cheese it sometimes with force powers, but you only get 3 of them, which is incredibly lame, and they're progress gated like all other unlocks. 

So you're not actually doing "builds" per se, even though that defeats the point of having a skill system. I hate this in action games that pretend to be ARPGs, but there is no build diversity. So instead it just feels like mandatory grinding. You're expected to unlock every incremental bonus because the game is balanced around it, so its juts action with the "RPG" being extra steps. 

The most annoying thing by far though is that Cal's lightsaber is basically a pool noodle. You can hit enemies multiple times, and they just get red scratches. Even when they finally die, they don't get cut it half or anything (at least the human ones), just fall bloodlessly to the ground. It doesn't feel like you're actually a Jedi with a lightsaber, which ruins the Star Warts vibe completely. I'm guessing they did these for family friendly reasons or some nonsense because the Disney Overlords said so, which is even more annoying. 

Lastly, lets talk about the story. Here's a spoiler warning, but the story is so thin and nonsensical it really doesn't matter. Anyway, the main plot goes something like this: you meet a robot that had its memory wiped, except for a hologram of a dead Jedi telling you there is a secret vault built by ancient, extinct aliens with a holocron in it containing a map of force sensitive children. You then have to go from planet to planet, randomly unlocking the droids memory in random places for seemingly no reason, until eventually you find out there is a mcguffin that opens the vault.

How did the aliens know about the force sensitive children in the present day? Don't know. Why did they record and protect this information? Don't know. Why did they hide the key to the vault on another planet? Don't know. Who were these aliens and how did they get wiped out? Don't know. How did the dead jedi learn about this? Don't know. Why did he wipe the droid's memory and send us on pointless quests? Don't know. And so on...I mean, there is literally a part where you're exploring an ancient tomb, and the only interesting thing that happens there is "oh look, these people drew trees on their walls. Guess that means they want to Kashyyyk because its the only planet that has trees amirite? Now you have to go there too." Remember how cool the Rakatan empire was in KOTOR? Yeah, so do I. 

Steer clear of this one. Its corporate Disney garbage with the same level of writing ability displayed in their litany of crappy reboots and endless spin off series like Ahsoka. Replay KOTOR instead.

Great addition to the Star Wars Universe

Overall, Jedi: Fallen Order was an okay experience. The most gripping part of the game was Cal's journey as a Jedi after a traumatic experience with the Empire betraying him, almost killing him and his master. I enjoyed watching Cal become more comfortable with the Force as he gained confidence that his mission was worth fighting for. I also enjoyed witnessing the side character, Seere's growth alongside him. However, I must say I was quite confused about how she found him on that scrap yard at the beginning in the first place.

I enjoyed the fighting mechanics as a Jedi. However, there was not enough variety in enemies; they got stale within the first three hours of the game. I absolutely hated the maps of the game. The progression of them was so in your face and forced, to the point where the maps felt artificial, and I was most uninterested in exploring them. It was so bad, in fact, that I wanted to quit the game, but its saving grace was its story.

The bugs were horrendous in the game, to the point where there were instances where I had to quit and load it again. There were also random funny bugs that were manageable to deal with. The fact I had to restart the game pissed me off, though; I was incredibly upset over that.

Overall in my opinion if you are in it for the game play its a pass however if you are here for the story I‚Äôd invest my time in this game. Ill be giving this game a pass since in the end despite the shitty maps, I did get some enjoyment from this game.

TL;DR - It's a good game, and I would recommend it. 

Pros 
- Story is interesting
- Gameplay is very Darksouls meets Metroidvania
- Ran fairly well on my main gaming PC. 

Cons
- Gameplay can feel unfair at times. Had to move the difficulty down to get through a few bosses. 
- Had a lot of issues on my Steam Deck. Crashes, inconsistent FPS. It's the only game I've played where updates made it worse. 
- EA launcher is garbage, and it was added after the fact in a later update. 
- Cloud saves were super inconsistent. But I suspect this is EA's fault. 

Even with its flaws, I still thoroughly enjoyed this game and would recommend it to any Star Wars nerd.

Great game. It's a lot of fun to explore the Galaxy with Cal and BD-1 (who easily outranks even R2 as the coolest droid ever). The story is really good and fits very well into the Star Wars Universe. Much better than any of those new movies. It's a wonderful combination of story, exploration, fighting and riddles, with likable characters and nice challenges. Fun and challenging game, but accessible to anyone regardless of their skill. Difficulty is configurable, and there are plenty of meditation points (save game points). Graphics and sound are nice, lore-friendly and polished. Story is quite good and engaging. Combat is really fun, although it may become a little bit too complex for some people as Carl learns new abilities (you have to learn as Carl learns). 

Something I liked a lot about this game is the feeling of progression, not only because Carl becomes better (unlocking skills and increasing his maximum life and force), but also because the player gets better. Almost all enemies, including bosses, have some kind of weak point that makes them much easier to defeat; you just have to be patient and resilient enough to discover them.

[b] HIKAYE [/B]
Ana karakterimiz Cal Kestis, Order 66 sirasinda ustasini kaybetmis, padawan seviyesinde bir Jedi'dir. Order 66'dan sonra hayatta kalan Cal sonraki yillarda mekanik olarak calismaya devam eder. Bir gun arkadasiyla is sirasinda bir kaza olusur ve Cal, Force kullanmak zorunda kalir. Bunu yapar yapmaz da Imparatorluk engizisyonculari Cal'in ensesine dolusur. Gizemli iki kisi tarafindan kurtarilan Cal bu iki kisiden birisinin eski bir Jedi oldugunu ogrenir ve o Jedi'in amaci da Jedi Duzeni'ni yeniden kurmaktir ve Cal'den yardim ister. Hikaye girisi bu sekilde ve hikaye adina soyleyebilecegim seyler var. Acikcasi hikaye icin alinacak bir oyun olmasada iyi kotu siradan bir hikayesi oldugunu dusunuyorum. Ne cok guzel ne de cok kotu oyunu size oynatir. Olay orgusunde bir problem yok olmasi gerektigi gibi ilerliyor. Karakterlere isinamadim ben sadece. Normalde oyunlarda oyle cok ust duzey karakterler beklemem ancak buradakiler beni cidden sikti. Ozellikle guya eski Jedi olan karakter oyunun sonlarina dogru isin kiliciyla oyle hareketler yapiyorki insan vay demek yerine madem bu kadar gucluydun beni niye yordun diyor. Cunku karakterler oynanis sirasinda uzay gemisinde oturmaktan baska bir sey yapmiyorlar butun ayak isleri sizde. Final ise cok guzel olmus. (Spoiler)[spoiler] Darth Vader'i cok guzel yansitmislar ozellikle. [/spoiler] Tabii ki finalinde tatmin edici olmasinda son boss savasinin da bir katkisi var. Kisacasi karakter anlaminda cok da iyi degil ama oyunu oynarken sizi baymayacak kadar yeterli bir hikaye var oyunda.

[b] OYNANIS [/B]
Oyunda bir suru mekanik var. Oynanis kismi aksiyon ve platform olmak uzere iki kisma ayriliyor. Aksiyon kismindan baslarsam isin kilici ve Force kullanimi gayet guzel olmus. Isin kilicinin gorselligi bir yana vurus hissi cok tatmin edici. Ozellikle insan olmayan dusmanlara kritik attiginiz zaman onlari uzuvlarina kadar dogramak cok guzel. Kullanimi da cok cok rahat olmus. Kacma ve parry mekanikleri de oyuna guzel yedirilmis bir alistiniz mi cok zevk alirsiniz. Dusman cesitlilig de gayet zengin. Savasmak guzel ve eglenceli yani neticesinde. Platform ise biraz karisik diyebilirim. Guzel ve iyi calisiyor ancak arada sapitiyor. Ben buraya atlarim ya dedikten sonra kac kere game over ekranini gordugum oldu oyunda. Bes yere atlayamiyorsa bes yere daha atlayamiyor karakter ve bu hem stabiliteyi hemde oyuncunun sinirini bozan bir sey. Boyle bir ikilemde kalmaktansa level dizaynlari dogru durust olsa cok daha iyi olurmus. 

[b] METROIDVANINA [/B]
Oyunun en kotu oldugu yer burasi. Oyun ne kadar aksiyon macera oyunu olsada bir o kadar da metroidvanina ve bu taraf baya kotu olmus. En basta harita dizaynlari. Haritalar asiri komplex bir yapi da aslinda bunun iyi bir sey olmasi lazim ama unuttugumuz detay oyun 3D. 3D Metroidvanialarin az olmasinin sebeplerinden birisi ne kadar komplex olursa olsun oyuncu nereye gittigini cabucak kaybedebiliyor. Oyundaki harita sistemi de sag olsun ozellikle renk paletiyle size hic yardimci olmuyor ustune kostek oluyor. Dakikalarca ben buraya nerden geldim ve nerden cikacagim sorulariyla mal mal haritaya baktigim oldu. Metroidvania oyunlarin temeli kesfe dayanir ve siz kesfettikce hep gelisirsiniz. Bu oyunda o gelisme hissi de sifira yakin. En basinda kesfettikce buldugunuz seyler tamamen kozmetik karakterinize hicbir katkisi yok. Sadece yukleme ekranlarinda gordugunuz gemiye bile skin topluyorsunuz. Buldunuz 10 esyadan en az 7 si kozmetik ve bu kozmetikler insani o kadar hizli bayiyor ki. Hem asiri karmasik hemde odullendirmeyen bir sistem oldugundan oyunun yarisinda kefretmeyi biraktim. Karakter gelistirmeye bakarsak gelisim guzel olmus. Hem klasik metroidvania gelistirmeleri ve perk agacindan yetenek secme sistemi var oyunda. Bir RPG gibi matematiksel hesaplamalara girmenize gerek yok. Perk sistemi guzel. Cesit cesit yetenek var istedigini sec begen al durumu var ancak metroidvania yetenekleri daha iyi olabilirmis. En basta Ori ile karsilastirinca oyunun sonlarinda hayvan gibi bir karakteriniz oluyordu burada o durum yok. Kotu degil ama daha iyi olabilirmis.

[b] LEVEL DIZAYNI [/B]
Level dizaynlari guzel. Oyunda bazen acik dunyadan cikip kapali mekanlara giriyoruz ve buralar gayet iyi yapilmislar. Sagi solu belli yeterince komplex ve sizi bogmuyorlar. Tek sikintisi oyundaki bulmacalar. Oyundaki bulmacalar o kadar can sikici ki bir anda isin kiliciyla harikalar yaparken oyun size gel bulmaca coz diyor. Ve hepsinde internetten baktim cunku oyuncuya bulmacayi cozme hissi de vermeye ugrasmiyor. Bunu cozucem diye hirslanmaktan cok ekstra bir ayak isi, zorluk hissi veriyor insana. Ayri olarak da boss savaslarindan bahsedecegim. Boss savaslari guzeller. Ozellikle oyunun sonlarina dogru cikan iki tane isin kilici duellosu var ki bunlardan birisi son boss. Asiri zorlar ve tatmin edicilier. Son boss gordugum en zor bosslardan. Boss anlaminda gayet tatminkar. Bir de oyunda sinematik aksiyon sekanslari var. Yani olmasada olurmus ama olmasi arti yon katiyor tabii.

[b] TEKNIK [/B]
Grafikler guzel. Optimizasyon da guzel gibi sadece sacma sapan droplar giriyor arada. Duz yolda yururken bir anda drop girmesi insani baya sikiyor. Oyunun en patlamali catlamali yerlerinde drop girmezken buralarda girmesi baya garip. Ilk ciktiginda oyunda baya bug varmis sanirim ama 2022 de baya az ben bir kere gordum o da grafiksel bir bugdi.

[b] SONUC [/B]
Guzel savas mekanikleri, fena olmayan level dizaynlari ve boss savaslari derken Star Wars seven insanlarin oynamasi gereken bir oyun. Daha cok Star Wars icin alinabilecegini dusunuyorum cunku oyunun temel kolonlarindan birisi olan metroidvania tarafi baya kotu oyunda. Iyi ki oynamisim diyorum kendim Star Wars baya severim.

Fallen Order is basically a Dark Souls Light: similar combat but more lenient, similar level structure with shortcuts but more vertical, similar gameplay with "bonfires" and so on. There's more action and some simple platforming, more story, cutscenes and dialogues as well. The writing can sometimes be Marvel-bad, but the plot itself is generally fine. Some characters, including Cal, are even quite likeable.
The game is surprisingly fun for a modern AAA title. And that's despite me not being a fan of Star Wars at all. Certainly going to get the sequel one day.
It's also a good place to start for anyone who would like to give Dark Souls a try, but is scared of its (deserved only in a small degree) reputation of a "brutally hard game".

You are an order 66 survivor, that can no longer live in hiding. Who begins his quest on reconnecting with the Force, fighting back The Galactic Empire in an attempt to restore the Jedi order.

[b]The Good[/b]

+ Reinvention of lightsaber combat focused Star Wars games, which greatly improves on the well established Jedi Knight & The Force Unleashed games
+ Fluid adaption of souls-like combat, that feels highly rewarding without feeling too difficult
+ Well aged after 4 years of release graphically and gameplay wise
+ Beautifully written and well paced story that leaves you needing more
+ Perfect amount of collectibles and achievements for completionists

[b]The Bad[/b]

- Below average performance optimization, bugs, crashes, hitches and stutters that affect the experience occasionally
- Expected more 'side quest' type of content, in a game world so big
- Some areas on planets are confusingly designed, I could get stuck somewhere for a little while
- Amount of unique enemies
- EA launcher

[b]Thoughts[/b]

This is a must play for any Star Wars fan, and even might appeal for non-fans because of just how fun it is. The acting is phenomenal which really immerses you to believing in the story that is being told, so it feels real.

Would I recommend this game? Yes. One hundred percent. Lots of entertainment value, and especially a great pickup if you see it on sale on the Steam store and want an amazing bang for buck game. Good replay value.

Introduction:
STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order, developed by Respawn Entertainment, takes players on an epic journey through the Star Wars universe, delivering a thrilling and immersive gaming experience. Combining action-packed combat, a captivating storyline, and breathtaking visuals, this game has become a beloved addition to the Star Wars gaming franchise.

Gameplay:
The gameplay in STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order is a perfect blend of exploration, combat, and puzzle-solving. As Cal Kestis, a young Jedi Padawan, players navigate diverse and visually stunning environments across the galaxy, encountering various challenges and enemies along the way. The combat system is fluid and satisfying, allowing players to utilize lightsaber attacks, force powers, and agile maneuvers to overcome adversaries. The intricately designed puzzles add an extra layer of depth to the gameplay, requiring players to think strategically and utilize their Jedi powers to progress.

Storyline:
Set in the aftermath of Star Wars Episode III: Revenge of the Sith, the game's storyline is a compelling tale of redemption and survival. Players follow Cal Kestis as he seeks to restore the Jedi Order while evading the clutches of the ruthless Empire. The narrative is well-crafted, with engaging characters, unexpected twists, and memorable dialogue that captures the essence of the Star Wars universe. It successfully immerses players in the rich lore and mythology, making them feel like an integral part of the larger Star Wars saga.

Graphics and Sound:
Visually, STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order is a masterpiece. The game features stunning landscapes, meticulously detailed environments, and realistic character models that bring the Star Wars universe to life. Whether exploring ancient temples, bustling cityscapes, or treacherous forests, every location feels authentic and visually captivating. The sound design is equally impressive, with iconic Star Wars sound effects and a breathtaking musical score that enhances the overall immersion and creates an atmosphere of epic proportions.

Exploration and Replayability:
The game encourages exploration, rewarding players with hidden collectibles, upgrades, and additional story elements. The vast environments are filled with secrets and surprises, enticing players to delve deeper into the Star Wars lore. Additionally, the game offers multiple difficulty settings, allowing players of all skill levels to enjoy the experience. With its engaging gameplay and rich content, STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order possesses high replayability, inviting players to revisit the game and uncover everything it has to offer.

Conclusion:
STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order is a must-play for Star Wars fans and gamers alike. It successfully captures the essence of the beloved franchise, delivering an immersive and thrilling adventure set in a galaxy far, far away. With its engaging combat, captivating storyline, breathtaking visuals, and a well-crafted gameplay experience, this game stands as a shining example of what a Star Wars game should be. Prepare to embrace the Force and embark on an unforgettable journey in STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order. May the Force be with you!

Long story short: a great Star Wars single player experience overall, but it's not all sunshine and rainbows. 

Story is great, most of the time. There are times where I felt disconnected and don't know why I'm doing this or what prompt me to in the first place. However, when it's good, especially in critical plot points, it truly delivers. Character growth is sufficient to say the least, but I felt a decline in the quality of character building near the end of the story. Difficulty can be adjusted at any point in the game, however, I didn't particularly find the sweet spot. I started with Jedi Master but soon after switched to Jedi Knight. I feel like Jedi Master isn't enjoyable because the enemies hit really hard, and when encountering new enemies, of which I have no idea what their moves are, it became quite annoying. However, in Jedi Knight, the game feels too easy for me. A lot of the time I traversed from checkpoint to checkpoint while only losing less than half my health bar without using any provided stim. Maybe I should've stick with Master x.x

Gameplay is alright. Parkour feels pretty much the same from the start till the end with minor positive changes. Combat feels weighty, parries feel great. Skill tree give you extra moves and perks to add to your kit. If I have to nitpick, the bossfights often feel more like a pairing game (especially in Jedi Master). What I mean by this is the parry and dodge system. I feel like the player need to pair the boss's moves to either a dodge or parry and when we paired them wrong we get punished hard.

DESPITE THAT, I enjoyed my time wholeheartedly in SWJ:FO. The opening scenes alr hooked me and I loved the experience.

loved the story and the characters. boss fights are challenging and fun. the level design is also good, with much platforming, puzzles and also well placed enemies. however, there's no build variety like other souls games and the game itself is quite short. overall decent game.
