STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order has truly raised the bar for Star Wars gaming experiences. From the moment I ignited my lightsaber, I was transported to a galaxy far, far away, and the journey that followed was nothing short of epic.

The storytelling in Fallen Order is a triumph, seamlessly weaving a compelling narrative into the vast and beloved Star Wars lore. The protagonist, Cal Kestis, is a relatable and engaging character whose journey to rediscover the Jedi way is both emotional and thrilling. The game successfully captures the essence of the Star Wars universe, delivering a cinematic experience that feels like an interactive masterpiece.

Visually stunning, the game brings iconic Star Wars locations to life with meticulous detail. From the bustling streets of Nar Shaddaa to the haunting landscapes of Dathomir, each environment is a testament to the developers' commitment to authenticity and immersion. The attention to detail in recreating lightsaber combat, force abilities, and the overall Star Wars aesthetic is commendable and adds an extra layer of nostalgia for fans.

The combat system is a true highlight of Fallen Order. Lightsaber duels are intense, strategic, and immensely satisfying. The learning curve for mastering various force powers and combat techniques is well-balanced, allowing players to feel the growth of their Jedi skills throughout the game. The inclusion of challenging enemies and powerful bosses ensures that every encounter feels like a significant test of your abilities.

Exploration is a key element of Fallen Order, and the level design is both intricate and rewarding. Navigating the different planets feels like a genuine adventure, with secrets to discover, puzzles to solve, and a multitude of collectibles that cater to the completionist in every player. The Metroidvania-style progression system adds depth to the exploration, encouraging players to revisit areas with newfound abilities.

The sound design in Fallen Order is impeccable, featuring the iconic hum of lightsabers, the familiar blaster sounds, and John Williams' legendary score. It's a symphony of Star Wars that enhances the overall immersive experience and evokes a sense of nostalgia for fans of the franchise.

In conclusion, STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order is a stellar addition to the Star Wars gaming legacy. Respawn Entertainment has crafted a game that not only pays homage to the beloved universe but also stands out as a fantastic action-adventure title in its own right. Whether you're a die-hard Star Wars fan or a newcomer to the galaxy, Fallen Order is an absolute must-play, delivering an unforgettable journey through the Force. May the Force be with you!

There are a couple things I had trouble with and got annoyed with though!
#1 The combat,
It was pretty cool and entertaining, but I had an issue with my blocking/parrying and my dodging, to where it didn't count or read and the enemy ends up landing a hit on me.
#2 The unblockable red attacks,
The enemies loved doing these and alot of times, even though I press the dodge, it still hits me, which was pretty annoying. The purge enemies and the bosses love to use these attacks, especially the last boss, who constantly used these, ending up killing me and making me redo the fight.
#3 Stunlocking,
Did this happen to anyone else? I constantly got stunlocked by enemies, causing to lose like 90% of my health. It happened with fast attackers, example, the purge enemies with the daggers and double sided baton thingy, the 3rd and 9th sister, and multiple enemies like the baton stormtrooper commander, melee nightbrothers, and Undead nightsisters.

Overall, it's really fun game and I recommend people to at least give it a try, but probably not at full price, I got it on a really good sale at the whopping price of $8.

A nice Star Wars game. Story is decent. A bit linear at times but quite fun. I finished it in 17 hours without rushing it. Definitely better than what Star Wars has become these last years.

First of all, this is not a lightsaber combat game like the old Jedi Outcast & Academy. This is a baseball bat fighting game. The only part where it feels like a lightsaber is deflection of blaster bolts (which is a lot of fun!). You can even parry animal attacks with a lightsaber (facepalm). And enemy dark jedis are complete nonsense.

Player attack animations often have a oddly long and unnecessary back swing (especially for a lightsaber... but for a regular metal sword too). I wish I could do quicker slashes and stabs from the guard position.

Looking past that, the combat can be fun. 

For context, I never played a souls-like game before (only a bit of Hollow Knight, but didn't get far in it).
I played this game on Jedi Master difficulty (3/4). I could never get a feeling like I'm getting ahead of the difficulty curve - always felt slightly behind. If that was the intended purpose, good job developers.

I got to learn the animations and the move set of every new enemy, and before I got fully comfortable with it, the game threw new and more enemies at me. I only got to relax during puzzles (which I found to be fairly challenging). There was never a situation when in combat I was just going with the flow and dominating it (I wish there was at least some, it feels good to feel powerful).

My favorite part of combat is timing parries, but most enemies have 1 or more "unblockable" attacks. Their animations don't differ that much from regular attacks, but the game hints at this by flashing the enemy with red color and playing a sound cue. I found this part to be arcade-y and immersion breaking. I would rather this part have some consistency and you'd have to deduce whether an attack can be blocked from its animation.

There is very limited health regen, and when you run out of it, the only choice is to meditate (at a save station), which respawns all the enemies (behind and in front of your path). On one hand, it was fun to grind this a little bit in the early game, on the other hand, before I significantly increased my health and regen ability, it was quite tedious to progress.

Personally I hate save stations. I'd prefer the ability to save any time out of combat (meditation for health recovery and enemies respawn could keep working as is).

Character upgrades are decent. They are simple and well explained, and the choice between them is not difficult but not obvious either. At the end of the game I unlocked almost all the upgrades, so there aren't different builds.

Exploration is the worst part of the game. It was quite a frustrating experience for me, because lots of exploration is locked behind abilities that are unknown to me beforehand, and I felt stuck for so long - because I couldn't understand what am I missing to "get over there". E.g. there's a crashed Star Destroyer, and I wished to go inside it and explore... but couldn't find a way and was very disappointed. But I was able to get in there much later, after I got a "double jump". Seriously, double jump??? Jedi don't double jump, they just jump higher!

If the game gave me all abilities from the beginning, it would fix my biggest issue with it (confusing exploration).

Vanity customization. You can *visually* customize your ship, character, droid and lightsaber. You find these "skins" while exploring. Personally I found this feature very odd and immersion breaking... why would my character bother with repainting the ship that is not even his! And I've never seen droids  get repainted in Star Wars either. Lightsaber is also a very personal and jedi don't just swap them around. I wish the feature just wasn't present.

Environments and levels. You visit a bunch of planets, each having a distinct style. For me the highlight is Dathomir. The sound design there is 10/10, and visually it's great too. It also reminded me of the other grim Star Wars places - Korriban and Malachor V from KotOR II. This is the part that tipped my review from "Not Recommended" to "Recommended". Dathomir was just great.
Overall there's lots of good quality art in the game on each planet.

Story is inconsequential, not even worth talking about. The game never got me worried about anything story-related. What a pity. Even the childish Jedi Academy story was better. But that's the state of Star Wars these days. But hey, "inconsequential" is much better than Episodes 8 & 9, so that's good! There's lots of bits of lore scattered around - you get a little bit of XP for collecting them and the main character will say a few words, but rarely anything interesting.
You travel with 2 other characters, but they also feel inconsequential (even though one of them is sorta important to the plot) because you only interact with them in your ship. There's also your droid, which is my favorite part of the lore\story. He's so cute and I adore the chat between him and the player character.

Technically the game is very well made. It supports ultrawide resolution out of the box (apart from cutscenes which are pillar boxed; but this isn't a cut scene heavy game).
I ran the game on an i7-8700k + RTX 2080 Ti, 3440x1440, maximum (Epic) graphic settings without dynamic resolution, and my average FPS was around 80, with rare dips to 65-70 when looking and some scenery. Graphical fidelity settings are detailed enough, but I didn't bother fiddling with them. Visual effects settings are separated from them and clearly named.
The game supports full control scheme remapping EVEN ON A CONTROLLER, WHICH IS SO RARE! I applaud for this, even though it should be a given...
I have an inexpensive mSATA SSD, and the game load times are good. However once in a while an odd "long" load happens.
In my 30 hours of play, the game never crashed, and barely encountered any bugs (there was 1 glitch with the enemies floating in the world models), well done on this part!
My main complaint from tech side is the EA app. Another app that I have to run and update. In my 30 hours of play (spread over a few months, such is life), i had to update the app almost every time I tried to launch the game...

Yet another contemporary title that disappoints, aligning with the prevailing trend in entertainment over the past few years that relies heavily on nostalgia, presenting it like a carrot dangled over our heads, feigning that the franchise remains true to what we originally loved and supported. When playing as a force-sensitive character in a game, my primary expectation revolves around the fluidity of movement and gameplay reminiscent of previous Star Wars installments, like Force Unleashed. These games made us feel we were on the brink of fulfilling our Star Wars fantasies, with compelling force abilities and dynamic lightsaber combos that made embodying a Jedi a mere controller's reach away. Unfortunately, the current game takes the opposite approach.

Right from the start, players are bombarded with constant uncanny valley cutscenes prone to glitching into a myriad of pieces with the slightest variable deviation. Unskippable tutorials attempt to explain their clunky new systems, constantly detracting and pausing from the "immersive" experience. The unchallenging and repetitive parkour lacks evolution from the old 2000s systems, such as "wall run" and "climbing vines." Really EA? Even for those who enjoy this style of gameplay, the controls feel clunky, with the character constantly succumbing to slippery grappling animations, and awkwardly sliding off poorly constructed geometry, leading to egregious glitches. Parkour becomes the only activity between combat scenarios, or cutscenes, offering little reward to progression or exploration. The overly complex map system imparts a false sense of depth, as there's no freedom of path choice or mission selection. Every planet evokes the same vibe, save only a different texture palette and enemy variety. The promise of diverse environments, like exploring the innards of the Death Star, or exploring the jungle of Endor, leaves the experiences we wanted unfulfilled.

While the game attempts a Souls-like style of gameplay, the adaptation is a complete failure and my least favorite aspect. The progression system seems purposeless, creating the illusion that the character's difficulty to use is justified by adding "game mechanics." The Souls-like combat, a cycle of dodge, dodge, attack, repeat, lacks the rewarding feeling that souls-like games flourish off, and serves as a constant reminder of the tedious nature of the entire game, and the "go find the guy who stole your points" punishment appears as a mere excuse to extend gameplay hours, compelling players to navigate the poorly designed maze of the map repeatedly.

Acknowledging some positive elements, there are some great visual elements and a storyline that some may appreciate, but these aspects are overshadowed by the limitation of choice in what to look at and when, taken by force camera movements and perspectives. The potentially beautiful sceneries and battles lose their novelty, making players feel like they're playing a telltale-style game void of the multiple choices to impact the story.

If you find enjoyment in this game, it's possible you're gaslighting yourself or lack a reference point for quality in the gaming industry and art.

I sat down and was going to a list of backlogged dames that I wanted to get through.

I bought this some time ago and wasn't able to play it on the other rig and figured that since I got a better desktop that I would download it and see how it would run.

I get through the first world of the game and think to myself that I need to see how things proceed when I get to another world. Next thing I know, I'm hooked at what I'm doing and playing this game through the weekend.

I finished it not long after posting this review.

The combat feels solid and I often panic when I have more than two things thrown in my direction. Puzzles feel intricate and I find myself sitting there wondering what the next piece of what's in front of me is for. I adore the characters and wonder what it is that they will pull next.

If the sequel wasn't in a position where it had issues with performance then I would buy it to see what Cal Kestis would be onto today; however, I'll only make that leap when I have a stronger rig ready to enjoy Star Wars that I grew up on.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ Visuals and sounds really captures Star Wars
+ Fun and reasonably challenging combat
+ Likable characters
+ Decent story
+ Snappy controls

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- A bit too much backtracking
- Saving system is unnecessarily tedious; save points are also placed poorly
- No fast travel makes collecting collectibles a real chore
- Fixed FOV; can be annoying when swarmed by enemies and you can't see them

[h1]Neutral[/h1]
+/- Holographic map is very detailed, but could really use a waypoint system
+/- Using healing stims has a delay and can get interrupted; a bit of an unnecessary layer of difficulty

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Game starts off a little slow, but becomes a lot more fun as you unlock new skills and traversal abilities. Game length is probably a little too short to merit the price tag, so wait for a sale to get this one.

Short version: Buy this game on discount only. Game is missing fast travel, and has some weird 'game' logic that makes invisible walls seem like a fun day out in areas.

Long version:
I want to love this game. I really do.
But the backtracking is annoying.
The puzzles are badly designed.
The exploration is a chore.
The navigation is horror because the map is unintelligible at best.
The combat is OK but nothing to write home about.

The one puzzle with the ball in the cage, where you can't get the angle made me uninstall it and then reinstall it because I still want to see the end of the game.. I have tried 35 hours to love this game. I have REALLY tried. 

Is it glitchy? yes.
Is it frustrating because of bad game logic? yes.

Is it still Star Wars? Yes.
Is it good Star Wars.. sadly.. yes.

Special warning for people that have OCD/Completionist tendencies: There are many areas locked off until the end of the game that you will try to get to. Do not try to collect things or 100% maps until right before the VERY end of the game and be ready to tackle some insanely illogical puzzles that were tested 'happy flow' only. Think.. a math exam, where there are for sure 3 correct answers, but only 1 is accepted. You'll be spending a lot of time on those other 2 'incorrect' answers, just because the game likes to spin you in circles and waste your time like that. This game does NOT respect your time.

This is like the best star wars game. puzzles are a bit annoying but everything other is great. Also because of some reason graphics are better on this game then Hogwarts legacy.

NON-SPOILER PROS AND CONS:
(TLDR: I give it a 8/10)
(Side Note: I have yet to play NJ+ and beat the game on Story Mode)
Pros:
. BD-1 (the lil robot that follows you).
. Runs really well - only had one fps issue which got fixed with a restart.
. Story is simple to follow yet feels very expansive and innovative
. Lots of fun collectibles that allow a variety of customisation options for your outfit, poncho, lightsaber and BD-1.
. Although limited to five planets, there is plenty of exploration that does not feel too short.
. Plenty of variety in enemies to fight.
. Backtracking options when exploring.
. Combat is pretty decent and requires skill.
. New Game + permitting extra content.
. Characters are all likeable, especially Greez.
. Nice little nods to the Clone Wars era here and there.
. Soundtrack is a nice combo of new music mixed with the John Williams soundtracks from the original trilogy and the prequel trilogy.
. Achievement hunting is very doable with minimum difficulty - you do not need to play NJ+ to do get 100%

Cons:
. Although backtracking is available, some areas are too limited and one-way meaning you need to do more unnecessary exploring.
. Some of the collectibles require BD-1 to scan and if enemies are nearby, he will not and this can lead to skippable extras which make the following con even worse.
. Not all extras are indicated on your map, specifically datalogue entries, flora for the terarrium and most force echos. Note: These are needed for achievements so it can be annoying if you are going for them.
. There are times where the game does not elaborate on certain things which make it feel unfair (see SPOILER PROS AND CONS below).
. Some (not all) achievements are bugged - I specifically unlocked 5 achievements but they did not pop until I restarted the game and hit a save spot.
. Combat can be a bit janky when fighting multiple enemies at once, especially when you need to dodge and counter (though I may just be a bit inexperienced atm).

SPOILER PROS AND CONS (You have been warned!)
Pros:
. BD-1. Again. Best droid in the galaxy! Nothing majorly bad happens to him. He does not die.
. Yes, you can change your lightsaber colour when Kal has to get a new one. There is quite a selection and you can change it at anytime.
. Cere's backstory with her padawan Trilla/The Second Sister is very strong and makes me wonder why Reva needed to exist in the Kenobi series.
. Cere is interesting as she is a force user who is struggling with the balance of the light and dark side of the force and it makes me wonder is in store for her in the future.
. With the final Nightsister joining Cal it feels like Dathomir is concluded and nothing else can be done with it, allowing the Star Wars series to move on and focus on new worlds.
. The inclusion of Kyshykk was a great touch as we can see what the Empire has done to it post-Order 66 
. The final cameo of Darth Vader was an awesome touch! He's not even named by the others yet everyone reacts like their in utter fear.
. The ending was simplistic yet effective and showed how Cal had learnt from his journey within the force and the game.

Cons:
.Nightssister Merrin was a bit underwhelming and I think that's mainly due to her joining the crew so much later in the game - I hope though with the sequel we will see more of her.
. During the Darth Vader encounter when he grabs you, it is unclear that you need to drag your mouse to the right  force pull the ceiling down which cheats the player into an unfair death. This is due to the game not previously having interactive cutscenes with the mouse and comes out of nowhere.
. Darth Vader's cameo felt a bit underwhelming before the end as it does not leave an impactful note other than Cere almost using the dark side - it feels bit like it was inspired by Rogue One's ending without understanding why Vader's cameo was important.
. The Second Sister's fights were too repetitive, with her attacks being the same. 
. The final battle of the Second Sister was a tad annoying with the inclusion of her slam attack. This is because the game expects to dodge any attack where the enemy glows. However, in this case if you dodge you don't have enough time to do what the game is expecting you to do (which is to jump).

All in all! Great game!

Extremely late to the party, but this was a bunch of fun to play through. 
Chose to go on Jedi Master (2nd highest) difficulty, which was certainly a choice given I hadn't played any souls-like games for 5+ years (god damn Oggdo Boggdo was a hell of a learning curve). Made it feel so much more satisfying as I eventually progressed through certain sections. The combat feels fantastically fluid, and the parkour genuinely realistic (or as realistic as it can be for a force-powered murder machine).
I encountered minimal stuttering (3080, 5900X) with some textures, and only had two crashes to desktop during my total playtime.
The story is pretty standard Star Wars fare, but the performance given by Cameron Monaghan as Cal drew me in like nothing else. It will be a literal crime against nature if he isn't allowed to portray Cal in live action.
There are few single-player games that I would be excited to play through from start to finish again, and this is one of them.

Best star wars game i played

‚Ä¢ Easily the best Star Wars game in the last 10 years. Maybe also the best Star Wars anything in the last 10 years.

‚Ä¢ Is it a weird episode of Shameless? Yeah this episode of Shameless is kinda odd

‚Ä¢ Star Wars Jedi Fallen Order is a third person action game set between Revenge of the Sith and Rogue One. The player controls Cal Kestis, a Jedi who went into hiding after surviving Order 66 as a Padawan, and must now go on a quest to try to rebuild the Jedi Order.

‚Ä¢ The Good

‚Ä¢ Using my lightsaber and force powers in combat made me feel like a powerful Jedi. Force pushing enemies to send them flying off a cliff never stops being fun, you can also pull them towards you, slow their movement so they can‚Äôt block your attacks, throw your lightsaber at mid-range enemies and kill distant enemies by deflecting their blaster bolts back at them.

‚Ä¢ Several different enemy types including Stormtroopers and other Imperial soldiers armed with blasters, shock batons, rocket launchers and flamethrowers, wildlife, giant monsters, droids, AT-ST walkers, and Sith wielding their own lightsabers and force powers.

‚Ä¢ Combat is challenging on Jedi Master difficulty (the third of four difficulty levels). Regular enemies feel nicely balanced and are fun to fight, and sometimes you can take advantage of Stormtroopers and wildlife attacking each other, but let‚Äôs just say the bosses are not messing around and will have you wishing you could turn to the dark side. Be prepared to die a few times while you learn their attack patterns. One thing I liked about the boss design though is they‚Äôre mostly 1v1 fights so they feel like epic showdowns against important characters, instead of the usual video game bosses where you spend most of the time fighting a bunch of respawning minions.

‚Ä¢ The story is interesting, arguably better than some of the recent films, and voice acting is good. Cal‚Äôs droid ally BD-1 has as much personality as R2-D2 or BB-8.

‚Ä¢ Music and sound effects of lightsabers and blasters feels like Star Wars.

‚Ä¢ Controls are fully rebindable and work great with mouse and keyboard.

A mix of Tomb Raider's puzzles, traversal, cinematic feel and Sekiro's combat plus Soulslike elements, along with platforming and level design reminiscent of Metroidvanias set in Star Wars universe. None of these elements are as fleshed out or polished as in the dedicated titles it draws influence from, but they can all still stand their own ground here and mesh together surprisingly well, resulting in a combination that manages to provide a somewhat unique experience.
There's not a lot of variety in any aspect when it comes to gameplay, other than Cal acquiring new abilities and upgrades to shake things up a bit, but as it's not particularly long, it doesn't overstay its welcome and remains fun til the end.
The graphics are beautiful and environments are gorgeous. Interface is functional and fits very well thematically.
Story is straightforward, short and simple, but good. There are bits and pieces of extra lore scattered all around. Cal is an extremely likable character and the small supporting cast, companions and opponents included, are just fine as well.
Camera can be off at times and I've experienced occasional stuttering, but other than that it's a decent game all around. The only absolute let down in my eyes are Cal's mostly odd and wonky moves and animations, but that is not a huge issue. I could see the complex map design with a lot of verticality, unlockable shortcuts and backtracking due to lack of fast travel being annoying to people who are more interested in swordplay part. Personally, I enjoyed the way maps were laid out while doing main objectives, but could not bother trying to look for and pick up most of collectibles.
Besides being a good action-adventure Star Wars game, I think this is also an excellent introduction to the Soulslike genre, since it's more of a lite version - the standard more narrow and focused well thought out world with different kinds of hidden collectibles and power ups, combat, check point and level up mechanics are there, but it has 4 difficulties, no RPG elements and isn't as combat heavy.

[h1]Metroidvania[/h1] with extremely boring Puzzles; not souls-like. I expected it to be more cinematic. The only best bits are at the start. Old Darksiders1(for example) is much more cinematic than this. Get it only if you are a die-hard fan to play something star-wars themed. Anyway, it looks very cool and I want more games of hack and slash puzzle genre (but not as slow as this Jedi FO).


[b]** Why Negative? **[/b]
~Allies are all boring underdogs and There are barely any encounters with proper villains. 

~Just random mobs and mobs with bigger health(feels like videogame: Control).  | you barely meet lightsaber wielders, fair or fearful bosses, enemies just feel cheap.

~Enemies dodge attacks  | you have to wait to attack. You have more chances to get downed by 3 evading mosquitoes than a trained soldier.

~Enemies stance bar  | you can't hit their hp directly, so you wait more to attack

~Bossfights have no wind up time, are spontaneous and unstaggerable  | un-soulslike, dodge has barely any i-frames, patience for that big attack for an opening


[b]** Here's my issues. **[/b]
-    Starts off really well; but its not souls-like, its just Metroidvania: The pace is extremely slowed down with nothing to explore but puzzles and "yet to be unlocked" areas. This'd be fine, yes, but there is a very long disconnect from the villain and story as you spend so much time running around and... you see that door? OOOOOH nonono, you have to walk all the way around it (Similar door issue: Borderlands the Pre-Sequel).

-    Then (as a Prince of Persia Fan), platforming is brain-dead and sometimes its not mimicked enough or plain evil (there is this part with deadly pistons where you had to run on the wall to "jump higher"; the only thing I had to search). Every guide on the internet just jumps towards the piston and goes up without understanding why. If you do a puzzle, you follow already established rules; don't add random stuff. More on this: Sometimes character won't grab the ropes, and You have to move AND look around to understand the puzzles. A lot of people are going to quit playing because of them. Similar issue game: Darksiders 2.

-    If you are a big fan of the lightsaber battles: There is only 3. Sekiro has nothing to do with this and enemies don't have any wind up to attacks. There are multiple bosses that are just normal bosses with higher health. And also (just like Darksiders 2), normal enemy mobs dodge attacks. This is the most boring thing ever, I can parry everything they throw but I have to wait to attack every single time. I perfected three lightsaber duels just for funsies (coming from playing Sifu). Not worth it; bosses attacks and my dodge are flawed. This'd be easily solved by making the block button cancel/stop your attack animation(but it doesn't).

Summary: Only (somewhat) fun I had was in trying no dmg Lightsaber duels(Jedi Master). The rest is an absolute mess. I feel if I rushed the game to the end I'd have more time spent in an un-enjoyable walking & puzzle simulator (because platforming is horrendous).
Cancer.

[h1] Recommended only on sale [/h1]

[b]Story and Presentation: (7/10)[/b]
- Not a hardcore Star Wars fan, it's just "okay", not sure if canon
- A lot gets thrown at you, characters, events, Star Wars lingo, for what seems to be just for fan-service
- There are enjoyable set pieces
- You follow a conventional hero's journey of a weak and pathetic main character who never redeemed himself
- The main character is a mouth breather, who always have his mouth open for some reason and talks like he just got his molars taken out
- All throughout, you've been retracing the footsteps of a Jedi Master, uncovering the mysteries of an ancient race of force users but never learned what happened to his fate
- You never learned what happened to this ancient race, you got nothing out of it in the end other than they are force users
- The ending felt like the entire journey is pointless

[b]Sound, Music and Voice: (9/10)[/b]
- The sound design basically is the only thing that saves this game
- The satisfying sound of light sabers clashing, parrying blaster fire or melting through flesh
- The majestic orchestral music playing in the background
- The voice acting and lip syncing are well done

[b]Graphics and Visuals: (7/10)[/b]
- 8700k/1080ti, 144p, High-ultra, 90FPS lock
- Constant framerate dips specially when changing areas
- It looks, feels and smells like Star Wars
- Incredibly frustrating when you enter a new area with obviously a lot of enemies, you landed, you're surrounded, then it dips
- Mo-cap and facial animations are pretty good
- The set pieces and cutschenes are pretty good
- The main character looked like Peter Dinklage, and one of your crew looked like Dave Chappelle

[b]Level Design, Structure and Gameplay Loop (6/10)[/b]
- This souls like is worse than Bandai Namco's attempt at Code Vein
- Respawn has a skewed interpretation of what makes a souls-like, souls-like. Just because you've got a bonfire save point mechanic, enemies respawning and a maze-like level design doesn't make a souls-like game fun. You get lost on FromSoftware's level design because there are so many paths that could lead to anywhere with no restriction. Here, they artificially make the player feel lost in the level design by trapping them certain areas with no way of going back.
- The most annoyingly frustrating thing about the level design is using a lot of one-way traps, if you made a wrong turn, you would end up going back to the start and have to fight your way back to where you're supposed to go
- A lot of the levels are story-locked because either your character doesn't have the double-jump yet or your droid don't have the ability to open certain doors
- There's some uncharted-esque platforming here, wall running, rope swinging and puzzle solving which adds to variety but ultimately still janky and underwhelming
- You can fall from edges by walking and jumping but for whatever reason can't fall off by rolling.
- No build variety, no armor sets, nothing to grind or work towards
- This is no action RPG, this is basically a story driven souls-like
- The only thing that saves this category is it mixes up some areas by randomly replacing usual mobs with named, mini-boss bounty hunters

[b]Character Progression: (5/10)[/b]
- There's no meaningful progression to speak of
- Every loot in the game are purely cosmetics
- Also, why put tons of breakable pots with nothing in it?
- Even on that regard, most of the cosmetics are just swapping color schemes
- Your skill tree for whatever reason is story-locked because your character got some amnesia. At some point you'll end up sitting in skill points because there's nothing to use it to
- No build variety, no stat, nothing to grind, nothing to work towards
- The only satisfying thing here is constantly modifying what your light saber looked like

[b]Combat: (5/10)[/b]
- Combat is super clunky and janky, it's the worse Souls clone out there
- I hate the half-baked dodge in these Souls clones. A single tap would do a sidestep and a double tap would do a roll. Just let me roll and give me the iframe, this is pointless as it takes you twice the amount of time/reaction to get an actual roll going. The sidestep is useless because most attacks are sweeping attacks and has absurd tracking.
- No animation cancel, your character would commit to finishing the animation which also means if you get hit and you flinched, your character will finish that entire flinch animation and also eat the succeeding hits you can't roll out of
- It uses this Sekiro style posture gauge, parrying would reduce the enemy's posture, however it regenerates to full straight away. You have zero passive skills that would help in this posture mechanic. What's super annoying about this is once you got succeeding parries, broke the guard and hit the enemy, they would launch a poised counterattack.
- Using the force in combat is hit or miss, you can't seamlessly transition to doing light saber attacks to using the force and integrating it to your combo, your character would have to pause or finish the animations. Sometimes force push would register damage, sometimes it would just knock them down. Force pull should leave the enemy vulnerable to attack but instead would immediately block your attack or doesn't get pulled close enough.
- Absurd tracking enemies doing charged attacks.
- Sprinting and landing a sprinting attack is also janky, for whatever reason your character stops sprinting and half the time you miss the opportunity to land a blow after a force push
- I ended up just putting the final boss to Story difficulty, after playing the entire game at Grand Master, it's not worth it

[b]Difficulty: (6/10)[/b]
- Played: Jedi Grandmaster Difficulty
- Difficulty is jacked and there's one-shotting
- Most of your kit are useless other than force push
- You've got basic rats resistant to the force??
- LOTs of cheap ambush nonsense coming out of nowhere
- The game pads the difficulty by placing your character into a trapped section

[b]Encountered Glitches and Bugs: (7/10)[/b]
- No crashes in 26 hours
- Absurd amounts of framerate dips all through out
- Absurd amounts enemies getting stuck, getting thrown to air
- Your character also janks and gets thrown to the air when climbing rope shortcuts
- Using the force is hit or miss and super janky, sometimes it would damage or kill enemies, other ties it would just knock them down

[b]Fun: (7/10)[/b]
- The majestic orchestral starwars music that plays in the background are enjoyable
- Visiting places like Dathomir and Kashyyk is fun
- There are enjoyable set pieces
- Playing as a Jedi, using light sabers and using the force alone adds to the fun after not having one for a decade since Force Unleashed
- For every good thing this game presents, it constantly offsets it with lots of jank
- I would even argue that this is THE worst souls like game. I even enjoyed that 15-hour indie title Mortal Shell more than this.

[b] OVERALL: 6/10[/b]
- This game is over-hyped and over-rated only because it's star wars.

Jedi Fallen Order fits perfectly into the Star Wars lore. For me, this was the cherry on top of a delicious cake. It is canon.
The game itself is amazing. It has enough environment variety and world development for it to may be considered semi-open world. 
The combat is satisfying, with several difficulty levels, so it is not too easy or too hard, depending on the level the player chooses, according to his skill. Not only that, but it has enough variety, mixing force powers, with saber moves. The combat does relies heavily on parrying and dodging, specially against the harder enemies / bosses, giving it a bit of a souls-like taste.
The game starts by advising the player to use a gamepad, but I'm a since forever user of mouse and keyboard, and had no problem at all to play it with the last. I did tweaked the key bindings, because I found the default key for dodging not being practical, and changed it to L-ALT.
On a final note, for those that like to aim for 100% achievements, this game is not unfair, meaning, it has no unfair achievements, like the kind that demand a lot of grinding.
I love games with great setting and story. I have Bioshock as a benchmark for this. Fallen Order fills these requirements perfectly. Loved it. Definitely recommend it.

A solid game. Not quite as hard as many people led me to believe it would be.

It has multiple difficulty levels to choose from so you can tailor the experience to your liking.   

Good story and characters. Great combat. Exploration was sometimes a chore and some of the environments didn't make sense outside of the context of this being a video game.  A bit on the short side, in that it took me about 15 hours or so to beat.  

But overall, it was a good experience and I had fun.  Rating: 7.5/10

In a universe as wide-ranging and complex as the Star Wars universe, THE ONE perfect Star Wars video game cannot exist. I love to conquer Geonosis as a Clone Trooper in Battlefront as much as I enjoy defeating Jedi as a Sith in The Force Unleashed. Choosing an era and an allegiance means neglecting other representable perspectives. Nevertheless, Jedi: Fallen Order is ONE perfect Star Wars game. The player accompanies a young Jedi apprentice in the post-republic outer worlds on a mission regarding the fate of future Jedi, which is simultaneously his journey to becoming a fully fledged Jedi himself. The world design is phenomenal; the planets are different due to their flora and fauna, while latter contributes exceptionally well to the authenticity of the biosphere. Therefore, exploring planets always feels different and allows the player to further investigate a little bit more of the endless fantasy that characterises Star Wars, even though climbing and walking are (almost) mechanically similar throughout the game. The gameplay is constituted of melee combat and action-adventure-like jump‚Äôn‚Äôclimb exploration passages as well as puzzle areas, with a few cutscenes and overall positive cinematic tendencies. The story is mediocre, with too much emphasis on character relations in cutscenes, but functions well as a vehicle to explore the world ‚Äì one of the two main reason to play this game. The other is the battling system. Never before have lightsabre fights felt so good and ‚Ä¶ just cool. The combat offers a multitude of opportunities to be the most stylish and badass Jedi existing, and the skill tree opens the pathway to an increasing number of sabre attacks, combos and force attacks. The difficulty can be changed during the playthrough (but I highly recommend the hardest degree). Despite that most collectables have merely a minor visual purpose and only some strengthen the protagonist, going for 100% is worth every second. Jedi: Fallen Order finds a dynamic balance between exploration, puzzles, and combat, and presents this wonderful adventure in its convincing and engaging world.

So it has taken a long while to FINALLY finish this game. I do enjoy a good Star Wars story and game, but is Jedi Fallen Order a good game? I mean its published EA so does it have all the typical EA nonsense, of loot boxes, cut content sold as DLC, and more? Well let's get into the pros and cons of Star Wars Jedi Fallen Order


Pros-

- Authentic Star Wars asethetic (the overall atmosphere has that very distinct Star Wars feel)
- Sound (The voice acting, music, and enviromental sounds are all very well done)
- Combat (Simple, but deep, various combos with lightsaber with mixed in force powers etc.)
- Story (it makes you connect with the main character and the journey which seems to be almost a lost art in most story focused games nowadays)
- Length (perfect overall game length about 15-20 hours if only focusing on story)
- No loot crates, cut content, or any of the typical EA business stuff, we as gamers have come to expect.
- Variety (traveling to a variety of different locations and not Tatooine for once)
- RPG Mechanics (skill and character growth skill tree)

Cons-
- Backtracking (while different areas are available to explore as gameplay elements are made available. There is still a lot of backtracking across environments)
- No fast travel (shortcuts become available as  you explore, but this ties back to the backtracking)
- Enemy variety (the enemy variety is very limited, storm trooper, wild life, sith inquisitors is about it.)
- Enemy Respawn (enemies respawn when using meditation/save points, some will like it others will hate it. I fall into the later.)

Overall, I was quite shocked that EA even let Respawn make a single player Star Wars games without all the typical EA business nonsense. Overall, I would give Jedi Fallen Order a 40/50 (8/10 for the traditionilsts) If you are Star Wars fan it is an absolutely purchase. Even non Star Wars fans can enjoy this as the game does a great job giving fans the Easter eggs and calls to the fandom they will appreciate, but makes the story accessible to those who are not steeped in the Star Wars fandom and mythology.

How do I begin to review such a masterpiece? As a lifelong Star Wars fan, I knew I wanted to try a video game when I finally built my own PC. I grew up watching my dad play Force Unleashed II, but wanted to attempt something newer. This was beyond the expectations I had.

The graphics honestly aren't as polished as I'd expect a 2019 game to have. The character faces and hair suffer the most. It feels like Cere is bug eyed. However, not much else genuinely looks bad. The lighting is really well done, especially reflections on armor.

Each planet is well thought out and stunning. They're fun to explore and find the secrets in. That said, the maps are incredibly confusing and way too large to navigate efficiently. A waypoint system would've done this game wonders. A lot of my time is just running around, trying to figure out where I was supposed to be going.

The save mechanic is nice but also terrible. Saving at your convenience - nice. Having all enemies respawn - not nice. I get why they do, but it just becomes cumbersome to refight all the enemies you just killed because you wanted your health refilled. Stem canisters do slightly circumvent this issue, but not entirely if you're a clumsy player.

Enemies are decently difficult. I should preface by saying I did have to downgrade to story difficulty during Second Sister's second fight. I had a really difficult time specifically with bosses. Cal also locks onto enemies and you can't turn your camera to run, which is annoying.

Controls are shit. There are so many useless powers you accumulate. It's way more buttons than most players will want to remember. I was often clicking through, looking for the right skill for a moment. On top of that, the many lightsaber attacks don't differ by much at all. The skill tree is poorly organized and way too big. There's variation upon variation of skills that you just never use. I forgot I could throw my lightsaber at all. I do appreciate, however, that skill points are fairly easy to come by.

Customization is off the charts. BD-1 skins, ponchos for Cal, Mantis skins, and a fully customizable lightsaber really elevate the experience and make it feel personalized. That being said, tracking them all down is a nightmare. If you don't have a 100% guide handy, you won't find them all, plain and simple. Already started and want to 100% it now? Prepare for cumbersome backtracking (especially Zeffo).

Fitting this story into the lore is not difficult at all. They don't change much at all about established canon, they just give you an explanation for a possible inconsistency (no spoilers here). Cal's powers are all perfectly reasonable for a Jedi of his caliper, as are Cere's.

Lore aside, this works as a stand-alone story. Cal is believable and interesting, as are his whole crew and your villains. No one really lacks character. It really does feel like an immersive universe. Yes the maps were big, but I never felt like it was dragging when I was purely going for the next goal. With all that out - the end was awful. As spoiler free as I can - a final character development felt rushed and unnecessary (like it happened just to aid another character's development), and a beloved non-game character is incredibly underpowered and sloppily added. It was disappointing, but not enough that it soured the whole experience.

TL;DR Not the best game I've ever played, but I'm glad I put the hours in. Decent graphics, decent story, decent controls. I heavily recommend story difficulty if you don't often play combat games.

Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order is a stellar addition to the Star Wars gaming universe, seamlessly blending engaging combat, a captivating narrative, and an authentic Star Wars experience. The lightsaber battles are a highlight, striking a perfect balance between skillful choreography and player control, making each encounter feel both intense and rewarding. The game's level design is meticulous, offering a mix of challenging puzzles and breathtaking environments that capture the essence of the Star Wars universe. The narrative, centered around the young Jedi Cal Kestis, is both compelling and emotionally resonant, with well-crafted characters and a storyline that feels like a natural extension of the beloved saga. Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order successfully delivers an immersive and action-packed adventure, satisfying both Star Wars fans and gamers alike.

Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order manages to capture the essence of the Star Wars universe with an impressive blend of engaging gameplay, rich lore, and lightsaber-wielding action.

One of the standout features of Fallen Order is how seamlessly it integrates into the vast Star Wars lore. From the iconic locations to the familiar faces and the exploration of Jedi history, the game feels like a genuine extension of the Star Wars saga. The attention to detail in recreating the ambiance of this beloved universe is commendable, immersing players in a galaxy far, far away.

The combat system deserves praise, offering an exhilarating lightsaber experience that makes players feel like true Jedi warriors. The combination of lightsaber attacks, force abilities, and parrying creates a dynamic and satisfying combat loop. Every encounter feels like a cinematic duel, and mastering the lightsaber techniques is both challenging and immensely rewarding.

The gameplay is a thrilling mix of exploration, puzzle-solving, and intense combat. The level design encourages exploration, and the Metroidvania-style progression keeps players hooked as they unlock new abilities and discover hidden secrets. The game strikes a balance between linear storytelling and open exploration, offering a well-paced adventure that keeps players engaged from start to finish.

However, it's fair to acknowledge the game's shortcomings. Some facial animations for human characters could be more polished, occasionally detracting from the overall immersive experience. While it's a minor setback, it's noticeable enough to warrant mention, especially considering the high standards set by other aspects of the game.

On a positive note, the diverse array of alien species is well-crafted, and the attention to detail in their designs adds authenticity to the Star Wars universe. The variety of planets, each with its own unique ecosystem and challenges, further enhances the sense of exploration and discovery.

In conclusion, Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order successfully captures the magic of the Star Wars universe, offering an exciting blend of lore, lightsaber combat, and compelling gameplay. While some facial animations may fall short of perfection, the overall experience is a fantastic journey for any Star Wars fan. It's a worthy addition to the Star Wars gaming catalog, delivering an adventure that resonates with the spirit of the galaxy's greatest saga. May the Force be with you on this unforgettable odyssey.

For a AAA game, this was pretty good. It still has a lot more hand-holding than I would like, and they make most of the combat way more forgiving than the FromSoftware games, but it was still a nice challenge at higher difficulties. Exploration was quite satisfying.

Some of the worlds had huge, expansive maps. This was really cool the first time through, but they didn't get too much faster to traverse when coming back, which really deterred me from wanting to go use my new abilities to get stuff I couldn't the first time through. Even worse, the "rewards" were 90% just skins. Nothing interesting or useful at all. This was very AAA to me, where people love stupid stuff like paint colors or outfits, but that wasn't interesting to me in the slightest, which left me with no motivation to track down most of the secrets.

The game is definitely pretty. I wished I could have skipped some of the cut scenes, which I couldn't find any way to do. I'm not into Star Wars, and I was mostly interested in the gameplay, not the narrative, but the game really tries to push narrative on you.

All in all, it was a good experience, and I would recommend. It's definitely more approachable for newcomers than other Souls-like games, and the Metroidvania-like upgrades to movement were a cool addition to the formula as well.

Bought not long after launch. Only just got around to playing it. Such is the situation with my Steam account these days. - Given that you can pick this up for less than ¬£10 these days, this is a ridiculous bargain. And yes, even despite the negativity surrounding the EA launcher requirement, which, to be honest, I've personally just learned to accept (it sucks, but do you think EA cares?)

The game is great, and for fans of Star Wars, this serves a hefty helping of fan service.

The good stuff is too long to list, so I'll just stick to the bad stuff:

1 - PC optimisation. With a pretty high spec PC, I still had moments of frame drops - Seems to be an acknowledged issue that never got fixed
2 - The 'parkour' aspect is VERY clunky at times. Seems the programmers went to great lengths to prevent you from cheesing paths. And given that you repeatedly visit areas (to progress them further following upgrades, etc.), this was understandably important to prevent sequence breaks. But with this in mind, sometimes the INTENDED movement mechanics simply don't work. Just as one example, a running jump can sometimes COMPLETELY lose all momentum the moment you take off.
3 - The ending is a little... ehhh. No spoilers, but this went for a build-up that had zero foreshadowing and ultimately ended up making the game go out with a whimper instead of a bang.
4 - The map. WHERE you have to go is clear. How you get there is NOT. You'll often get frustrated just wondering where the hell, or what the hell, the game wants you to do.
5 - Combat. The game would clearly be a bit boring if you just sliced through everything/everyone, but it's a little frustrating when all your enemies can counter or stun lock you and you can counter and stun lock nothing (and in this regard, the 'parry' system is garbage). Never ONCE did the combat feel fluid (like that which was done so well in the Batman games).
6 - Backtracking. OH BOY does this game pad the clock by making you run somewhere to pointlessly, and I mean POINTLESSLY, run back. - The lack of a fast-travel option between the meditation spots was a big mistake. I spent the first half of the game happily exploring. It got painstakingly boring when I found out it achieved practically nothing. I then spent the last half just trying to get to my objective to advance the plot as quickly as possible.
7 - Looting. Don't bother, it's 95% only cosmetics and ones that aren't actually that creative.

Overall though, and despite that somewhat lengthy negative list, this is still a solid 7.5/10. It is NOT, however, the masterpiece gaming media attempted to portray this as.

For less than ¬£10 though, which this commonly achieves now in sales, it's a no brainer!

Respawn did a lot of things right with this game. The movement feels natural, combat is responsive (if unforgiving), the visual fidelity is impressive, and the story is believable. It does, however, suffer from one issue you'll only encounter if you are a completionist, or, to a lesser extent, desire as many healing/force assets as you can obtain: backtracking.

If you want to 100% this game, you'll be backtracking [b]a lot[/b] - possibly several times to the same location, depending on what you're after. While there are shortcuts one can unlock, there is no quick travel system. If you want to swap which planet you're on, you have to manually run back to your ship, which means figuring out which direction you came from, or devising a new route back. This wouldn't have been a dealbreaker for me had I known it before purchasing, even though [i]I did[/i] go back and grab everything, but it's worth knowing.

This game is pretty dang good actually, which surprised me a bit actually. I always thought that the fantastic response to this one was mostly due to it being a decent game, but that it came from EA (post Battlefront 2 too) which made it look way better than it actually is. Turns out that is not really the case, but I still feel that it gets higher praise than it actually deserves. The response to this game reminded me a lot of Horizon Zero Dawn, which is just an alright game imo, but Jedi deserves the positive response more and is a better game than that one without a doubt. 

The game is pretty much a good "first draft" of a really good Star Wars game. That sounds worse than it is really but it kind of feels that way. Every part of it is pretty good, but nothing really feels fantastic, and nothing is really bad either. Movement and climbing feels like Uncharted, but I would hope for something a bit more "impressive" 3 years after the last one in that series. Exploring the different levels is also pretty fun, but something about it feels a bit bland to me. Combat feels pretty nice, but it is not very deep and kind of slow (very personal as I want a faster combat system when using lightsabers, even more Sekiro inspired post that game). I know that this can be explained with how Cal is not very experienced but it does not make it feel deeper or better unfortunately lol. Story is also pretty good, but does not feel that special to me. Cal is a nice protagonist though and one of the better Star Wars characters that have appeared especially these recent 10 ish years... The game overall gives the impression that the devs were kind of playing it safe with this one, and perhaps a bit safe with certain things.

But the absolute best parts of the game, or the one that truly impressed me was the graphics, sound and how focused it is. The visuals and sounds were both stunning, as well as the animation work (maybe not Cals running animation though which looks really stiff and odd). The truly awe inspiring vistas that you come across frequently throughout the game are just fantastic. But the focus of this experience is really really nice. There are only a handful of planets, and therefore levels, but they are tied super well with the unlocking of the different abilities. The skilltree is not very large, but each ability manages to feel quite impactful to all aspects of the game. And the best part is that you get everything in the game by engaging in the combat and exploration. You know, the fun parts of the game. No stores, crafting stations or even upgrade parts (like +5% resistance to fire). It feels very refreshing and nicely stripped back to its great core parts.

I was also surprised with how much customization there was as well, which was all the kinds of loot there is (except bonus points for health and force), with the lightsaber customization being a true high point. Really glad EA did not force any microtransactions with more customization, which is not beneath them in the slightest. Also very glad there is not any additional content to the game, which makes it feel more that the game is the complete package, just as intended by the developers.

There is not a lot of bad stuff to bring up, as I feel there is nothing really that stands out as bad (just as with most good stuff never being truly fantastic). But what I do really dislike is the performance and loading times, even though they do not really affect my overall enjoyment of the game, at least not as much as the things mentioned before. The loading times (tested both on HDD and M.2 NVME SSD) are always 40s to over a minute, and you will encounter them every time you die (which could be often considering where the game takes its main combat inspiration: Dark Souls). This is actually the slowest loading game I have come across, on two different PCs over the last 6 or so years (probably even longer). Really bad in my experience, but I have heard that some people do not have this issue which is nice to hear. 

And do not give me any of this that I see on a lot of forums on this topic when asking for help: "Oh complaining about x amount of seconds of loading times? Back in my day we had to wait minutes blah blah blah". I know. I have also experienced that before, but that does not mean we should settle nor tolerate the same poor experience/performance decades later, when other devs manage just fine. It just feels lazy. Just because you put up with something bad in the past does not justify its existence decades later.

The other big problem is the constant stuttering, which makes this the worst game in this category as well these past 6 years. I know that this is mainly a problem with UE4, but wow, no other game has ever been this bad in my experience. The only thing I hope for is that Survivor is at least better in these two aspects... 

I have heard that Jedi Survivor is basically the potential of this game realized (but with really bad performance and bugs included lol, but may be fixed) and I am actually looking forward to playing it quite a lot now, which surprised me just as much as the actual game did. A very good "first draft" or foundation perhaps, but not something truly special (yet). But there is some huge potential here.

I love this game!

If you want to play a souls like game but feel intimidated by the difficulty that souls games are known for, Jedi fallen order is a great game to introduce you into the genre. This isn't to say that the game is easy, it is however more forgiving than a lot of other souls like games and can offer an extreme challenge when bumping up the difficulty.

The game looks good, not amazing or spectacular, but it's good overall. The motion cap on some characters does look a little odd at times but isn't really a problem. The worlds and atmospheres are fun and each world feels unique and satisfying to explore and adventure. I believe the exploration in this game is good enough I actually felt compelled to gather all of the collectibles and fully explore each map, something that not every game can achieve the urge to hang around places you've already been for over an hour.

The characters are fun and interesting. The banter and interactions between characters during cut scenes in the best way possible, felt like I was watching a TV series at times. I also love that Darth Vader also feels like a genuine threat and menace, that although you've grown so much from your adventures, he's true force not to be reckoned with.

In the beginning bosses were really difficult and took a few times to beat, but as I played the game more and more I was able to block and parry quicker. I found it really satisfying when I was able to correctly counter an enemy the first time I encountered them. The game does a great job at not throwing too much at you when you're first learning, but it doesn't feel too easy either. I played on Jedi knight my first play through.

I highly recommend this game, especially with how often it goes on sale. Hopefully this review has given a little insight into what to expect, and may the force be with you on your journeys.
Dark souls with light sabers

I'm going to give this an upvote, but with some warnings for future purchasers. 

First and possibly most important thing to know about the gameplay, as that this game dropped when Dark Souls series was huge. The reason this matter here is there are two core gameplay elements which, if you don't like them, you will not like the entire game. 

First mechanic is the Save Point system. There are certain places you can save, and when you do, you replenish your stim (heal) charges. 

Second goes with it, and that is enemy regeneration. Every time you save, all enemies will regenerate in all areas. Even a room you just left. 

Backtracking for Unlocks / Shortcuts. I really hate the feeling of backtracking. Even irl I'll choose a different route back just to not backtrack.  To be clear, you MUST backtrack in order to get everything. Sometimes you have to eait until you get some future skill upgrade and return. 

And about the map...

Map is hella annoying spin-it-what-level-is-this-shit-rotate-it-shit-zoom-out 3D hologram style, with no ability to place markers or follow bread crumbs. The world maps are quite good, and navigation has a Tomb Raider / LOtR feel. But navigating has the stated challenges, and they are especially immersion breaking when you need to get on YouTube to figure out how to get through some unimportant area. 

if you can swallow all that, we've got Tomb Raidery / LotR  puzzle-environments, with enemies to fight. Sweet Jedi abilities, plays so good @ 120hz 4K even on a 3060, and though lots of rails, they are really nice rails. Sound design is Star Wars perfection. It would be had not to like the game if you are a big Star Wars fan. But if you are a big full-service RPG fan, you will be let down. I saved you lol

If you're a Star Wars fan, if you've played Jedi Academy, if you've played Unleashed, then you won't like this game. You won't be able to feel like a Jedi. Almost all standard Jedi techniques are forgotten by the main character. Because of the story? No, because of the gameplay. It's deliberately simplified, and the level design is planned in such a way that you'll be glad that after 2/3 of the game, you finally learned not only to push objects away but also to attract them! Speaking of level design ‚Äî it's boring and irritating. Be prepared to navigate the same maps several times. And it won't be like in Prince of Persia: Two Thrones; it will literally be the same path, with the same enemies, in the same places.

The plot is simplistic and predictable. Playing the game to find out what happens next? No, that's definitely not the reason. Besides, Disney's canon rules prevent this game from inventing anything new, making the entire storyline literally meaningless.

The parkour is annoying. It's not the parkour from Assassin's Creed, it's not the parkour from Prince of Persia; it's a simple solution the game designers found to prolong the gameplay.

This game is often compared to Uncharted or Dark Souls, but it's more like the four part of the Prince of Persia.

As someone that has kind of faded away from Star Wars content the last few years, I didn't really know what to expect with Fallen Order. All I really knew about it was that it was kinda similar to Dark Souls style combat with quality cinematics. What I got however, was a fantastic experience. It felt great to have a story set in the Star Wars universe that didn't revolve around the same 6 characters. All the new characters had great chemistry with each other and the storyline was easy to follow with big set-pieces and moments. Cal felt like a better character than 90% of the characters introduced in the sequel movies and the supporting cast all had their own motivations and were fully fleshed out to bring together a very solid narrative and experience. 
 
While frustrating at times, most of the time I felt pretty comfortable with the different combos and parrying enemies throughout the game. Button mashing still was a decent strategy, but the game really shined when you utilized Cal's full arsenal. I often found myself struggling more with basic enemies than the bosses, which was a surprise. Even with tough parts of the game, it never felt unfair or cheap having them beat me. It was always a result of me making mistakes and missing timings. That is the kind of difficulty in games that I enjoy rather than just stupid hard just for the sake of it. Once you get the hang of it, its a blast just carving through enemies in various ways, while still keeping an eye out for tougher enemies that can throw a wrench in your plans. 
 
Fallen Order was another type of game that I probably didn't think I would play in years and I am glad that I did because it was overall a great time. The Dark Souls-y combat still isn't my favorite, but the entire experience is good enough that I can power through and have a good time. I will definitely look to play the 2nd one at a later point just to see what happens to the characters that I was surprised to be attached to.

It's Tomb raider with a StarWars story. Run around (alot) look for data, kill a few storm troopers, fight a few bad guys and spend more time trying to work the maps out (and everything else)... (drawn out, too much to do)
Was it good.. Yes,

jumping is a pain, if you are off by a few mm, you fail... (tree of origin) (oh and don't miss the feather!) And, you try getting back in the swap... on Dathomir!   
and the list goes on... spend time and the game rewards... Good story (it's Star Wars)

So, yes Good and yes bad... possibly to much going on and the little details missed... Good effort by the Team who made it.

TLDR: Get the game on sale. Otherwise, I would get a different game.

- Movement/Abilities feel so clunky.

- Enemy encounters do not feel very balanced at all, either way too easy or annoying as all hell (not in the good way). And somehow, both options can even occur at the same time.

- Bosses feel so boring to fight against.

- Combat is passable, I thought the parry was fun to use. But, there is a lack of variety in the moveset for a decent chunk of the game. You're pretty much just spamming x and every now and then throw out a parry.

- Level design is fine. It isn't fromsoft tier (that really isn't the easiest thing to match anyways), but it gets the job done.

- The story's not that bad, if you're going to play this game for any reason you're probably going to play it for the story.

All and all, this is the most 5/10 game I've ever played in my life. If "meh" were a game, this game would be it. Get this game on sale if you want to try it, it's the only time I think it would be worth the money.

Note: My opinion on this game was made primarily though playing the game on Jedi Grand Master difficulty. Your experience may differ greatly from mine depending on the difficulty, though judging the ease of certain encounters, the game would probably be less annoying, but way more boring to play through on lower difficulties.

In a galaxy far, far away . . . EA actually released a good game without performance issues or microtransactions!

You follow the journey of Cal Kestis, a Jedi forced into hiding, as he embarks on a journey to stop the Empire with a crew he runs into along the way. With the lovable droid BD-1 always by your side, you slowly regain your force powers, defeat a bunch of stormtroopers that have still not learned how to aim, and even find unique plants that you can grow in your ship! The storytelling in this game is truly fantastic, and there are a handful of truly memorable characters, but the thing that warmed my heart the most was Cal's relationship with BD-1: the way Cal truly cares for his droid-partner, and the comedic interactions between the two steal the spotlight. There is nothing negative to say about the story, it makes a great addition to the Star Wars universe.

As much as I liked this game, there are two major things which made the game unnecessarily frustrating at times. First of all - there is no fast travel in this game. At all. Not even to your ship after you've completed the game and are just trying to get some collectibles. I personally don't think there was a strong enough reason to have an absence of fast travel, other than trying to prolong gametime. Second of all - the map design. While BD-1's holomap looks cool and like something you would see in a Star Wars movie, it was unintuitive and difficult to use at times, and there is also a complete lack of a minimap, which just makes it that much harder.

Generally, this game is great. The gameplay is smooth, you can choose your difficulty level if you're chasing a challenge, and there are a number of different enemies and bosses to beat. There are some extremely cool parts of the game, and if you are a fan of the franchise, you will probably enjoy this game.
I really enjoy this game, personally my favorite StarWars game franchise.

Exceeded all my expectations, and I'm not one to gush.

The world they built is like, "Whoa, look at this!" From busy cities to ancient tombs, it's like a Star Wars postcard. Graphics? Top-notch, of course. I felt like I was starring in my own low-budget Star Wars spin-off.

Now, the lightsaber fights? Oh, baby. Cal got cooler moves as I played, and it wasn't just button mashing. The lightsaber felt like a badass extension of my Jedi self. I was into it.

Storyline? Seriously engaging. No spoilers, but the characters and their little dramas were surprisingly good. It's like they took a soap opera script and threw in lightsabers. 

Exploring was my jam. Puzzles, secret spots ‚Äì they made me feel like Indiana Jones, but with a lightsaber. Sound? Iconic tunes and lightsaber hums ‚Äì I was humming along. Voice acting? Not bad, not bad at all.

For Star Wars fans and the regular gaming folk, this game's a winner. Great graphics, fun combat, and a story that won't put you to sleep. Kudos, Respawn, for this unexpected joyride through the Star Wars universe!

[h1] Scroll to the bottom for TL;DR [/h1]

this game is honestly phenomenal, a semi open world game that allows a LOT of customisation (and even more with the power of modding) for me i would say this is almost my perfect SW game with a few hiccups.

where my problems lie, (which there are very little) is sometimes Cal will jank out with platforming and will not connect with the platform / pipe / rope or whatever it is you're trying to reach and can result in falling, this wouldn't be much of a problem, but you do take damage if you fall down a cliff (if you are on any other difficulties other than story mode) while the damage IS small, it is a minor annoyance that can have you wasting your limited stims (healing) depending on your health, or if you want to limit any damage taken in general. i wish this was made better.  

and the 2nd problem is optimisation could be better, i played this both on my old PC (a gtx 1050) and my new PC (gtx 3060) and it still has the same frame issues on certain planets in certain areas, i.e mainly Kashyyyk, which in a game like this where you need to time your parries and dodging, frame drops are frustrating. though having said this, this is still far more optimised and playable than Jedi Survivor.

3rd, and this was sorted in Jedi Survivor (thankfully. however i wish it had been in this game also) about half way through the game Cal unlocks the ability to have dual lightsabers (or to be exact, splitting the lightsaber in 2), but you only get to use them doing a special move, which consumes your force (or i guess stamina.) which sucks, you have different stance styles, single handed, double bladed, and not.. dual? i just always found that odd. again, this isnt a problem in jedi survivor, they added much more lightsaber stances / styles, including a blaster / lightsaber combo which is awesome, but here, seems like such a tease. 

those are mainly the only gripes i can really think of honestly. again, very minor. this is close to a perfect Star Wars game for me personally.

this game also has a lot of collectables found around the different planets that go towards customising cal with ponchos, BD-1, the ship 'The Mantis' and his lightsaber, which is the most lightsaber customisation we've seen in any of the SW games thus far. (this is now outdated with Jedi Survivor adding a LOT more customisation lol)

[b]game synopsis:[/b] this is set 5 years or so after RoTS (Revenge of the sith), most if not all jedi are believed to be dead, or being hunted, and you play as Cal Kestis, a young jedi padawan that has been in hiding since the purge of order 66, trying to live a normal life as a scrapper but after being found by sith inquisitors he's on the run and on a mission of finding himself again as a jedi and who he is as a person, and dealing with the burden of failing his master Jaro Tapal, and relearning all his previous force abilities with his droid companion, BD-1, for the sake of spoilers and not wanting ruin it for someone who hasnt seen anything on this game, i wont speak any more on the story.


[b] TL;DR: [/b] 9.5/10! I must say, this game exceeded all my expectations. Respawn has crafted a truly remarkable gaming experience that pays homage to the beloved Star Wars universe while introducing an original and captivating story.

I was immersed in a rich and beautifully realized world. The attention to detail in the game's environments is breathtaking, from the bustling cities to the hauntingly atmospheric ancient tombs. The graphics are stunning, and the level of realism adds an extra layer to the immersion, making it feel like I was part of an epic saga.

One of the standout features is its combat system. The lightsaber combat is incredibly satisfying, with a perfect balance of strategy and fluidity. As Cal gains new abilities and hones his skills, the combat evolves, offering a sense of progression that keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging. The lightsaber feels powerful and responsive, making every swing and parry a joy to execute.

The storyline is a true highlight, weaving a compelling narrative that kept me hooked from start to finish. Without giving away spoilers, the characters are well-developed, and their relationships add emotional depth to the overall experience. The game successfully captures the essence of the Star Wars mythos, blending the epic struggle between the light and dark sides of the Force with a personal journey of self-discovery.

Exploration is a key component, and the level design encourages players to venture off the beaten path in search of secrets and hidden lore. Solving puzzles and unlocking new abilities to access previously inaccessible areas make exploration rewarding and adds an extra layer of satisfaction to the overall experience.

The attention to detail extends to the sound design, with iconic Star Wars music enhancing key moments and the hum of lightsabers immersing players in the world. The voice acting is top-notch, bringing the characters to life with authenticity and emotion.

This game is a triumph for both Star Wars fans and gamers alike. It captures the magic of the Star Wars universe while delivering a compelling and satisfying gaming experience. With its stellar graphics, engaging combat, and immersive storytelling, it has earned its place as a standout entry in the Star Wars gaming canon. May the Force be with Respawn for delivering such an epic adventure!

The game has left me [strike]scarred and deformed[/strike] feeling more frustrated than entertained. Despite a few positive aspects, I'm sure I won't be buying the sequel.

[b]Cons[/b]:
- The game is overwhelmingly focused on platforming, jumping, parkour and solving childish puzzles.
- Every area in the game (well, except your ship) is a nightmarish maze (especially the planet [spoiler]Zeffo[/spoiler] which unfortunately you're required to visit twice)
- No fast travel, even after completing the main objectives on a planet you have to run back through the maze to your ship. I think I spent 20% of my gameplay just running back to the ship after each mission. Just look how popular YT videos on "how to run back to your ship" are.
- Completely unnecesary souls-like elements that don't quite fit into the Star Wars universe in my opinion.
- The game is painfully linear, player can't really make any choices that could impact the story or alter the ending,
- The AI of the stormtroopers is laughable. They just stand still, shooting every few seconds while shouting generic lines like "Oh, look, that's a Jedi!" or "You won't escape me!". A funny thing is that you often need to strike them multiple times with your lightsaber even when you should be able to kill them with just one slash.
- Character development feels rather unsatisfying.
- Player can't use weapons other than their lightsaber (I was hoping I could use some nice guns like in Jedi Outcast or Acedemy),
- All items that you can find and pick up are just cosmetic skins for your poncho, droid or ship. I stopped bothering to open boxes after a while.
- Lack of side quests, the game sticks strictly to the linear main storyline.

[b]Pros[/b]:
- The story is somewhat interesting (though it feels very Disney-esque).
- Good graphics, I liked the views.
- Swinging your lightsaber can be cool at times.
- Force pushing enemies off cliffs can be funny.
- Boss fights were quite well designed and a breath of fresh air after killing brainless [strike]chickens[/strike] stormtroopers.
