When I got to know that this Star Wars game is Souls like, I had my doubts. But this game is amazing and a very fun and satisfying experience.

Positives: 
- It does not matter if you have seen the movies or know anything about the Star Wars universe to enjoy this game.
- The combat is very satisfying.
- You get upgrades and unlocks gradually and at the right time.
- The graphics are beautiful, the performance is stable.
- Although it has souls like mechanisms, it has a difficulty setting option that can be changed anytime with no negative impact. Although I did not need it since the game is already forgiving, its a good to have feature so that everyone can enjoy the game.
- The map is difficult to read, but once you understand it, it eases things.

Negatives:
- Microtransact-------- umm where are the microtransactions? This is an EA game, how could they do this? On a serious note, this is how single player games should be, no microtransactions. Good job EA on this.
- The only negative in my opinion is the lack of fast travel. Personally I don't want to go through the same areas again, but I am sure others will enjoy it. This is more of a personal issue since I do not get much time to play so I try to maximize my experience.

If you are on the edge, go ahead and buy it, you will not be disappointed.

P.S. There is a level where there is a forest. Won't spoil anything but the amount of fun I had in that level is something that I do not experience often.

Wonderful game! I had an absolute blast playing it. Reminds me of all the reasons why I love this franchise. EA had a lot to prove and they gave us something great. I like the Assassins Creed/Tomb Raider like gameplay. It compliments Star Wars very well.

 Combat took some getting used to, but once you get a handle on it, it becomes much more immersive. It‚Äôs much more tactical then most and requires some patience instead of just plowing through everything. Which to me, makes it much more unique. It‚Äôs not super hard but certain boss fights can be very challenging. Not throw my controller challenging, but enough to were I‚Äôd have to learn from my mistakes and adjust my approach to the battle. Just like a Jedi! 
It also reminds me of the old Jedi Outcast and Jedi Academy Games. Worlds are all unique and fun to explore, if a bit linear, which I know bothers some but I could care less if it‚Äôs linear as long as it‚Äôs interesting. 

Story was familiar but great to play through. Pretty sure I loved all the new characters and can‚Äôt wait for their story to continue. Platforming was fun and intense at times. I enjoyed collecting all the cosmetics and learning about the new worlds and characters. All in all, I loved it. It‚Äôs the single player Star Wars experience I‚Äôve needed for a long time. In my mind, best Star Wars game since the original Force Unleashed. Buy it or rent it just to see what you think, and may the force be with you.

Foremost, the props: the game looks and feels like a nice Star Wars game.  Overall, the early game play is suitably epic, has nice story building, and overall begins well.  I did start having an early suspicion that the climbing mechanic was going to be overused, and my character would likely suffer overly frequent death-by-not-hitting-the-"e"-button-fast-enough-to-climb-after-jumping, but fortunately, the re-spawn mechanic after falling wasn't punishing, and so overall, pretty content...

...right up to the point where I went to the first planet.  Somehow, I went from moving a rapid clip through the game where my meager PC/keyboard skills more than carried me to absolutely stuck.  I bought a Star Wars game, and I immediately ended up in a miniature Twister game.  I lost blood flow to my fingers -- twice -- in an effort to remember how to stun, run, duck, no stun, not heal, run, die.  By the Almighty, did I die.  

Run, jump, sorry, just didn't hit "e" fast enough, 
Run, jump, climb, chase down monster fighting the extra from the set of "Starship Troppers", get a mud-hole stomped by my backside.
Run, jump, die
Run, jump, climb, mudhole.
Mudhole.
Mudhole.
x23
Quit Game
Write Review

So, it is with sadness that I report the Republic has fallen, the Jedi younglings are officially #&*@'ed, and Kal Kestis and his 1/2 of a robot chihuahua are flat on their digital assets somewhere out in the universe.  This game went from fun to *#&@-you too quick for my weak skill set to accommodate.  That wasn't what caused the great purge, however.  It helped, but what finally helped zero out the bits this game used to occupy was the frequent reminder of "There, there, mommy's boy, you can always move the game difficulty to somewhere above thumb-sucking.  I'm sure it'll be fine then."  In all honesty, I'm sure it wasn't quite this smarmy, but after reading something like this a few times, thus is where my brain landed, and I'm not going back to find out.

So, if you like repetition, low self-esteem, yippy, coked-up tiny robots, and a chance to play a ginger in a Disney franchise, wait no further.  I'm going to take my weak gamer skills and go have fun.  Delete.

One of the most unforgettable scene of the game is when Cal Kestis looks at Darth Vader and said "We really are in a STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order." Truly a genius level writing, it sends shivers down to my spine.

The game sucks most of the time. I feel like I'm running around in circles, trying to find my way back to the Mantis (that's the ship you use). There's a lot of jumping, puzzles etc. but I can't fully enjoy it due to terrible map and mediocre level design. Gave it a shot, spent over 6 hours with the game and am considering uninstalling it right now.
I love the graphics and sound tho, it just ain't enough to keep me with Fallen Order any longer.
Overall, I'm glad I didn't pay full price for the game as it would be a waste of money, at least for a casual player like me.

The worst parts of Uncharted mixed with a half-ass Souls-like clone. 

I played this game on Storymode after beating the first boss and seeing just how delayed the dodge was. They want to be a Dark Souls clone but they can't even be bothered to have TIGHT, RESPONSIVE controls. So Storymode it was. They didn't care enough, I don't care enough.

The story itself is just awful. At no point did I CARE about the characters, none of the "impactful" moments made me feel ANYTHING, each character is just as bland and boring as the next. The planets you travel to are slogs. You go there once, leave, eventually come back and progress further. It's like they knew Metroidvania games exists but were too stupid to understand what makes those games work.
The writing is cognitively dissonant. For example; in one part you sneak up on two Empire pilots and listen to them talk about their lives, you know them out, steal their AT-AT and get it blown to bits with them still inside, and all the main character does is act all casual about it. None of which gels together and all feels like it was written by three different people and somehow jammed together. 

And it just ends. The ending of the game just kind of happens. I was at 67% when I started tonight and ended up beating the rest of the game in less than an hour. To get to that 67% it took 11-ish hours. Just weirdly paced and improperly put together by people who didn't know what the hell they were doing.

Oh, but the game LOOKS nice. So if you're one of those people who likes to look at things you can't go to or interact with, but looks really expensive to make, this is the game for you.

Graphics: The game has decent graphics, thanks in part to Unreal Engine 5. 

Story: The story is intriguing, but it is getting a little tiresome to find yet another lone jedi surviving in hiding after Order 66. Yoda really missed a lot of Jedi when he claimed Leia was the only other hope besides Luke. This little cliche in the Star Wars storytelling really needs to die. 

Gameplay:Dull at best, frustrating most of the time. The combat is hardly better than an old-school button masher. The pretense of finesse for the Jedi is lost quickly when you have many, many enemies who wield lightsaber-like weapons that are faster and more skilled with them than you at the start and you never get better. The only way you win is because the game hands you victories. While you are slashing at them with your button-mashing, and they are seemingly deflecting EVERYTHING, suddenly the play slows, the game gives you a little animation, and you slice up a foe and move onto the next. Boom, you win. . . because the game needs you to progress. 

But, the combat only makes up 10% of the game. The rest is map puzzles. and ON MY SWEET BABY JESUS, these maps are annoying, overwrought, unnecessarily complicated, and act more like mazes than maps. You are required to solve puzzles while navigating mind-numbingly complicated maps. Once you realize the puzzle has little to no guidance within the game and you've resorted to Googling the answer, then you are in need of getting back to your ship or the next portion of the maps puzzles. The problem; the holo-map you have in-game is about as useful as a cheese baseball bat, and you spend most of your time running in circles trying to figure out how to your next objective. To make matters worse, there are many, many times you are trying to get around the map and find your objective where you slip or fall back into former section, which will require you to spend half an hour getting back to where you fell, only to hope you don't do it again. I have never been both this frustrated and bored with a game in many a year. 

As you are trying to solve the puzzle to progress in the game you find the game has little to no clues to help and provides extremely vague ideas. So, you eventually resort to Googling it, or stumble across it with dumb luck (Seriously, the game has in-game hints your droid gives you, and they tend to be so vague, it hardly helps). Once you've done that, you are either required to get back to your ship, or progress to the next puzzle objective. But, lo, you must find it. The map you are traveling in is so ridiculously complicated that you run in circles, often finding yourself back where you started. Or worse, you make it to a location where you can't backtrack and are forced along another even longer path back to where you were to begin with. Don't worry, they give you a 3d holographic map your droid can project. . . which is less helpful than asking a toddler for directions. So, by this point, you have run around for a good hour, made no progress and find yourself Googling answers, only to find that most people can't help you. Eventually, you discover the vague path you were meant to use and get to your objective. Several hours have passed by this point and you have accomplished little more than literally running in circles until you stumble across the answer or, again, dumb luck strikes. 

Conclusion: Writers hate a review that is simply DNF, meaning Did Not Finish. That means the reader was so unimpressed with the book they put it down without even getting through it. I rarely DNF a game, I will bull my way through it to see if the ending justifies all the frustration. This game earns a full DNF. I got lost in yet another map of theirs and spent two hours trying to figure it out and even online help was of little use. I realized I couldn't care less if I finished, so I won't. The reason I tried this game was because there was a sequel and I wanted to play them both. Well, if this game is any indication of how the next will be, I will never try it. EA games, I want a refund.
It was fun the first 3 planets. But got bored on Darth Maul's planet despite getting excited to go there. My problem is there is no fast travel on the planets so you can to backtrack again.

Although I enjoyed aspects of the experience, I do not recommend this game.

My biggest complaints were combat and traversal.

I found combat to be very frustrating. As someone who greatly enjoyed Dark Souls and Sekiro, I never got around to enjoying combat in this game. The game purports to emphasize parrying, but parrying is not simply a matter of timing. So many times, I'd press block, only to watch Cal continue with his attack animation and have a chunk of my health bar disappear. Sekiro made me *want* to learn its unique mechanics (having come first from Dark Souls). Fallen Order did not.

There was also a huge dichotomy in the usefulness of force powers. The typical stormtrooper, as you might expect, was pure fodder, and happy to serve as rewarding expenditures of my force bar. But there was very little between that and the more difficult enemies, who seemed to shake off force powers as if I was merely breathing hot air in their direction. Which was all the more frustrating when the game would flood you with both sets of enemies at once.

(NOTE: I tend to approach these kinds of games with a more instinctual approach. For those who tend more toward studying each enemy patiently, you may not have my same frustrations.)

Traversal was also very frustrating. The maps twist and turn with multiple levels. But rather than large open spaces connected by corridors, a la Dark Souls and Sekiro, Fallen Order is almost all corridors and rooms with intricate connections between points. There's no way to fast travel between points, nor is there any navigation system beyond the map. You can unlock shortcuts, but, ironically, that frustrated me further by increasing the number of confusing connections between areas. 

The map is a 3D projection, which, in my experience, was difficult to interpret. A bright shortcut rope for one section of the map could overlay on top of the particular section you were in, and it wouldn't be clear that you were several areas away from that rope until you've rotated the map enough times. This issue is somewhat caused by the level design; a strictly tiered map along the lines of Dead Space or Resident Evil 2 REmake might misrepresent some of the sublevels, as well as how connection points could take you from the northeast-most point on elevation-level 5 to the west-most point on elevation-level 2. AND YOU CAN'T USE THE MAP WHILE UNDERWATER OR CLIMBING. Which is a relatively minor complaint given that the underwater sections aren't terribly convoluted, but it did mean that I couldn't plan my routes until I made my way back to land.

Some more minor complaints are the aimless-feeling platforming and the inability to skip cutscenes. Specifically, there is a *lot* of platforming in this game, and so much of it feels like platforming just for platforming's sake. It felt like a huge emphasis was placed on getting you to have you crawl across multiple sprawling vertical sections over having areas make any real sense on a practical level. Which would be fine if crawling across things felt fun (like Assassin's Creed) rather than a chore to get to the next fight zone or cutscene. And speaking of cutscenes, you can't skip cutscenes. So if you're playing new game+, or had to quit before meditating at a meditation point, you'll have to sit through the cut scene again.

In conclusion, I think some people would enjoy this game--and clearly they have. But if the above resonates with you, then maybe you should avoid it. Even having bought it on sale, I really wish I hadn't. That said, I was able to force (hehe) myself to finish it, so take that for what it's worth.

This is an ok game that's hiding a magical secret great game in it somewhere. I kept hoping it would reveal itself throughout my initial and follow-up playthrough but unfortunately it never appeared.

The mechanics of this game (which I played on Jedi Master difficulty, a good fit for my skill level) are going for an almost souls-like approach to combat and metroidvania world design. For me, a fan of both types of games, this seemed like the perfect combination! There are seven worlds that unlock as you progress the story and skills you unlock that allow you to eventually fully explore them. The game doesn't attempt to alleviate the usual problem with metroidvania-style design: usually, it feels sluggish and incomplete to explore until you have unlocked most or all of the major abilities. This is most definitely the case with Jedi: Fallen Order, most notable when you unlock game-changing movement and combat upgrades about halfway through the main story. I can forgive it for this (like I said this is a common issue with metroidvanias) but this is where my issues with the game only begin.

Jedi: Fallen Order has a high degree of visual polish and an unfortunately low level of bug-and-animation polish. This game's movement feels stilted at times and lacks the precision of control (especially in combat) that other games going for higher difficulty usually focus on getting right. As a general rule I have two categories of difficult game: one where I get mad at myself for messing up, and one where I get mad at my in-game avatar or the controls. Jedi: Fallen Order falls more often into the latter. Almost all games, whether well-designed or janky, I will experience moments that I will call 'bullshit' and feel the sudden urge to throw my controller or keyboard into the next time-zone over. I experienced a lot more of those moments with this game. Getting ganked by enemies the camera won't let me see, combo moves not activating, or the classic I-could-have-sworn-I-dodged-that are all happening just a little too often. Sometimes enemies will remain upright instead of ragdolling after death, and on two separate occasions I had to restart the game due to getting softlocked and unable to progress.

Contrast these bugs with the honestly excellent and well-fitting art direction. The new planets, ships, and characters made for this game make for a perfect addition to Star Wars canon. Exploring the new locations gave me the motivation to keep going when the game itself proved to be underwhelming or frustrating. The writing is decent and the cutscenes are well directed. But speaking of the cutscenes...

They are, and will always be, unskippable. They are sometimes a few minutes long and this unfortunately was the nail in the coffin for a New Game Plus playthrough. They occur with a shockingly high frequency to the point where I feel like they wear out their welcome and halt the pace of the game, especially in the early areas when attempting to restart.

I would give Fallen Order a tepid recommendation to the average gamer and a you-should-try-it to any big fans of Star Wars! I like this game and I wanted to love it but unfortunately it falls short of the mark. I haven't played Jedi: Survivor at the time of writing. After playing Fallen Order, I am still interested, but it's definitely not a high priority. 6.5/10.

[h1] STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order - A Galactic Odyssey for True Jedi Enthusiasts [/h1]

"STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order" is a celestial gem tailor-made for Star Wars aficionados, offering a captivating and narratively rich experience set in the expansive Star Wars universe. Developed by Respawn Entertainment, this third-person action-adventure title immerses players in the role of a Jedi Padawan, delivering a galaxy-spanning adventure that explores the aftermath of Order 66 and the struggle for survival against the relentless Empire.

As players embark on a quest to rebuild the Jedi Order, the game presents a narratively driven, single-player journey that mirrors the struggles and challenges faced by a Jedi hero-turned-fugitive. The story unfolds against the backdrop of a galaxy under Imperial rule, featuring iconic locations, weapons, gear, and adversaries that resonate with Star Wars fans. The narrative introduces fresh characters, locations, and mysteries, providing a harmonious blend of the familiar and the new within the Star Wars universe.

The gameplay mechanics of "Fallen Order" masterfully recreate the intensity of Star Wars lightsaber battles seen in the films. Cinematically charged lightsaber and Force combat invite players to strategically approach enemies, leveraging Jedi training to overcome challenges and unearth the secrets that lay before them. This attention to detail ensures an authentic and immersive experience for players seeking the iconic Star Wars lightsaber experience.

The protagonist, Cal Kestis, and his companions add emotional depth to the narrative, drawing players into a compelling story of survival, redemption, and the enduring legacy of the Jedi. Priced at ‚Ç¨39.99, the game offers substantial value for the immersive storytelling and cinematic gameplay it provides. While the current price is reasonable, vigilant shoppers may catch the game on sale, enhancing the overall value proposition.

In conclusion, "STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order" stands as a testament to the power of storytelling within the Star Wars universe. From thrilling lightsaber battles to uncovering the mysteries of a long-extinct civilization, the game caters to both Star Wars devotees and newcomers alike. At ‚Ç¨39.99, it's a solid investment, though keeping an eye out for sales might sweeten the deal even further, making it an absolute must-play for anyone captivated by the epic tales of the Jedi.

Wow. what a game. I put off buying this game for a long time, because I was afraid that it was bad, full of woke nonsense and in general, since it is owned by EA, it would just kill my already fading love for StarWars. Man was i wrong. The story is good and interesting to follow and the main character Cal Kestis aka one of the few members of the fallen Jedi order, who fits the story perfectly. Lightsaber fencing is great and satisfying. Although there are few planets, they are well thought out and beautiful to explore. The map itself isn't as complicated to navigate as some people are making it out to be. The appearance of the Lightsaber can be changed in the game, which is great, by finding new appearances hidden in chests all over the planets. Another thing that can be changed is the appearance of Mantis-the ship (in my opinion, it is not that important), the appearance of the small robot BD, which is good, and the appearance of Poncho that Kastis wears, which in my opinion is pointless, because they are more or less all the same different colors. Planet atmosphere and ingame music is StarWars good. I wouldn't say that maybe this is a Soulslike game, but then again I played it on JediKnight level which is more like Normal mode. Once you learn the moves of the enemy, then it's easy. Also, the more power talents you learn, the stronger you are. Personally, it doesn't bother me because I play for my own pleasure and in my free time that I have. Its a StarWars game worth buying/playing and thats saying a lot today.

Decent but flawed. Run around the galaxy (4 planets) with a handful of forgettable characters you never grow attached to at any point via a meh story as you fight clunky controls, UX issues, bad gameplay ideas from the 90s like punishing you for dying, frustrating save points esp before boss fights, slow loading after respawns, and having to repeat levels over and over again once you unlock a new ability. Watch in awe as you narrrrrrrrowly squeeze through tight space after tight space (seriously how many hours did they spend making that look nice) with your robot pal BD as you, one of the lone remaining jedi after order 66, run away from forgettable villains while you to research the places that will help you talk to the people who tell you where to go to find the clues to find the key that unlocks the thing that helps you save the jedi order hidden away by a jedi hologram for safekeeping. Love timing your button pressing at very specific intervals? This game is for you. Love getting knocked over and very slowly getting up / very slowly trying to heal yourself? This game is for you. Love when EA scatters loot boxes of DIFFERENT COLORED PONCHOS?! THIS GAME IS FOR YOU! (seriously there's like 30) Do you love micromanaging 5 different parts of your lightsaber (the end parts! the middle part! the parts between them! the shading of those parts!) that you can never see except for while youre customizing it? This is the game for you. Do you love when EA reminds you  how special you are because you paid extra by (I kid you not) putting in caps "(PREMIUM CONTENT)" after lots of tiny lightsaber customizations you find in boxes in the game? This is the game for you! Everything you know and love from EA's secret sauce of spending lots to get the rights to familiar IP, then using a familiar gameplay formula, familiar focus on useless "upgrades" and familiar letdown despite a big budget is here. 

Nice things I loved besides the robot: map highlights things in red that are currently blocked to you until they're unblocked then appearing green (annoying to have to replay but nice to call it out), epic John Williams music being used at select times, getting the Empire environmental feel just right, hm yep wish there was more but shrug i played it and ill never play it again

Meh.  A good story line (for Disney levels of good, anyway) and good visuals, but honestly, compared to Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy or the older combat styled Star Wars, it's lacking.  The combat system has no nuance and the puzzles are... more  about finding relevant STUFF in amongst all the visual dazzle and less about actual puzzles.  It got better as Cal developed more skills, but honestly, the character control and combat never felt fluid and powerful like a Jedi-character should.   Worse, even with all the openable short-cuts, it feels like 90% of the game is running back and forth, without any real purpose except to extend the game time.

And don't even get me started on the "take control away from the player without warning" cut-scenes and camera systems.  Blech.

All in all... not even as good as The Force Unleashed as a Star Wars game and that's a pretty low bar for me.  Feels like they tried to build something like JK: JA, but got so caught up in the flashy visuals that they forgot to make the actual gameplay fun.

The light-saber was a nice game mechanic, but was ruined by the fact that you get all lightsaber types in one package, diluting their unique styles into one less than stellar package.  Forcing the player to choose a lightsaber type (dual, staff, single) at each customization station and thereby switching fighting styles (fast, powerful, combos) would have made this game mech shine.

Frankly the best part of the game was how fluid and easily BD-1 meshes with the character.  It felt very seamless and added some interest to the game that didn't feel contrived, similar to the squad-system in the Republic Commando games.  

So... if you like great visuals and playing with your... droid... go for it.  Otherwise... go buy the older games and enjoy way better gameplay for less.

Fighting Stormtroopers is fun thanks to their reactions (dialogue) during the fights.

Fighting against bosses is all the same, you learn when to parry (hold block right before strike. Parry window increases the easier difficulty you play on). And learn when to roll/jump to avoid attacks you can't parry.

And then you attack them during their recovery, normally after they did a red glow attack or when you broke their stamina.

There's not much in customization when it comes to gameplay. You get plenty of lightsaber parts and reskinned outfits to dress up with.

I have a lot to say about this game. 

First of all, the story is good. My only problem was that it ended too quickly. It took so much to get there and the ending was like if we blinked two and everything were gone. Didn't like that.

Secondly, I started to play this game on jedi knight mode (medium) because I felt like stroy mode (easy) wouldn't be fun. I was wrong. The enemies are unreasonably way too strong on medium. I literally died over and over again to the Ninth Sister and my only option was to change the game mode in order to be able to defeat her. I wanted to go back and grind because I felt like I'm not strong enough for that fight, but I couldn't. The game didn't let me :) So my only option was to change the mode to easy. It's incredible how huge is the difference between the two modes. I wonder if medium is this hard, how does the hard mode look like? 
So if you don't want to explore for 28972 hours, I recommend you to not pick Jedi Knight mode. I ended up finishing the game on Story mode, but it wasn't fun because it was too easy. But medium just slowed me down and lowkey made me bored.

Another thing is, that I often felt lost during quests and didn't understand what the game wants from me because it wasn't obvious. The idea of the puzzles in this game was nice, however it was a true challenge for my patience. I often felt frustrated while playing.

I bought this game when it was on discount. I would not buy it on full price or not even on half price. It's not that good. But for a few euros it was worth it.

And still, I'm recommending it. The story is good and I started to like everything in the end, but by then it was too late and it ended way too fast.

At some points this game made me feel like it's not for me. I understand it's supposed to be an exploring, fighting game, but it gets boring at some point if you have to do this for too long. And man let me tell you that this game was able to waste a lot of my time. I wish they added fast travel. When you have to go to a location for 30 mins just to get a few minutes long cutscene and finally feel a little joy that you are finally reached your goal, the game will tell you to go back from where you started. At least they added shortcuts, but even with those, it was still a pain in the ass. Basically I had to run from one place to the other while fighting the way too strong enemies and get some skill points. It was not fun. It lowkey made me drained. 

Not to talk about the bugs. They had more than enough time to fix them. And yet, there is a lot. Sometimes you walk into the ground, sometimes the jump doesn't work nor the force powers. Sometimes you end up being stuck on an eternal loop of death because you end up respawning on a sliding platform and can't turn right fast enough because without jumping  and not doing what you are supposed to do you can not make progress. So much fun /s

I'm sorry, I tried to like this game but it works so hard to be unlikable. 

First of all, it runs poorly. I don't play newer games much so i'm not yet used to this idea that pc games don't run well anymore (again) on high end pcs. I have a laptop with a 3070ti. the game runs at 130 fps on a 2k screen, but has constant drops, the more i went on the more they came. it's not enjoyable on this aspect alone. 

Now, the game. Jedi FO is a mediocre work of entertainment, I won't waste your time on the some many stupid flaws, like the fact that enemies (always) say the wrong thing at the wrong time, for ex you kill one of them and some one says "he killed them all". The real problem is that it's so f boring. You are basically a space ninja and you spend the first 5h killing space squirrels all the time. Then you die and you have to start a big chunk over, because it has Dark Souls' checkpoint system. The story starts really cool, for the first 30 minutes, then it disappears and it's not seen since. I know it's supposed to have cool moments, I just don't want to waste useless hours to get to them, and then I guess the game ends. 
So, I'm sorry, I don't recommend it.

star wars Jedi fallen order is an okay game at its best and below average at worst, the only reason this game has any notoriety is because the star wars brand is attached to it and if it is not for star wars then this would just be a mid AAA game like the rest.

to start of this review i want to write that the combat system in this game is mostly good for the lower difficulties, where my problem arises is in the higher difficulties where your slow movement speed does not match the attack speed of the enemies and you are essentially fighting the game just to move your character. 

compared to games like hollow knight which allow you to move fast enough to keep up with the enemies even in the hardest content Jedi hampers you with it's incessant need for realism that it actively hampers the combat.

the planets in this game vary from interesting to blatant fan service, overall i like the planets in the game but the fact that 2 of the 5 playable areas are lifted from other star wars media makes it feel like fan service and it makes the star wars universe feel very small and unoriginal.

as for the areas themselves they are not your average empty open world with items to collect and stuff to do on each end of the map, most of the maps are closed of pathways that twist and turn sometimes back into themselves which gives it a distinct metroidvania/soullike feel and that i do appreciate.

something i like less is some of the mechanics with which you explore the areas, mainly the slide mechanic and how it just does't work most of the times, the game seems to freak out every time you jump onto one of the slides and it just seems like the mechanic wasn't coded very well or it was an afterthought.

the progression in the game is fine for the most part if you are an explorer or completionist you will find all of the upgrades on your first play-through. and as for the story itself it is just vapid nothing, nothing memorable nothing egregious just nothing.

my biggest critique with Jedi and the reason i am giving a down vote is the fact that it is a AAA game. AAA games have an obsession with making games look as realistic as possible in every aspect possible from the graphics to how slow your character moves and you won't notice how truly detrimental it is to the gaming experience until you play something like Hollow knight.

like i wrote the obsession with realism has already negatively affected the combat system but it ranges to far more stuff like the sections where Cal moves through rubble which are agonizingly slow due to how realistic he moves and there are far more examples that i can't be bothered to mention.

another thing the game does at it's own expense is the graphics, i had to lower down all the settings because the game could barely run otherwise on my mid-line PC, sure it's great to have good graphics in a game but if you can't play the damn game then what is the point.

lastly i would normally analyse the game to see if there is anything beneath the shell of this game but there just isn't, this game isn't a gem of a game that will constantly keep me playing and that will be remembered for years down the line like Hollow knight. no this game is just to be played through once and completely forgotten a far cry from the old AAA games like halo, they don't make em like they used to. 

in short Jedi fallen order is just alright as a game, the fact that it is hamstrung by the fact that it is a AAA game and the fact that it is part of star wars means when you pull it all away you are just left with an mediocre game that will not be remembered a few years down the line. 5.5\10

edit: looking back i made this review when i wasn't in the best of moods so my opinion was a little skewed by the bullshit that was some of the later achievements. still can't be bothered to change what i say in the review but i will recommend it. that being said the game doesn't go above a 7 for me. 6.8\10

STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order shows us that EA has some humanity in them after all. This is basically DARK SOULS made more accessible through difficulty settings and with a much more straight forward story and universe.

You play as Cal Kestis (Who has the likeness and voice of actor Cameron Monaghan), a Jedi in hiding working scrap yards on the planet Bracca. Cal is forced to reveal his powers when his friend is put in danger. The Inquisitorius are hunting down any survivors of Order 66; a galaxy-wide purge in which most Jedi were killed. This is a canon story that shows us Cal's journey of embracing the force and making new allies in his journey to survive his hunters.

Fallen Order gives us a perfect combat system, in every way. This already great system is made even better through various difficulty settings which allow for different parry timings and more unforgiving / forgiving game play depending on what you desire. I'm a big fan of Cameron Monaghan so getting to play him in a game of this stature and high quality was really a treat. BD-1 is a great droid companion and I love how exploration-driven the game is in general.

Fallen Order has very good level design but features a pretty awful map and very little fast travel options which can make 100%-ing the game extremely annoying sometimes, since you have to go back and forth from areas you've already been to multiple times. The graphics are fantastic and the customisation is . . . Serviceable, although it would have been nice to unlock all of the lightsaber colors much earlier in to the game and have alternative outfit options to the ponchos. I understand if one would prefer to create their own character but this is a canonical story-driven game about a specific person with well produced cutscenes so that simply is not what this is if you were hoping for that. I will mention the game can be very glitchy due to the amount of freedom you have, your character will clip through walls and objects often.

Fallen Order is a great STAR WARS experience that left me wanting more. I have completed the game three times now on three different platforms on various difficulties and the game holds up well each time.

[h1]I was never a Star Wars fan, but luckily Fallen Order doesn‚Äôt require you to be one.[/h1]

In 2010 then-president of EA said something about single-player games being ‚Äúfinished‚Äù. Here we are now with EA publishing one of the best and most successful single-player titles of 2019 under its wing.

Fallen Order tells an original story of Cal Kestis, an apprentice jedi hiding on a scrapyard planet called Bracca. Once he gets found by the Empire hunting the jedi and rescued by some strangers, he learns that the goal of his saviours is to restore the fallen Jedi Order. Having really no other place to go to, Cal agrees to help and embarks on a journey full of danger and failures, but also with a lot of soul-searching and new friends. 
The main advantage of the story is its characters. The main cast is not only always there for Cal, either just to chat about everyday things on the ship or to actually listen to his problems and be a genuine support on the journey, but they also impact the events of the game in a not-so direct way. Greez is being hunted by space gangsters which give you a hard time later, Cere [spoiler] is the former master of the main antagonist of the game [/spoiler]. 
Probably the most important character though, is our companion who is always there for us. Although the little droid, BD-1 doesn‚Äôt really say words, he communicates really well with Cal. The ‚Äúdialogues‚Äù between the two form a very cool dynamic and really bond us with the two characters. 
Generally the writing of this game is amazing. The quieter moments with the crew members feel genuine and immersive. It‚Äôs this kind of absorbing story in which instead of saying ‚Äúoh it‚Äôs a trap, nice‚Äù, you say ‚ÄúDAMN IT CAL IT‚ÄôS AN OBVIOUS FU.CKING TRAP DON‚ÄôT GO IN THERE PLEASE‚Äù 
[strike]Also, The Hot Goth Alien Cult Mommy.[/strike] 

In terms of gameplay, I'd say this is a softcore souls-like. An enemy that kills you takes your current xp and sends you back to your last meditation circle. To recover your xp you have to reach him again and hit him. Now it‚Äôs a cool attempt to make you more careful not to die and lose stuff, but it‚Äôs not really working. I was playing on second to hardest difficulty and honestly, I either did not care about the lost xp (it‚Äôs really easy and fast to farm back) or I just went and hit the guy that killed me not even because I wanted my experience back, but because he was just in the way. 
The combat is sweet. You can do parries and precision dodges or just roll around if you don‚Äôt feel comfortable with your timing. Low on health? Call out to BD to toss you a stim right into your hand. Fighting with your lightsaber lets you do a variety of moves such as throwing it at enemies or literally teleporting to them to close in on them faster. Your fancy glowstick also has a two-sided mode ‚Äì it exceeds at fighting groups of enemies. It also has an attack in which you dual wield the glowstick and many players wish that this was a permanent mode. 
You can also use [i]The Force[/i]. In combat you can slow enemies down, pull them towards you or (my personal favorite, classic move) yeet them off a cliff (as a side note - many games have cocky enemies talking sh.it, and then get their asses floored seconds later, but hearing a clone yell ‚ÄúYOU ARE NOTHING COMPARED TO ME, JEDI" while falling down the abyss after getting yeeted off a cliff face is something else). Powers have many versions; a charged push can throw away multiple clones or even a big troll-thing. 
The Force is also used to solve many different environmental puzzles either to progress or to unlock a secret. Outside of combat you explore several places in the galaxy. You move around by climbing some plants, wall running, swinging on some vines, etc. Cal runs and jumps (man, hopping around was just so cool to me) around in a very intuitive way and it‚Äôs all incredibly animated. What I must say though, is that swimming overall feels very off and has some really bizarre animations. 
At first visit to some places the exploration feels really natural and immersive. I hardly ever got lost anywhere, even in the more open areas, and if I was ever in trouble, I could always use the map to see unexplored paths I had left. 
Unfortunately, backtracking to certain locations to get the leftover secrets and chests is an absolute disaster. Dathomir is a great planet, it‚Äôs a challenging, beautiful wasteland with cool lore and story. Going back to it and trying to reach the swamp area again is just a sh.itshow though. It‚Äôs so unnecessarily convoluted. It even seems like in this one place, past the bridge in the village should be an opening to just let you through. Instead, it‚Äôs blocked by this little wooden wall that you can‚Äôt jump over, so you must go around the whole location. It‚Äôs a serious flaw that is not only easily fixable, but just feels like somebody just forgot to put something there. 

The game looks very good and has some amazing landscapes. It also has a photo mode to play with. Regarding animation ‚Äì most of them are amazing and very creative (BD tossing you heals is just so good). Besides swimming, the only complaint would be the lack of finisher animations. Some foes only have one and others get repetitive after a while. 

Now the sound design ‚Äì maaan, this is [b]THE[/b] science fiction game. The space crafts flying around, blasters shooting, things exploding, funny glowsticks swinging around. They‚Äôre not only high quality and very characteristic, but they all just have the [b]oompff[/b] you know? The soundtrack amazingly complements the vibe. It‚Äôs very movie-like. What blew my mind is that if you listen to the OST album of this game on Spotify PC, it replaces the player bar with an extending lightsaber. How cool is that? 

I didn‚Äôt really encounter any technical issues, but what‚Äôs funny is that there is an infinite jumping glitch in the game that they did not patch. It‚Äôs not really that useful though, because you skip many invisible triggers while using it and it screws up the collision and map loading. It is funi. 

I was never a Star Wars fan. This is probably my first encounter with this franchise since Republic Commando on Xbox Classic or randomly seeing The Clone Wars on TV. Nothing wrong with the universe itself, I just never really got hooked by it. 
I was never a Star Wars fan, but luckily Fallen Order doesn‚Äôt require you to be one. It‚Äôs a wonderful adventure by itself. Maybe even a good starting point into the SW universe for a newbie like myself ‚Äì and don‚Äôt get me wrong, I‚Äôm in no position to say that this is a good piece of the Star Wars media not knowing the rest of it. Nonetheless, from my experience with it, I can say that it‚Äôs enough to get you hooked on.

As a Star Wars fan who hasn't played Dark Souls (that this apparently rips off), loves exploration games like Uncharted and Tomb Raider (that this half-way emulates), and doesn't totally hate the backtracking progression this has at its core, this was actually a fun one to play.

-The combat system is satisfyingly fleshed out and reasonably competent.
-Encountered minimal performance issues in the form of often brutal cutscene stuttering but rare gameplay stutter.
-Glitches like falling off weird geometry were present but thankfully still not too common.
-The enemy AI is laughably bad making the game ultimately too easy even on hardest difficulty.
-The looting aspect is dominated with cosmetic unlocks so exploring feels disappointing and unrewarding.
-The puzzles are okay ranging from 1 brain cell easy to getting stuck at most a few minutes but the droid puzzle hints are offered way too quickly, often before I even realized I was in a puzzle area.
-The story is okay with a decent sprinkling of cool Star Wars lore and has several epic moments.
-The length of the game is short with no exploration and average if you try to hit every corner.

Bottom line: I'd say it's worth your time and worth your money if it's on sale.

The main story has only 10-12 hours of playtime, and I wasn't exactly rushing. While the visuals are fine, it could hardly be classified as a AA title, let alone a AAA title. Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order strikes a balance between gripping narrative and exhilarating gameplay, offering an immersive journey in the Star Wars universe. The protagonist, Cal Kestis, evolves from a padawan survivor to a formidable Jedi, and his story is complemented by a well-crafted ensemble of characters. The lightsaber combat is a highlight, requiring skill and strategy, while force powers add depth to exploration and combat. The game's level design encourages exploration and discovery, mirroring the essence of classic action-adventure titles. Despite occasional technical hiccups, Fallen Order stands out as a strong and respectful addition to the Star Wars gaming legacy.

The main selling point, it's good Star Wars content in terms of lore, visuals, and story. Unfortunately, the game itself is pretty shallow. While you can see the inspiration they drew from Metroid Prime, Dark Souls, and a bit of Tomb Raider, it feels a bit shallow in its own implementation. If it weren't for the Star Wars charm, I probably would not recommend it. But, the environments, story, and characters elevate this, borderline mediocre, game into a fun experience... If you can get it on sale (I bought it for 3,99‚Ç¨).

Overall, it's a good game, and if you have the time to binge the story you'll probably have a great time. Having played the game in chunks, the gameplay feels a little flat. The progression tree is mostly passive upgrades and a few basic combos. The combat itself - up to the point I played - only consisted of light/heavy attacks with 2 lightsaber stances and dodging. The lightsaber stance being an optional unlock early on, but otherwise wouldn't unlock until much later in the story. You also unlock the basic force powers such as push and pull, as well as a unique [spoiler] slow time [/spoiler] power, but they're more important for map progression and quickly disposing of fodder enemies. 

Combat is the basic souls-like experience, dodge and hit in the opening. There's not that much variety in their attacks. You parry melee users to break their balance and then attack them, monsters and mechanical bosses are just dodge/rush loops, and ranged enemies are trivially dealt with by spamming the parry button to deflect blasters. The only exception is the shock trooper, which fires rockets that you can deflect with a force push. 

World navigation feels good for the most part. The locations look amazing, and if you've ever played a metroidvania you'll feel right at home. The routes are pretty linear with some secrets here and there, and you'll regularly unlock shortcuts that open up the map. You also go into multiple Jedi "tombs" that require a bit of basic puzzling to get through. The puzzles, so far, haven't been super complicated, but they also aren't trivialized by glowing navigational markers. The game does offer your pet droid to give clues when you're stuck.

Lastly, the game has plenty of Quick Time Events (QTE's) spread throughout, but the developers have been so kind to offer players the choice to skip them altogether if they find those annoying. Which I appreciated a lot.

As a big fan of the star wars universe I loved this game a lot. It included everything I expected from a Star Wars game. I was pleasantly surprised by EA's attention to detail and commitment to the Star Wars universe, marking a positive shift from their other game titles. The beginning may seem slow for some, but as the story unfolds, any initial boredom is quickly overshadowed.

Overall 4/5 stars. 
This is a very well done game with lots to explore and collect. The campaign is not difficult to complete and there are some very cool boss fights. The graphics are beautiful and the different themes for different planets means the scenery is not getting stale as you play through the campaign. 
Light saber customization is complex with lots of choices, however customization for things like Cal, BD-1, and the mantis are lacking (you can only change the paint colors). 
However, it's difficult to acquire all the data scans for completion. Many of them are bugged to where you have to find the nearest meditation spot and return to where the scan would be (if you know where it is that is). It's also helpful to note that BD-1 data scans will not be available if you've aggro'd any creatures or enemies in the area. 
Fun game overall, but if you're going for completion expect to look up a lot of guides, there are many hidden force echo locations that you will miss on your play through.

"Do you like Star Wars? Do you like jumping and swinging from a vine, dropping onto a muddy slope and sliding down at breakneck speed -- sliding until you hit a wall where you leap and cling to it, before using the Force to slow a fan blade so you can leap through to the next room? All in two seconds?

Well, have I a game for you:

Star Wars: Red-headed Parkour Guy

In Star Wars Red-headed Parkour Guy, you play a kid from that one television show who deals with his abandonment issues by slaughtering literally hundreds of people in a quest to find out the names of everyone who can also parkour.

Along the way, he deals with Spooky Magic, betrayal, characters from television shows that you may or may not know about, betrayal, and Goth Girl love interest.

Of course by the end he's grown as a person and stepped into adulthood.

All of the above is true, but it also includes amazingly charming big-eyed creatures, an adorable tiny droid superior to everyone else in every way, grumpy fat aliens, Jedi Moral Shenanigans(tm), every lightsaber color under the rainbow, and of course, stormtroopers to abuse in a number of telekinetic and parkouresque ways.

If you didn't know what this game was about, thrill to an intensely modeled lightsaber construction system that is EXACTLY THE SAME as the one you can do at Galaxy's Edge, the new Disney Theme park.

Yep, you can build the same lightsaber as the one at the real life theme park.

So is this game good?

Yes! Despite all the shades of corporate blandness compressed onto this delightful little game, it delivers an After-School Special style story in a fun gymnastics playground of parkour leaping, swinging, sliding, and climbing.

Whether you like Star Wars or not, there's a fun game all around the joy of movement, and there's a nice little story about a lost Jedi padawan seeking a way to survive in a hostile universe.

Star: Wars: Jedi: Fallen: Order is worth playing, and a fun little game that will leave you both frustrated and satisfied in exactly the correct proportions."
it has lag at times but it is super fun

Many has applauded this as the first proper singe-player Star Wars game in many years, and in a way they are right. On the presentation/athmosphere side of things it's great: it looks right, the story is good, the voice acting is good, it does feel like an authentic Star Wars experience through and through. Unfortunately it's all dragged down by very poor gameplay.

The gameplay consists of 3 main parts:

1, Puzzles: the puzzles are generally OK. Not inspired but servicable. My only complaint here is that 0.2 seconds in to a lot of the more complex ones the game starts incessantly bugging you with "Do you need a hint?" prompts.

2, Combat: the combat is just... well, sh*t. Unresponsive/laggy controls, wonky hitboxes and uncancellable, long attack animations are unfortunately par for the course for these types of games, but what really takes the cake here is the camera. I don't think I've seen camera controls this bad since the early 2000's. There's a lock onto enemy option (which doesn't always work, and you usually fight multiple enemies anyway,) but even if you manage to turn it onto someone, be prepared to be looking at a wall while a stormtrooper is giving you the world's most thorough prostate exam with an electric baton a lot.

3, Exploration/traversal: there are many smaller problems here that may not be game-ruining on their own, but added together makes this the worst part of the title.
- a lot of the game areas are just way too dark. And by way too dark I mean pitch black, even when using my lightsaber as illumination as the game suggests. I don't know who thought this was a good idea, it would be obnoxious even in a horror game. I can't count how many times I walked off a ledge I just didn't see was there. And it's not a problem with my gamma settings, because other areas look just fine.
- there's a lot of Prince of Persia style jumping sections, but whether Cal grabs onto a ledge or just stoically falls to his death seems to be decided by a coin flip.
- the level design is just some of the worst I've ever seen. It uses verticality the worst way possible, with no clearly delineated levels, and overlapping pathways (ie. multiple corridors passing over/under each other.) Combine this with a map that they for some reason decided to make translucent, so you will always also see the parts of the level behind/above/under the one you're currently looking at, and it makes for some of the most frustrating navigation in any game ever. Especially on the largest planet with the most complex map, I often felt like my eyes were bleeding trying to figure out where I am, where I need to go, and especially, how to get there.
- the rewards for exploring are not that great. It's not really an open world game, but there are "secrets" hidden around the levels. These are: meaningful upgrades (least common,) lore bits with some XP attached (more common,) and useless cosmetics (most common.) The last one is a perfect example of less is sometimes more: if they were just removed from the game and not replaced with anything, it would already improve the experience. It's just incredibly annoying when you spend minutes trying to get onto an especially hard-to-reach platform, only to be "rewarded" with your 147th poncho material.
- the loading screens are atrocious long, and pretty frequent too. Sure, they are disguised as elevators, and crawling through crevices in the wall, but that doesn't really make it any better. God forbid you step into an elevator by accident when you try to dodge in a fight, because then you'll have to wait a whole minute to go up and then back down again.

If you're looking for a casual romp through space as a powerful Jedi, this isn't it.  Pretty much every thing is significantly more powerful than you are, I've never felt more useless.  I'm sure it's a great game if you're into Dark Souls like games, but I couldn't get past the first planet.

Take if for what it is: 4.5/5
OK so yeah, I know the new one is coming out tomorrow, but screw it I am late to the party. I just finished this one (yes again the old one that everyone has played except me‚Ä¶). It is freaking awesome. An amazing experience that I really enjoyed.
The game starts off with a nice intro and a story that pulls you in quickly. I do wish there was a bit more on some characters, but they were keeping it short and focused. It is still probably one of the best Star Wars stories since the Empire Strikes back. Again, my opinion here, I like all of the old ones and even prequel, but screw Disney‚Äôs new 7-9 which I just did not like, and the TV shows are meh. Just my opinions. Alright, enough of going off topic and those are for another day. This story is awesome, and I highly recommend just playing through Story mode if you just want to enjoy a good Star Wars story.
The gameplay and graphics are also good for how old this game is. The controls work well too, and you feel powerful, but not too powerful. I noticed it has a great balance in difficulty with multiple modes. The gameplay is a bit like Souls games, but not terribly slow/excruciating like the souls‚Äô games out there. I enjoy Souls games here and there, but this game has much faster paced action which is more to my liking.
The only thing I knock it a little on is, traveling through the maps can get cumbersome. There might be a lot of back tracking and I just wish you could at least fast travel. Also, the platforming is not bad, but could use a bit of tweaking to make it more fluid. These issues are not too bad, but really did feel a little annoying sometimes. If they fix/tweak these in the sequel it would literally be perfect!
I cannot wait for the sequel to come out. Let‚Äôs just say it is one game I am pre-ordering for sure. Overall, enjoy this great game for the time being.

https://rootreviews.brutalroot.com/2023/04/star-wars-jedi-fallen-order-review.html

This review was tricky, because there are many equally good and bad things in this game.

[h1]The bad[/h1]

Let's beging with the bad, because that's how I started experiencing it. To make it short, this game has all the defects that an AAA game shouldn't have: it suffers from bad writing, a bad PC port despite at best decent graphics (if you don't look at the wookies), numerous small bugs... The promotion of a "Souls-like" game is basically just for the save system (if you die, your enemies come back... Alright.). And finally, just like every time with Star Wars, the universe is a huge, fantastic place, filled with an incredible number of different species... And we're still ending up playing as a young white dude, whose major exotic feature is to have red hair. He also has as many layers as a crepe, and could have been written by a 8 years old.

The Deluxe Edition isn't worth the price, too - a few skins for your poncho (btw, why did we have to have so many plastic ponchos, and not a single Jedi robe? I understand they went for a "Good, Bad, Ugly in space" aesthetic, but why the plastic?), your pet droid who has feelings, and your ship, the design of which is otherwise completely forgivable. Plus some dev commentaries, but who bothers with that? [spoiler]The only thing I feel worthy of this edition is to be able to choose lightsaber colors from the beginning - but it also detracts from unlocking that at the end, so I would still suggest not to buy it.[/spoiler]

I'll take a bit of time to discuss the technical side of things.
- To begin with, don't bother trying top playi it on a Steam Deck - the EA launcher basically prevented it altogether for me (although apparently it does work for some people). Too bad, I had basically bought the game because I had read that it was the Deck was a great format to enjoy it (which it would have been, IF IT HAD RAN)
- Even on my Windows desktop with an RTX 4070, the game suffered from heavy stutters and extremely annoying screen flickering. The heavy stutter almost made me abandon the game - it's not a very hard game, but it is timing critical, and that stutter made me lose at very annoying times. Anyway, the flickering was apparently due to a bug with the high-resolution shadows; switching the shadows to medium fixed it. And the stutter was due to a very stupid thing: the Bluetooth controller (it's not a third party, it's an actual Xbox controller so the blame isn't even there). I just had to plug it in, and the game worked mostly flawlessly until the end.

[h1]And then again...[/h1]

And yet, despite starting by hate-playing it, after episodes of exhaustion, anger and blind rage, I ended up enjoying the game quite a lot. The gameplay is nice and tight (once the stutters have been fixed anyway), the level design is really good, going back and forth feels really great. What it really is isn't a Souls-like game, but a 3D Metroivania in the Star Wars universe, which is actually great.

As a guy with completionist tendencies, the amount of stuff to find and unlock in the game is just right to aim at finding it all without getting exhausted on it. And most of the stuff you'll find is cosmetic, and how often does cosmetic content is only in an in-game chest rather than a lootbox or a DLC, nowadays?

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Despite this game suffering from defects a game developed by Respawn and produced by EA should NOT have, including bad writing and very annoying bugs even on higher-end configs, it was all in all still a very enjoyable experience. Not at full price but for 5‚Ç¨‚Äé, it's 40 hours of fun: go for it.

Title: "Jedi: Fallen Order - A Stellar Journey into the Force"

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ

"Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order" delivers an immersive and captivating gaming experience that successfully combines the rich lore of the Star Wars universe with engaging gameplay and a compelling narrative. Developed by Respawn Entertainment and published by Electronic Arts, this action-adventure title brings the Force to life in a way that will resonate with both Star Wars enthusiasts and gamers alike.

One of the standout features of Jedi: Fallen Order is its meticulously crafted storyline. Set in the aftermath of Order 66, players assume the role of Cal Kestis, a young Jedi Padawan who narrowly escaped the purge. Cal's journey is a gripping tale of survival and self-discovery, interwoven with familiar Star Wars elements and characters. The narrative is masterfully paced, keeping players invested in Cal's quest to rebuild the Jedi Order while uncovering the secrets of the Force.

Visually, the game is a spectacle to behold. From the bustling streets of alien planets to the eerie atmospheres of ancient tombs, each environment is meticulously designed, showcasing the attention to detail put into bringing the Star Wars universe to life. Character models are well-crafted, and the animations are fluid, contributing to a visually stunning and authentic Star Wars experience.

Gameplay is a seamless blend of exploration, puzzle-solving, and lightsaber combat. The lightsaber combat, in particular, stands out as a highlight. The system feels weighty and impactful, requiring players to master parries, dodges, and precise strikes. As players progress, they unlock new Force abilities that not only enhance combat but also open up new areas for exploration, adding a layer of depth to the gameplay.

The level design is another commendable aspect of Jedi: Fallen Order. The worlds are interconnected, promoting exploration and rewarding players for revisiting areas with newfound abilities. The Metroidvania-style progression adds replayability, as players are encouraged to return to previous locations to unlock hidden secrets and areas.

The game also strikes a balance between challenging combat scenarios and a sense of empowerment as players grow stronger in the Force. The difficulty curve is well-calibrated, ensuring that each encounter feels both challenging and rewarding.

While Jedi: Fallen Order is a triumph in many respects, it's not without a few minor flaws. Some occasional technical hiccups and texture pop-ins can momentarily disrupt the immersion. However, these issues are overshadowed by the overall polish and quality of the game.

In conclusion, Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order is a must-play for fans of the franchise and action-adventure enthusiasts alike. Respawn Entertainment has delivered a memorable gaming experience that successfully captures the essence of Star Wars while introducing a fresh and engaging story. Whether you're a Jedi Knight or a Padawan, this game offers an unforgettable journey into the heart of the Force. May the Force be with you!

It's a good lookin' game with a really boring story that leads to nowhere. An annoying parkour/puzzle solving simulator with shitty movement, many bugs, unfair AI in the world of Star Wars. I recommend it only for HC fans with some Xanax and booze...

So playing this again after couple of years after my first playthrough on ps4 I can pretty much say the overall experience on pc regardless several technical hickups is vastly superior.

The main component of this game is story, I didn't really care about it earlier and just for the record I still think Cal as main protagonist is ugly and at times borderline unbearable prick but the story is well constructed self contained piece of extended universe with no extremely interesting characters but they all fit in nicely and probably the only one that has a potential for emotional connection of all characters is Merrin.

Second center piece of this game is gameplay. I wouldn't really call it souls-like because even though it shares some concepts (limited stimpacks, leveling at meditation points and respawn of enemies on rest) playing as a jedi is still a power fantasy, not as huge as playing space marine in w40k but still you aren't the underdog here 95% of the time. Combat is smooth with good flow and if I had to compare it to something it would most likely be the batman arkham series.

4 years after the release it still looks great and even though there are no breathtaking vistas the graphical fidelity is there and most important thing is it stays true to star wars visuals. Combine it with typically great music and traditional sound design and you get the atmosphere you would exprect from star wars.

On the other note, there are places with fps drops (not too dramatic that it would feel like stuttering but notable and a bit annoying at times) and sometimes you will see some weird collisions and hitboxes mostly when fighting enemy bigger than humanoid. And if this is still a thing for some people yes you will have to install ea app to play this.

Overall Fallen Order is very solid single player experience with best story since Jedi Academy and I sure as hell will be looking for some sale on Jedi Survivor.

I enjoyed this game up until my current boss battle with Gorgara.  I've attempted this battle many times and for a good 50% of the attempts I have died due to the controller stuttering and Cal freezing.  The result in the best case is often a missed opportunity for a good hit, but more often than not it results in a huge blow being dealt by Gorgana.

I've seen people complaining about this controller stuttering issue for a while.  Fix it already.  This is (almost) the most I've ever been annoyed with a bug in decades of gaming.

This game is trying to be the Dark Souls of Star Wars franchise without understanding what made Dark Souls good.

The cinematics, graphics, and soundtrack are beautiful. The combat is tolerable, but the perk trees are the same annoying shit we've seen in all single player games in the past 15 years. And that's about it.

The rest of this is just me ranting about the story and Star Wars in general, so to keep it short- avoid this game even when it's on sale. Just watch the cinematics on YT or read a plot summary. I regret spending those 5 euros that I will never get back, because that's how much I spent on this steaming pile of moose shit when it was on sale.

3/10, I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME.

The plot is terrible. [spoiler] So, you're telling me that we are chasing after a holocron with possibly outdated locations of Force-sensitive children so that we can, what, DECIDE TO DESTROY IT IN THE VERY LAST SCENE? Like, what the fuck was the point of everything? [/spoiler]

Cal keeps remembering THAT HE CAN DO SHIT WITH THE FORCE JUST AS HE IS ABOUT TO FUCKING DIE. It's the greatest plot armor I think I've seen in any fucking game. If you die, it's by your own fault, but this dude always either gains a new ability, or somehow manages to survive by sheer coincidence, or by external help. Cal is the world's most useless jedi, because nothing in this would have happened if other people weren't nudging him in the right direction.

And what's this obsession of the SW writers with the period between Clone Wars and SW4? Why are we continuously exploring how the rebellion started? Why should I care? I've seen enough fucking material from this period that frankly, I don't understand how it's even possible that they keep fitting new rebellion and new jedi order founders into the story. Why can't we get a KOTOR 1/2 remake? Why can't we get something from before the movies? What if I want something from the First Order period? Or hell, even from the New Republic period, however short that was? WHY ARE WE STILL OBSESSED WITH THE REBELLION? Star Wars writers just need to let go of this period, because it's the sole reason why SW is losing fans- we are tired of the Rebellion, and we want some new material in other eras. But the writers for SW are so incompetent at their job that they can't even come up with something new.

It's the same shit you've seen in Star Wars many times. A fallen jedi overcoming his past to fight the Empire, trying to look for some McGuffin, and destroying it at the end to prevent it from falling into Empire's hands. That's basically the plot of Star Wars 7. And I couldn't fucking care less. 

TL;DR: The game in three words? "Unoriginal and uninspired."

This game pretends to be a triple-A star wars game, and while it is certainly pretty and cinematic it has very little to do with what the Jedi actually do in the movies and shows - 50% of it is (bad) 3d platforming, with a 20% of "what the fuck am I doing in this room how do I get out", 15% bullshit (https://youtu.be/g6qbYdMjAz4, this took like 20 minutes because to interact with objects you need surgical precision), 10% combat (a minority of which is against humanoids which is actually fun), and 5% story.

A shame because I quite enjoy the cinematic combat system, and I think a game focused more on that could be exceptional.

Exploration is also lackluster, while the worlds do feel tight the actual exploration rewards are primarily skins.
There's a skill tree which is... Ok, in a "the Witcher 1 had a deeper progression system than this game" kinda way.

[h1]STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order‚Ñ¢, the mixture of two things I'm [i]great[/i] at: platforming and parrying.[/h1]

This is game was such an adventure from start to finish. I think it took me ~1 year to actually finish the game (y'know, juggling this, other games, and my personal life). I even had my laptop reformatted and lost all my progress worth of ~30 hours of gameplay (halfway through the story). Good thing that save files were available to download online but that took me another ~10 more hours to go back and retrieve all of the chests and secrets I've collected in my first playthrough. And, believe, it did not feel tedious at all because the game itself was such a fun experience that it didn't even feel like a redo.

[h3]Graphics and Animation[/h3]
If I were to be honest, it did not have the [i]perfect[/i] animation for a game made in 2019 but that doesn't mean it was not beautiful. Sometimes BD's animation for health stims would happen but the healing would not register‚ÄîI'd think it's just part of the souls-like experience lol. Sometimes the cut scenes would bug out and the voice audio would be delayed for 1~2 seconds. It was funny to watch. However, what I did love were Cal's poncho/outfit getting wet after getting out of the water and the way light would reflect against the wet clothes, and the cut scenes before and after boss fights. It got me hooked into learning more about the story, but more on that later.

[h3]Level and Area Designs[/h3]
As I've said in the title (sarcastically), I'm soooo amazing in platforming that it's what killed me more than the combats and majority of the areas are focused on that. I'd have to blame the scenery for distracting me and causing me to fall to my demise. Kidding aside, each planet triggered my desire to explore for [i]*in an excited voice*[/i] SECRETS. Zeffo was both a dream and a nightmare for completionists because: 1) it was such a huge map; and 2) well, it was such a huge map. It was like going to four different places in one map and no, I have no complaints. The transition from the aesthetics of what I assume to be was the Stormtrooper's base to actual tombs, which were two in Zeffo, did not clash at all. Everything, from landscaping to scenery felt perfectly placed and I'm here for all of it! The other maps were just as pleasing to look at. [spoiler]There's a total of six planets (in order of appearance): Bogano, Dathomir, Zeffo, Kashyyyk, Ilum, and Nur (not explorable after the final boss)[/spoiler], and me, being the completionist that I am, I looked into every nook and cranny of what I can explore on each map before actually progressing the story, hence me getting all the upgrades and stim canisters before fighting [spoiler]Malicos[/spoiler].

[h3]Characters[/h3]
Yeah, Cal may be handsome with all his scars and slipped back hair but we all know who's the real star of this game: BD-1. All the emotions can be seen on its two WALL-E-like eyes and beeping sounds. Dare tell me straight to my face that BD-1 is not adorable, I would curse you with all of Merrin's witchcraft. BD-1's lore made me feel more emotional damage than Cal and Cere's backstory and I don't even know if that's a good thing or a bad thing. Regardless, the dynamics/personalities of the characters did not feel forced. But what felt forced was Merrin [spoiler]suddenly, or well slowly, becoming Cal's romantic interest[/spoiler], but then again, who am I to complain? I'm definitely [spoiler]shipping it hard.[/spoiler]

[h3]Story[/h3]
I can't really say much about the story because my playthrough of this was not continuous. Sometimes I would play every other weekend or once a month and I would have to recall of where I left off. I still have some bits of pieces of lore scattered all over the maps (the echo things that give you expi/skill points) and I'll try to go back to get them all. But, on my playthrough alone, with the backstories of Cere, Trilla, and Cal, I'd say it was okay. Not that great but not sh*t as well. I did like the progression of each act/chapter though, the going back and forth to each planet, making it more satisfying when you explore with better abilities and skills.

[h3]Soundtrack and Sound Design[/h3]
There's not much to expect. It's the typical STAR WARS vibe. But I kid you not that sometimes the bgm for fights would creep me out whenever it would cue in but not a single enemy was in sight and it happened while I was at Dathomir with all the undead b*tches.

[h3]Overall[/h3]
I'm just so happy that I decided to buy this game a year ago. Even got the Deluxe Edition and I did not regret it a single bit despite it just being additional cosmetics that I never really used lol (oh and the bonus content/artbook that I only looked at once, I think). Sometimes the boss and mini boss fights would end up being funny because it was so easy to cheese it and some can even be just tossed over to the ledge but nonetheless, I really had fun, to the point that this game/franchise is making it into my favorite games list. I just hope that the next installment, STAR WARS Jedi: Survivor‚Ñ¢, is just as good, if not better.

Jedi: Fallen Order - A Stellar Star Wars Adventure

Jedi: Fallen Order is a Star Wars game that had fans eagerly waiting, and it doesn't disappoint. As a long-time Star Wars enthusiast, I was thrilled to dive into this immersive experience, and it captures the essence of the galaxy far, far away beautifully. Here's my in-depth review of this epic journey through the Force.

Gameplay:
The gameplay in Jedi: Fallen Order feels like a seamless blend of the Star Wars universe and modern gaming. You assume the role of Cal Kestis, a young Jedi survivor of Order 66, and your journey is filled with lightsaber combat, Force powers, and exploration. The lightsaber duels are fluid and satisfying, and the progression system allows you to customize your character's abilities and combat style. The platforming and puzzle-solving elements, combined with Metroidvania-style level design, provide a refreshing change of pace, making the game more than just a hack-and-slash adventure.

Story and Lore:
The game's narrative is a compelling and authentic addition to the Star Wars canon. It delves into the aftermath of Order 66, the rise of the Empire, and the plight of the Jedi survivors. Cal Kestis is a relatable and well-developed protagonist, and the supporting characters add depth to the story. The attention to detail in terms of Star Wars lore, with references to familiar locations and characters, adds to the immersion and makes you feel like an integral part of the universe.

Graphics and Sound:
The visuals in Jedi: Fallen Order are stunning. From the intricate designs of various planets to the lifelike character models, the game captures the essence of Star Wars beautifully. The atmospheric and environmental effects are top-notch, and the lighting and particle effects enhance the overall experience. The sound design is equally exceptional, with John Williams' iconic score and authentic Star Wars sound effects immersing you in the galaxy.

Difficulty and Challenge:
The game offers different difficulty settings to cater to various player preferences. If you're a fan of challenging combat and tactical gameplay, the higher difficulties will provide a satisfying experience. The learning curve is well-balanced, allowing both newcomers and experienced gamers to enjoy the game at their own pace.

Replay Value:
While the main story is engaging and offers a fulfilling experience, Jedi: Fallen Order also encourages exploration and completionism. The incentive to revisit planets, find hidden secrets, and unlock new abilities can keep you engaged even after the main story is complete.

Bugs and Optimization:
During my playthrough, I encountered a few minor bugs and optimization issues. However, these were infrequent and didn't significantly hinder my enjoyment of the game. It's worth noting that some of these issues may have been addressed in post-launch updates.

In conclusion, Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order is a fantastic addition to the Star Wars gaming legacy. It captures the spirit of the franchise, offering thrilling lightsaber combat, an engaging story, and the opportunity to explore iconic Star Wars locations. If you're a Star Wars fan or just a lover of action-adventure games, this title is a must-play. May the Force be with you on this epic journey through the galaxy!
