I really wish Steam had a star or points system, rather than a Recommend: Yes or No, because there are so many good things about this game but also so many things that downright pissed me off. I really want to give this game a solid 8/10, but just can't because my gameplay experience kept getting ruined and interrupted by stupid bullshit and clunky mechanics. Is this a good game? Yes. Is the story good? Yes. Are the characters good? Yes. Are the graphics good? Yes. Is it fun? Yes. All those questions I answered yes too but I can't help but mention some of the sheer BS in this game that really ruins the experience. At many times during my time the controls felt unresponsive, I would double press B to dodge and Cal just wouldn't. I'd hold LB to block and he'd just stand there. Sometimes, during combat, I'd press UP on the D-pad to get a Stim from BD, Cal would then say his little line like "BD, Stim", and then the action would just cancel itself. The maps in this game are excellent and so fun to explore, but are just ruined by the sheer overuse of animals and wildlife that jump out of the ground and annoy you. Some of those big spider and slug things were more difficult than the final boss fight. Additionally, some of the obstacles and parkour was so picky that if you didn't jump or drop at the exact damn centimetre, you'd fall off. Just little things like this really interrupt the game for me. Respawn have got to remember, we're essentially playing a movie, so it's kind of gotta feel like one.

I'm going to say "Recommend" for this game because I believe it is an inherently good game, but the experience is heavily hindered and interrupted by little bits of BS and annoyances which I hope they iron out in Jedi: Survivor. I'd give this game 6/10.

At the moment i really love this game, the cinematic, graphic, ambientations everything is amazing 10/10.

Although a LOT potential - marvelous graphics, great story - the game is a disappointment. 
Reason are CONTROLS. They are so frustrating, even random, that you cannot make a tactic out of it.
For example - dodge. It comes in 2 forms ON THE SAME BUTTON: 
1) Step in direction to avoid the attack (totally useless against bigger enemies with large swing)
2) Roll, if you press it twice quick. 
However, YOU DON'T KNOW THE DIRECTION WHERE YOU WILL ROLL. The reason is - computer executes step, but that step can EASILY go in one direction, totally different where you pressed. For example, if you press dodge + right, character can dodge LEFT, because the dodge makes more sense to do it to LEFT. However, when it comes to ROLL, he will also roll to the left, most of the times ending on the hand/weapon of opponent. 
With inability to predict what your character will do, EVERY fight becomes frustrating, even with zergs. 

What EA should've done is take OLD Jedi games - Kyle Katran, for example - and apply THESE commands. Or, better yet, play Witcher 2 or 3 and use that controls. There, you have full control over your character, as you are himself. 

Also - did I mention that there is no KEY BINDING SCHEME? You don't have any graphics for keys if you use keyboard - only controller. When game launches, it says that "it is best experience on controller" and turns the key bindings graphics to controller. So when starting, I was thinking that I cannot run the game because I don't have controller. And when I wanted to check the controls - you can do it only if you go to the "Edit keybinding" screen. And only there, you can scroll and scroll, instead of choosing in the beginning - controller or keyboard (with possible switch later, if you need) and you have graphics for your choice. As any other game has. 

Pity, as whole thing looked marvelous and graphic and story is absolutely stunning. I would give between (thumbs up and down), but since it allows only one option, I stick at down, because of all frustration I had using controls.

[h1]Graphically beautiful and emotionally uncompelling[/h1]

Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order seemingly had all the ingredients that would make a great game ‚Äì franchise with immense following, already mature and evolved lore developed through past games and other media in the franchise, and a promising development team.

Unfortunately, although the game was graphically breath-taking more often than not, shallow and one-dimensional characters managed to completely obliterate my will to emotionally invest myself to the story. This comes as a great shame honestly, as there were points in the game that managed to scratch that itch for second ‚Äì just to further inflame the rash. I gave myself some thought about this, as it is seemingly unfair for me to expect the intrigue and level of detail I once enjoyed as a kid playing KOTR or past instalments of the Jedi series ‚Äì just to come to the very same conclusion. It seems that whoever was writing the script of this instalment seemingly forgot that Star Wars has always been a glorified space version of your regular soap opera, filled with intrigue and sometimes dumb choices ‚Äì and I say this with no grudge whatsoever, as that is one of the main reasons, I actually liked Star Wars franchise in the first place (as long as it does not cross the line of absolute stupidity). So, for those seeking a gripping story ‚Äì I‚Äôd recommend looking elsewhere.

Now, about the gameplay ‚Äì the only potential saviour of this game. While transversal is quite alright, the same cannot be said for souls-like gimmick of a combat system. This mainly stems from the fact that although the beforementioned combat system looked good on paper, its implementation was utterly catastrophic. Your lightSABRE feels more like a lightSTICK. Parry elements are godawfully clunky and random, whilst force powers are barely useful ‚Äì and don‚Äôt get me started on lightsabre-on-lightsabre combat that is nothing but a button mashing contest. Even games like Jedi Academy (that was published 20 years ago‚Ä¶ JESUS I‚ÄôM OLD) saw more compelling swordplay. In short, I see no point for the industry to board these goddamn souls like combat train if it‚Äôs not ready to emulate that sweet *umpf* sound you exhaust after hitting a perfect parry, roll, or whatever.

Overall, I may say that I will most probably play the sequel. However, this is only due to my space addiction and a hunch they saved the intrigue and protagonist‚Äôs internal battles for later. [b]If you were to ask me if I would recommend this to anybody else, I would most definitely say ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just not worth the time, at any cost‚Äù.[/b]

The game is quite good.  But...

You WILL fight with the EA launcher that is forced upon you.  You WILL fight it every single time you launch the game from Steam.  

It will fail to launch almost every first attempt because Steam and EA launcher cannot effectively communicate because they obviously relegated this programming task, both companies, to their summer interns.  Because of this, the game experience is ruined right at launching.

It will most likely fail the second attempt at launching, after the first attempt, for the same reasons.  From that point on you either have a 50/50 chance, or you have a 0 chance.  In the latter, Steam thinks it has launched, EA launcher thinks it has launched and integrated with Steam, but no game ever actually runs.  You are now at a point where it will never launch until you hunt down the individual processes in Task Manager, kill them all, and start your launch again all over from scratch.  Again, be prepared for it to not launch properly.

Daisy chaining and integrating two separate launchers together to launch the game is the playground of terrible software engineers and incompetent company managers.  Congratulations to everyone involved in this launcher fiasco.  Truly.

There is a big market for souls-like games and I'm sure this game appeals to that market. Personally I think this doesn't translate to Star Wars well at all. Enemy types are just casually skinned with Star Wars visuals with minimal thought to whether they match up. Combat is just as sluggish as any other Souls-like, with a focus on whittling down more potent enemies which is aesthetically terrible for a Jedi with a lightsaber, Lightsaber combat animation looks more like fantasy sword combat, passing through enemies with barely any effect. The visual and VO acting is good but the story feels more like low quality old-EU than good Star Wars to me. Overall It's not terrible, but not worth finishing and even on sale I feel it was wasted money. Such a disappointment.

I regret getting this game.
It's not a video game, it's a beautiful, interactive movie. While you have some choice in play, generally, you're just following the script until the next cut scene. 
It advertises - YOU CAN RUN ON WALLS... but only specific walls. You can force pull/push! ... but only specific things (while, I understand everything cannot be interacted with, I expect a much larger choice than what is given here).
I play this game in 30 minute intervals every few months. While enjoyable for 30 minutes, anything longer makes me frustrated at how good this game could've been if it focused on being a fun game, not just an aesthetically pleasing game.
Engaging gameplay and storyline with some customization options.

I wish this game took only some aspects of the Souls-like games and left the other ones to rot.

POSITIVES:
Looks great. Most of the time.
When you do well in a fight, it's really satisfying.

NEUTRAL:
It is fairly challenging, which is fine, though I don't always want to / have the time to spend half an hour on a single fight. Yes, I am bad at this game :).
The controls don't always feel responsive, especially when you're trying to move around / dodge. 

NEGATIVES:
The save system. Yes, it's the staple of the genre but I don't care. I hate it. Partially solved by a third-party mod which allows you to quicksave, but that's hardly ideal and doesn't work 100 %.
Backtracking. Always, all the time, forever. While using a map that's DOOM level bad.
The game just feels unpolished/unfinished. The animations range from beautiful and fluid (mostly Cal), through janky as hell (enemies, monsters especially; sometimes Cal as well), to simply frozen with objects sliding around (monsters). The environment is basically non-interactive (breakable vases - those actually made me laugh, you can also cut predefined pipes/vines etc.) and strangely empty, which really breaks immersion.
Group fights are a total chaos. Enemies just run at you or fire at you with a complete disregard for their fellow man. Which is funny the first time but feels really stupid afterwards.

Overall not for me. And I'm really bumped about that.

Tldr: Jedi: Fallen Order is a 3rd person action RPG with a focus on platforming and combat, with combat most like a soulslike. Exploration is encouraged but exploration is retracing steps over places you've already been to because you need a new upgrade or force power to access the previously unavailable areas which are mainly very small offshoots or simple walls that hold an upgrade, usually cosmetic only. I should also mention that although it seems like you have some choice in which order to visit planets it's mostly a linear affair and you are strongly encouraged not to go to one of your first two choices. I ultimately didn't care for the combat, levels, nor story at all and decided to save myself the grind and stop playing. I do not recommend this game.

Gameplay: As described above, this is a single player 3rd person action game with light RPG mechanics. The main focus is split pretty evenly between combat and light platforming/puzzles as you progress through the story. I'll focus on the combat first. I did not realize that this was based on soulslike combat and so when I was thinking that man these enemies are tough on the jedi setting, it was all intentional. I had started the game hoping for some lightsaber combat like Jedi Knight 2 or 3, but this is much more about memorizing patterns, heavy emphasis on blocking, dodging and forces you to manually do a lot of the work I enjoy not doing (auto avoiding/reflecting blasts when your lightsaber is out, for example). If you like soulslike, I think you'll find this combat a little lighter in comparison, but for me it was much too much that style. The 2nd part of the gameplay is a heavy emphasis on platforming and puzzles as you explore and progress through levels. I love platformers, this isn't fun either. It has the normal jump from platform to platform, but the majority of the platforming is stuff like sliding down and timing jumps as well as wall-running with some ropes thrown in here and there. All of that sounds great, but I found a varity of bugs even however many months post launch that would ruin my platforming and made it just a grind to get through. Plenty of times I'd jump from platform to platform only to have the protaganstic act as if he had hit a wall and then stumble around and fall off the prior edge (it was hilarious on the ice levels as he'd land on the next ice slope and then look confused and shutter up the frozen slide and fall off). Nothing in the gameplay made me feel I was having fun so I give this a 3/5, only because I think the combat could be something soulslike people might enjoy.
Story: The reason I play single player RPGs is for a great story. This is Star Wars but new Star Wars so you are running into some people from the new trilogy and it looks like they were trying to flesh out the characters that were never given a chance in those movies, but the plot is still barebones. I never connected with the protaganist nor the side characters in my 7 hours. My favorite was the droid who was a perfect companion, even turning on his light when we entered a dark cave automatically, if that tells you anything. You also can't skip story scenes which I wanted to do as they pretty quickly grated on me. 2/5 as I felt no need to progress to learn more.
Music: I love Star Wars music but I didn't find the music here to be that great aside from the few usual places that you hear some John Williams. 3/5
Graphics: The Graphics were high fidelity, but the environments I thought were very lifeless. The first world that you land on was just dull, and I never felt it improve from there. Nothing I saw made me go "wow" and usually when i'm exploring exotic worlds or ruins I would hope to see something that makes my jaw drop but nothing here made me do that. 3/5.
Fun-factor: I just didn't find it here. Pretty much from the get-go I was thinking that there were some strange design choices made, but hoped it would improve with new force powers or movement options but after 7 hours and 3.5 planets (as I had started the one you're strongly encouraged not to go to first) I finally said enough and will spend my time with a better game. 2/5.
Overall: I know this game was received positively by many people but I just didn't get engaged by the story, characters nor worlds. And I love Star Wars, I enjoyed Kotor 1&2, The Old Republic, as well as Jedi Knight 1&2, but this just didn't land. 2.5/5. There are better games out there to experience and better ways to enjoy the Force.

Really solid game if maybe a little short. Does a great job with storytelling baked into the overall experience.

Really solid action-adventure game, brought down by an overall roughness around its edges and lack of compelling innovation in combat, traversal, and storytelling. A slightly derivative amalgamation of what other games in the genre have done better, in a fun Star Wars package.
The story is fun and surprisingly engaging on a replay, but it feels overly familiar and tropey. Characters are well designed but lack proper development and opportunities to interact with them. Cutscenes are spectacular, they look great and are very well animated, outside of them character animation tends to be rather stiff looking and inorganic.
The story has some great moments, spectacular set pieces, and it‚Äôs overall pretty well paced. Doesn‚Äôt overstay its welcome and has a few surprises sprinkled about. A great Star Wars adventure that can‚Äôt fully shake off a feeling of familiarity and predictability.
Traversal gets more engaging as the game goes along and the player starts unlocking new abilities, but it doesn‚Äôt ever come close to being as engaging and polished as what Naughty Dog perfected in Uncharted 4. I‚Äôve never been a big fan of this style of platforming, and while double jumping is fun enough, it still hasn‚Äôt won me over.
Combat is where the game struggles the most. When it works properly it‚Äôs an extremely engaging attempt at bringing Souls-like combat to a mainstream audience, with the addition of unlockable combos and cool force powers. Sadly, it lacks the polish and exactitude that From Software tends to bring to their games, specially around collisions and character animations. There are plenty of combat encounters that are just annoying to get through in any of the very welcome difficulty levels because of this reason. It feels like with some more time in the oven this could have been fixed, as the bones of the system seem really solid and fun to play.
Easily the best Star Wars game in a long time. A solid foundation that I hope the sequels build upon.

[h1] The Good [/h1]
‚Ä¢ [u]Engaging Lightsaber Combat[/u]: Jedi: Fallen Order delivers satisfying lightsaber combat, capturing the essence of the Star Wars universe with fluid and impactful melee encounters.

‚Ä¢ [u]Compelling Storyline[/u]: The game features a well-crafted and immersive narrative, exploring the journey of Cal Kestis in the aftermath of Order 66, adding depth to the Star Wars lore.

‚Ä¢ [u]Beautifully Rendered Environments[/u]: The game's visuals excel in creating stunning and detailed environments, from lush planets to dark and ominous Sith temples.

‚Ä¢ [u]Exploration and Metroidvania Elements[/u]: Jedi: Fallen Order incorporates exploration and Metroidvania-style mechanics, encouraging players to revisit areas with new abilities and uncover hidden secrets.

‚Ä¢ [u]Character Development[/u]: Cal's character development is well-executed, and the companions, such as BD-1, contribute to the emotional resonance of the story.

‚Ä¢ [u]Nod to Star Wars Fans[/u]: The game pays homage to Star Wars fans with references, Easter eggs, and nods to the broader Star Wars universe, creating a sense of authenticity.

[hr][/hr]

[h1] The Bad [/h1]
‚Ä¢ [u]Occasional Technical Issues[/u]: Some players may encounter occasional technical issues, including frame rate drops and minor glitches that can momentarily disrupt the experience.

‚Ä¢ [u]Limited Customization[/u]: While the lightsaber combat is engaging, customization options for lightsabers and character appearance are relatively limited, leaving some players wanting more variety.

‚Ä¢ [u]Linear Design[/u]: The game, despite having exploration elements, follows a somewhat linear design, limiting the open-world feel that some players might expect.

[hr][/hr]

[h1] The Ugly [/h1]
‚Ä¢ [u]Camera Angles and Platforming[/u]: The camera angles during platforming sections can be problematic, leading to occasional frustrations and misjudgments, impacting the fluidity of gameplay.

‚Ä¢ [u]Inconsistent AI[/u]: The AI behavior, particularly of enemies, can be inconsistent, occasionally leading to unpredictable encounters that may feel unfair to the player.

[hr][/hr]

[h1]Overall Score: [/h1]
[h3] 8.3/10 [/h3]

This is a good game with a great story. If you like Star Wars, you should play this game.

It has nice customization of the lightsaber, interesting level design, and very well developed combat mechanics, but when it comes to what SHOULD be the most fun part of the series - the lightsaber vs lightsaber combat, it falls short. In these scenarios the game puts you into a series of intentionally unwinnable fight scenes (not difficulty wise), or the AI just uses a never ending series of unblockable attacks, so you spend all your time dodging like its dark souls, and much less lightsaber-to-lightsaber clashing. 

The system itself is put together pretty well, actually. So having multiple "you're supposed to lose this fight" fights, at that point I just lost interest in the game as a whole.

You can make a story about someone who's weak without making boss fights that have you lose, or "even when you win, you lose" kind of thing. (Again, not gameplay difficulty kind of "can't win", but "story" kind of "can't win"). 

As a side note as well, since you're a Jedi who has a range of abilities to do certain things, there are many situations where despite all the techniques you know there's often a single way to deal with a problem, with no other possible solutions or approaches (like the Dathomir Nightbrother's Village bridge, where they sit up there shooting unblockable attacks at you, with the only solution is to simply run through the middle). Its disappointing.

Just to recap though, everything else about this game is fantastic, so if you're okay with fighting several bosses where you're SUPPOSED to lose against (or be rescued from), then go for it. 

It just wasn't a satisfying experience for me.

Except the Scenery. The scenery is easily 11/10.

playing this on jedi master was a perfect way to learn how the jedi felt during order 66

all jokes aside i'd give it an 8.75/10 for minor quirks like fast travel or story based side quests, the story was fantastic and i loved the gameplay.

If this is one of the best modern Star Wars games, oh boy am I glad I did not play the rest of them.

Graphically, it's really good, but you pay for it with rather poor performance, especially when traversing into new parts of levels, but also during some combat encounters.

Combat itself is your run of the mill souls-style, meaning a lot of rolling around and dodging and parrying. Honestly, it does feel satisfying for the most part, but there are some issues with hit registration here and there. Some of the enemies also have the annoying ability to change attack direction even when they are in an attack stage where that does not really seem physically possible.

The music is very forgettable, which is a huge let down considering some of the absolutely stunning musical pieces Star Wars had over the years.

The narrative is pretty run of the mill, so are the characters, at least as far as I got into the story. Considering some of the absolute burning garbage piles the Disney SW era has spawned, a thoroughly meh run of the mill story is probably a huge win for the SW fandom.

The platforming is current-era-Tomb-Raider, but worse in pretty much every regard, and the new TR is already far from perfect. It's not outright bad, it's just a bit off. The snapping is not quite as good, the jumping is even less predictable and lacks precision, some animations seem to have a couple "empty" frames at the end where the character just freezes in place which makes it feel super clunky, like controlling a particularly unwieldy robot. This extends to some animations outside of platforming as well, which does impact some puzzles, etc.

Speaking of puzzles, they are not super hard to do, but the physics ones are extreme pain in the ass because object physics are not very good.

I could deal with the boring narrative, or middling imprecise "realistic animation" based platforming, or with the lack of technical polish, but all three? And at this price-point? Nah. The rest (music, hitreg issues) is just the last couple nails in the coffin.

Overall, it's a pretty uninspired game and what good parts it has get counteracted by a pretty noticeable lack of polish, even several years and patches after release. It's, as the kids say, pretty mid. I'd give it a pass unless you are a big fan of this type of games and Star Wars and there's a pretty significant discount at the time. There's better Souls-like/lites out there, there's better Star Wars games, and most of them are cheaper as well.

Should you play this game as a Star Wars fan? Yes.
Should you play this game as a generic gamer? Yes.
Should you play this game as someone who enjoys Dark-Souls like Melee Combat? Yes

The game starts off with a great story which evolves with great character depth and growth, with a very surprising ending that noone would have expected!

PROs:

- A few planets to fly to, each with a unique fauna and mini-bosses, including a fully explorable world
- You can set your character skills however you like, there's no set path
- You can customize your lightsaber greatly
- The game included many new characters and lightsaber colours into canon (important if youre a star wars nerd)
- The worlds feel alive, the graphics are really nice and the ambience is on-top

CONs:

- I would have wished for more accessible planets
- The story is fixed, there are only a handfull of choices that you can achieve yourself - most of which aren't even game changing, just part of a conversation
- I expected a few more bosses. There are a few but not every planet has its own boss which is a downside for me. Also, you fight one boss more than three times which is a little tiring

Did you ever hear the tragedy of Darth Plagueis The Wise? I thought not. It‚Äôs not a story the Jedi would tell you. It‚Äôs a Sith legend. Darth Plagueis was a Dark Lord of the Sith, so powerful and so wise he could use the Force to influence the midichlorians to create life‚Ä¶ He had such a knowledge of the dark side that he could even keep the ones he cared about from dying. The dark side of the Force is a pathway to many abilities some consider to be unnatural. He became so powerful‚Ä¶ the only thing he was afraid of was losing his power, which eventually, of course, he did. Unfortunately, he taught his apprentice everything he knew, then his apprentice killed him in his sleep. Ironic. He could save others from death, but not himself.

Update: switched to my gaming PC and the EA app seems to have synced my save game in the background, but a version that was one week older than the current one. This game is more like a Star Wars version of Uncharted than an actual souls like. Storytelling is 12 year old Disney writing with terrible characters and cutscenes you cannot skip. This game feels a lot like the the Tomb Raider reboot series, which I didn't enjoy at all.
It's another example in a long list, that most triple AAA games these days are not for me anymore.

Although I quite like the overall atmosphere and the lightning effects but the rest just feels stale and generic.
To many design choices which killed immersion for me.

GAINING XP:
While you still get a bit XP from killing enemies, there are random spots ( a lot of them ) where you just press a button to scan something or listen to a echo of the past and voil√† you gained a big chunck of XP..................really?

Movement:
Way to many of those "sliding down a slope" sections where you get the feeling driving a truck with the handbrakes applied.
Jumping onto ropes or while climbing is very imprecise, especially at the end of those "sliding down a slope" sections.

COMBAT:
Basically it's a imprecise version of the Dark Souls combat system, but at least it looks cool.

LOOT:
In 9 out of 10 cases all you'll find in chests (after a non-skippable animation of 3 seconds) is purely cosmetic nonsense.
New colours for your sidekick, lightsaber, new poncho, new whatsoever................boring.

RIDDLES:
Tedious, simple, boring

This game has an excellent story that, interestingly enough, wasn't originally written to be a Star Wars game. It has some details in it that loosely tie in with the recent Disney Star Wars TV series.

The gameplay is good but not amazing.
- I liked that the progression wasnt too 'hand holdy'. It tells you your main objective but doesnt walk you through every little step on how to get there. They did have hints for puzzles in case you seemed like you were stuck, but other than that you rely more on the character dialogue to figure out what youre supposed to do next. I think more games could benefit from doing that. 
- The environments and creatures were great, your typical Star Wars experience (except for the Wookies, the Wookies are hilariously ugly in this game). I didnt feel like it was very rewarding to go off the main path though. The game mostly has meaningless cosmetic unlocks, with a few areas that will benefit the protagonists abilities.
- The combat was done well. The only gripe is that they give you 4 difficulty levels, but no achievements linked to difficulty. The higher difficulty settings make things pretty challenging and I didnt want to sink endless hours into this game so I appreciated the option to flip between difficulty settings as you progress through the game.
- Unfortunately this game is a laggy mess. Huge frame drops happen anytime the game is loading something. I tried to optimize my settings and didnt get any improvements. I had the same problems on medium as I did on epic. This game has no loading screens, and loads in the next area while you are moving through transition points. A problem I noticed with this was that the game actually starts loading (lagging) before you even get into the transition area. Its awful.

Overall, I would say that this was a great game mostly because of the epic story, but wait for it to hit a steep discount because the gameplay wasnt as legendary as I had heard, and this game likes to play hot potato with your frame rate.

While I did enjoy this game to a degree something felt really off about it from the start. I love soulslike games, but one for star wars feels really weird. Lightsaber combat can be a really cool thing to emulate, but this game just does it in such a weird way. I really enjoy souls-like combat, but it just doesn't really work for lightsabers as well as it could. Moving away from it's gameplay, story wise this game is just mediocre at first and then the ending completely ruins the rest of the games writing. I won't spoil anything, but everything you work for in the game is basically pointless. You accomplish the overarching goal of the whole story, and then the cast just chooses to do nothing with it. What an immensely disappointing ending for a game that could have achieved so much. This game overall just feels like they tried to build a star wars game around a souls-like game format, instead of building a starwars game that is meshed with soulslike features.

Overall the game play is decent. I think the highlight for me were the puzzles and exploration. I really enjoyed the level design, how they fold back in on each other. That said, there are a number of times when I wish the clear path forward was more visible. You see 2 options, left or right, you pick right and it goes to a cut scene or boss fight, and it turns out later on when you come back, going left was a simple collectible before which you would've gone right anyways.  

Combat is fine, I enjoyed the troop fights more than anything. Boss fights I found to be annoying and too souls like. Why do I have a massive health bar if most monsters 2/3 hit you? You're supposed to be able to parry/block most attacks except when the enemy turns red, but I found that there were so many more boss moves that were also unblock-able but not flagged as such. I get it some people might like that type of mechanic, I don't. Turning down the difficulty would've made the regular combat too easy.  

Overall, it was a decent play through, and I'd recommend it to anyone who is a fan of the franchise.

The force is strong with this game. 

If you want that authentic Dark Souls experience, turn the difficulty up to Jedi Master. You'll be rolling and dodging and parrying like crazy trying to stay alive even from measly stormtroopers. It is also a decent metroidvania; your powers open up more of the map so expect to return to an area multiple times just to uncover more secrets. 

My advice is to take your time with the game, immerse in the story, and find your rhythm during combat. Button mashing will get you killed fast. This game rewards grace and precision as you mix sword techniques and force powers. Master that and you'll be as ruthless as "Anakin in a room full of younglings" in no time.

Having just finished a second full playthrough (a few years later), I can say that this game still holds up. Light souls-like mechanics but much more forgiving in combat. There are still a few bugs in the physics engine that see Cal bounce off of walls unexpectedly, and traversal post-game is an absolute pain - fast travel is sorely missed here! - but overall, it looks beautiful, has an engaging story and remains a lot of fun to play.

I like story mode. It is just enough action to be fun and interesting but I can focus on the story like it is an interactive movie. Just my style!

A very nice Souls-Metroidvania like game.
If you enjoy a tight(ish) combact system with exploration and revisiting maps you already went though, you will definitely enjoy the game.

Not as hard / tight as other Souls-like games, exploring doesn't feel that rewarding, mainly since without some specific gear that gets unlocked via the story you will keep having to revisit and explore a bit more, feeling more blocked in your exploration then actually "unlocking" new content or ways to travel.

The story, unless you are a huge fan of Star-Wars is completely skipable / missable, since everything you need to know about it will happen in the first and last 60 minutes of the game. The plot moves along as you expect it to move along, but in the time period it takes place in the Star Wars universe, it would be foolish to assume major changes / surprises / plot twists.

In general, 20ish hours to complete, a bit more to 100%.
All in all, would still recommend the game, since between the gameplay loop, the combat, and the art / sound design, it's a solid game.

Just don't expect the game to blow your mind or be the best 3rd poerson action-adventure out there.

If you want a great story from Star Wars, then this is certainly a great story very similar in feel to Force Unleashed with all the emotions (have some tissues prepared for a few scenes that are heartbreaking). However, with how glitchy and buggy the gameplay is it can be really frustrating... i.e. certain cut scenes not triggering correctly, an enemy glitching into the wall and you cannot continue and have to reset the scene, confusing instructions at critical moments, etc.... 

I liked the challenge of playing it in Jedi Knight mode when the controls worked the way they were supposed to, but when I hit the attack button a dozen times and Cal just sits there being beaten up by an enemy, then it is not a challenge, but a frustration. I was mostly interested in the story, so I switched it to story mode to give me even a chance at beating the enemies with all the glitchy game play. 

So, good story, semi-decent gameplay, but short. I finished this game rather quickly and would have loved a little more meat on the bones so to speak. It would have been nice if there was more content to the story and not as much random exploration. It was frustrating trying to find specific paths after unlocking the maps as you could not see where you had not been or how to get to certain areas.  Lots of filler content rather than story and true exploration. 

I do appreciate how it does give an open world feel while still keeping you in line for the story itself, but not worth the usual $60 - $70 most games are worth now a days. If you really want this game, wait for it to be on sale is my suggestion.

Well, that was definitely the best Jedi game I've played since Kotor. The game features a serviceable souls-like combat system, with a parrying system that can feel epic at times and busted at other times. But I think the mythos of the world that the Lucas-crew created shines through. 

As with all SW games, I feel like the story-telling is always stuck in the past trying to retell the stories of the movies rather than add (almost anything) to the worlds/galaxies that are new. That is fully on display in the storyline.

Even so, I really liked the characters. Even the creepy bug-eyed lady was alright by the end of the game (seriously, where is a mod to fix her eyes so she looks like the actor and not creepy as hell). In particular, night-sister Merrin was my favorite character outside of Cal Kestis.

The ending was interesting and I hope they lean on this in the second rendition. The big reveal, the lost apprentice, the lure of the dark side. All fantastic storytelling.

Lastly, it must be said, this PC port blows chunks. Forced TAA, blurry visuals with AA or flickering visuals without. The game never looks the way it should. There needs to be a remaster that includes DLAA to fix the visuals and this game would be a solid 9/10.

[hr][/hr][h1]SYNOPSIS[/h1][hr][/hr]
About 14 hours of the best character writing and Star Wars storytelling in gaming / Roughly 6 hours of gameplay that drags out the experience for *slightly* longer than it needs to be. / And an extra 8 hours of collection-hell for those of you who want to wrap up the experience in a nice infuriating bow.

All in all: [i]Star Wars: Jedi Fallen Order[/i] is a SOLID game that‚Äôs well worth the journey!

[quote][h3]CORE CHARACTERISTICS[/h3]
[b]‚Ä¢ STYLE:[/b] Space-Wizard Action-Adventure
[b]‚Ä¢ AVG. SESSION:[/b] ~1 - 2 hours
[b]‚Ä¢ CHALLENGE:[/b] Easy to Brutal
[b]‚Ä¢ MOOD:[/b] Story-Driven w/ Heavily Skill-Based Combat
[/quote]

[hr][/hr][h1]üü¢ THE POSITIVES[/h1][hr][/hr]
[b]‚ûï The STORY (in fact, *all* the writing).[/b] The writing team [i]came to play[/i] in the Star Wars universe, and they DO NOT disappoint. The game tells a story at an interesting and exciting moment in Star Wars history, and does so while creating a brilliantly-written cast of characters that emerge as not only some of the most memorable characters in the Star Wars universe, but in the gaming space, as well.

[b]‚ûï The CHARACTERS.[/b] While I certainly expected Cal to be the star, I was surprised by the quality of the whole surrounding cast. EVERY character has a personality, a drive, and feel like they make consistent decisions when confronted by challenges‚Äîboth the light and dark. They are memorable, powerful, and carry the game through the few areas where it struggles.

[b]‚ûï The VOICE-OVER.[/b] Only adds to their humanity (or alien-in-ity?)... The voice cast is absolutely top notch, and do an amazing job of adding [i]soul[/i] to each character. When combined with strong writing and motivations, they create truly iconic heroes and villains. [i](...better than some cinematic Star Wars characters‚Ä¶)[/i]

[b]‚ûï BD-1.[/b] The LEGEND‚Ä¶ I didn‚Äôt think I‚Äôd find a new favorite droid, but I have found a new favorite droid.

[b]‚ûï The MAJOR SET PIECES.[/b] Throughout the game, there are several ‚ÄúWOW‚Äù moments that somehow manage to deliver all the immersion and excitement of rampaging through the Star Wars universe as a powerful space wizard. I won‚Äôt spoil them, but it‚Äôs well worth playing on Story Mode if only to enjoy these glorious moments! (‚Ä¶definitely stick around to the end of the game!)

[b]‚ûï EXPLORATIONS OF THE FORCE.[/b] I can‚Äôt go into too much detail, but WOW‚Ä¶ The way the game explores the Force through flash-forwards and echoes is REALLY powerful. Again: I won‚Äôt spoil them, but they are some of the most memorable moments in the game.

[b]‚ûï The FEELING OF BEING A BADASS SPACE WIZARD.[/b] With great power comes great power fantasies. And while the fights can be challenging, overcoming them through practice and patience‚Äîor just slicing through a large group of Stormtroopers‚Äîfeels AMAZING.

([b]TIP:[/b] As a non Souls-esque player, ‚ÄòJedi Knight‚Äô was perfectly challenging enough for me. I probably could have gone ‚ÄòJedi Master‚Äô but don‚Äôt require that torment in life...)

[b]‚ûï The MUSIC.[/b] Everything about the soundtrack nails that perfect ‚ÄúStar Wars‚Äù feel: from the instruments to the ambiance and the excitement of the battle tracks.

[b]‚ûï STORMTROOPER DIALOGUE.[/b] Is SO GOOD. I‚Äôd end up pausing for moments to listen to them chat because they are so, so relatable. [i](Especially the feeling when an unstoppable space-wizard rolls through and ruins your day‚Ä¶)[/i]

[b]‚ûï KILLING STORMTROOPERS.[/b] The game does a phenomenal job of making them feel *just* threatening enough, just proud enough when they manage to land a hit, and just terrified enough when the lightsaber comes out to make for a brilliantly perfect Star Wars experience!

[hr][/hr][h1]üü° THE..."TAKE IT OR LEAVE IT"[/h1][hr][/hr]
[b]„Ä∞Ô∏è LEVEL DESIGN.[/b] The world design is amazing when it‚Äôs not downright ENRAGING. It feels great when you‚Äôre exploring and following along with the story, but becomes a tangled mess of maze-like tunnels when trying to find the one correct path, an obscure collectible, or even just taking the long path back to your ship.

[b]„Ä∞Ô∏è ICE SLIDES.[/b] Get tired quickly. The mechanic has moments where it ‚Äúfits‚Äù in the world and feels fun (i.e. at the very beginning), but ultimately adds little more than mechanically frustrating, pace-breaking deaths in the middle of otherwise interesting moments.

[b]Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è The GAMEPLAY.[/b] Overall, it‚Äôs FINE, but the controls and combat aren‚Äôt *quite* as tight as I‚Äôd expect. Particularly in a game where precision is critical, it feels like many deaths are attributed to animation locks and dropped inputs instead of mastery over your attack combos or learning the attacks of your enemies.

[b]„Ä∞Ô∏è The MINIMAP.[/b] While it‚Äôs a super cool and thematic implementation, it is difficult to read, navigate, and doesn‚Äôt paint a clear picture of where you need to go at any given time.

[b]„Ä∞Ô∏è OPEN WORLD CHESTS.[/b] Feel like an afterthought, and often feel like a thematic break in the mid-to-late game.

[b]„Ä∞Ô∏è BOUNTY HUNTERS.[/b] An interesting‚Äîbut half-delivered‚Äîconcept. I don‚Äôt mind that they‚Äôre in the game, but wish they had a more relevant (and less random) purpose other than breaking your flow through the world.

[hr][/hr][h1]üí¢ THE NOT-SO-GREAT[/h1][hr][/hr]
[b]‚ûñ The ease of falling outside the world.[/b] For as much as the game encourages the exploration of every nook and cranny, the world isn‚Äôt quite as seamless as you‚Äôd expect. It‚Äôs easy to fall outside the bounds of the world or get stuck in an inescapable nook, forcing a reload to your last checkpoint.

[b]‚ûñ FORCE POWERS.[/b] The implementation of Force powers feels exceptionally limiting and incredibly frustrating. Whether you‚Äôre accidentally using Force-attacks or regenerating it at a snail‚Äôs pace, it‚Äôs a huge hindrance to the flow of your combat.

[b]‚ûñ BUG: Enemy aggro can break collectible/achievement/crate interactions.[/b] An annoying bug that comes up often, enemies can prevent you from seeing or interacting with resources and collectibles throughout the world, leading to post-game scavenger hunts that can add frustrating hours to your play time.

[hr][/hr][h1]‚ú® THE FINAL WORD‚Ä¶[/h1][hr][/hr]
[i]Star Wars: Jedi Fallen Order[/i] is a phenomenal game and one of the strongest Star Wars games available if you‚Äôre looking for a great story, a deep dive into the history and lore of the universe, and characters who are well-deserving of a [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1774580/]sequel[/url] to continue their journey.

It‚Äôs not the longest game you‚Äôll play, but it also doesn‚Äôt overstay its welcome if you‚Äôre looking for a quick adventure through an awesome story. Highly recommended!

Really fun Star Wars game but not without it's issues. Could have been a fantastic game, ends up still being very good and definitely worth your time regardless of if you're a Star Wars nerd or not.

First thing I'll say is there is an awesome amount of different enemy types from imperial troops, to wild creatures, a different array of robots, lightsaber users, magic using savages, bounty hunters, and even taking on an AT-ST a few times! So no shortage of different enemy types that you will need to learn to fight and use different abilities against. Having said that, the abilities with which you get to use as you progress through the game feel a bit weak at times. Very rarely do they give you a decent advantage in combat to make them worth their use consistently. For example if you use force slow, the moment you hit your opponent they're right back on the offensive. There was no reason to ever use the upgraded version that slows for longer because of this. And the combat itself whilst for the most part is very fun doesn't make you feel like a Jedi. You can slice a robot in half with a finishing move that looks cool, but anyone attacking you with a melee weapon will just block attack after attack from your lightsaber until you've beaten down their defence meter which is infuriating. Just feels like you're robbed of feeling like an awesome Jedi in the way that past Star Wars games have.  

My main other gripe is the level design and map. The worlds you visit are pretty fun to explore but are an absolute nightmare to navigate. especially when coming back for collectables. The levels are too big for starters; they really could have cut them in half and made them separate levels. But because there are several different ways of navigating between different levels on a certain planet (elevators, zip lines that only go one way until upgrading, air vents, slippery slopes etc) it is really confusing trying to work your way around. In trying to make the game like uncharted/tomb raider they've made navigation a mess so you'll find yourself zooming in and out and rotating the map every way imaginable trying to figure out where the heck you are and how to get to where you want to go.

Anyway, super fun game. Just gotta be patient navigating the levels, and look at your enemies moves carefully for openings so you don't get stuck hitting their guard all the time. 8.5/10 for me.

Pretty disappointing. It starts off with a great tutorial, but quickly goes downhill into boring characters, a plot that's hard to care about, lots of fairly lame platforming and a very janky combat system.

Platforming is just tedious and it's hard to tell if you're being an idiot or need an ability. Sometimes you get to a hidden spot by clipping through some decorations mid-maneuver and can't even tell if that was the intended path or a glitch. Traversal abilities are kinda basic, but also infuriating in how artificially locked down they are. Can't dive two meters to get a chest? Wait until you get a breathing thingie. Not sure if you can solve a puzzle? You just need to go through 2/3 of the game for the character to literally remember he can also double-jump.

Combat is a bit rubbish. It tries to be some sort of precision dodge/parry, but the timings and animations just never seem to be consistent. I completed the game on Hard (no achievement, so thanks for wasting my time), but still can't tell if I'm just failing to see it. Half the time I fail to parry, the other half a parry works when timing was way off. But you can more or less just cheese your way through the toughest encounters with some force slow-mo.

Exploring and finding hidden stuff is just hugely disappointing. It's all useless cosmetic crap. Because you need 16 ponchos.

You also get some shoddy EA launcher that wants you to set up an account and runs on startup by default. The game takes five minutes to launch, and you never know if it's going to or got stuck. But if you press launch again, you risk the game auto-reopening after you're done and shut it down. 10/10 great feature.

80% of the game just makes you want for it to end sooner. Not sure where there other 20% are. It takes you 15 seconds to travel between planets, but three times as long to ride a shortcut elevator. Game messes with time itself.

Game is excellent for only one playthrough. There are no QoL updates that allow for a streamlined second playthrough: no cutscene skips, no tutorial skips or dialogue skips. It's good, really really good surprisingly for something under the EA umbrella (i know it's Respawn, I sunk countless hours into Titanfall). That being said, it is a lot like Detroit: Become Human. Good on the first playthrough, but not worth a second run through unless you truly enjoy every cutscene and dialogue. The only redeeming factor of some of the new content is that you get access to the Meditation battles, which circumvents any need to replay the game to fight bosses again. The quality is evident. So far EA has not ruined another company, but even going onto the second installation in this series, the stability falters making a good game less enjoyable. Sad, but true. Take it with a grain of salt, or just get a 100% save to spare you the headache of replaying everything and just skip to the meditation battles.

I love Star Wars. There is mostly a good game here. But there is one overwhelming flaw with this game that takes it from being a good game and just makes it a frustration fest. That is the combat mechanics. You see in order to heal yourself, you have to stand still, wait for your druid to pop up a healing canister, and all the while be in a position to take no damage. The problem with that is, you are in a position to take lots of damage and can't sit still. There are many, many times that I have died in this game because of this. There are many instances of being surrounded by multiple enemies. Each time that an enemy hits you, you are staggered, which can basically get you stun locked and the enemies can literally juggle your health down to nothing because of one simple mistake. If you do get your self into one of these positions, because of the heal mechanic requiring you to stand still, you must then dodge roll yourself away, while these multiple enemies are chasing you, and with different timings coming at you with unblock-able attacks that must be dodged, and you can see where I am going with this. There are so many situations where you are just constantly dodging, needing to heal, and not being able to. The stagger juggling is a frustrating mechanic. That combined with the need to stand still and be completely defenseless in order to heal is what makes this game a bad game that I can't recommend.  Respawn Entertainment. The game certainly lives up to the name. The only way to get through some of these combat encounters is to constantly respawn, and just spam dodge and hope that you can get a few lucky breaks. It's not about timing and skill so much as it is just luck.

This game really grabbed my attention in the beginning; I loved the intro. I was expecting a Star Wars adventure, not a bunch of 'parkour.' There's so walking and platforming and the combat isn't good enough to tie it all together. The sections between the beginning and the end of the game were quite boring. The whole middle part of the game felt lacking, with some poor dialogue and delivery. I didn't become interested again until I returned to Dathomir after Kashyyyk.

This game looks and sounds amazing. The planets, the distant views, animations (when they don't occasionally bug out), and the cutscenes‚Äîall the environments looked fantastic. The level of detail in them was astounding. I think there were only a few minor issues with Cal.

The characters in this game seem all over the place. The main crew seems great; the dialogue was fine, the animations were fantastic, and the story moments were well placed. The only time it felt off was when Cal learns about the Second Sister and returns to the ship. It seemed like there was missing dialogue. There are also moments when Cal looks really strange, like he's staring blankly or has an uncanny valley effect going on. This doesn't align well with his dialogue, which is either really good or really bad. The Second Sister was not well-executed until the end of the game. She was laughably nonthreatening until later in the game, feeling more like a generic villain saying, "I'm evil, I'm going to do bad things, fear me!!!" This issue got even worse with the Ninth Sister. They turned a character that could have been a teen drama joke into a villain, and it was terrible. Nothing about this character felt villainous or relatable, and they weren't even so evil that you'd love to hate them. Clearly a throwaway character, and I was glad they got thrown away so I didn't have to interact with them anymore. The story's conclusion was quite good in my opinion and the clear highlight of the game.

Aside from the story, which carried the game, there's the combat. It was serviceable at best. It just felt strange to be wielding a lightsaber and having it function like a baseball bat. Sometimes it cuts through limbs, but most of the time it might as well be smacking people over the head with it. The number of things that could seemingly block a lightsaber was confusing as well. I'm not entirely sure where the lore stands on what they can and can't cut through, but seeing them cut holes in doors but be blocked by batons was weird. I guess the in-game reasoning for this is either the Nightsister magic maces or the clone trooper energized baton. But since everything seems to block you, the game pushed me to parry everything, just waiting around to parry something if my Force meter was empty. It reminded me of some of the newer 2D Metroid games, where you parry everything, except there's no poise meter, so your parries don't guarantee a successful attack afterward. You usually have to wait around for two parries. It was satisfying to fight so many enemies at the end of the game and unleash everything you've built up, but building those skills throughout the game was not fun, and there weren't enough moments that truly embellished combat.

If you're not parrying stormtroopers, it's some random selection of animals. I love being a Jedi, traveling from beautiful planet to planet, just to fight a variety of rats. So many rats and rat-like creatures on every planet. The enemy variety in this game was abysmal. There's a clear pattern of a big creature that every planet has, along with a bunch of smaller creatures. I understand there have to be gameplay mechanics, but I do not find it fun or immersive to be fighting a goat. You're a space samurai with a laser sword, and you're fighting a goat. The clone troopers were easier to fight than said goat.

The game ran mostly fine for me; there were some loading stutters, but that may be because I didn't have it installed on an SSD. Otherwise, it was running at around 70fps to 90fps at 4K on a RTX 4070 Ti. It did utilize a lot of CPU; I am using a 2600X at 4.2GHz, which is getting a bit old but managed.

A year or more after swearing I was done with this game, I decided to give it another chance. I am making it further than before, but I really feel the game play is flawed in some important ways. First: if the game design wants me to beat my head against a hard section or boss by dying over and over again, OK. I personally dislike this design choice when it's combined with tedious platforming in order for me to get back to the area I'm stuck on. I get wanting me to succeed at a section of the game, but the save points are often located in obnoxious places. Second, I really feel that they dye, dye again style is at odds with the lore of the game. There is no in-game reason for me to be dying and resurrecting constantly, so designing the game in a way where I have to expect 10-20 deaths per boss really takes me out of the immersion. It's not a good jedi power fantasy to die repeatedly to a big bat in a cave somewhere. I'm not saying the game should be made easier per se, just that the lack of a lore-based explanation for constantly dying coupled with the obvious game decision to design the game around dying really feels off to me. 

The controls really feel sluggish. I've died multiple times where I felt I detected the incoming attack and responded, but it just didn't work. 

I also find it frustrating that there's not a great way to regain resources in combat. I really like the push forward design of games like Doom. I find in Jedi Fallen Order that the inability to recover health at all in combat means that taking damage early in a hard boss fight leads to me just giving up and dying so I can re-attempt the boss with a clean start. Simply put, for me, it's more fun if after I mess up and take a bunch of damage there's a way for me to recover that doesn't entail repeating the same stupid platforming section I've just done 8 times. 

Overall, this game is incredibly frustrating. Dying over and over and over, then doing sluggish clunky platforming to get back to the spot where I can finally try again is really annoying. I find myself still wanting to play it, but frankly, I don't know why.

Bought this game from a sale and gladly so 'cause this title is tedious.
For starters I spent several days playing 5D chess against steam and EA app just to get this game up and running.
(To be honest it was just the EA app, nothing else, but off to a good start anyway).
For what it is worth the visuals are pretty neat, no stuttering, tearing or floating main character for me. If I should use one word to describe graphics i'd use sterile (or clinical?).
I've yet to discover more about the story itself, but thus far it seems about as imaginative as recent d+ Star wars series were(Book of Boba Fett, Kenobi et al) and that is not a praise. Storywise there is nothing that makes me want to play to reveal more of it.

You should be fighting against the empire and monsters, not controls. Most likely this is due to lack of effort made in porting the game (always a good sign when a pc game recommends using a controller). I have to admit though that the guys behind original keybindings must be true sith (especially the dodge button).

And also the all time classics: invisible walls. When a place (wall/ curtain etc) seems perfectly climbable/runnable but Kal just jumps up'n down or falls righ off it is frustrating af. And when you finally ragequit you'll have to go through areas you've already played 'cause only savepoints, no free save. Also who was the smart ass that thought that enemy respawning after resting is a good idea?

Fallen Order. Star Wars answer to the Dark Souls series. You play as Cal Kestis (played by the incredible Cameron Monaghan) one of the few remaining survivors of order 66. Cal has lost his faith and connection to the force but an accident at work forces him to use his powers to save a friend and exposes himself as a Jedi. Cal is now on the run with a band of scrappy survivors to find a Jedi Holocron that contains the location of the future of the Jedi order before the Empire does. 
The gameplay is addictive, challenging at times brutal and makes you feel like you're a real Jedi. You'll need to concentrate on each enemy choosing your attacks carefully. The level design is fantastic and stunning at times. Offering lots of exploration and rewards. The puzzles aren't too challenging and the platforming sections can be both irritating and satisfying. 
The best part of this game hands down is the story. Interesting characters, a heroes journey and cameos from fan favourite characters. in a time in the Star Wars saga that we know about. 
Fallen Order is easily one of the best Star Wars games ever made.
Come for the lightsaber fights, stay for the PTSD and survivors guilt

Jedi: Fallen Order - A Galaxy of Missed Opportunities

How do I even begin to explain this game? Well, I'll start by saying that I recommend it, but with several caveats. The only redeeming qualities are the stunning scenery, engaging characters, a few amusing lines from Stormtroopers, and the undeniable Star Wars charm.

But let's get to the heart of the matter. Jedi: Fallen Order is 94% platformer, 4% agonizingly tedious boss fights, and a measly 2% actual fun. Get ready for a relentless cycle of backtracking due to horrendous checkpoint timing and locations. The platforming, in my opinion, is poorly executed, monotonous, infuriating, and downright tedious. The boss fights consist of constant evasion and blocking, but you'll still meet your demise because the tracking is off and the animations throw the timing out of whack.

The fleeting moments of enjoyment stem solely from the fact that it's set in the Star Wars universe, and a handful of humorous lines in cutscenes. As I played this game, I clung to it because it was Star Wars, yet I despised every minute, longing to uninstall it with each passing second. It's as if they attempted to mimic elements from Dark Souls/Sekiro and Tomb Raider but managed to get both wrong.

The only time I was genuinely elated during my playthrough was when the game informed me that I was nearing its conclusion. It signaled an end to my torment. This isn't an action game; it's primarily a platformer with Star Wars slapped onto it as a backup name. Respawn should have stuck to their other titles, like Titanfall and Apex Legends.

I'm thankful that I acquired this during a sale, but I'm also disheartened that I own the game and that I've learned its true nature. The ending only compounds the disappointment, providing no reason to revisit the game.

On my rating scale, Jedi: Fallen Order earns a paltry 2/10. At this point, I'm not sure what else to do but uninstall it and find something more enjoyable. May the Force be with you, even if it wasn't with this game. I'm going to go cry.

I'll start by saying that I'm not too far into the game, so it could get better. I'm hoping that it gets better. 

I started with high hopes, since I've heard great things about the story line and characters. So far though, it's been more of a combination of Temple Run and Tomb Raider; which, while not bad, is not exactly what I was expecting. I've had experience with Star Wars games across a variety of platforms, so I was expecting a similar balance of combat play style and story, Regrettably, I've died more times speeding down an ice tunnel and missing the rope to cross than I have at the hands of an Imperial enemy. 

Maybe it's because I'm not far enough into the game, but at this point, it feels like most of my time in-game is spent parkouring my way across the planet and little time spent furthering the storyline or gaining a greater grasp of the characters. I still plan on finishing this game at some point, but rather than it being an enjoyable sojourn to one of my favorite nostalgic universes, it's feeling more like a grind and when I have more compelling games in my Steam library, it's been knocked down the list of top games.

Most boring game I've played all year. The combat is clunky and uninspired. Story line boots off extremely quickly but doesn't really hook you in, just introduces you to who you are and what you'll be doing. Cal really should of be a customizable character, but instead we get given the most vanilla fantasy teen protagonist. The missions are an absolute chore to progress as well because they're incredibly linear and do not reward free-thinking at all. Hell, half of the obvious mission routes on the first world you go to are straight up blocked unless you go somewhere else so Cal can have a PTSD flashback and remember a skill he somehow completely forgot he could do but now he can do it perfectly.

Also, the climbing. Absolute zero difficulty to it but it's just slow and clunky, and it's goddamn everywhere you go. Honestly, feels just like the developers decided to shove a bunch of climbing obstacles in just to stretch out the game and make it last longer than it should.

This game in my opinion is incredible, the pros outweigh the cons. The game is beautiful and each planet is incredibly well detailed, in terms of character designs I feel that they are also very well made and they feel like real people. The combat aspect in the game is done spectacularly and gives the player a true sense of power and agility, The game uses a sort of skill tree with different combat and perk abilities unlockable by acquiring skill points which are gained by xp, it's a very well built system and gives the game alot more depth and a sense of progression. The main weapon of the game being Jaro Topal's broken lightsaber wielded by the main character Kal Kestis (Jaro Topal's apprentice). The biggest flaw most people have with this game is that people feel that the campaign is too short which I can definitely agree with, other than that the story is very well thought out and it helps solidify the point of the game. This game is great and although I don't think it should be as expensive as it is, but if your into STAR WARS especially Jedi then this game is definitely for you.

A good game worth playing - BUT: beware the EA details.

The positive: the game itself:
- Challenging fights against a variety of enemies and enemy constellations that all have their unique combat mechanic details. Lightsaber combat right from the start! <3
- A (re)spawn system that makes you think before you headlessly jump into any fight.
- Well-designed worlds: a handful planets, visually appealing, worth exploring (lots of small stuff to find), with clever platforming progression mechanics (paths and shortcuts that unlock with skills throughout the game).
- A (simple) skill system worth investing point into.
- A simple but good story.
I would wish there would be more such games.

The negative: the EA details:
- Requires a separate EA account and linking it to your steam account.
- Requires accepting the separate EA privacy policy.
- Requires the EA software to run while you game, which requires an internet connection.
- It's impossible to skip the game intro screens, which take unnecessarily long.
- "Close game" is hidden in settings, and privacy settings are hidden in settings under a point called "extras" (and they're on by default).
I would wish EA would allow their games to be better than that.

**Introduction:**

From the very outset, you are thrust into a meticulously crafted and immersive scenario that sets the stage for a unique gaming experience. However, rather than plunging directly into traditional tasks, the game gently eases you into its world, providing an opportunity to become familiar with its intricate keyboard controls. It's an engaging journey, though I couldn't help but repeatedly murmur, "Oh, this isn't a walk in the park." Some missions present intricate mechanics that may initially feel daunting, yet they possess an underlying logic that allows players to discern their path.

**Key Points:**

**1. Varied Challenge Levels:** Throughout the game, you'll encounter missions of varying difficulty levels. Some may leave you momentarily feeling trapped in a loop, but these instances are transient. With persistence, gradual discovery, and acclimation to the game's mechanics, you'll find your way and adapt to its unique playstyle.

**2. A Game of Consistency:** Consistency in key commands is paramount, and taking breaks can lead to moments of forgetting which keys to press when you return. To avoid this, I'd recommend playing this game in a single, uninterrupted session to maintain your command over the controls and avoid unnecessary frustration.

**3. Puzzle-Driven Gameplay:** Brace yourself for a gaming experience laden with puzzles that challenge your problem-solving skills. The game often requires nimble navigation akin to that of a ninja traversing hoops. While there are moments of inconsistent difficulty, they remain within the realm of conquerability.

**4. A Stellar Star Wars Experience:** This title ranks among the finest Star Wars games I've had the pleasure of playing, delivering a captivating narrative that unfolds within the framework of constantly bustling missions.

**Conclusion:**

In conclusion, this game presents a multifaceted and occasionally challenging journey that rewards players with an intricate storyline and a unique gaming experience. While certain missions may initially seem like puzzling enigmas, they gradually unveil their inner workings. However, the game's demand for consistent mastery of keyboard commands necessitates continuous play to avoid the frustration of fumbling with controls after breaks. Nevertheless, this title stands as one of the standout Star Wars games, offering a gripping narrative seamlessly intertwined with a whirlwind of missions that will keep you engaged throughout.
Good game. Story, combat, environments = goated.

Lightsabers can't cut through wood or flesh apparently, forget metal. Even random jungle slugs and spiders will tank 5 to 7 direct hits before dying in normal difficulty. It's underwhelming. Don't give me a lightsaber early if you don't want me to slice through things and I'm getting wrecked by literal prairie worms.

By the way, we're nonstop slaughtering wildlife, but sure, we have a sPiRiTuaL cOnNecTioN WiTh nAtuRe (not joking, the phrase appears in-game as such). I guess Cal's master never taught him to use the Force to appease and calm simpler lifeforms (manipulating them seems better than mutilating them). There's no sense of justice when killing a simple beast. Give me space fascists with actual moral responsibilities, and let me try to win them back to the light at least once.

Combat is like a regular action-adventure game, with limited moves, timed actions and annoying enemy unblockable attacks that makes them glow red. Nowhere near as fun, creative or complex as the old Jedi Knight and Jedi Academy games, which had localized dismemberment, combinations, and "anything touching the sword takes damage" design, not "1 attack, 1 reaction". You are regualrly staggered by several enemies without meaningful chance to take command. It's just bad gameplay. Wait for the zombie scene where they deprive you of your weapon and you can't use the Force powers because you are constantly staggered by a swarm of green-eyed corpses.

Puzzles are fine, and dungeons / tombs are kinda cool, but not necessarily the most fun to play (for instance, it's hard to know where you aim with Force push / pull, when these are essential to solving the puzzle). Minimap is great flavor, but aweful design, switching levels randomly, and you have to retrace every level several times without any indicator, so you can't escape it. The rewards you find for exploring are snippets of Star Wars lore, and colors / skins (no exaggeration): color for the lightsaber handle, color for the ship, color for the droid, color for your... poncho. It's absurd.

Regarding progression, some parts were good, but mostly it was frustrating. Good things include killing groups of stormtroopers in villages, and some action sequences (sliding). On the bad side, a couple of times the game is taking your agency with a cutscene at the coolest moment. Why are they still doing this? Let me kill or release the boss that I just defeated in combat, or let me try to escape the laser beams of the ship that's chasing me. Very linear. Illusion of choosing which mission you do first, but no bearing on the story or equipment in the end. Soon the game doesn't even bother to make you choose destinations any more. Really makes you want to play some goofy but responsive first-person action RPG with lots of freedom.

Regarding the universe, the planets are iconic and varied, the atmosphere is one of the stronger aspect imo. A little bit bland characters, not terrible, but zero complexity or moral choice, and forget about being tempted or choosing the dark side, or grey Jedi path or anything. They talk about it but it's shallow ("Oh no, you lied to me about your padawan! Now I've got trust issues, but I'm also an orphan", "I could have saved him! If only I was better... But you were only a child!", etc.).

Mediocre Star Wars Sekiro. The level design and puzzles are easily the worst part about this game not to mention the many enemies that feel more annoying to beat than anything else. The bosses are decent but never challenge to the point of feeling super accomplished after beating them. Most of the time, I just felt lucky. I never felt inclined to do the exploration. The story is pretty good but there should be a way to skip cutscenes for those who want to play the game. I found myself checking my phone or getting something to eat, walking my dog, going to medschool, getting married, etc. instead of watching the cutscenes. There is an inherent issue with the parry system in that you cannot cancel an attack in the first couple of milliseconds, making parrying then attacking more rhythm than skill (not my favorite mechanic). It's a fine game to play on an easier difficulty but if you want a challenge due to difficult obstacles rather than worse luck/more finicky timing you will not find it here.

"Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order - A Galactic Adventure Worth the Hype"

"Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order," developed by Respawn Entertainment and published by Electronic Arts, stands as a triumphant addition to the Star Wars gaming universe. This action-adventure game successfully captures the essence of the beloved franchise, delivering an engaging story, thrilling lightsaber combat, and a richly detailed galaxy far, far away.

Compelling Narrative (5/5):
At its heart, "Jedi: Fallen Order" tells a captivating Star Wars story. You step into the boots of Cal Kestis, a young Jedi Padawan who survived Order 66. Cal's journey is an emotional and gripping one, as he navigates a galaxy under the oppressive rule of the Empire. The game's plot is filled with unexpected twists and memorable characters that contribute to its depth.

Authentic Star Wars Experience (5/5):
The attention to detail in "Jedi: Fallen Order" is astounding. From the meticulously designed planets to the faithfully recreated starships and creatures, the game feels like a genuine Star Wars adventure. The iconic sound design, including the humming of lightsabers and the roar of TIE fighters, adds to the immersion.

Satisfying Lightsaber Combat (5/5):
The lightsaber combat in this game is a standout feature. It's fluid, precise, and requires strategy, making you feel like a Jedi as you parry blaster bolts, unleash Force powers, and engage in intense duels with Inquisitors and Sith. The combat system is both challenging and rewarding, making each lightsaber clash a thrilling experience.

Exploration and Puzzles (4/5):
"Jedi: Fallen Order" offers a blend of exploration and puzzles reminiscent of classic action-adventure games. As Cal, you'll visit a variety of planets, each with its unique challenges and secrets to uncover. Solving puzzles and using your Force abilities to traverse obstacles adds depth to the gameplay.

Character Progression (4/5):
The game features a robust character progression system, allowing you to customize Cal's abilities and lightsaber. As you gain experience, you'll unlock new skills, which significantly impact your approach to combat and exploration. This progression system adds depth to the gameplay and encourages experimentation.

Technical Performance (4/5):
While the game's technical performance is generally solid, some players may encounter occasional bugs and glitches. However, these issues are minor and do not significantly detract from the overall experience.

Conclusion:
"Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order" is a triumphant return to form for Star Wars games. It captures the essence of the beloved franchise with a compelling narrative, authentic world-building, and thrilling lightsaber combat. Respawn Entertainment has masterfully crafted an adventure that feels right at home in the Star Wars universe. Whether you're a die-hard fan or a newcomer to the galaxy, "Jedi: Fallen Order" offers a memorable and immersive journey through a galaxy far, far away that's sure to satisfy your inner Jedi.

Giving this a thumbs up to encourage EA to steer away from the Dark Side.

Although this game crashed so often that I almost rage quit. I rarely play modern AAA games and this is a reminder why.

Its clear that this is a big budget game, with lots of polish everywhere. The graphics are great and capture the grand scale of those Star Wars movies. The sound and music was good although I missed that classic Star Wars theme! The voice acting was generally excellent with one exception you encounter late in the game.

The game was fairly well placed with good progression of skills. One negative is that it requires backtracking to complete the game as your new skills allow access to new areas, so it can get a bit tedious.

I played it on the second hardest difficulty and didn't have too many problems, although it felt that some of the enemies had unfair move sets where they could chain stun you. I get that it is trying to be Star Wars Dark Souls but the enemy design is not on the same level.

I would recommend this as long as it is stable enough for you to play. Apart from a few random crashes I had one spot where the came would reliably crash if I moved to a certain spot on the ship. Luckily I was able to continue the game and it resolved itself, but a game should not be released in this state.

I really enjoyed this.

Cal Kestis is a great edition to the lore as are the various characters you meet along the way.

The game looks great (A great game to show off your PC) and very well optimised, with a lot of level and enemy variety.
Some of the locations are fantastic and quite varied in design.
A fantastic soundtrack with alot of familer Star Wars strings and melodies.

Also worth noting this game has one of the best cameos in video game history, try not too let anyone spoil it for you.

Whilst not quite as good as the Jedi Outcast or Knights of the old Republic games i believe its in the top 5 best Star Wars games ever released.

A sequel would be very welcome.

Highly recommended.
