From a galaxy far, far away comes an extraordinary gaming experience that transcends time and space. Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order is a tour de force that beautifully fuses captivating storytelling, intricate gameplay mechanics, and stunning visuals to create an epic adventure that will resonate with fans of both the Star Wars universe and action-adventure gaming alike.

Set in the aftermath of Order 66, Jedi: Fallen Order follows Cal Kestis as he embarks on a quest to restore the Jedi Order while evading the clutches of the Galactic Empire. The narrative is rich, emotionally charged, and brimming with Star Wars lore. The characters are multifaceted, each with their own motivations and complexities. The plot twists and turns like a hyperspace jump, keeping players engaged from start to finish.
 
Jedi: Fallen Order delivers a visual spectacle that feels straight out of the cinematic Star Wars universe. The meticulously crafted environments, from the bustling streets of Nar Shaddaa to the ancient tombs of Zeffo, are a testament to the developers' attention to detail. Crisp textures, dynamic lighting, and realistic character models immerse players in a galaxy that's as captivating as it is authentic.

The heart of Jedi: Fallen Order lies in its exhilarating gameplay mechanics. The lightsaber combat is a true standout, seamlessly blending a mix of fluid strikes, parries, and force powers. The combat system strikes a balance between accessibility and depth, offering both novices and seasoned gamers a satisfying challenge. Each encounter feels like a choreographed dance, where mastering your abilities is key to overcoming even the most formidable foes.

One of the game's standout features is its meticulously designed levels that encourage exploration and reward curiosity. Each planet feels distinct, offering a range of environmental puzzles, secret passages, and hidden collectibles. Navigating these intricate landscapes is a joy, and the Metroidvania-style progression ensures a sense of accomplishment as new abilities unlock previously inaccessible areas.

Jedi: Fallen Order showcases decent optimization. With a variety of graphical settings, players can tailor the experience to their hardware capabilities. During gameplay, the game maintained a steady frame rate, and load times were impressively short, ensuring minimal interruptions to the immersive gameplay. The only real downside that I could find to playing this on PC was having to use the EA launcher and anyone who has used the EA launcher knows how bad it is. 

Jedi: Fallen Order seamlessly blends a compelling story with captivating gameplay mechanics. Its stunning visuals, exhilarating combat, and intricate level design set a new standard for Star Wars games. Whether you're a die-hard Star Wars fan or a gamer seeking an unforgettable adventure, this title is a must-play. May the Force be with you on this extraordinary journey across the stars.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I have tried and tried over the past few years to like this game, but for the life of me cannot get through it. As a player I place a lot of importance on writing and character complexity in single-player games, and this game seems to lack both of those quite a bit. Cal is very "pair of pants" and his portrayal and voicing is gratingly saccharine sometimes. All the other characters might as well not even be there. There's very little to connect to and drive you to engage with the story.

In my opinion this feeling of absence is also egged on by some aspects of the gameplay. I personally disagree with the choice to attach a lot of "soulslike" gameplay aspects to a Star Wars game. Things like respawning enemies, health potions, emphasis on blocking and dodging... they all take away from the environment and make finally beating a super hard enemy feel like a chore rather than an accomplishment.

4/10 game for me.

First off, there's a lot to like about Fallen Order; as a Star Wars story, it's fantastic and has a very likeable and memorable cast, the Mantis crew are a great group and Cal in particular is a very well rounded protagonist. The world design is wonderful and each location is beautifully crafted - and since I'm on the subject I may as well mention that as far as graphics and performance go, there's nothing to complain about here either. However, for all of these good points, the game has a few large and frustrating drawbacks.

What brings the game down for me is the gameplay loop and combat. I can appreciate the soulslike aspects of the game - long, winding levels with multiple checkpoints and shortcuts should have been a good thing; as a big fan of Dark Souls and other games in the genre,  learning enemy attack patterns, exploring sprawling levels and finding shortcuts should have been a fun time. However, the combat makes backtracking through each world a chore, which is only made worse by the absence of any kind of fast travel between meditation points. On paper the combat seems like something one could look forward to, but that's unfortunately not the case - attacks often seem ineffective which, considering Cal uses a lightsaber, makes little sense when you're fighting cannon fodder like stormtroopers. Dodges, blocks and parries are inconsistent, and while some enemies do require multiple parries to stagger, the fact that they can simply continue their attack chains despite being parried essentially makes the action feel useless. As for dodges and blocks, there are many cases where it doesn't seem to matter how good your timing is, you're going to get smacked around like a toy anyway, which becomes incredibly frustrating when you're up against multiple enemies that aren't immediately staggered by parries, can easily break through your blocks, or are resistant/able to counter your Force abilities.
While the combat makes backtracking incredibly frustrating, it also just doesn't feel like its worth the trouble a lot of the time. Fallen Order has a lot of sprawling maps with treasure hidden in hard to reach corners and such, however the effort needed to reach these treasures often feels unrewarding as 90% of these chests and hidden force echoes only unlock mediocre cosmetics

Overall I'd give the game a 6/10, with the positives largely resting on the story, characters and art direction. The combat's glaring inconsistencies, in addition to making the game generally frustrating to play, make backtracking and exploring a slog, and the lack of rewards for even bothering to explore the levels often makes you feel like you're wasting your time. I can only really recommend the game if you're already heavily invested in the Star Wars universe or have played Jedi Survivor ahead of this one

I'd like to start by saying this game is overrated, i did enjoy some of it especially at the begging but then you find yourself slowly repeating the same thing over and over with a few more enemies or one or two new ones. Then you do it again and again until you get bored.

 the awful combat system bothered me the whole game, i mean a game that took a lot of inspiration from Souls's games you would think it will have combat system similar to Skeiro but instead you get some poor arcade fighting movements and terrible parry mechanic not to mention some skills were useless and you barely use them if ever the entire game.
A nother thing to mention is the exploration in the game is not the best you can tell they tried to be like Uncharted or Tomb Rider but they weren't very successful at it, the map design was terrible and the tedious backtracking was a pain in the ass.
The story was Okey not very impressive though they can make it more entertaining its Star Wars after all so they could add a lot more to the story.

i do like to say the game has beautiful graphics and character design and acting (both physically and vocally) and you will get some kind of fun playing it particularly at the begging you will be interested but slowly start to wear you off with the bad combat and map designs. 

if this game will turn into a series then they better improve the combat a lot and a better map design, and maybe add lore from the Star Wars Saga to give the story more depth.

in conclusion, if you are a Star Wars fan then you probably will enjoy the game, and if you are not then maybe not too much because despite what others say you actually do need to watch the movies to have a better understanding of whats happening in the game.

overall i will give it 4/10

Fallen Order is a 3D metroidvania with souls-like elements. Sounds great on paper, at least for me, especially that it is set in the Star Wars universe. However, the game turns out to be a disappointing mess.

[h1]Combat[/h1]
It's generally okay, has some steep learning curve but once I got the hang of it I raised the difficulty to the highest and played through most of the game with relative ease, with some exceptions along the way. However, I have many issues with the combat.
[list]
[*]It feels really [b]clunky[/b] and [b]unresponsive[/b], resulting in a lot of frustrating moments which could be avoided if only Cal responded to the commands I was giving him. [b]Stable framerate[/b] is a must. 
[*][b]Unblockable attacks[/b] are too [b]inconsistent[/b]. Even if you react in time, there is no guarantee that you won't get hit. It's not a timing issue, because there were several times I perfectly dodged an unblockable (I know it's perfect because of the slow-motion effect from a late-game ability) just to get hit by the very same attack anyway. What's more, the unblockables are [i]tracking[/i] the player, presumably to punish you for dodging too early, but the tracking angle in some cases is insane. Finally, some of the unblockables have [i]very short wind up time[/i] combined with [i]huge damage[/i]. Overall, the concept of unblockable attacks is fine, but the implementation is bad in many cases.
[*]The combat system and most enemies were clearly designed for 1v1. [b]Fighting crowds is terrible.[/b] This is a problem especially in the beginning before you get the double-saber, but it gets worse again late-game when the game decides to throw at you entire armies of annoying weak enemies. It's not fun getting hit by a blaster outside your field of vision while you're trying to hit a closer enemy, it's not fun parrying/dodging already hard attacks just to not have an opportunity to counter attack after because there is already a queue of enemies waiting to hit you during your animation. It's simply [b]not fun to fight crowds[/b] in this game. Even when I win without a scratch, it feels like I cheesed the fight and/or got lucky, not satisfying at all.
[/list]
The hardest content in this game amplifies all the combat issues. The last boss is a big jump of difficulty, but for all the wrong reasons mentioned above. An unblockable which has a very short wind up time, is very inconsistent to dodge, and which one shots you when you have anything less than about 90% of health. Two times during the encounter, the boss spawns a flying droid and spams unblockables on the other side of the map. Depending on the timing of the unblockable and the droid shooting, which mostly depends on luck, it is literally impossible to not get hit. The last boss overall is one of the worst bosses I've ever seen in a video game. Not the hardest, not at all, it's just badly designed. The devs apparently wanted to lock you out of the ending to feel you "earned it". I think most people are just going to ditch the game out of frustration or lower the difficulty, but maybe I'm wrong.

Post-game optional arenas are terrible because they mix together a lot of seemingly random enemies which should never be combined together. Especially when you put together the ones designed for 1v1 with the crowds. The arenas show all the issues with fighting crowds in this game. You have barely any way to deal with multiple enemies other than running, dodging, and getting a single hit here and there, on repeat, which makes for a very boring and long fight. Big crowds of random enemies kill all the fun and creativity of the combat system.

[h1]Exploration[/h1]
Outside of combat, it turns out [b]most of the game time you will spend on mediocre platforming[/b] and searching for collectibles in ugly, confusing, and illogical environments. As a reward, you'll usually get some obscure Star Wars lore, which I bet most people don't care about much, a lightsaber part which you barely notice while playing, or another god damn poncho. The main reward for me was actually the experience points, and the fact I feel the urge to 100% games for some reason. Otherwise, I wouldn't bother.

The game is not particularly pretty either, the environments are [b]dull[/b]. It's not that the graphics is bad, there is a lot of detail, but the art style... is not pretty. What's more, the [b]levels feel empty and artificial[/b]. 
There's not a lot of friendly/neutral NPCs, and when there are, they are just standing there. It feels like there is almost nothing but enemies and the MC in the whole galaxy. Maps don't feel like they could be real places in SW universe, they are weird and gamey. Seriously, how are imperial soldiers and other normal people traversing through the maps, if I need to use the Force, special equipment, and a lot of acrobatics just to get from one room to the next?! And they are somehow already there on the barely accessible and very dangerous platform without railings I just spent half an hour climbing up to? Even for Star Wars standards, the levels barely make any sense, killing my suspension of disbelief. The only [b]good[/b] thing I can say about exploration is the [b]puzzles[/b], they felt like how the tombs in new Tomb Raiders should've been done. Unfortunately, there is only a couple of them.

The [b]plot is not particularly interesting[/b] either. It's fine, and gets better with time, but I didn't really care. I didn't get attached to any of the characters, except the droid perhaps. The most interesting were from Dathomir, but they were not given enough screen time. It also bothers me a little how many Jedi turn out to be alive after Order 66, but I guess it's a vast galaxy after all, so it's not that impossible.

[h1]Summing up[/h1]
I can't bring myself to recommend this game. I felt like I had to force myself to play it when I started, and even after I got hooked, most of the game annoyed me. What pushed me forward was mainly the desire to "git gud" and the fact it's Star Wars. [b]Remove the Star Wars part, and you get a very mediocre Tomb Raider with souls-like combat, at best.[/b] Playable? Yes. Enjoyable even? I guess. If you have to play it, I can only recommend playing on lower difficulty to avoid at least the combat frustrations, even though I consider combat to be the best part. I must say, I am glad it's over, and I probably won't touch the sequel for a while as it's probably just more of the same.

[b]A modest amount of enjoyment served up with a heaping helping of irritation and aggravation[/b]

I think I must have not done my usual research before buying this game, because if I had I don't think I would have bought it. The combat is Sekiro, the save mechanics are Dark Souls, and the level system is Metroidvania. So, you have very tricky combat with a high level of difficulty which practically requires you fight the same foe over and over again until you memorize their attack routines, a save system that doesn't let you save when you want but rather when you encounter one of the few-and-far-between save points and punishes you when you die by sending you back to the last save point, respawning all the monsters you just killed *and* taking away all the experience you just earned; and to top it off you have impenetrably maze-like levels with less-than-helpful maps. A triumvirate of rage-inducement, all with a coat of Star Wars paint.

So, why not just give this a thumbs-down? Well, two things. Other than what I just mentioned, the game was quite enjoyable. It's nice to look at (hardly cutting-edge graphically but some good character and level design), and the story and writing is pretty good. I especially appreciated that it was a Star Wars story that mostly stood on its own without being encumbered by fan service and 'memberberries (at least until the very end when [spoiler] the writers felt the need for the eye-rolling inclusion of Darth Vader - [i]so[/i] disappointing[/spoiler]).

And the other thing? Easy Mode Exists. After the 6th or so go-round with the first boss battle without getting anywhere close to finishing it (not realizing at the time that I actually was close because I only needed to get them to half-health, oh well) I swallowed my pride, switched the game to Story Mode, and got right through the battle with zero irritation. And that became my standard MO: progress through the game on Normal mode, enduring my fair share of rage at the game's various "features", bump the difficulty down to Easy for the boss fights to spare my poor controller from getting hurled against the wall, bump back up, carry on. Hardly an innovative approach, but regardless it worked.

So if you're looking for a single-player Star Wars game, you could do worse than this. But caveat emptor, my friend. Caveat emptor. Rage awaits.

The game is rather challenging to play, not necessarily due to its inherent difficulty, but mainly due to its unresponsiveness and numerous glitches.

While the story is not terrible, it isn't the best either. In certain areas, it appears forced, with little to no character development. Don't misunderstand me, the protagonist's voice is incredibly annoying, but that can be rectified with a few modifications.

What renders the game nearly unplayable, however, are the control issues. The controls frequently fail to respond when activated. You might press keys and experience either no response or significant delay before an action is carried out. Consequently, in a game reliant on timing and skillful control use, it becomes almost impossible to evade attacks or block them. You might attempt to block, but nothing happens until after your enemy's attack connects, and then your character attempts to block. This often leads to significant health loss, and there isn't much you can do about it.

Moreover, your enemies can attack you while you're hitting them. This makes it doubly difficult to dodge some attacks as your character is in the middle of striking them. Since the enemies don't recoil, they hit you before you can even move, leaving cheesing the game AI and playing oddly to circumvent these issues as the only viable strategies.
good game

I imagine people liked this pretty mediocre and generic adventure game because the last 3 Star Wars games under EA before it were so horribly flawed. And a barely working, boring, and generic mix of every indie game on the market with a Star Wars skin was just incredible? 

Whether it be both Battlefronts that have known issue lists that are years long even before the updates with entire chunks missing, or boring flight sim games that are blatantly a minimum viable product, to mobile slot machine games. Yeah, this was the breaking point for me. I signed out.

This is all Star Wars is ever going to be. Apathy. And Apathy is death.

So to start let's talk about the graphics. They somehow got worse than 2017 Battlefront 2 (BF2), which slammed the saturation to max, smeared lens flares, and eye straining vignettes everywhere in an attempt to look better when it looked better as an almost photorealistic movie without all of that in 2015 Battlefront. 

The best looking things are the Stormtroopers, which clearly use the old photoscanned models from Dice's games, and look strangely higher quality and out of place. Everything looks incredibly mushy and like scratched play-doh. I think when Force Unleashed 2 (TFU2) had sharper and more impressive looking effects and textures to me, that says everything right there. A 2 hour long Xbox 360 game from 2010 looked much nicer and was more fun. You could stop reading now, and that'd summarize so much of this, but let's go on.

Gameplay. It's very boring. I feel like a wild monkey as opposed to an untrained Jedi. My attacks feel flat and lack impact due to some strange delusion that human characters cannot be dismembered due to the rating? So chopping up robot arms on human characters and wild animals minding their own business into pieces isn't more violent? Yeah meanwhile, Force Unleashed 1 and 2 had dismemberment and were T rated. No one cared.

You barely use the force. Ever. You are so heavily limited by some stupid overheat bar yet again like it's a chastity belt. Like the other EA Star Wars games, I give none of them a pass for this mechanic, either give me more uses or remove it and use the Jedi Knight or TFU systems. Swallow your pride. I am a Jedi. I'm going to act like one any way I want. That includes using the Force.

On the topic of enemies, they did mostly well here.

Enemies kept the one good thing from TFU and other Star Wars games, they are very vocal and act appropriately when being blasted away with a force push or the only one left. Yelling in fear or running for their lives. And there's also a lot of them, and they feel very menacing. And there's a good variety of bad guys. Good job, I expect that. Too bad they're not fun to fight when I'm wearing a chastity belt.

The combat is like Dark-Souls, but with most of the fun subclasses and interesting RPG upgrade paths missing. And as someone who has played those games before, I can tell you this is the biggest fault of this game. Dark Souls always gives you tons of ways to break the game and get stupidly powerful, which means you can basically negate the challenge entirely by exploiting engine jank and shoddy programming, or find organic tools and methods to overcome a challenge, and this has led to countless debates, that it's a meme with every new release.

But that's the fun of a game like Dark Souls. This fun part has been blatantly removed here. It's gone and replaced with a chastity belt. "No fun allowed in the Star Wars game, otherwise it might shatter our fragile egos here at Respawn." Might as well be this game's motto. If you were to repeat any game's mistakes, I hope it would've been leaving that fun jank in, but no, it's copy pasting the crappy upgrade system from TFU2. Of course.

So what about the story? Well, the story would've been better if I didn't have to play this boring trash, but in isolation, it's not terrible. But it's not good either.

So immediately, you start by dismantling giant ships in a scrapyard. (Sometimes foreshadowing is very obvious.) And you climb through a bunch of incredibly nonsensical gamey looking platforming sections on this clearly unsafe ship, which I'm actually fine with since it's a tutorial. It's pretty fun. They even reference Nar Shadda from TFU. I approve, good start.

Then you and your friend find a Jedi Starfighter on the side of a cruiser, and you both fall due to a cable breaking. Which makes you use the force to save your friend from dying. And immediately, an Imperial Droid sees this. Which is where the pacing of this mission goes to die. Apparently the Empire is made of Endermen from Minecraft, and they immediately find you and your friend.

Your friend is killed, and you are pushed on to a train. Which was incredibly disappointing to see EA make another game where they pull this impatient crap with the Empire basically stopping anyone from ever developing as a character, like 2017 BF2 or TFU2 yet again. 

However, the following escape section is very good. And again acted as a great tutorial, that if not for being a little gamey looking, it was very tense and action packed. A stranger in an odd ship pulls up next to the train to help you escape, but she has to take out the Tie Fighters first, and tells you to keep moving. Eventually you are cornered by a Sith, and are forced to face her in a one on one duel.

And on that note, something these games have consistently done well is the music. And this is no exception. You feel completely outmatched as she zooms around you like a Death Eater from Harry Potter. You and her clash, and then you escape as the stranger rescues you. I still don't know what it's going to ever take to just get a full game that's like the opening section of this. Because after this, it was all downhill. We go to Shrek's Swamp, and it's full of Pokemon and giant frogs. And I've lost all interest. We are now chasing ghost balls we'll never use like every stupid Jedi story Disney has made.

The rest of the game is autopilot filler where the only good thing is that it ends. It plays and looks like a janky Uncharted clone made in 2012 ported to Xbox One, because it is. The story itself is such a slog to get through, so I'll give you the highlights from now on.

-There's a big funny frog in Shrek's swamp who farts in a cave and is the only tough fight in the game aside from a cheap shot difficulty spike at the end
-You Fight AT-STs that have worse animations than 2015 Battlefront
-You fight Purge Troopers that aren't as cool as TFU, but are just ok (Probably because Dice made them for BF2 and never used them)
-You fight on Kashyyyk alongside Saw Gurerra to free Wookies, which was a much better sounding premise for this game that I would've preferred (More on that later.)
-You go to Malastare and fight a Grey Jedi, which was probably one of the coolest places to go in a game like this. 
-You also befriend a witch. They include her more than I thought they would've. But she doesn't get much development.
-You go to the planet where Starkiller Base would one day be built. That alone could have been the most interesting place to go with the story and talk about the history of the Jedi and explore their origins, too bad!
-There are some order 66 flashbacks, which are the best parts, and look better than most of the game?
-Cal has a cool force sense ability.

So closing thoughts. If this game had focused on Cal and his friend joining Saw Guerra, and struggling with his past of being a Jedi during Order 66, that would've fixed it for me. I wanted to be part of an adventure, and do something cool, which is why I liked Star Wars games. But this game focuses too much on boring crap, and struggles to be mediocre. There are very few exciting moments, and you're constantly punished for wanting to have fun as Cal is cut short from developing at every turn. Simply put, I cannot recommend this game. There is more bad than good in it. And it killed my interest in this IP. Apathy is death.

[h1][strike]9.5/10[/strike] 7.5/10 (see edit)[/h1]

Immersive Star Wars game with a deep story. Its like an improved version of KTOR. The movement and atmosphere feels a lot like a Dead Space game (just without the horror), and the skill system is reminiscent of Assassins Creed

That said, there are quite a few minute details that break immersion. Such as all AT-ST's spawned at the same time will walk in the same timing; while walking or running, the light saber does not cut through objects like it does when you attack; and player movement matches the camera, not player orientation (so if the player is climbing but the camera is at an angle, the player will jump parallel to the camera).

[h2]EDIT: I have three points to make[/h2]

(1) [b]The game is not designed to be played on the Jedi Grand Master (hardest) difficulty.[/b] Some of the boss fights are obviously designed to be "really challenging" for even the easier difficulties. When you play the game on the hardest difficulty, its next to impossible unless you are perfect or get lucky and find some way to exploit the mechanics. To top that, the checkpoints aren't always forgiving for the challenging stuff and [b]the loading times to respawn can be horendous depending on the location in game.[/b] I kind of want to try Dark Souls once I finish this game.

(2) [b]This game is super buggy.[/b] I think if someone played this on the "Story Mode" difficulty, they wouldn't encounter these bugs because they wouldn't have to exploit mechanics to complete the game, but man is this game has some serious issues. Aforementioned in my previous point, you have to play outside the box if you are playing with the most difficult difficulty. Therefore, you will encounter bugs with the AI. Some example, (a) a mob touching a wall and then flying up into the ceiling and out of the world, (b) mobs simply walking or jumping off ledges, (c) mobs not "activating" all at once even in small rooms. So if you enter a small room, one Stormtrooper might come to you but the rest will just watch and shout at you. These are just three of the bugs. I've been recording my play through, and [b]thus far, I've encountered roughly 20 unique common bugs that either break the game, make the game easier, or ruin the experience/immersion.[/b]

(3) [b]The default PC controls are pretty bad.[/b] I changed the key binding to be similar to Battlefront II (2017). Here is what I changed:
[table]
	[tr]
		[th]Action[/th]
		[th]Key[/th]
	[/tr]
	[tr]
		[td]Evade[/td]
		[td]L Alt[/td]
	[/tr]
	[tr]
		[td]Interact[/td]
		[td]G[/td]
	[/tr]
	[tr]
		[td]Droid Interact[/td]
		[td]V[/td]
	[/tr]
	[tr]
		[td]Heal[/td]
		[td]L Ctrl[/td]
	[/tr]
	[tr]
		[td]Slow[/td]
		[td]Q[/td]
	[/tr]
	[tr]
		[td]Push[/td]
		[td]E[/td]
	[/tr]
	[tr]
		[td]Pull[/td]
		[td]R[/td]
	[/tr]
[/table]

tl;dr This is a good, long game, but man is it buggy and unforgiving.

TLDR: Unless you are an EA fanboy and love the EA App, buy this on PS5 or X Box only.

Game is great, absolutely one of the best Star Wars games I've ever played.  It's a star wars game that plays like Dark Souls/Elden Ring in some respects.  If you like Star Wars, and Dark Souls/Elden Ring, you will love this game.  The music is incredible, the sound effects are incredible, extremely familiar to source material.  You can really get a feel for being a Jedi.  Enjoy!

The problem is on PC you have to install the EA app, despite the fact I bought this on Steam.  It wasn't like that when I first bought it, but it is now.  Cause FUCK Electronic Arts.  This isn't the first time EA has tried to screw with legitimate customers.   Sometime after Dragon Age Origins came out, EA launched the Origin platform, and pulled all their products from Steam.... after people bought the game on Steam.  Forcing those people that bought the game on one platform, (probably because they didn't want Origin or the EA app), to have to install TWO platforms on their PC to play the game.

Electronic Arts.  You keep forcing your products/apps on customers that nobody wants, you won't have any customers anymore.  I stopped buying Battlefield games after Battlefield 4, (thought mostly cause they are not fun anymore), I don't buy Dragon Age games on PC anymore after Origins, I don't buy Mass Effect games on PC, I don't buy your cash grab SIMS games at all, I only obtain Need for Speed games for massive discounts or during free deals.  I've obtained most of the recent release EA games for free because of either EPIC games store weekly free deals, or PlayStation Plus membership free game downloads.  I'm all for competition in the market, but your products, specifically Origin and the EA App, are worse than the competitors that came before you, AND after you.  EA is so out of touch with the market they are actively trying to ruin.  Also, STOP putting micro transactions into games!  Triple A titles that cost $60-$70 do not need this toxic cash grab mechanic.  Your game is NOT free!  You made enough money off the sales!

As a huge fan of the Soulsborne games, it's pretty fun. I wouldn't really call it a Soulslike though. More of a Metroidvania with Soulslike elements (which is not an issue at ALL as far as I'm concerned, I love Metroidvanias too and Soulslikes likely wouldn't exist without them). So I'm just gonna write this as a review of why I think this ISN'T a Soulslike. Keep in mind I still recommend it. 

-less punishing in general. there are difficulty options and you don't lose acquired skill points when you die. also seems like so far the bosses aren't that big of a deal. also, stamina is not consumed by rolling which is a big deal for sure. also falling into a pit doesn't kill you, just hurts you, which is a godsend with the climbing and platforming that pops up as an occasional anoyance

-more focus on parrying, at least to be most effective. reminds me of Sekiro with the posture bars that decay with more parries. 

-completely different level up method where you don't increase stats but get new abilities and power up the abilities you do have. also ability unlocks that fundamentally change how the game plays (e.g. the first major one, Wall Running)

-a huge lack of weapon variety, which is fine, but to me Soulslikes have more than three options. plus you can switch it up on the fly. 

-the map is very different, still coiled up like a good Soulslikes with lots of shortcuts and stuff, but more focused on new traversal methods than skillchecks. plus it has a holomap straight out of Metroid Prime, which is very non-Soulslike imo.

-more focus on story and characters, with cutscenes and all. Cal even narrates a lot of what he's doing or talks to his droid companion. a much more talkative game.

-fashion kinda sucks ass. only can change poncho and outfit colors, no real customization unfortunately. fashion souls is endgame, after all. you can change up how your lightsaber looks quite a bit, but I can hardly see the thing in game so it's hard to care that much outside of color. 

So yeah it's definitely closer to something like Metroid Prime than any Fromsoft Soulsborne game, just something to know going into it. Still a ton of fun.

I am pleasantly surprised. I waited to purchase this game for a long time; eventually picked it up on sale and then sat around with it due to it not running properly on Linux. Proton finally pulled through (for me) some time this past year.

My initial thoughts before playing the game were dour due to Star Wars fans around the interwebs basically shitting on the game and its story. And I can say that, from my perspective, they're wrong. Now, it's no Knights of the Old Republic, I thought the story was pretty straight forward and easily digestible. The gameplay was nothing new - if you've played Assassin's Creed or Dark Souls, you pretty much already know the controls - it suited the style of the game quite well. Also, as someone who believes game developers are trying to milk open-world games for all their worth (yet being so very shallow), this was a nice change of pace with the semi-open semi-linear style. I think this was the best choice for the game.

I do have a few issues with the game itself, but they're quite minor irritations rather than big problems (#JusticeForTheWookieDesign).

Now requires an online connection and signing into EA launcher. For a single player game this is unacceptable. Also no dismemberment system where your energy swords can cut off people's limbs like in previous Star Wars games from years prior!

[h1]Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ (5/5)[/h1]

STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order‚Ñ¢ is a triumphant return to the single-player Star Wars adventure genre, offering an immersive and emotionally charged experience that captures the essence of the beloved franchise. With its engaging storyline, thrilling lightsaber combat, and well-crafted world-building, it stands as one of the finest Star Wars games of its time.

[h1]Likes:[/h1]

Compelling Storytelling: Jedi: Fallen Order‚Ñ¢ follows the journey of Cal Kestis, a young Jedi on the run from the Empire. The captivating narrative, filled with twists and turns, explores the struggle between the light and dark sides of the Force, drawing players into a tale of adventure and redemption.

Satisfying Lightsaber Combat: The lightsaber combat is a highlight of the game, offering fluid and impactful duels that make players feel like true Jedi warriors. The combat mechanics strike a perfect balance between challenge and reward.

Well-Designed Planets: The game's planets are beautifully designed and diverse, offering a sense of wonder and exploration. Each location is filled with secrets, puzzles, and lore, creating an immersive and engaging world.

Intuitive Exploration and Metroidvania Elements: As players progress through the game, Cal gains new abilities that unlock previously inaccessible areas, adding a rewarding Metroidvania aspect to the gameplay.

Loyal to Star Wars Lore: Jedi: Fallen Order‚Ñ¢ respects the rich Star Wars lore and introduces new characters and elements that seamlessly fit into the existing canon.

[h1]Dislikes:[/h1]

Occasional Technical Glitches: Some players may encounter minor technical issues, such as occasional frame rate drops or texture pop-ins, but they do not significantly detract from the overall experience.

Limited Customization Options: While the game offers some cosmetic customization for Cal's appearance, some players may desire more extensive character customization features.

In conclusion, STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order‚Ñ¢ is a brilliant and thrilling Star Wars adventure that fulfills the dreams of fans longing for a single-player Jedi experience. With its compelling story, satisfying lightsaber combat, and expertly crafted world, it delivers an authentic and emotionally resonant journey in a galaxy far, far away. Whether you're a long-time Star Wars enthusiast or new to the franchise, Jedi: Fallen Order‚Ñ¢ promises an unforgettable and epic adventure as you take on the role of a young Jedi seeking to restore the Order and face the trials of the Force. May the Force be with you on this captivating journey.

They have done a great job with this game! Truly great storytelling that does the Star Wars franchise justice, especially since it is set after the prequel trilogy and after the Emperor"s Order 66, leading to the demise of the Jedi. To create a great story combined with amazing metroidvania/soulslike elements of gameplay, truly remarkable. The crew are no-named characters new to Star Wars, and with all of the movies, spin-offs, animated series, to get the player to care about them in my opinion  was the most difficult feat of this game. Happy to say that they achieved this strongly, and a second game in this series is certainly going to have a very high bar to meet. Good luck Respawn, & after Titanfall 2, I'm a firm believer that you have what is needed to make the massive sequel to Jedi Fallen Order!

Fallen Order is a game with excellent production values that mixes metroidvania world design with a combat system inspired by Dark Souls. Indeed, it is as awesome as it sounds.

The worlds you will be visiting are quite varied, and labyrinthic in their design. There are collectables for those of us that enjoy collecting, enviromental puzzles for those that enjoy to be puzzled, and cool new combat moves for those that enjoy being cool. The characters are nice and the story is engaging, which is a refreshing thing for Star Wars lately. The music could be very well signed by John Williams, and there are some truly memorable set pieces.

Now, the thing to keep in mind is that the first two thirds of the game are the most infuriating cavalcade of bullcrap you will ever experience. Enemies soft lock to you when you dodge so they hit you anyways, your attacks dont interrupt them but they interrupt you, even your heals!, there is an embarrassing amount of -gotcha pulls with enemies purposely hidden to kill you, and most of the combat will be against multiple enemies, but you wont get the skills to effectively fight against them until, you guessed it, two thirds into the story.

Thats when it opens up, and with all your powers you truly feel like a Jedi. The game is not that long, so its not devastating to put up with the first half of the game until it gets good. The great parts are great enough to make you forget the bad.

Of course, since this is EA we are talking about, I recommend it only at a discount.

A game with a decent storyline, great graphics, characters and a great world setting but it gets very repetitive and I find myself not able to push through the game after a while. I have often tried to give it another shot but it just gets boring after 20 minutes of gameplay because most of the time you are running around maps  with clearly defined predetermined paths, while also dealing with uncharted style puzzles. Sometimes you get to beat some annoying enemies which also are repetitive because you can learn their attacks quite easily, with the occasional bossfight. 

I feel this game would have been great ten years back when I would have been younger, because it seems like it follows the same techniques as a lot of older games, differing just by scale, graphics, dialogue and characters. Would not recommend.

Lots of climbing, rope swinging and exploration. Not that much fighting and the fighting that you end up doing is underwhelming because you are fighting storm troopers or easy to kill monsters who got no chance against a lightsaber user (I played on Jedi Master difficulty btw). 

I did not like the mechanic of finding cosmetic loot boxes but recovering in-game lore was cool. It would have been even cooler if all the lore was done with cutscenes instead of reading, but I guess that would be too expensive for them. 

The last fight was very good. I enjoyed fighting other lightsaber users. The sound track is really good. 

The overall story felt a bit disjointed and unimpactful. It seemed to me that the game was incomplete. Also seems poorly optimized. Random frame drops were prevalent. 

Overall, an okay game. Get it at sale.

Very good game. Definitely worth playing.

It's good. It's not great, which is a shame, because I can clearly see that it had the potential to be great, but it stumbles too often to be better than good.

First, the combat. It's at its best when you're mowing down hordes of weak enemies, particularly stormtroopers. Basic stormtroopers are a joy to fight, running through them, tearing them apart while deflecting blaster bolts back at ranged troopers. Fighting tougher enemies starts to get not as good. It's not too bad when they're solo, but when you have a purge trooper accompanied by other enemies, it's kind of a pain. You never feel like you quite have the control over the flow of battle that you should. 

Parrying is rather frustrating, as it seems random whether you'll have to just parry one attack before you can riposte, or if you'll have to parry a series of attacks. Feels bad man. Bosses are okay, but force powers feel next to useless against them most of the time, which is irritating. Lightsaber combat is fun, but you're a Jedi. You should be able to use force powers to good effect against more than just rank and file enemies.

Still, even with the issues, combat still averages out to be pretty good. It could just be a lot better.

Second, exploration. Again, good, not great. There's plenty of secrets to find, and mostly finding them feels good, but rarely do you get anything that feels substantial. Most secrets are either a skin or a bit of lore, with very rare parts of an upgrade to health or force power, or even better, a new stim canister. All the secrets come with a bit of XP, too, which is helpful, but even with that, the skins and lore feel like very underwhelming rewards. I started the game exploring pretty thoroughly, but once I finished the last visit to Kashyyyk, I stopped going out of my way to explore and just sped through the rest of the game. I would definitely not recommend 100%-ing this one, just explore as much as you find fun, and when it stops being fun, move on. There's just not enough worth pushing through to find it all.

Third, the story. Again, pretty good, but not quite great. Voice acting is quite solid, the story is interesting but doesn't feel like anything particularly special. I liked the characters, and in particular liked Merrin, but we definitely did not get enough time with her. Cal and Cere had pretty solid character arcs, as well. No real complaints about the story, just didn't stand out enough to be more than good. Very good, even.

Fourth, sound and visuals. As I mentioned, the voice acting is solid. Sound design and OST are good throughout the game. The visuals are nice, but lighting had some weird glitchiness in many, many places. Nothing that made the game unplayable, but very noticeable.

Now, for some nitpicks. First, holy Mass Effect elevators Batman. Some of them are looooooooong. Kind of ridiculous. Platforming is mostly fine, but there were enough times where jumps failed or wall climbs failed to initiate or the camera slid into horrible angles (particularly during sliding sections) that it definitely merits mention. The map is bound to BD-1, so is unavailable when he is not with you, or when climbing or underwater. Very annoying. UNSKIPPABLE CUTSCENES EVERYWHERE. If you put unskippable cutscenes in your game, you should be fired. Out of a cannon. Into the sun.

Nitpicks aside, the game still averages out to be good. I would definitely recommend it for fans of Star Wars, 3D action combat platformers, and metroidvanias. Just... don't 100% it. Just don't.

[h1]Amazing game![/h1] Never have I thought that I would like it so much. Even though I was playing it on mouse&keyboard. Interesting story and plot, that has become canonical, fascinating data bank and tactical guide, exciting fights and enemies, intriguing detailed unique planets, and even the irritating, but quite realistic system with steam taking or attack blocking delay - altogether have made this game so good. Of course there are little strange things, like underwater animation of chests opening, re spawning of destroyed objects after resting, and especially uncomfortable and strange inability to roll off the platforms. Also there are some little bugs, like definitely imperfect sliding. But these little problems are so insignificant, that just can not in any way affect the overall impression. 

The fairest [b]9/10[/b]!

PS and the cherry on top was the possibility of meditation training after the end of this game. 
Thank you and May the Force be with you!

So I start by saying I like Action Adventure games, and I like Star Wars, so I got this to satisfy those 2 passions I have.

I just finished this game main storyline, and I'd say it is a mah game. the story is good, but the gameplay is a bit more desiring:
- There are no fast-travel points: you have to get back track all the way to return to the ship after reaching the far end of a mission, and you get lost many times. The holomap is not clear and cumbersome. Many of those time when I get lost, the map doesn't help, no indications in game which way to go. I went many times the wrong way for really a long time (repeating the same puzzles to reach a point) to find it is not the right way. I had to go to walkthrough videos many times.
- (I come from many many hours of Assassin's Creed game, where you can climb anything, here climbing even the simplest cliffs is not available.)
- Even now after year of the release of the game it still has many bugs, I got stuck in some places due to bugs in moving and collision detection.
- There are many sections in each planet that are unreachable at some points of the play, but will be accessible once you get a new skill and come back to that planet. I personally hate this in games, as I never re-play a game or go back to complete it 100% after I finished the main storyline (I have many many games in my backlog, there is no time to replay games), I am not a completionist.
- The game length is good (short compared to other Action Adventure games), but due to the above annoyances I mentioned I would have stopped playing if it was a longer game.

I love the story but the combat and encounters are so poorly designed around each other.  Going back through areas at the end of the game when you've unlocked everything is cool - you can realise how many tools they gave you to deal with the enemies, but before you get those powers and upgrades, you're just charging and hoping.

A perfect example is the double-bladed lightsaber.  The game explicitly tells you it's your main tool for engaging with groups and yet they give it to you so late in the game, after you've faced off against groups for hours with no fun way to deal with them, either be reckless and get lucky or bait out fights one at a time, and they also give it to you immediately before a one-on-one duel!  What?

I can only recommend playing on Jedi Knight difficulty at max until you've unlocked everything, then start playing the real game at whatever difficulty you feel comfortable with.

I wanted to love this game so badly, now halfway (ish) through the campaign I am just disliking the gameplay more than I was when I started. Disclaimer being it may just be a skill issue but I digress. I love Star Wars and want to say upfront that the story is amazing, however I find the gameplay to be frustrating. You can only save at designated save stations which is frustrating when you die in a boss battle and need to run from that save point to die and  run over again. The actual combat mechanics are ok but not super complex. At the time of writing this review I was stuck on the fist "real" boss fight with the second sister. Seeing her do cool spin moves and jumps and lunges make me wonder if those moves are in the skill tree and when I'll get far enough to do these cool maneuvers. You can't. It does make me feel like a student but the boss just seems too challenging (again maybe skill issue). I also find that the map is hard to read so when going from location to location I'll end up getting lost or going in a circle, even more frustrating is getting to a puzzle room and the real puzzle is figuring out what the puzzle is. The puzzles don't seem intuitive to me which then becomes frustrating once more.  A game that does similar things but better in my own opinion is God of War 2018. It has great combat, puzzling but not unreasonable puzzles, and a fantastic story. In short I can't recommend the gameplay but can recommend the story.

Update: Okay, VERY good game, but I maintain that it's very poorly optimized for PC and can only recommend it if your rig greatly exceeds the recommended system requirements.

Good game, but terribly optimized. I meet or exceed the RECOMMENDED requirements, but it still overheats my computer and restarts it after 30-45 minutes even on the minimum graphics settings. Meanwhile, I can run Doom Eternal with everything but Texture Pool Size cranked up to Ultra Nightmare with neither lag nor overheating. There's no excuse for such poor performance. Maybe get the console version, (it feels kind of like Star Wars Dark Souls on the higher difficulties, in a good way) but don't bother with the PC version unless you have a massively overpowered gaming rig that has liquid cooling or something. It'll roast your GPU no matter how much you turn the settings down if you have a standard fans+thermal paste cooling solution.

It also installs than annoying EA app that replaced Origin against your will, and requires a workaround to run without it. That's a hindrance of all EA games that most of us are used to, however.

Developer Respawn builds a Star Wars adventure that constantly reminds me why I fell in love with the Skywalker saga as a child. Fallen Order is a love letter to the classic trilogy, respects the clone wars, and shows me the dark era of the Empire like no other Star Wars story before.

Well, I think it was a bit underwhelming with all the hype built trough the last years. For a triple A title it still has bugs that are not game breaking but still annoying to see (those frogs just feel designed so sloppy), AI is often confused, gameplay features a lot of walking throughout areas with nothing much more, especially in the first part of the game. It just gets boring to travel to one corner of the map and then struggle again to come back to the start to the Mantis ship. 
Story feels superficial to me. It feels a bit flat and linear - is Cal learning to become jedi master, is he trying to stop inquistors one by one, is he joining the Rebels (which we see but are there just as an easter egg) - none of this gets built on and he is what is called a Pollyana - A character who is always optimistic no matter what may happen to them. Which is not bad as an idea but there's nothing more than that, which is why it feels boring.
Anyway, cinematics are executed very nicely and the visuals are great but big studios like EA like to lower standarts for starved for games fandoms like Star Wars (which for good or bad I'd like to count myself in :D) by releasing minimal quality-effort-put-in games (Battlefront 1 - eh, Battlefront 2 - lootboxes, Battlefront 2 updated - cut out from development in the middle of nowhere, Star Wars Eclipse - just a trailer, no actual game in development despite announcement which trailer was even made by outsource movie company not familiar with games, somewhere in South-East Asia, Squadrons - nobody heard or played it). My expectations might be too high but I can't call a boring game, great fun and "best Star Wars game since Disney bought the franchise" just because the other new SW game titles are "okay", does not make this one great.
Looking forward to Survivor, hopefully it is bigger in terms of design.

It's a great addition to the Star Wars franchise and for those who haven't tried any Star Wars games and want to play the role of a Jedi, then this is the game for you.

The gameplay is fantastic, the lightsaber combat, while minimalist, really pays off as you unlock more of the skills that Cal seeks to regain.

The enemies are diverse and even though there are only about five planets, it is filled with such life and little details that you can't help but feel immersed into it.

The best of this game is that even though it has a requirement of 60+ gigabytes to download, it can affordable run in any types of PC. Heck, I only have a GTX1060 and a Core i7 Intel processors, but I could relatively play it at 60fps, if you ignore the bits and pieces of framedrops, here and there.

Overall, the game is worth buy, considering that it's always on sale, and it's a great game to start out if you want to jump in to the Galaxy Far Far Away.

If you enjoy a star wars game. Get this. If you enjoy a game with a "Souls - Like " experience,  look for another game. Jedi Fallen Order is nonetheless a game that pays tribute to its star wars fans, by showing you environments that feel like it belongs in star wars, combat that makes you fight and feel like a cool jedi, and has a well told story that sets it up nicely for part 2. However....It does come with its set of issues, especially in the game/combat design and game direction and level design. For example, you can be done doing a mission and now all of the sudden you have to crawl, and navigate yourself going all the way back to where you came from or sometimes you fight like a cool Jedi Master, only to be Indiana Jones the next second. Trying to solve tedious and unnecessary puzzles. For the most part 65% of the game is just you climbing, running, jumping, exploring and doing puzzles and 35% of it is just stimulating combat. Another thing I like to mention is that for a game that has the tags of a " souls - like " genre. It really fails to meet to that level of standards when it comes to that genre. Fallen Order Bosses/Minibosses don't have lots of variety as there are only 4 main bosses, and the rest are common creatures turned mini bosses, but more aggro. Not to mention that they are all a breeze and take from 1 - 3 attempts on Jedi Master. Even on the Jedi GrandMaster difficulty it really isnt that much of a challenge with the exception of maybe only 1 main boss. The combat while still done great, doesnt flow as well as the actual souls - like games like Elden Ring, Sekiro, Wo - Long, or Nioh. As fighting can feel clunky, delayed and the parry unresponsive at times.  With that aside however, as a star wars fan there is still much to do. As you can customize your lightsaber, unlock references and relics that tie it back to clone wars, see popular characters that make a scene in the game, unlock force powers that make you fight like a jedi and be told a well written story with good narrative that leads it up for part 2. And even after you beat the game, there is still so much to be done as you unlock rewards, and modes for when you beat the story. I will say though. If you want a " Souls-like " game, then find another game. If you want to play a better game then look somewhere else. If you are a starwars fan, wait for this game to go on sale. As good as this game is, it isn't worth so much to the point where you have to rush in and buy it. wait for a sale.

There was a lot of doubt surrounding this game before its release due to Respawn Entertainment having only developed shooter games. Nevertheless, Respawn Entertainment pulled through with this one. As many have already stated, this game is essentially a blend of souls-like combat with Uncharted esque platforming and puzzles. The game does not innovate in any way at all, which is fine. The game takes things that have proven to work and makes great use of them. The story isn‚Äôt anything that would leave you pondering about it, but it serves as an excuse to explore an unseen timeline outside of literature, "the dark times" between Revenge of The Sith and Rogue One. Due to the nature of the game‚Äôs setting, it‚Äôll occasionally dabble in the more esoteric parts of Star Wars lore that could seem out of place for the more casual fans of the franchise. The game feels like a throwback to LucasArts era of Star Wars games, in a good way.

The composer has done a great job simulating John Williams‚Äô style; everything sounds like it could've been played in the original films. Even though the OST is very Star Wars-esque, it‚Äôs not very memorable. I personally can‚Äôt tell if this game has any leitmotifs or recurring themes aside from the iconic ones that the movies established.

This game is mostly a novelty; you‚Äôre paying for a Star Wars themed ride here. It takes less than ten hours to complete the game if you don't partake in side activities. With side activities, I got about 30 hours in.

The game isn't too challenging. I played on the most difficult setting and ended up dying only a couple of times. If you‚Äôre looking for your next souls-like fix, this game probably isn't it. If you‚Äôre intimidated by the souls-like association, don‚Äôt be; as I implied earlier, the game has difficulty settings unlike most souls-like games. The game's difficulty can be adjusted to be very forgiving, anyone can experience the full game without missing out on anything.


Setting

Fallen Order takes place in 14 BBY, which is 5 years after ROTS. The Empire has now established a permanent presence around the galaxy. All the Jedi that survived the initial purge are considered outlaws by the Empire and are actively being hunted by the Inquisitors, the Empire‚Äôs solution to the remaining Jedi. You, Cal Kestis, a 17-year old Jedi in hiding, must find your place in this oppressive galaxy.

I found it interesting how this game ties together almost all forms of Star Wars media into a single package. The game pulls content from the Clone Wars series, the Rebels series, Rogue One, the prequels, and even the sequels. I've always felt like there was a disconnect between the prequels and the original trilogy since the art direction was quite jarringly different. Rogue One helped to ease that transition, but this game is probably the best bridge so far between the prequel and the original trilogy.


Gameplay

The gameplay revolves mainly around three key features: slashing, blocking, and dodging. There are also force powers, which are special abilities that consume a limited resource. The force powers are very abusable and can easily trivialize every encounter in the game. The game heavily encourages you to perform timed blocks (parries) instead of dodges. When you parry an opponent‚Äôs attack, you not only avoid all damage but also damage the aggressor, but if you dodge incoming attacks instead, it might leave you vulnerable to follow-up attacks. The dodges are mainly reserved for the rare unblockable attack.

Weapon or movement variability is limited to the one weapon you start with. The game allows you to unlock additional special attack patterns, but none of these can function as your new main fighting style; they're essentially just specializations. Think something like toggling on aoe mode to clear some swarming enemies.

I want to recommend this game, but I can't. There are many glaring issues with the controls and in-game indicators.

For instance, it is possible to get swarmed by creatures, and unable to move and they will MortalKombat spam keys while you are down killing you instantly or making it to where you can't even get up.

If you are fighting a larger creature, sometimes the red overlay for an unblockable attack doesn't show leading you to believe the attack is blockable when it isn't.

When the red bit comes up and you dodge, sometimes they follow it up with an instantaneous second red strike and you can't dodge fast enough.

Controls don't have an order of operations. If you are pressing one key and try to block, the block will not register. This makes combat, especially for someone with nerve damage even more challenging.

One of the most mind numbingly boring and bland games I've ever played. I've tried to get into Fallen Order three times and ended up putting it down each time.

Despite good voice and motion capture performances by the game's cast, Fallen Order's story is yet another unimaginative Star Wars story filled to the brim with generic Star Wars tropes and plot points that continually fails to intrigue the player throughout the length of its story.

Fallen Order's primitive attempt at souls-style combat is frustratingly janky, unsatisfying, and frankly does not fit into a Star Wars game at all. The souls mechanics in this game either do not fit into a Star Wars game like respawning enemies after resting at a meditation point (this game's bonfire) or are half-arsed like the soul/XP retrieval system after death, which does not pressure you anywhere near like it does in Dark Souls since XP in Fallen Order is abundant and there aren't many skills to invest XP into so you'll power through the skill tree early into the game.

Enemies in Fallen Order are generic and unvaried; they're either variations of Stormtroopers just with different equipment or wildlife like giant spiders, giant toads and giant rats, all of which are boring to fight due to the aforementioned janky combat.

Fallen Order's planets/environments are just as bland and unimaginative as its enemies, like Bogano which is a flat marshy swamp planet, Zeffo which is a cold and windy mountainous planet, and Kashyyyk which has been reused in Star Wars media time and time again. While playing through the story you'll unlock abilities which can be used to unlock and explore previously locked areas on planets. However, all planets are unrewarding to explore and don't offer anything unique to see or do. While you can find health or force upgrades through exploration, most of the time the only things you'll find is random junk which Cal (the protagonist) can interact with to say a generic line or two about or customisation items which just boils down to ugly ponchos all of which look worse than Cal's base outfit, some colour palette changes to Cal's droid or ship, and lightsaber parts most of which you'll never see while playing since logically you can't see your lightsaber hilt when it's wielded by Cal and thus lightsaber colours are the only customisation which actually make a noticeable visual difference.

Overall, even with a hefty 80-90% discount, I still wouldn't recommend buying Fallen Order and advise against doing so simply because it's sluggish waste of time to play and there are countless other games which do what this game attempts to do, just ten times better.

Additional notes: well what a surprise! many people were praising the game for being great, I never was a fan of Star Wars but I decided to give it a chance... and this game right here is a bit the Arkham series of the Star Wars license I reckon! In other words, giving a new shine back to the series! If you remember good games like Dark Forces or Jedi Knight, if you were into SWTOR and the like, or if you are a fan of Star Wars, you ought to play this game! It is always pleasant to see Monaghan act in a movie or game, Merrin is adorable (romance please!), and story/narrative direction is actually very, very well done! (not a surprise though coming from God of War director). The introduction scene, and the first tutorial level, with its direction twists and camera tricks and gripping actions were remarkable.

So yes, it has a few flaws, like being a bit too short (very few levels), a bit clunky and buggy here and there, being a bit dry (NOT a single item in the game, no other weapon)... but aside from that? What an interesting, slick take on the current successful gaming genres all mashed together with a Star Wars theme!
Planet exploration and interspecies teams dialogues ala Mass Effect, check!
Casual take on the Dark Souls fighting and firelinks system, check! (on Jedi Master difficulty finishing the game was sometimes tough for me!)
Tomb exploring, smooth platforming and puzzle solving ala Tomb Raider/Uncharted/Prince of Persia, check!
Amazing scenery, pulp action cutscenes and crazy boss fights ala Metal Gear and God of War, check!

If that sounds exciting to you, and you don't expect this game to be a masterpiece, but just really cool as a week end lounging session, try it now! Note that clearing the game 100% and achievements (without help) will take about twice longer I reckon.

I wanted to like this game so much and have given it a few tries. I suspect it's the kind of game that's extremely worth it if you push through, but I just can't find the motivation to get beyond the first few hours of the game. 
The actual gameplay is mostly just a ziplining and wall running platformer with maze-like 3D maps. There's very little "I'm playing a Star Wars game" and a lot of "I'm playing an over-engineered early 2000s puzzle platformer that happens to have lightsaber noises." 

If you've got hours to waste just getting a feel for navigating the bizarre level design,  there's probably the amazing game everyone else seems to have found in there, but it's just hard to justify investing that much time in something that seems so bland an unrewarding.

Don't buy this, or any other EA games from the Steam store.  Any time I try to play any EA game THAT I HAVE PAID FOR it says "To continue linking your account, please head back and start over."  All I do is click and that is what it tells me.  I can't log in separately to the EA app that you also HAVE to install to play any EA game you buy on Steam, because I don't know what user name Steam used to create my account on EA.  Both Steam support AND EA support refuse to acknowledge the issue.  So now I have several EA games that I have not been able to play for 2 years.  Steam literally just took the money, shoved all responsibility off to EA, and ran away, without even being able to tell me my EA user name.  EA blames Steam (rightfully) and Steam blames EA, and you can spend the rest of your life going back and forth between the two of them and talking to a different customer service representative every time.  Save yourself the insanity and buy any EA game directly from the EA app.

Everything about this game is great: the graphics, the story, the combat. Even the little dialogues that the enemies have are funny and entertaining. This game captures some of the magic of when Star Wars is best, but the gameplay is so bad (and mediocre when best) that I found myself rushing through it on Story mode as I simply couldn‚Äôt be bothered with its awful controls and mechanics. 

So the positives first: 
- The game is incredibly beautiful and it has a lot to offer if you take your time to look around. You will be exploring multiple different biomes and there are truly some sights to behold.
- The sound design is fantastic. Well, it is Star Wars. Exactly the kind of sound design a Star Wars game should have. 
- The acting is quite ok. Probably quite good even. Well, it is Star Wars, so it is full of odd characters, often too silly dialogue and a lot of forced plot elements that might not sit well with you.
- The story is overall quite fine. It is again incredibly generic in the way Star Wars usually is incredibly generic and just walking the same tropes as so much other fantasy/science fiction media, not to mention rethreading much of the same territory as previous Star Wars content. 
- Playing on Story mode will at times make you feel like a true Jedi cutting through hordes of enemies and that can feel ok.

The negatives: 
Combat and mechanics:
- Combat mechanics are incredibly basic, yet don‚Äôt work well. Whether targeting an enemy or not, your character will often strike at air even when an enemy is nearby if you are not perfectly aligned (should not happen with a game that has fixed targeting). Also, targeting an enemy makes it oddly difficult to dodge attacks, so I ended up almost never using it. 
- Talking about controls, the game can be incredibly counter-intuitive and it is obvious the game was made for a controller (I played on PC) and that the game was not optimized for this experience. 
- Continuing the talk of control issues, the game animation locks you all the time, making dodging, parrying and fighting enemies quite frustrating. Instead of being a fast-paced and fluid combat system, you basically only have to parry, then dodge the occasional attack and then strike once you wear out your opponents parry-bar. Very, very boring. 
- The force abilities feels quite useless for combat purposes. All stronger enemies seem immune so you can only use it on minor opponents that are easy to kill anyway.
- Game is quite unforgiving even on second-easiest difficulty level. You have very little health and might die in 2-4 hits (Depending on the opponent), while having to hit even the easiest opponents maybe 4-5 times yourself before they die (and harder opponents probably 20+ times) Keep in mind the dodging/parrying combat system I described above and you might understand why it is not funny and can be very challenging as your blocks can often be penetrated. Some powerful abilities the opponent uses also feels unfair because of animation locking making it difficult to escape/dodge. 

The negatives: 
Other: 
- Path-finding and puzzles can be very, very poorly made. I don‚Äôt remember the last time I had to go online to solve puzzles or simply figure out where to go next, because so many solutions to puzzles are illogical or revolve around you finding a tiny thing that is easy to overlook, whereas the map is made in a way where it is not exactly obvious where to go to reach your mission destination. And it gets even worse when you realize that you sometimes solve very hard puzzles just go get one meek cosmetic upgrade. 
- Although the game is beautiful and is ‚ÄúMetroidvania-esque‚Äù in that you have to return to the same areas with new abilities to unlock and access things that were previously not reachable, the game really gives you no real incentive to do so. All upgrades (aside from skill points) and thus pick-ups are cosmetic only. Meaning that they scattered the map with tons of crates for you to open but you have no reason to open them. There are a few exceptions to this as the game also enables you to upgrade your health and force bar by finding 3 hidden objects twice (giving you ca. 25% bonus for every three you find). Finding these can be somewhat useful, just as the health pack pick-ups can be good, but 90% of the time you will simply find a small story thing or a cosmetic, meaning you probably lose out on any incentive to really explore the world. At least if you dislike the combat mechanics as I did.

Although Jedi Fallen Order premiered in November of 2019, it remains heavily talked about to this day. The game immediately became a massive hit, generating a positive response and welcoming over 20 million players across different platforms. Considering this year‚Äôs sequel turned out to have terrible PC optimization, there is no better time to understand why the predecessor got such an overwhelming amount of praise in the first place.
Starting with the obvious, implementing a souls-like combat system into the Star Wars world was an incredible idea that got brilliantly executed. It may feel cruel at the beginning but punishing for stupid mistakes changes a Padawan into a Jedi. I have never been introduced to the famous video game series distributed by FromSoftware (or any substitute), so it was a fresh experience for me. Thanks to the combination of patience and persistence, I could gradually witness my manual and tactical progress which was very satisfying. If a total casual like me is able to beat this game on the normal level of difficulty, anyone can‚Ä¶ especially taking into consideration the proximity of checkpoints. The diversity of enemy types resulted in me memorizing different strategies, inevitably making the gameplay more exciting. This turns every boss fight into a thrilling event. What encourages playing even more is development through the skill tree. It enables you to differentiate potential attacks and strengthen the connection to the Force. This feature works fantastically in the context of the story which centers around young Jedi trying to regain his power and establish a new order. I wouldn‚Äôt exaggerate about the main storyline being utterly moving yet it definitely delivers a purpose to explore the whole galaxy. The fragment of space that we are privileged enough to discover maybe doesn‚Äôt impress with its size but it was designed in detail. Each of the planets has loads of secrets to reveal to potential players. What emphasizes this fact, even more, is a graphic layout that simply took my breath away. Everything seems tangible and the ugliest places have something oddly beautiful about them. 
The only thing that I could consider a serious disadvantage is a map structure and lack of fast travel. As a matter of fact, I necessarily wasted countless hours struggling to return to my ship. The game was called ‚ÄûStar Wars Get Back To The Mantis‚Äù by more cynical players and I can fully understand their frustration. The map design can be quite problematic and, as I wrote before, there is no form of fast travel, so getting lost and wandering around the map becomes quite obvious, sooner or later.
Despite the annoying element, this video game provided me with a mountain of exhilaration. Star Wars Jedi Fallen Order is an absolute must-play for the fans of the franchise and casual gamers, in general, looking for another amazing adventure to experience.

EDIT 7/8/2023:

I've nearly completed the game at this point and I've decided to revise my review. Within the context of my original review (see below), yes the combat can be frustrating, however, I switched the difficulty to Story Mode (the lowest difficulty) and never looked back. Even at this level the combat was still somewhat challenging. but it made the game vastly more enjoyable and I was able to feel immersed in the story and the exploration. I'd highly recommend doing this if you, as I mentioned in my original review, have a difficult time with "Souls-like" combat. Again, I've nearly completed the game now (~95%) and I'm happy to say the game has thoroughly disproved my skepticism. I found myself in awe at the landscapes and scale of the environments and set pieces. I'm so happy I stuck with it and so happy that I was wrong. 

Original review:
"This is a gorgeous Star Wars game. The environments are breathtaking and the atmosphere is spot on. My main issue with this game, and this absolutely comes down to personal preference, is the difficulty of combat. When people mention this is a souls-like they're correct. The combat is almost entirely reliant on parries and dodges. I do not enjoy souls combat and even on the easiest difficulty I find this game to be very frustrating. In my opinion, as others have pointed out, I am a Jedi with a sword made of pure energy and as such I shouldn't have to worry about constantly being on guard against nearly every enemy in the game. Enemies are almost always on par or far more powerful than myself. The various planet's denizens and wildlife are given flavor text via discoverable journal entries that explain away their resistance to lightsabers in the vain of "this powerful creature has a heavy outer shell that makes it naturally resistant to lightsaber strikes." If I remember correctly, Luke in the original trilogy had no problem slicing off a certain giant white beast's arm with a single swipe of his blade. I'm not asking for every thing that crosses my path to be made of cardboard, however, having the lower-mid level enemies be more creative in their approach when sizing up a Jedi and then having higher level enemies posing a larger threat would have been appreciated.

I do plan to slog through the game simply on its merit of being a beautiful world and I want to experience that part. My word of caution is to avoid this altogether if you don't like "souls-like" combat."
