This is one of those games I wish there was a neutral button.  Game is well done.  Graphics, sound, top notch.

Combat and progression are ripped straight from Dark Souls, but much more floaty.  If you really want DS type combat, just play DS as this is not as tight and nowhere near as good.

The platforming and jumping puzzles just aren't for me, which sadly are what most of the game is about.

A good atmosphere and passable combat mostly brought down by incessant jumping puzzles and platform sliding.

I played a few hours and got bored.  But for those who like the puzzle/jumping aspect you will probably love the game.  And it definitely has a fantastic Star Wars vibe.

This is a good action game. It lacks quite a bit of stuff and feels like story telling at moments, but it is nice to play. 

Graphics are nice, but on PC Port some shaders or filters cause fps drops even on really good spec machine, making it not optimized for PC. I am glad I can use non-xbox controller through steam input, because X-Box controllers aren't any good. Game itself was made for different platform, so port and configurations on PC are at fault. 

Gameplay wise it is fun to play, however gets repetative after some time. Imo game lacks interactions with neutral NPCs and non-action moments, like markets, walking amid cities, using force in conversations and such, but well, we can't have everything. As the game is, it is okay to play it and it is enjoyable. 

If I had to score it I would give it maybe 8/10 or more like 75/100 . It is a good game to play if you like Star Wars, but that's it.

STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order‚Ñ¢ is a magnificent masterpiece that perfectly captures the essence of the Star Wars universe, delivering an epic and immersive experience. From the captivating storyline to the stunning visuals and exhilarating gameplay, this game keeps you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. The combination of intense lightsaber battles, mind-bending Force abilities, and intricate level design makes every moment feel like a heroic journey. The attention to detail, accompanied by a phenomenal score, creates an authentic and nostalgic atmosphere that transports you to a galaxy far, far away. With its balanced difficulty and rewarding progression system, it appeals to both casual and hardcore gamers alike.

A fantastic game from start to finish. The game was challenging and the upgrades you get over the course of the game make combat and exploration very fun. It was fun to see a section of the map you can't get to, then getting a power up and thinking, "I need to go back to X to see what is up there".

One complaint is that the map system sucks, especially if you are like me and want to 100% each area for achievements. I had to pull up videos multiple times because I had no idea where to go and the map just looks like a blue blob.

It is also annoying to not have any fast travel system. I usually hate fast travelling in games, but this is not an open world game, it is very linear parkour, combat, and puzzles. If you do it once, doing it again just feels boring. Plus, there were many times where I completed an area, left, only to realize I didn't pick up a seed or something and had to travel all the way back.

Those two issues are only problems for people that are looking to 100% the game and find every little collectible. If you just want to play for the story, then these won't negatively impact your experience much.

My name is Yoshikage Kira. I‚Äôm 33 years old. My house is in the northeast section of Morioh, where all the villas are, and I am not married. I work as an employee for the Kame Yu department stores, and I get home every day by 8 PM at the latest. I don‚Äôt smoke, but I occasionally drink. I‚Äôm in bed by 11 PM, and make sure I get eight hours of sleep, no matter what. After having a glass of warm milk and doing about twenty minutes of stretches before going to bed, I usually have no problems sleeping until morning. Just like a baby, I wake up without any fatigue or stress in the morning.

I was told there were no issues at my last check-up. I‚Äôm trying to explain that I‚Äôm a person who wishes to live a very quiet life. I take care not to trouble myself with any enemies, like winning and losing, that would cause me to lose sleep at night. That is how I deal with society, and I know that is what brings me happiness. Although, if I were to fight I wouldn‚Äôt lose to anyone.

[Modified English variant] ‚Äì You can call me Yoshikage Kira. I‚Äôm currently 33 years old. Not that you‚Äôd care, but I reside in northeast Morioh‚Äôs villa district. Also, I‚Äôve yet to marry. In order to make a living, I work for Kame Yu department stores. After a long day‚Äôs work, I return home no later than 8 PM. I don‚Äôt like smoking, but do enjoy the occasional drink. I‚Äôm always in bed by 11 PM, and I make it a point to get no less than 8 hours of sleep each night. Before bed, I drink a warm glass of milk. It‚Äôs always coupled with 20 minutes of stretching to decompress from the long workday. Sweet dreams are the usual result of this.

I then awake as refreshed and recharged as a newborn child, ready to take on the day‚Äôs challenges. And after my last checkup, I was given a clean bill of health. For as long as I could remember, I‚Äôve done everything in my power to live a productive life that allows me to pursue a lasting inner peace. This may be a foreign concept, but I choose not to concern myself with winning or losing, life‚Äôs troubles, or enemies who bring sleepless nights. That is how I cope with this backwards life we find ourselves living. It‚Äôs what brings me happiness in a world fraught with hardship and misery. Of course, if I were ever to engage in combat, I would win the battle without question.

A game that gets Star Wars. Some might even say it gets it better than Disney. An exciting romp through a familiar galaxy far, far away with a trusty droid and a lightsabre at your side. 

Jedi: Fallen Order managed to beat the odds and be a single player game from EA that isn't just good, it's great! At it's core it's an odd mix of platforming, metroidvania style level design and souls-like combat. All covered in a coat of Star Wars paint with a good dose of spit and polish. It's hard as nails at times, but it rewards those that persist and learn to dance to it's tunes. 

Storywise: meet Cal Kestis, former Jedi padawan turned scrapper. Avoiding trouble, hiding his powers and lightsabre from the empire until all the empire comes for him and he's left with nowhere to run. Cal's a very likable guy. A good kid with a lot of endearing qualities and the crew of the Stinger Mantis, the ship that saves him certain doom, are as well. If only the game gave these people room to breathe and be people for a bit. The story goes at a breakneck pace at times, giving little room for fluff. Yet it manages to put together a cast that I enjoyed and wanted more of by the end. The game lets the characters breathe during the last third and it allows the voice cast to shine. The potential for awesome storytelling is here, Respawn just need to embrace it. 

Audio and visuals wise: it's a big budget tripple A game. it's gorgeous and the devs know it. Jedi: Fallen Order will make you pause and admire the view from time to time and it never fails at making me go: "Dang, that's pretty." The physics and AI get wonky at times, but I can excuse it. 

All in all: a game that's worth the money and is on sale more often than it is not. Go for it if you enjoy Star Wars and if you don't, then this might just be your step into that universe.

A really solid, fun game. Having 100% it, I'll give my thoughts. I really liked the general mechanics of moving around the gorgeous landscapes. I used a map-able mouse and keyboard, which worked like normal and was well integrated. 

The good;
- Amazing audio / music / soundtrack. For me, it really made the game. 
- I'm not much of a story person in games, but I actually enjoyed it. Admittedly, I was forced into watching everything, as you can't skip scenes. But it was a tidy, straightforward narrative. 
- Graphics were really good. I ran on ultra. 
- No bugs / crashes etc
- Loved the dynamic between me and BD bot. 

The meh;
- Combat. I found the responsiveness of the combat very sluggish and frustrating. Although the combat was challenging at times, it was a good balance on the whole. The variety of attacks / powers was nice, and you can set up some fun combos. 
- Map design. Very linear. 
- Good length of game. Took me 38 hours to 100%. 

The bad;
- Chests. Collecting stuff from chests was really underwhelming. Didn't add anything. Just a few bits you can customise the look of things. Yawn. 
- Backtracking. The linear nature of the maps makes you retrace your steps. This can be a massive chore. The shortcuts don't often help much. Added to this, that maps can be a bit of a rabbit warren, and it wasn't fun navigating around them. 
- Map / No compass. I get lost easily. I found having no compass made for a lot of confusion on which direction i was going. The map I also found to be quite tricky to read on a number of occasions. 
- End boss. Very anticlimactic. Was way too easy to beat her. Other, earlier bosses proved much harder.

A Disappointing Experience: A Review of Jedi Fallen Order

Introduction:
Jedi Fallen Order is a game that left me incredibly dissatisfied, making me regret not doing more research before purchasing it. As someone who despises the Uncharted series, I found this game to be a continuation of the same formula, with frustrating levels filled with nonsensical climbing and jumping. Moreover, the design choices for the lightsabers and helmets were particularly unimpressive. In my opinion, the game failed to offer anything innovative, and I will have to rely on extensive modding to rectify the disappointing choices made in character development.

Gameplay:
One of the major aspects that left me disenchanted with Jedi Fallen Order was its gameplay. The levels were nothing short of asinine, with endless climbing and jumping sequences that felt forced and lacking in creativity. Instead of providing engaging and varied challenges, the game seemed to prioritize repetitive platforming mechanics that quickly grew tiresome. This monotony ultimately diminished my enthusiasm and made the overall experience feel tedious.

Design Choices:
Perhaps one of the most glaring disappointments in Jedi Fallen Order was the design of the lightsabers and helmets. As a fan of the original Star Wars movies, I believe that the lightsaber is an iconic weapon that should be revered and respected. However, the game decided to deviate from this timeless design by introducing lightsabers that looked outright ridiculous. The overly elaborate and impractical designs failed to capture the essence of what made lightsabers so compelling in the first place.

Character Development:
The choices made regarding character development in Jedi Fallen Order left much to be desired. The game's characters lacked depth and failed to engage me emotionally. Their motivations felt shallow, and their interactions were often uninteresting. To salvage the experience, I will need to resort to heavy modding, seeking to enhance the characters and their stories to create a more immersive and enjoyable gameplay experience.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, Jedi Fallen Order was a letdown for me. Its gameplay relied on tired mechanics, the design choices for lightsabers and helmets were unimpressive, and the character development left much to be desired. While original ideas are commendable, they must still pay homage to the iconic elements that define a beloved franchise like Star Wars. Unfortunately, this game fell short in that regard. If you, like me, have reservations about Uncharted-style games and expect a more faithful representation of the Star Wars universe, I recommend researching extensively before investing in Jedi Fallen Order.

Pro: 
-Fun Gameplay
-Interessting Story
-Good Graphics

Con:
-Not made for mouse and keyboard
-Only shows button-binding for controllers
-Still has some minor bugs (such as healthbar disappearing until you die or lightsaber activating on your hip or being unable to open chests and being stuck in the approaching animation)
-Story is kept way too short
-Character arcs seem to come too short (So the sister of the night joins my crew, yay... but there are only two missions left until the story is over? what for? she is - although an intersting character etc. -barely worth mentioning)

If you're a fan of lightsabers, mind tricks, and the occasional urge to headbutt your monitor, Jedi: Fallen Order is the game for you!

This game is like a mashup of Dark Souls and Star Wars. Prepare for some serious dying (and swearing), but it's all part of the Jedi training, right? The combat is all about precision, timing, and having the reflexes of a Jedi cat on caffeine. It's less about power trips and more like a dance-off with laser swords. So fun, yet frustratingly addictive!

And forget about the typical lightsaber-wielding experience where you're an unstoppable force of nature. In Jedi: Fallen Order, you'll feel like a scrappy underdog trying to survive in a galaxy far, far away.

All in all, I thoroughly enjoyed Jedi: Fallen Order, despite the occasional urge to unleash my inner Sith Lord on my poor controller. It's a fresh take on the lightsaber-wielding experience, where precision and timing matter more than flashy moves. So, fellow Jedi enthusiasts, I wholeheartedly recommend this game. May the Force be with you, and may your patience be as strong as Master Yoda on leg day!

Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order is a highly anticipated action-adventure game that attempts to immerse players in the thrilling world of the Jedi. However, while the game does have its strong points, it falls short in several key areas, leaving much to be desired.

One aspect that left a significant impact on the gameplay experience was the repetitive nature of the game's structure. The pattern of engaging in a lengthy parkour sequence, followed by a puzzle, a quick skirmish with easily defeated enemies, and ultimately a boss fight became monotonous and predictable. The lack of variation in this regard diminished the excitement and sense of exploration that players expect from a game of this genre.

The parkour sequences, though intended to be challenging, ultimately felt excessively long and cumbersome. Maneuvering the protagonist, Cal, proved to be a frustrating experience due to his stiff and unresponsive controls. Furthermore, the color cues used to guide the player's path were often unclear, leading to unnecessary confusion and causing players to rely on the map frequently to ensure they were moving in the right direction.

The puzzles in Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order provided a mixed bag of simplicity and difficulty. While some puzzles offered a satisfying challenge that required players to showcase their problem-solving skills, others felt too simplistic and failed to provide a sense of accomplishment. It's worth noting that the gratification derived from successfully completing the more intricate puzzles was a highlight of the gameplay experience.

Where the game truly falters is in its combat system. The lightsaber, a weapon that should feel powerful and iconic, unfortunately feels more akin to a toothpick in the hands of Cal. The limited repertoire of combat moves available to the protagonist left the combat encounters feeling stale and repetitive. While there might be more interesting moves hidden within the game, they often require the use of a power bar that depletes rapidly. This poor balance between the usage of powers and their limited availability led to frustration and hindered the overall enjoyment of combat.

Adding insult to injury, the decision to incorporate a Souls-like gameplay style into Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order feels misplaced. The punishing difficulty of boss fights can quickly turn into a torturous experience for players. Rather than enhancing the game's immersion and enjoyment, the challenging nature of these encounters can often feel unfair and unbalanced.

In conclusion, Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order falls short of its potential due to its repetitive gameplay structure, clunky parkour mechanics, and frustrating combat system. While the game offers moments of satisfaction through well-designed puzzles, these are overshadowed by the game's shortcomings. Ultimately, the decision to incorporate a Souls-like experience into a Star Wars game feels misguided and detracts from the overall enjoyment.

[code]MY RATING:	‚úî ‚úî ‚úî ‚úî ‚úî ‚úî ‚úî ‚úî ‚úî ‚úî	10 / 10[/code]

Friends, when it comes to Star Wars, I don't know a single person who doesn't remember a billion movies from this series and especially several games that were released. Although they weren't all that great (Battlefront 2), they were still quite fun to play. However, in 2019, the series got its first really great game, which enjoyed criticism and popularity all over the world, and honestly Respawn Studio, which is behind games like Apex Legends and their most famous Titanfall series. But this was quite an unexpected step, so how does the game affect me?

[b] Story [/b]

In the game, you take on the role of Cal Kestis, a scavenger on a planet occupied by the Empire, but you soon find out that Cal is actually not just any scavenger, but a Padawan from the Jedi Order who was exterminated after Order 66 (Thanks to Sidius), however, after you fight with the Inquisitors you will find one ex-jedi knight and one small veteran pilot who will be with you on your journey to restore the Jedi order, which is cool and I liked it, however, you will be faced with many challenges and mainly puzzles on your way, such as I probably never expected the connection, yes, there is the Tomb Raider series, which has been doing this since its inception, but even so, I would never have expected this in a Star Wars game. It's like you take Lara Croft, put her in the Male gender, give her a Lightsaber and move her into the Star Wars world, quite an unexpected but pleasant surprise.

[b] Gameplay [/b]

As I mentioned, this game has a really specific gameplay, which is probably clear to everyone and, above all, has already been familiar. However, what is interesting is that even as a Padawan, Cal had to hide and could not use his abilities, which also caused him to forget some abilities, such as Throwing, Pulling or even Double Jump? Well it's Star Wars we won't go into it. However, the further you are in the game, the more Cal remembers and gets his abilities back and it's really cool, but it can happen that you will be in a location where there is a Crate with accessories (which you only collect as cosmetics, there's nothing interesting about it) but you can't to get there, because you don't have a given ability to get there, so you'll have to wait until Cal remembers it and then if you remember that you left something in a location... It's crazy, but whatever. However, that's not all, for every Scanned enemy, element, item or for every killed enemy, you gain Skill Points and with those you buy upgrades to Cal's abilities. More health, Bigger Force bar, more health regeneration, interesting tricks with your Lightsaber, but there's just enough of it. To be honest, you can get all the abilities by completing the game, but you have to explore the whole world, which takes time, but it's worth it (I finished the game 5 times). However, if you couldn't do it, there is one more cool option and that is that after completing the game you will unlock New Game+ where you start from the beginning (How else) but you have all the skills you learned from the last game, which is great. However, the enemies are a bit more experienced and a lot more annoying enemies are spawned (so enjoy).

[b] Optimization [/b]

As for the optimization of the game itself, I have to admit that the developers really cared (Not like in Jedi Survivor, where the game runs at 30FPS). But seriously, this game has really great Optimization, I played the game on Ultra at 60FPS and above, so I don't see any big problem with the Optimization or the technical side of the game. The only thing that is a bit of a problem is the Dathomir location where, despite the settings, I had slight tearing and microlags which is not exactly great but it was nothing terrible, subtract a few more bugs or poorly responding terrain and you have your opinion. Some locations have really "interesting" terrain on which you climb, you either hardly see it or you jump on it and the game lets you fall off the map (AC Unity style).

[b] Conclusion [/b]

However, if you've ever thought about buying this game for me I can highly recommend it, in the whole 208 hours I wasn't bored once and it really is a ride from start to finish, mainly what's interesting about this game so if you really like Star Wars so this game won't let you go even for a moment, for me I was able to last a maximum of 6 hours straight, because I needed a break (Maybe it was because it was already 1AM in the morning). Well, try it, try it, if you don't like the game or it's not your style, the Steam refund system exists and you can return the game, but I think it's really not a waste of money for this game even at full price.

[b] PROS AND CONS [/b]

‚úî Great Optimization
‚úî Easy to learn Hard to Master

I want to like it. The controls are so bad they admit it at the beginning of the game. They also force so much boring game play over and over. For instance having to SLOWLY get back to a boss from a save point. They know you'll die but put the save point so far away. No baddies to fight, just walking and boredom. Re-spawn right where we need to be when it's clearly a battle you're expected to die a few times to figure out the mechanics. Graphics are great. Story is interesting so far. I added dodge and some force moves to separate mouse buttons to help with the bad controls in combat. Why do I need a controller with my PC? It isn't a console. With that said, I highly recommend a mouse with extra buttons. 

It is a pretty short game. I was able to complete the game with 95% completion in about 20 hours on Jedi Knight. There is an extra combat mode available after you beat the story that is challenging but I doubt I'll pick it back up now that I've completed it. Not a lot of replay value at all for me. I'd just be running around looking for cosmetics and I'm not too concerned with that at all. You can't even notice most of them when you're playing. Light saber color is about the only thing I can see cosmetically. The ponchos look like trash bags and there's only 5 outfits. Coloring the ship is ok but you hardly see it. Customizing the light saber is cool but I forget all about it once I'm back playing. Like I said, the color is the only thing you'll notice. I did take my time exploring so I found most items the first run. The map is good at showing you where you can and cannot go as you unlock abilities. I had maxed my abilities by the time I got to the end battle. Some have had to grind for a few ability points but I didn't find leveling up difficult.

To summarize. It was definitely created for consoles and the port to PC wasn't great. With a "gaming" mouse it will make the combat more fun. It's short and re-playability is low. If you want a decent single player game that won't eat a lot of time this is a pretty good choice.

Great experience.
The plot is interesting, and Cal's character is attractive and fun to play. The difficulty curve (if you can call it that way) is good, and progressing while discovering your ancient powers is definitely rewarding. Opponents benefits from many detailed patterns and skins as the characters design appear to be one of the most gorgeous point about this game (not especially for Cere though). Special thanks for the Bounty Hunters here and there! 'Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order' is beautiful and you will never realize, except for this game, that five planets are too few to explore. The lore and the universe are fully respected. It is a pleasure to evolve in such a colourful, complex and varied worlds. The main opponents (the Empire) are amazingly represented and evoke huge powers. The music and soundesign are gorgeous. The game offers diverse difficulty levels. It feels like being a game held by strong ambitions and all things considered, well executed.

On the other hand, there are many buggy incomprehensions as when Cal's lightsaber goes through the environment without any damage (referring to the workbench as well as other structures or objects). This goes with many collision and texture bugs and walls you can go through as you get closer to the borders of the maps. Things are made to look good when they are far away, don't try to interact with what you see in the distance. There are way too many collectibles for such a short game (the main story lasts for something like 15 hours) and you are not even rewarded for gathering all the useless objects around the whole galaxy (these are just skins and dreadful paintings). Don't fall into the trap of the deuxe version as I did because wow, this is a void of content. The cutscenes are numerous and sadly unskippable. If they do bring some depth to the story they also are full of conveniences and pathetic dialogues. If, as I've said, planets are fun to explore, they're much less fun to navigate using the mini-map, which is a real nightmare. I can't see how they could have done it better though but it still remains very hard to use properly. And why not using fast travels? Aren't the camps made to do that? The game takes years to launch, as well as going from a planet to another: don't expect to play for less than 20 minutes on this one. But in the end it is not worse than this last inconvenient: you have to use the EA launcher AND be connected to the internet in order to play, even if you have the game (as me) only on Steam! I didn't count the number of times I had to restart my PC just because the EA launcher didn't let me play... Such a mess.

I like to wait for the perfect time to play my games. Hopefully, giving it enough time for patches and fixes to optimize it as best as possible in the process hence, the later review. I remember this game was well received and a pleasant surprise from EA's usual live service affairs. So, imagine my shock to see it on sale for $5. Never been a big fan of Star Wars and I had crossed out EA (among others) completely from my personal list after Dragon Age: Inquisition, one of the lamest RPGs I have ever played prior to Andromeda's debut, the combination was something I would simply ignore. However, Fallen Order being a well reviewed, triple A, single player title created by none other than Respawn for five bucks was too much of a deal to pass up and I jumped on it. The sequel is out and making the rounds with feedback of much needed optimization, I figured this would be the perfect time to play the original and find out if its worth pursuing the maligned sequel. The short conclusion is that I am glad I only paid $5. 

Unlike other games, you are not playing a master Jedi with powerful skills, capable of taking out a handful of enemies at once, you are instead playing as Cal Kestis, a Padawan that had his training cut short as soon as order 66 was initiated, forcing him to go into hiding in a remote planet as a scavenger breaking down warships. At best, Cal is an average Jedi, both in skill and power and this is well translated through the Souls like combat in place. While capable of dispatching lowly vermin or a regular trooper, encountering anything slightly above generally ends up being a challenging endeavor that borders on feeling like a boss fight. Cal starts out very fragile, only able to sustain a few hits but his capabilities can be improved over time as you gather experience points to invest in his skill tree but that sense of fragility never goes away so you always have to approach every encounter with some care. Much like the Souls games, defeat is inevitable and you are penalized by losing all of your accrued experience points but the game marks the enemy that killed you as a chance to gain back what you have lost if you manage to strike it once. But all too often the game tends to glitch and does not mark the enemy upon respawn, making the loss of your exp permanent making the experience feel rather unfair at certain points. Combat is also not based on your relative position and requires to player to press the right button to evade an attack, even if you managed to evade an attack by pressing jump instead of dodge the game tends to rubberband you back in position to take the hit. To add to this, enemies sink into the ground or randomly jump into the sky and the odd stutter during a wall run can lead to cheap deaths. At one point Cal's jump doesn't have the distance to clear a gap between slides and you are fixed into a loop where he continually falls to his death failing the jump. Cinematics also tend to stutter everytime the camera changes angle and the culmination of it all can lead to a very frustrating experience, especially on harder levels.  

I also think the Souls like combat wasn't well implemented or the devs didn't think things through beyond cashing in on the latest trends. While the combat difficulty can be acceptable, enemies re-spawning at rest points does not make sense since this is not a grind heavy game. Characters in Souls games can indefinitely keep leveling up and upgrade their attributes where Cal has a set amount of skills after which gaing exp has no purpose and it gets quite exhausting as you have to once again clear areas full of enemies that you had already killed. The rewards for exploration also feels anemic as you mostly unlock alternate costumes and skins with no real ingame benefits. All in all the game is a hodgepodge mess of ideas that doesn't compliment each other well with the concept of the actual game. Its not all bad, the story is quite interesting and the VO are well done but you will have to suffer through the rough gameplay to experience it.   

4 years after launch this game still suffers from issues that it did at launch and its sequel is much the same. As such I find it difficult to recommend this game at full price and would advise anyone to wait for another steep discount prior to purchasing the title. I am just lucky to have only paid five bucks for this game, any higher I would probably much more livid with its performance.

Although the story doesn't have much to do with the original series of films (neither episodes IV to VI, nor the rest of the trilogies), the atmosphere of the Star Wars universe is all there. Incidentally, of the various StarWars games I've played, I must say that what I liked most about this game was the fact that it was an unknown character, a padawan made a Jedi by force, which is almost not the story of Luke Skywalker, in another time and in a parallel universe. I really enjoyed the game!

Having said that, it's not the perfect game, especially in the animations and voice-overs of some of its characters. But it's something we can easily ignore, because everything else is pretty good. I would give 9.5/10.

As a 52-year-old father, I may be one of the oldest players enjoying Jedi: Fallen Order, a captivating single-player game. Being a single father to my 16-year-old son hasn't always been easy, especially with his busy schedule of hanging out with friends or endlessly scrolling through TikTok videos. It was becoming increasingly challenging for us to find common ground and spend quality time together.

My son had already experienced the wonders of Jedi: Fallen Order before, and he had shared stories of his adventures with me. Intrigued and hoping to connect with him through the game, I decided to make a Steam account and get the game for myself.

As I loaded into the game and started playing, I found myself in awe of the immersive world and intricate gameplay mechanics. However, I soon encountered moments of confusion, unsure of the best way to progress. Seeing my struggle, my son stepped in and offered his expertise, guiding me through the challenges and helping me uncover the game's secrets.

Playing Jedi: Fallen Order alongside my son was a truly remarkable experience. We laughed, strategized, and immersed ourselves in the captivating storyline together. It became a shared adventure, strengthening our bond and creating precious memories reminiscent of the joy we used to have when my wife was still alive.

This game not only provided us with countless hours of entertainment but also served as a powerful reminder of the importance of spending quality time together. It rekindled our connection and reminded us that, regardless of age, there are incredible experiences to be shared and enjoyed as a family.

Jedi: Fallen Order has become a cherished part of our lives, symbolizing the rejuvenation of our relationship and the joy we find in each other's company. It has shown us the profound impact that a video game can have in bringing generations together and creating lasting memories.

So, to all the parents out there, don't hesitate to dive into the gaming world and explore the adventures that await. You may discover not only a fantastic game but also a powerful tool for strengthening the bond with your children.

I really wanted a successor to Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy, and while this definitely does scratch the itch of playing as a Padawan finding their place in the Force, the controls and combat animations leave a lot to be desired. Combat does not feel fluid, and while the forced animations do look good visually, it means you are unable to enjoy much freedom as you are unable to cancel animations so you're locked into this clunky dance with the AI that can be pretty hit or miss at times.

Furthermore, there are a ton of powers that are missing that you may have grown accustomed to from other Jedi games, which makes this one feel underwhelming. However, the saber combat tends to make up for that as its pivotal role in your limited arsenal.

The start is also rather rough, as the game does not give any hint as to whether or not you will be able to get improved powers, so starting areas are rather frustrating since you are locked out of exploring parts of the map due to not being able to, for example, scale a wall just out of reach. It is only half-way through the game that you truly unlock what should be a "base kit" of a Jedi to actually start playing the game normally.

As for maps themselves, it is nothing more than a glorified linear platformer that allows you to unlock shortcuts along the way that feed into the loop that eventually comprises of the "open world". You will revisit worlds, and there will be backtracking, but the gorgeous scenery sure does keep things interesting!

With those issues out of the way, the story was riveting and the environments exceptional! Character detail was incredible, with audio feeling as if you were watching the movies themselves.

All in all, if you are looking for a polished Star Wars combat-focused game, this is not it. But if you're looking for a solid world-building lore-based story experience, this ties perfectly into the original movie trilogy.

This game is really damn good, I'm not particularly a Star Wars fan but I thoroughly enjoyed playing through the entire game from start to finish. The graphics are beautiful, amazing protagonist and antagonists, all the characters were memorable in the game which I love. The level design is good but since you have to backtrack a lot if you want to get everything, navigating the map was a bit of a nightmare. I was very disappointed to find out there isn't any fast travel between meditation points. The game was a decent challenge on the hardest difficulty but once again, groups of smaller weaker enemies sometimes pose a bigger threat than an actual boss due to numbers and just spam attacking, all the boss fights were very enjoyable however. 

Overall I would definitely recommend this game to almost anyone, the only difficulty is navigating around so as long as you are not completely new to games then I'd say to give this a try.

I hated this game so much it literally made me to not want to buy the squeal.

1. the lagging, its a single player game and it has lag? i have an alienware laptop which runs any game at full spec and this game ran like crap.

2. the collectables were trash, so not worth the time and effort to find them, just different colours nothing more, no other outfits for your character, just lame ponchos.

3. the maps were a total maze leaving you running in circles for hours just to find a container you missed,  when a map has  multiple routs you can take you need to have the ability to set markers on your map to lead you to the area you are trying to revisit.

4.  force push and double jump wasn't unlocked until very late in the game, which meant a lot of areas of the maps couldn't be accessed until then, forcing you to have to go back to each map and spend hours trying to re-find all the chests you couldn't get before, only to end up getting lost going in circles.

5. your force powers and combat moves were pretty basic, especially compared to the bosses and your force meter was too hard to fill, you could only do 3 or 4 force attacks and your meter would be empty but the bosses can just spam force attacks on you.

6. the bosses have so many moves that you cant block or parry, forcing you to just dash away and throw your lightsaber, which i found to be the best way to defeat bosses due to the incredibly hard parry timing.

7. there was no indication given that when the final planet became available if you travelled there then that was it, the game would lead to the end and you wont have a chance to revisit any of the other worlds.

8. many puzzles were just frustrating, having to force push a ball at the exact right angle to push it into the correct spot, made me want to yeet my laptop off a cliff.

9. half the game your crew talk about some creature on board your ship and you never find it and there is no conclusion on it, i saw it once hiding under the navigation holo desk and that was it, there seemed to be no point in it.

10. there seemed to be no point in collecting the seeds also.

Overall i found this game more tedious and frustrating rather than fun, compared to the force unleashed games this was terrible.
After completing the game you get 1 different outfit and still cant skip cut scenes, pathetic.
uninstall and never play it again is what i will do and there is no chance in hell that i will fork out $120 for the new game.

Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order is a highly anticipated action-adventure game that attempts to immerse players in the thrilling world of the Jedi. However, while the game does have its strong points, it falls short in several key areas, leaving much to be desired.

One aspect that left a significant impact on the gameplay experience was the repetitive nature of the game's structure. The pattern of engaging in a lengthy parkour sequence, followed by a puzzle, a quick skirmish with easily defeated enemies, and ultimately a boss fight became monotonous and predictable. The lack of variation in this regard diminished the excitement and sense of exploration that players expect from a game of this genre.

The parkour sequences, though intended to be challenging, ultimately felt excessively long and cumbersome. Maneuvering the protagonist, Cal, proved to be a frustrating experience due to his stiff and unresponsive controls. Furthermore, the color cues used to guide the player's path were often unclear, leading to unnecessary confusion and causing players to rely on the map frequently to ensure they were moving in the right direction.

The puzzles in Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order provided a mixed bag of simplicity and difficulty. While some puzzles offered a satisfying challenge that required players to showcase their problem-solving skills, others felt too simplistic and failed to provide a sense of accomplishment. It's worth noting that the gratification derived from successfully completing the more intricate puzzles was a highlight of the gameplay experience.

Where the game truly falters is in its combat system. The lightsaber, a weapon that should feel powerful and iconic, unfortunately feels more akin to a toothpick in the hands of Cal. The limited repertoire of combat moves available to the protagonist left the combat encounters feeling stale and repetitive. While there might be more interesting moves hidden within the game, they often require the use of a power bar that depletes rapidly. This poor balance between the usage of powers and their limited availability led to frustration and hindered the overall enjoyment of combat.

Adding insult to injury, the decision to incorporate a Souls-like gameplay style into Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order feels misplaced. The punishing difficulty of boss fights can quickly turn into a torturous experience for players. Rather than enhancing the game's immersion and enjoyment, the challenging nature of these encounters can often feel unfair and unbalanced.

In conclusion, Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order falls short of its potential due to its repetitive gameplay structure, clunky parkour mechanics, and frustrating combat system. While the game offers moments of satisfaction through well-designed puzzles, these are overshadowed by the game's shortcomings. Ultimately, the decision to incorporate a Souls-like experience into a Star Wars game feels misguided and detracts from the overall enjoyment.

As soon as I heard the Hu in the opening sequence, I thought, sweet, this is going to be a kickass game. And gameplay wise, the intro did not disappoint: fighting stormtroopers atop a moving train in a mecha space world set the bar very high. Too high. I bought this game for $5 because it looked cool and did no background research on the combat, so I had no clue it mimicked the Soulsborne games with no checkpoint/saves apart from 'bonfires' (meditation circles in this game). Apart from combat feeling clunky in an AC Odyssey kind of way (effective parry timing feels so hard, enemies can kill you in the middle of a healing animation, it can take several presses for the heal button to even register) and the dodge button (tap not once but TWICE???) feeling majorly unnatural and tiring for the fingers, dying in Fallen Order can set you back a while and severely interrupt the flow. It just doesn't work with the amount of cinematics going on. Autosaves would have been a much better save system overall. That said, there are a ton of neat moves to unlock, and though the protagonist Cal doesn't really feel Jedi-like at the start, it becomes much more fun to control him by the end, issues notwithstanding. Plus slicing through droids and wiping out enemies looks so slick in those slow motion scenes.

There's quite a bit of puzzle solving here, I've seen comparisons to Tomb Raider but no definitely not, the puzzles in Fallen Order feel a bit more repetitive and TR, Rise and Shadow did it better overall. Still, Respawn did a good job of balancing puzzles with combat and exploration and they were a nice reprieve from mashing sabers and dying over and over in battle with hostile creatures. Speaking of difficulty, I played this game on normal (Jedi Knight) even though I started off on hard because I couldn't acclimatise to the parry timing or the tendency of the dodge button to fail, and here's the interesting part: even though Fallen Order had lost its lustre beyond the introduction and felt extremely tedious with its lack of fast travel features, I stuck with it, and the development of the story ultimately swayed me into enjoying it again. If you're the sort of person who enjoys complex characters, Fallen Order has some genuinely good redemption arcs. 

TL;DR Beep-boop-beep! Trill!

Man this is a game that is hard to recommend to most people.

I think the main issue with this game is the fact that it's a great story with (mostly) great characters that is dragged down by its gameplay, combat, and level design. The story is well written, though predictable and on the safe side, that is pushed along by a great cast of protagonists and antagonists. Making this game's plot canon gives weight to its connection with mainline characters and events occurring in the galaxy not long after the founding of the Galactic Empire. Character motivations are clear and logical, including the lore reason why the main character, despite being trained in the Jedi arts, needs to relearn skills (a nice touch).

However, this game's biggest failing is stretching itself too thin with its gameplay loop, combat, and level design. The game has 3 hats that it likes to wear: Metroidvania, Souls-like Action RPG, and Story-Driven Adventure. Sometimes, this trio works, but most of the time it makes the game a mess and/or the execution fails. 

For the Metroidvania aspects, the game is rather light and instead likes to *pretend* that it is a Metroidvania. Many parts of the map require backtracking once the main character gains skills and powers, which means you will visit locations multiple times for loot alone, not to mention story (one location excluding the hub world requires at least 2 return trips after the initial mission due to the story). Metroid Prime did this with locations requiring multiple return trips because of the story, but Fallen Order does not have the same flare and execution by showing story progression and change in the world. No matter if it's your first or fifteenth time, the same enemies will be in the same places. Mobs don't get stronger or change. The only differences that the world shows are more open doors and more corridors. They're are many other games that utilize return locales with much better execution, so it only feels like padded runtime rather than for interesting reasons. The reason why runtimes feel padded is that many of the Metroidvania/Souls-like "shortcuts" that you create only reduce traversal by a small amount. Additionally, "exploration" in this game hardly requires venturing anywhere far off the main pathway and instead just "going down the other tunnel." Again, it stretches itself too thin by trying to be a Metroidvania without realizing how many Metroidvanias require going off the beaten path for a long time, solving puzzles, or beating optional bosses that require more than an additional 2% effort on the player's part. There are a few great puzzles to get additional loot, but "few" is the operative word. If you make the majority of your puzzles as difficult as "find the glowing thing" as if it's an Assassin's Creed game from 20 years ago, you are not making puzzles, just an object to interact with.

The game is very cinematic with many well-rendered, albeit often poorly optimized, cutscenes with stutter as they are frequently used as loading screens. The cutscenes, when not used as a loading screen, run smoothly and are a great break to the combat and mediocre exploration. Some of these cutscenes and interactions are also an attempt to put on another hat...an RPG with a morality system; however, the devs must have forgotten about it halfway through because it think there are only a total of a dozen interactions where the player has agency in the choice of dialogue. To make things worse, these dialogue options make no impact on the story, only there for the player to interact just in case they...get bored...I guess. These cutscenes, along with the Nathan Drake-style map traversal gives it the Story-Driven Adventure aspect to the game, complete with the totally not obvious paint on all of the ledges for you to climb on and illogical placements for walls that the character can wall-run. Many of these aspects matter little to the overall scheme of the game and oftentimes only serve as roadblocks to help with the poorly executed Metroidvania aspects that require some skill to unlock first. To make matters worse, the Metroidvania and Nathan Drake-style combine together to turn into moderately filled arenas with trash mobs with a few interspersed special enemies connected by empty corridors. So if the empty corridors are just filler between arenas, how is the combat?

Like the rest of this game...poorly executed. The game tries to be both an Adventure game and a Souls-like with its combat and somehow took only the worst possible aspects of both. Many of the trash enemies take only a couple of uninteresting hits from your lightsaber even in the beginning of the game, which means by the end when you have unlocked all the additional skills, health, and damage, these are not even worth fighting because you just want to get to the next story beat. Because most arenas have only a few interesting enemies to fight, the combat gets boring and monotonous really quick. The combat system utilizes a dodge roll, parry, block, and skills, which is common with Souls-like games. What it fails to realize is that the system is designed as if the game is difficult and requires strategic thinking like a From Software game when instead the devs should have realized that they should award the player with aggression given the relatively small healthbars of most enemies and many of the enemies using telegraphed attacks that take a 132 step pre-flight check and 4 business days to complete. Almost all enemies have a stagger meter that can only be broken by 2 things: certain force powers and parrying. This means that you either spend 50% or more of combat waiting for the chance to parry or you spam force powers so you don't fall asleep. Many enemies that have stagger meters shouldn't even have them because they have less HP than the total number of strikes, skills, or parries to stagger them. Because the trash mobs take so little to kill, it makes the parry system worthless. To add insult to injury, bosses throughout the first two-thirds of the game *require* the player to parry and drop the boss' stagger bar to zero before being able to do decent damage. The boss fights in the first two-thirds of the game are the only real satisfying combat sequences because they actually require quick reflexes and using the parries to get to a damage sequence. The problem is in the last Act of the game, where most bosses have un-blockable and un-parryable attacks, which means you are forced to either wait even more time between parries and blocks or just spam force push. When the combat system begins to actively prevent the player to do what the game taught the player to do, you messed up. Then there are the elite enemies, which are either just trash mobs with more health or are so spam happy with quick attacks that instantly stagger you that you are forced to spam force push, making the skill once again an instant win button. The game did everything it could to feel hard but only made the game force push simulator.

Lastly, the customization is mediocre at best, and most of them come from the player taking an extra 10 seconds out of their boring map traversal to take the other corridor to find a chest in a corner, so most players will have at least 75% of all customization materials by the time they finish the game for the first time. Sadly, most of the ponchos are ugly or just don't match with any of the three (yes three) types of clothes that you can wear under the ponchos. The lightsaber customization is mediocre, with only about 12 different styles to choose from, half of them just recreations of lightsabers from the movies or TV shows. Lightsaber colors? Oh you only get two until the beginning of the last act. Hope you REALLY like blue and green because that is all you get with the base game up until then.

[h1] PROS [/h1]
[*] I absolutely love the fighting mechanics in this game, so satisfying and enjoyable
[*] The animation, worlds, and cut scenes for this game elevate your playing experience to max enjoyability (even 4 years later which is when I'm playing it)
[*] Story is amazing [spoiler] and you get to see Darth Vader & trilla turn good at the end!! [spoiler]
[*] Voice Acting is excellent and good mouth sync by animators
[*] The Easter eggs are so cool and fun, for example when BD1 hacks a KX-series droid, he has a chance to beep one of the original trilogy themes made by John Williams!
[*] This game is tagged as Souls-like and it definitely is, but it's such a good entry into the genre. It's not as hard as sekiro and there are options to change difficulty if it gets to hard for players
[*] Just the right amount of enemies scattered across each level
[*] No overly hard collectibles to collect for the completionists
[*] Fun achievements
[*] lots of new light saber and force mechanics that you can obtain through the skill tree to make your play-through easier & more fun

[h1] CONS [/h1]
[*] What the absolute fuck is the fire storm-trooper. He's so hard to kill. I'm salty asf.
[*] Some bosses are unreasonably difficult and the bounty hunter arena is SUCH a pain in the ass, half the time I restarted when I got killed by a bounty hunter just because I was afraid I would have to go through that shit again. But I guess that's just a key feature of souls-like games.
[*] Not going to lie, wish we had more worlds
[*] Map system is not super, it can tend to get very confusing about where you need to go and what areas you haven't fully finished yet (ESPECIALLY ON ZEFFO YIKES)

Overall, great game, even better Star Wars game. I've always been a supporter of Respawn since Titanfall 2 and boy they sure didn't miss with this. The animation and voice acting is smooth and the story is beautiful. The actual playing is even better and is addicting. I don't know about its replayability though because I've only just finished the game. There wasn't a single moment where I was getting super bored of the game and burnt out unlike some other games (looking at you ghostwire: Tokyo and Metro 2033). I am whole heartedly surprised this game didn't win GOTY.

Even though I'm a star wars fan, I couldn't stand the game. The lightsaber can't cut anything properly. Even Star Wars: The Force Unleashed 1 and 2 are so much better that I don't understand why this game is the way it is. There is a power pole, you can't cut it. it's just that sometimes you come across cables or plants, and you cut them through.
  Bullet deflection is fine too, but that dodge thing is killing me.
By the way, the game is designed directly for the console. So obvious that when playing on PC. I don't know if it will bother you, but it bothered me a lot.
Other than that, the story was so unnecessary dramatized that it made me nauseous.
The characters you don't care about talk to you, etc., the background stories of the side characters that are very uninspired.
The second game looks a little more promising. Maybe I'll play it, but this game disappointed me greatly. I don't understand how people love it.
You come to an area, you clean the creatures, you climb etc. accidentally fell down, the creatures you just chopped are in front of you alive. If you don't have a job, cut it off again.
Oh, and there's that ridiculous robot coming. That robot weighs at least 5-10 kilos. We also carry that robot on our backs, saying, come on, jump on my back and I'll walk you around. We see the garbage, bam he goes inside. Who the hell are you and you are looting for me. We carry that stupid robot that I don't really care about. Robot with broken leg, our guy is repairing shattered metal with screwdriver. And we sympathize with the game that made us fool.
It's not a recommended game, sorry for it. Even the Star Wars theme can't save this game.

A great Star Wars game. I do think it's slightly overrated.

Combat is great, it's super fun learning the weakness of enemies and how they work. Force powers were fun to mix into combat, but I kinda wish there were a larger variety of enemies.

Even though the story has some fantastic moments, like running through a moving train from the Empire, exploring a crashed Republic Venator ship, getting jumpscared by huge spiders, controlling an AT-AT, climbing up a huge tree with multiple crashed Republic ships, sliding down muddy areas while being chased by an Inquisitor, all the flashback scenes, running away from you-know-who, I thought most of the characters were bland, especially Cere, with Cal being slightly less bland than Cere, and Greez being slightly less bland than Cal. I actually really liked Merrin, but she's only a main character for the last 30 minutes of the game.

There are a good amount of upgrades that are useful, but a lot of the upgrades I got that included new moves were ones I never ended up using.

Running around, platforming and exploring while doing the story is fun, but really annoying when going for collectibles, since most of the maps are atrocious to look at, and some of the back tracking is very, VERY boring. If you missed any collectibles on your first playthrough, or just missed it while roaming around after the story, and then reach a point where you can't go backwards, you'll have to go all the way back. This was especially annoying when going through Dathomir, which has tons of areas where you can't go backwards, and some enemies that are a bit tougher than other enemies.

Although I liked customization, I didn't think anything was different enough. I get the customization options for the Mantis and BD-1, but for Cal all you have are different colored outfits and different colored ponchos. There's zero details besides the colors that get changed, which I wish wasn't the case, and I personally think that most of the lightsaber parts look horrendous.

I also think new game plus kinda sucks. I understand certain force powers being locked to story progression so you can't skip major parts in the story, but force echo upgrades should have been carried over (which only increase the amount of force and health you have), and whenever Cal heals his connection with the force, all new upgrades should automatically be unlocked.

8/10

I just finished this game recently and wanted to replay it since it was on sale when I got it. This is a game that Star Wars fans should play at least once.

First of all, the graphics are out of this world. The planets you get to explore are so realistic and beautiful. I felt like I was actually traveling through the Star Wars universe! The attention to detail is incredible, from the stormtroopers' armor to the lightsabers, everything looks sooooo awesome.

But the best part is being a Jedi. I mean, come on, who doesn't want to be a Jedi and use the Force? You get to play as this cool dude named Cal Kestis and go on this crazy adventure. The lightsaber battles are so intense and thrilling. I felt like a real Jedi knight, slashing and blocking those enemies like a total boss.

The story is like a rollercoaster ride. It's full of twists and turns, just like in the movies. You meet awesome characters along the way, like BD-1, the adorable droid who becomes your best friend. The voice acting is top-notch, and the dialogue is so well-written. It's not just a game; it's like being part of an epic Star Wars saga.

Oh, and did I mention the puzzles? They are challenging but super fun. You have to use your brain and figure out how to unlock doors and activate switches. It made me feel like a genius when I finally solved them. Plus, there are secret areas and cool collectibles to find, so it's like a treasure hunt.

Now, I have to admit, there were a few bugs here and there, but nothing that ruined the overall experience. The game is totally worth it, even with those minor issues.

To sum it up, Jedi: Fallen Order is a masterpiece. It's like living your own Star Wars adventure. The graphics are stunning, the gameplay is epic, and the story will keep you on the edge of your seat. If you're a fan of Star Wars or just love action-packed games, you HAVE to play this. IT IS OUT OF THIS WORLD. DONE AND DUSTED!

This game had a great story, and a progressive difficulty which is not seen very often. What I disliked about the game had to do with some of the combat feeling limited, as compared to other Star Wars games. That being said, it was very immersive.

This game is a perfect example of an average game. It's an average story, average presentation, average characters. However, what prevents me from being able to recommend this game to others is the clunky and unresponsive combat (no animation cancelling) and excessive backtracking.
fun game but no replay value

Great game that perfectly realizes the training Yoda was having Luke do on Dagobah.  Being a jedi is as much climbing and swinging around on ropes as being proficient with a lightsaber and the force.  Decent story with fun cameos.  Combat and meditation system definitely takes notes from the Souls series without being as unforgiving.  There are difficulty sliders too, so those interested in something Souls-like shouldn't feel too intimidated by this game.  There aren't any real stats to micromanage either, so you don't really need to worry about building a poor performing character.

I'm personally happy to see the souls-like mechanics get fed back into the game development system and start exploring the genre from there.  A couple of the borrowed souls mechanics don't really have a lore explanation beyond some arm waving, but I'm of the belief that not every game mechanic needs a lore explanation if it makes the game more fun.

At this point the game ran pretty stable on my 3060 & i7-7700K.  A few crashes here and there, but my save was never corrupted and I was easily able to hop back in an continue where I had left off.  This game will launch via EA games launcher.  Took just under 20 hours for me to complete the main story on the middle difficulty.

I recommend it only, as I am sure other people will enjoy it.

For me, personally, it's a 5/10 at best. You'd think the game has all the things I like, but... It just feels too "loose" in almost every single aspect. Story is loose, platforming is loose and combat is loose. I don't know if I was playing the whole game wrong somehow, but it felt very disjointed in every single aspect.

Pretty decent 20-ish hour game where that play time is definitely a pro. It's not "Dark Souls but Star Wars" like I was led to believe going into it. It's more of an action-adventure exploration game similar to Metroid or Castlevania. 

Everything in the game works fine 95% of the time, but there will be seconds where the platforming or combat just do not want to cooperate and it really took me out of it. Combat is probably the weakest aspect of the game. Trying to play this like a Souls game or even like Sekiro isn't going to work well. The parry timings are really weird and most of the enemies have hyper armor/poise in their animations. Fighting against multiple melee enemies can be pretty lame and getting surrounded is pretty much a death. You get abilities for fighting large groups of enemies, but you have no hyper armor/poise in your animations so any incoming attack will cancel your AoE attempts.

The bosses are all fine, as is the story. Decent game to pick up on sale and play over the course of a weekend.
This is a great game except for the final bossfight. It's worth it anyways.

This is one of my all time favorite games with a couple playthroughs on the Playstation under my belt. That being said, EA has made a grave mistake with the addition of the EA launcher to the Steam version. I bought this game on Steam with the sole intention of playing it on the Steam Deck when I travel. I was very unimpressed when I could not boot up the game while on the road. This is a SINGLE PLAYER ONLY RPG. There is absolutely no reason for this game to only be launchable when wi-fi is present.

In spite of this, I still give this game a thumbs up because its story, world-building, characters, level design, music, combat, parkour, and all the little details and fan moments in between make this a must play for Star Wars fans.

It's a good game! A souls-like unique in it's own way with an interesting story, intriguing characters, and fun mechanics. The world is very big with many secrets to find. If you're the kind of person who likes to pour over every inch of a game to see everything it has and be rewarded for it this is a game you'll likely enjoy. The level design and checkpoint system is reminiscent of Dark Souls but large and unique enough to not be a shallow copy. The combat is fun and gets better as you level up and unlock more abilities. The puzzles are also well thought and fun with one of my favorite features. The game asks you if you want a hint, it never gives it to you. Whenever you're in a puzzle area you can press a button and Cal will give you a hint. The game respects you enough to let you walk around and figure the puzzle out on your own without shouting the answer at you like God of War.

I did not like Star Wars: Jedi Fallen Order. This review is going to contain mild spoilers.

Let me talk about the things I liked about this game.

Some of the level design and art work is absolutely amazing. It truly captured the essence of Star Wars.

From a technical perspective, there are no issues whatsoever, other than the fact that there is double DRM to have to deal with - Steam and the horrendous EA App. There were no issues running the game at 3440x1440 resolution in borderless Window mode (excellent), and I was consistently getting over 120FPS on the highest settings.

Platforming is quite well done, especially in the good levels of the game.

I should have loved this game but I don't.

Star Wars: Jedi Fallen Order is a Souls like game, and this is the first of its kind that I ever played, and this concept is completely new to me. What I realized after playing this game is that for a Souls like game to be enjoyable, at least these two things need to happen -

The level design has to be very good. This is because there is a lot of backtracking involved. Under usual circumstances, one or two bad levels can be overlooked, but in a Souls like game, this problem is compounded because the player will end up revisiting the level more than once, and this can be very frustrating.

Enemies should be fun - not to be misinterpreted with easy.

The biggest problem with this game for me is that the game fails at both - the level design on some planets is not good, and the enemies are not fun.

There are a total of 6 planets in the game, and two of those planets are fun, and the rest are not. Less than 50% of the game that did not appeal to me.

- Bogano - Decent.
- Kashyyyk - The absolute worst.
- Zeffo - Excellent.
- Dathmoir - Could have been great, but ruined by enemies.
- Ilum - Decent.
- Nur - Excellent.

It felt to me that I spent most of the game fighting bugs, spiders in particular. As someone who has arachnophobia, this was pure torture. It got so irritating that I played these levels at 1920x1080 in windowed mode, without sound.

Just to give an idea, one of the objectives on the wookie planet is to climb a tree, and you get to fight bugs on the way to the top. It felt like Avatar Fallen Order. To drive the point home further, you even hitch a ride on the back of a bird. It absolutely did not feel like a Star Wars game. Add to this, there is a part of the game where you play without the lightsaber. It really made me question the intent behind this design.

After trudging through these levels, you get to play in a sci-fi setting with a dual lightsaber and it just reminded me how much fun this game could have been. I kept asking myself why the entire game wasn't like this. Is there a mystery audience out there that want to fight bugs and zombies in a Star Wars game?

Exploring a planet and looking for collectibles was out of the question because of the tedious design. Also, this game has the worst map screen I have ever seen in a game. This over engineered mess is truly a marvel of awfulness.

In addition to the bad level design there are very annoying things about the UX, for example, saving the involves mediating, which will is a painfully slow process of waiting for animations to complete. Its cool to look at twice, and then it gets very old.

The story felt weak and contrived. Nothing about the voice acting felt convincing and the cliche dialogue did not help - the usual Star Wars dialogue. The game suffers from plot armor, a character that should clearly died does not because of this kind of lazy writing.

I should have loved this game, but the bad level design, and enemies made me not enjoy it. If none of this bothers you, then you will have a lot of fun, as it is a technically competent game. I paid $4.79 for this, and I am not upset about that, but knowing what I know now, I wouldn't buy this game, because I did not have fun and there is no reason to spend $4.79 to not have fun.

Verdict - I don't like it.

My personal rating of this game is a 6, only because it's pretty. It's an old school puzzle platformer style game with a not very good melee combat system and basic RPG character building elements. It seems to be trying to rely on the Star Wars name for success rather than relying on being a good game. It has a cinematic story and seems to have a high production budget, but not a lot more. The endless jumping and scaling puzzles remind me of the old Tomb Raider games of the 90's. It has good graphics and a visually appealing game universe but the game itself is just not my style. If you like trying over and over and over to solve a puzzle or get through a fight, when you die and have to start at what usually equals 1/4 to 1/2 mile away, every single time, then this game is right up your alley. I can live with some games with checkpoint style game saves, but this one is too much. The only things that felt modern about this game is the graphics engine and the price. In my opinion, the only thing this game did well was piss me off. I am very disappointed and am actually looking to get a refund, which I don't normally do. I probably won't get one because I had the game for a week or so before I even played it, but I'm going for it.

After playing this game the first time in 2019 and revisiting this game 5 weeks ago, being able to experience the star-wars experience specific to Cal Kestis and its tie in the the canonical universe was simply awesome! From the Wookie interactions on Kashyyk to interacting with Kyber Crystals on Ilum (they foreshadow to construction of Starkiller base) to the hell-hole that is Dathomir there's simply so much excitement with an equal level of challenge. I thought i was a true fan of star wars and educated on its universe , this game helped me prove otherwise in a way that makes me want to be more invested. It took me 30 hours to 100% this game and i would honestly do it all again.

Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order, developed by Respawn Entertainment, aimed to deliver an immersive and exciting Star Wars adventure, placing players in the shoes of a young Jedi named Cal Kestis. While the game received widespread acclaim for its engaging storyline and challenging combat, it is not without its flaws. In this essay, we will explore the areas where Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order falls short and examine the aspects that hinder its full potential.

One of the notable drawbacks of Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order lies in its technical performance. The game suffered from occasional frame rate drops, glitches, and inconsistent loading times, which could disrupt the immersion and negatively impact the overall experience. Such technical shortcomings hindered players from fully engaging with the game's narrative and exploration, often resulting in frustration.

While Fallen Order attempted to incorporate puzzle-solving and platforming elements into its gameplay, it often fell into a pattern of repetition. The puzzles, although initially engaging, became predictable and lacked the complexity to challenge players consistently. Similarly, the platforming segments felt formulaic and lacked the innovation needed to keep players engaged. A greater variety in puzzle design and more inventive platforming sequences could have elevated the game's overall quality.

Exploration is a vital aspect of any Star Wars game, as it allows players to delve deeper into the rich lore and iconic environments. However, Fallen Order's exploration elements felt underwhelming. The worlds lacked a sense of true openness and discovery, often guiding players along linear paths with limited room for exploration. This constrained approach left players longing for a more expansive and immersive exploration experience within the Star Wars universe.

While the protagonist, Cal Kestis, is well-developed and engaging, the supporting characters in Fallen Order suffer from a lack of depth. They often come across as one-dimensional and fail to make a lasting impression. Greater attention to character development and more meaningful interactions with the supporting cast would have added emotional weight and further enriched the game's storytelling.

In a game driven by an engaging narrative, the absence of meaningful choices is a missed opportunity. Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order follows a linear storyline, leaving players with limited agency in shaping the outcome. The inclusion of impactful choices and branching storylines would have given players a sense of ownership over the narrative and heightened replayability.

Despite its flaws, Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order remains an enjoyable and immersive Star Wars experience. However, it is crucial to acknowledge the areas where the game falls short. Technical issues, repetitive puzzles, limited exploration, shallow supporting characters, and the absence of meaningful choices hinder the game from reaching its full potential. Recognizing these shortcomings allows for constructive criticism and the potential for future improvement in subsequent Star Wars titles, providing fans with even more memorable and satisfying gaming experiences in a galaxy far, far away.

I really like Jedi Fallen Order, it is a great Star Wars game even if it does have some flaws.

Let's talk about combat, the combat for the most part is a blast and I don't have any complaints besides some of the hitboxes being absolute a double s. You will have to actually battle back and fourth most of the times, not too difficult, but unless it's on Story Mode it's not really a piece of cake either. Some people do complain about you not feeling like a Jedi, but I also feel like they lost some of the point with it especially since Cal lost some of his way with the Force and is slowly relearning some of his abilities along the way, sure I wish I felt a little more powerful, but I definitely wasn't expecting him to be a Starkiller.

Story is really good, like top notch. I don't wanna spoil anything even if the game has been out for a minute. Just play through it or watch it on Youtube or something. Performances are also really good with actors like Cameron Monaghan (Cal), Daniel Roebuck (Greez), Tony Amendola (Eno), Debra Wilson (Cere), heck even Forest Whitaker (Saw) makes an appearance, just a really great cast.

I really love the way the levels look in this game, just like any other graphical aspect of the game these also look amazing and help immerse you into the game. Only really issue I have is when you complete everything and you wanna go back to grab all the collectibles, the amount of backtracking you have to do is absolutely nuts especially when you're on Zeffo like woof. It might've helped too had BD's holomaps actually been helpful, but they aren't and they start to get cluttered making navigation an absolutely pain, I wish they would've included some sort of fast travel options even if it was oh at Level 1 or Level 2 etc.

Also can we all just say f**k the EA launcher, like my god does this thing kill performance, my game would stutter and would have performance issues all the way through the game, one time the launcher crashes never opens and the game works fine, and you know what happens? My game is actually playing at a consistent framerate, like wow! And I had played through like 3 hours before I realized hey achievements aren't working..... cause they're tied to the EA launcher ugh. I did end up replaying to get all the achievements, but this isn't how this should work, when I order my game on Steam I do not want to have an additional launcher, had I wanted to play on EA I would have bought it there, it's absolutely nuts how many companies do this especially when it cuts performance in half.  Just play the DRM-Free version that's included, like for real, especially for the Linux homies.

Would definitely recommend this, one of the few Star Wars properties under Disney's control that is actually really good. Now all we need is to allow more studios to come up with their own single player stories or bring back some titles like 1313 and I'll be the happiest person alive. Also f**k the EA launcher.

First of all, the graphics, story and characters are great. The planets are large and the atmospheres realistic. The sound of the lightsaber gives you goosebumps. It's great that we can change the color of the lightsaber whenever we want. There are different combo techniques and it's fun to use them on stormtroopers. 

  The game's not over yet, I'll travel to damn Dathomir again. I enjoyed the game very much during the time I played it. However, however, I have so many positive things, I also have negative thoughts.  

---For example, we move back and forth between planets a lot. To get to a place on one planet, we have to go to the third planet to learn and come back again. It's a little annoying.

--- Another one is that NPCs are so stupid. Especially the stormtroopers :(

--- I had a hard time understanding the map and after you finish the mission you have to go back the same way, often by different routes.I wish there was teleportation between save points. It's a bit of a waste of time. 

I played the game for 20 hours and enjoyed it, even though it has its downsides. Especially BD-1 is very cute, our savior. It was really sad to see a different angle in the Order 66 scenes. I hope Cale can find a companion, he looks so lonely and desperate. It's a really good game for those who love the Star Wars universe, I'm looking forward to the end.  May the force be with you guys.
