Second time I've played this, first time on PC, and really enjoyed it a lot more - so much so that I 100 percented it. The story takes you on a bit of a treasure hunt of sorts, which leads you to a few different places, some already seen in Star Wars, and some new locations too, where you'll find main character Cal being roped into a few smaller storylines, and all the while being hunted by the sinister Inquisitors. There's some great moments here and there, especially with its Williams-esque soundtrack and small connections to the wider Star Wars world, but the plot itself is just okay, and while it would have been nice for it to be a little bit more involved in the game, it serves its purpose well enough to prop up the gameplay. The characters are equally middling - whilst they all have distinct personalities and great chemistry, there's very little development, and when it does happen it doesn't feel well set up or earned. 

That said, gameplay is where Fallen Order really shines. It blends the exploration and puzzle solving of games like Tomb Raider with Souls-like combat (or so I'm told), including its own array of challenging boss battles. There's a plethora of new skills, abilities and force powers to unlock as the game goes on, as well as the learning curve of the combat creating a rewarding progression experience. The maps are well designed, although a little bit bland to look at, and there's a lot of fantastic action sequences. Collectables and upgrades will keep you coming back to places you've already been after unlocking new abilities, and more of the maps open up for exploration. Customisation is there, both for the player, companions, and most importantly the lightsaber, although the limited range of options leaves it feeling a little shallow. Other than that, there isn't much left to say except it really is just a fun, solid experience that doesn't drag on and doesn't feel too brief.

Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order leaves me disappointed. There were many positive reviews for this game and even though I knew that some aspects of it were not to my preference, I saw it on sale and decided to give it a chance as I am a huge Star Wars fan (or at least I used to be before Disney). 

The Pros: The game looks great, but almost everything does these days, and with the kind of funding it had I can‚Äôt give it to much credit. The facial animations are top notch and I can easily understand the emotions of characters, even if they are not human. The audio is also excellent, and while nothing stood out to me from the music, it didn‚Äôt irk me either. However, this is where my enjoyment ends.

The Cons: The combat is terrible. If you enjoy games where it is hard to control your character or interact with the world then you may enjoy the challenge (i.e. Sekiro but unbalanced and a stupid camera). The timing for actions and the camera positioning are inconsistent at best which lead to many frustrating deaths. This is my biggest issue with the game as I was frequently dying, not due to a lack of skill but an inability to interact with the game the way I wanted to. In combat my camera would end up facing behind me, I would get stuck on objects, and the timing was all over the place. I became frustrated with the game when I should have been frustrated by the enemies I was fighting. Essentially, if you can‚Äôt buy into this style of combat, then you will not enjoy the game as it accounts for most of the content.
The story never grabbed my attention (and was rather cringy). The concept of a Jedi padawan who escaped from order 66 and wants to rebuild his order while finding their place in the world is interesting, but is has one glaring issue. To some extent, without evening finishing the game, I already know the ending. He fails, the empire becomes even more powerful and the atrocities they commit continue to increase in scale. We know this from the events of the original trilogy and it gives a feeling of futility to the main characters actions, and therefore mine. To be fair, I have not played much of this game and I do not know the ending. My point is, after 3 hours, I simply do not care enough to try and find out. The individual stories of the characters never made me ask why or want more dialogue, but instead I found myself asking why I couldn‚Äôt skip cutscenes.
The maps/environment are my last major gripe with this game. Yes, it is a game and I get that in some ways it will be unrealistic, but Fallen Order takes is unable to find a balance. It wants to be taken seriously in the cutscenes and then drops that as soon as you are in control again. The multi leveled, compact environment has something new around every corner (even though much of it is locked until later) but it does not feel like I am in the Star Wars universe. The difference between serious moments in the Jedi temple contrasted with the completely unbelievable landscape surrounding is frustrating. 

Overall, Star Wars Jed: Fallen Order is not a bad game by any means, but for me, it is not enough to recommend to others.

EDIT: This game is Star Wars. Unlike so much of recent works, this game has that Essence of Star Wars that hit's home. Do I still dislike the controls. ABSOLUTELY, but the patches have improved things substianlly (plus mods). This Star Wars Story is is hidden behind its gameplay being a barrier to entry that I wish was more adjustable. HOWEVER, this is Star wars beginning to end and I regret not sticking with it to experience it when it released (Fuck you developers for your buggy and inacessable release). PS. I love this story developers. please make more Star Wars (fuck Disney).

Fallen Order is a game that truly shows the potential that Star Wars games have. Over the years, there have been many games that tried to capture that true Star Wars feeling of adventure mixed with power and wonder, and Fallen Order does that beautifully.

Let's start with our characters. I love every single one of them. From Cal to Merrin, Trilla to Greez, everyone shines in their own way, even the NPC Stormtroopers get some small bits of personality thrown in. But Cal in particular is a character I want to talk about, because, from an honest point of view, he's not all that important. Cal is a regular Jedi that survived Order 66 and is now struggling to survive in a world dominated by a dark Empire, but he is no Luke Skywalker, he isn't the Chosen One and he doesn't have any deep connections to the force. He was a regular Padawan that now lives in hiding, afraid to take action while trying to survive. And that's why his story has so much meaning to me. Because everyting he goes through feels natural. When the game starts, he has to learn everything he was taught from the ground up, since the trauma he went through during Order 66 was so strong it damaged his connection to the Force. He isn't quick to trusting Cere or Greez and is waiting for their actions to speak for them, but he wants to leave this life of hiding in fear, so he takes action and tries to help them as best as he can.

As the game progresses, he becomes even more likable. His interactions with the others always feel real, specially with Cere, who basically serves as his new Jedi Master.

But we all know about Star Wars and its lore, how's the gameplay? 
Honestly, it's pretty good. I am a sucker for games that allow me to change fighting stances/styles on the fly, so the fact that I have two lighstabers that have completely different moves and attacks makes me pretty damn happy. Every move has a nice feel to it, the speed and strenght of the attacks feel adequate, they are a lot more realistic but satisfying nonetheless.
There are a few gripes I have with the combat, though. I think the game would benefit heavily from things like super armor during certain moves, seeing as they not only cost Force to use but also are not instant and require some wind up first, it's very common for you to get surrounded, try to use a special move to get some space but end up doing nothing because you got hit, and now you're in a situation where you're still surrounded, but have less health and less Force to use on special moves. 
Also, the souls-like combat with stamina bars and parries would go well with the game if not for the fact that you're constantly getting attacked by multiple enemies at once, making it very common for you to go on a parry-chain where you're just parrying attack after attack but can't damage anyone because the enemies just keep coming. Which also wouldn't be a problem to deal with if certain moves made for crowd control had things like super armor to make it a more viable option.
This is a lot more present in things like late game encounters and combat challenges, but as a guy that likes to dissect combat mechanics and take them to the extreme, it feels kinda sad that I can't explore this game's combat further due to cracks in the design.

But overall, the combat is very fun and it does the "making you feel like a badass Jedi" job pretty fucking well

Other things that are very much worth mentioning are the open world, which not only looks absolutely gorgeous but is also very well made. All of the planets are very easy to tell apart from one another, which really brings the whole level design together.
I would've liked for the game to have fast travel, though. It would've been a lot easier and less time consuming to have easier ways to travel around the map, specially for planets like Zeffo and Dathomir, which are either really fucking big or too linear, creating a lot of difficulty when traversing some areas for later, post-story exploring. Hopefully they include something of sorts for the next game.

Oh, and the story is actually pretty interesting, the things some of those characters go through really resonates with you and makes you cheer for them during happy moments but also feel their pain when the time comes. I played the game twice, and one specific scene made me cry during both playthroughs, and although I can be a softie for these types of things sometimes, this game really does a great job at portraying strong feelings, be them of sadness, happiness or even terror.

If you like Star Wars, you'll probably like this game a lot. If you like hitting shit with laser swords you'll also probably like it a lot. I know I loved it and so did my girlfriend, and that makes it good enough for me to recommend it.

solid star wars action game. it lends some aspects of soulslike combat but don't be fooled by some buzzword reviews, this is neither a soulslike nor a metroidvania. think of it more as uncharted in the star wars universe with fun melee combat. reminded me of the good old ps2 era single player third person action games.

Don't buy this game when origin got changed out for EA app the game became unplayable. The EA app says to try later. It's been 6 months.

The game is a good souls-like with a Star Wars theme (but a bit too much "hand holding" imo). The story is a bit cliche but the environments are engaging and interesting and the force holos do a decent job of giving the world life and makes it feel like you are part of something bigger. There are unskipable cutscenes and time wasting dialogues (especially on the Mantis) that can get a bit annoying. The use of force is well implemented and is fun to use in fights and combos without making it feel overpowered. The combat overall feels good and is great fun, but the boss fights get a bit boring and samey towards the end. The water sections are boring and the game would've been better without the ability to dive underwater.

Apart from gameplay there are no in-game purchases or micro transactions and that deserves praise on its own. There are some visual bugs (mostly textures pop-ins and stutters) and a few funny glitches, but nothing bad and I didn't experienced any game-breaking issues or crashes during my play through. The EA launcher integration is annoying and, combined with unskipable and slow EA logo, makes launching the game take ages, but once you are in the main menu getting into the gameplay is fast. There is a good amount of customisable settings in the menus that allows you to turn off annoying or unnecessary things (i.e. turning off QTEs).

For me story completion took about 18-20 hours of playtime playing at a leisurely pace. 100% with all achievements took me around 26 hours. There is replayability with newgame+, but I don't really see the point other than using NG+ to complete the achievements.

Overall the game is a good experience and would recommend to anyone who enjoys souls-likes and likes the Star Wars theme. Maybe skip this one if you are a Star Wars fan but don't like playing souls-likes.

A cinematic masterpiece. Story was amazing, with a surprise at the end that had the kid in me freaking out. It's a shame that the last few minutes of the story kind of crapped the bed, but overall up until excluding the literal VERY END of the story it was an amazing ride.

Gameplay-wise it was a good time, but the force-awakens games from 10yrs. ago did force powers MUCH better and were more fun. Force powers in this game are adequate to get the job done but weren't anything spectacular. The dark-souls fighting mechanics are at odds with the power ups and combos - the enemies can too easily interrupt you mid-attack, basically nerfing almost all the cool combos and attacks that you've built up throughout the game save for the most basic enemy types. That again is where the old Force-Awakens games shined in that once you were fully powered up you could rip through enemies like a hot knife through butter! Other than the most basic storm troopers and rat-things you never get to enjoy your whole toolbox of abilities in a truly satisfying way, and that goes for right up to the end.

Visually it's absolutely stunning, and if you've got good hardware ( I'm running a 5900x/6800xt combo that runs the game native 4k with all the settings on "epic" - and the graphics on those settings live up the "epic" naming scheme) it's basically like being in a starwars movie. almost 4yrs later it is every bit the graphical equal, if not better, then a lot of contemporary games.

I would highly recommend it, ESPECIALLY on sale.

TLDR: 6/10
- The running is very glitchy and it pissed me off a lot. 
- The story is average in terms of creativity and originality.
- Another game where dodge/parry/attack rinse & repeat is the way to win. 
- Started it a while ago, got bored, stopped, and came back (beat it in 14 hours). 

Gameplay: 7/10
- Less horse poop than dark souls; difficult at times, but not too hard. 
- Combat is designed in a way that you can only effectively light attack, any thing else will get you killed.  
- Running is the most glitchy and broken thing I have ever witnessed. 
- Sometimes the jumping after sliding would send me into a random direction causing me to miss many basic jumps.
- Blaster projectiles travel too slowly, so I used a mod to speed them up and it was more fun. 
- Deflecting blaster rounds is very satisfying.
- The bosses for the most part seem to be unable to land their empowered attacks and will miss even if you don't dodge.
- Combining many combat styles into one mechanic was interesting, but doesn't really work imo.
- Even basic enemies can stop your combo attacks and animation cancel you; thus they are useless.
- Only 3 'real' boss fights. 
- The puzzles are sometimes difficult to understand, but for the most part they are meh.

Story: 5/10
- We do not get enough planets imo, only like 5 (from memory).
- Cal cuts himself off from the force as a plot point to gain 'new' abilities.
- Very basic Star Wars plot here.
- Hero survives Order 66, finds crew, goes on mission, learns about self, beats boss. There is really nothing else to it.
- The main characters are acceptable, but not unique; we have seen stories like that many times before. 
- Merrin decides to join you before the last mission for no real reason; and does basically nothing. 

Final thoughts & final rating: 6/10
- I did like what this game had to offer, I just think that it is probably only worth around $30. 
- There is also no reason to play again, other than if you want to play new game+, to stomp on higher difficulties.

I'm an older gamer and I wanted to try one of the Star Wars games and also I wanted to see what the fuss is all about regarding the "souls-like" games, which I had not played.  The controls take some getting used to but what I like is that the port to PC doesn't involve a massive number of keystrokes for the movement and combat. The limited number of keys works well for combat and the abilities and there are not many keystroke combinations to remember.  This being said, the enemies are tough on Normal skill so patience and figuring out how to beat them is required.  I like the combat, it's realistic, and the light saber/force ability combination produces some satisfying kills.  There's a particular trick to defeating a boss that involves what to do during a boss's "unblockable" attacks.  I won't spoil it by revealing it here but it's counter-intuitive, that's all I will say about it.  The map takes some getting used to but once learned, it's actually quite good for getting around the levels.  The skill tree is cool, there's lots of character upgrades available.  Graphically, the game is nice, it looks good but it's not quite the photo-realistic stuff we are getting now.  Also, your rig has to be fairly powerful to get good frame rates and avoid stuttering.  I'm using a 1080 Ti still and it plays the game fine, just some stuttering in the cut scenes.  The story is good, Cal Kestis is a good character to play and the Empire is quite evil and nasty, as it should be.  My only frustration with the game is actually moving around.  There are a lot of movement puzzles and sometimes those slow the game down a bit.  All things considered, though, I am happy with the game and I intend to play the new one as well using the skills I learned in this game.  If you are a Star Wars game fan, this one should be in your library.

I want to like this game; it's souls-like, a genre I generally like, has interesting skills, and of course, is set in the Star Wars universe, but is a single player RPG experience. I think a lot of people love this game, and I understand why, but I just personally cannot recommend it.

Reason being is simple; for a game that relies on precision of action and reaction to enemy attack pattern the combat system is not nearly precise enough, and the latency on some actions, especially blocking, are maddenly sluggish and inconsistent. I have spent hours trying to beat Dark Souls bosses and never felt as frustrated as I have with bosses, and even more difficult regular enemies, even when I 'easily' overcome them. It just feels off and bad, rewarding spamming slow and pull to punch through enemy guard far more than tight blocking and attacks; enemies stagger, but then don't randomly on the same attacks; some unblockable attacks are stupidly easy to avoid, and others are virtually impossible, the enemy giving almost no telegraph time or honing in on you despite how well you time a dodge; and most frustratingly is when you try to transition directly from a block to an attack and the action is just ignored.

I don't claim to be a high reflex gamer, but lowering the difficulty, while allowing me to brute force my way through sections, felt just as unsatisfying. Again, I WANT to like this game, and hope the sequel is a bit tighter on controls, because it's ALMOST THERE, but it was a constant fight to finish this game, and one of the final boss battle literally has me walking away from this game.

Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order is an action-adventure game developed by Respawn Entertainment and released in November 2019. Set in the Star Wars universe, the game tells the story of Cal Kestis, a young Padawan who survived the purge that destroyed the Jedi Order after the events of Episode III: Revenge of the Sith.

The game's storyline is one of its greatest strengths. It is engaging, well-written, and immerses players in the Star Wars universe. The characters are well-developed, and players quickly become invested in their journey, rooting for them to succeed.

The gameplay in Jedi: Fallen Order is also exceptional. It is a mix of exploration, platforming, and combat, with a skill tree system that allows players to customize Cal's abilities to their playstyle. The combat system is particularly impressive, with lightsaber battles that are both fluid and challenging.

The game's graphics are stunning, with impressive attention to detail and a variety of beautifully designed locations. The soundtrack is also noteworthy, with composer Gordy Haab creating a score that perfectly captures the essence of the Star Wars universe.

Overall, Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order is a fantastic game that does justice to the Star Wars franchise. Its exceptional storyline, gameplay, graphics, and soundtrack make it a must-play for any Star Wars fan. The game's combination of exploration, platforming, and combat creates a captivating and challenging experience that is both rewarding and satisfying. In my opinion, it is a 10/10 game that deserves the praise it has received from both fans and critics alike.

Revisited this game over 3 years later after "gitting gud" and soloing almost all of Elden Rings main bosses (Melania included along with most side content, too). Read the old review if you want, bottom line is the game just doesn't feel good to play. The parry timing is simultaneously too lenient and too unforgiving at the same time. It feels like the parry window exists between where parry windows should exist. You don't parry right before they swing, and you also don't parry right as the swing would hit you. You parry during the start of the swing but not in the middle of it, which makes parrying feel SUPER janky. Enemies will barely even be starting their attack yet they get parried but a claw or bite that's right about to hit after you've had adequate time to react? Sorry, we wanted to make this game have memorization based combat, common sense means nothing here.

Attack patterns are as unintuitive and "just learn the patterns by dying to them a bunch" as you'd expect any artificially difficult game to be. I wish it wasn't a controversial statement to say that memory based combat is not good combat. Horizon Zero Dawn is a hard game (when at max difficulty) but it doesn't derive it's difficulty from arbitrary timing in animation. You see that you're about to get hit, you time your dodge, you reposition. It makes sense. If you ask me, and here's another controversial opinion (at least among "souls-like" games), it's satisfying to be rewarded for trusting your intuition. Note that I'm not saying it's satisfying to be rewarded for mashing defensive options, but when I time my button press for what feels like the right moment just for either the windup animation or the hitbox itself to linger and hit me after I dodge? That doesn't feel good. At all.

You can have a good combat system without it relying on me memorizing timing. I wish this longtime trend would die but games keep doing it. I understand the satisfaction of learning the flow of a fight... in moderation. Yes, learning the dance is rewarding, I personally even enjoyed fighting Melania... the first 100 times. This game feels like the subsequent 300 attempts every time a fodder enemy weirdly pivots without moving its feet, hits me after it's done swinging, or ignores my parry because I was "too late" (in this context, "too late" translates to "the moment a parry would occur").

Here's the old review from 2019:

The primary gameplay mechanic is dying. The game takes an average player 20-25 hours to beat from what I've heard, I beat it in 12 when I set it to the easiest mode so I could just enjoy the story (yOuRe hAviNg FuN WrOnG) aka you're supposed to spend 7 hours of your time doing nothing but dying... great game 2/10. Story wasn't worth it either but at least it's pretty.

STAR WARS Jedi Fallen Order is how EA showed that they are able to make great games without microtransactions. The world, combat and gameplay that they provide in one long story is admirable. Probably one of the best, if not the best game EA has ever made, or even the best Star Wars game ever made. Cal shows that even though Disney is very restrictive with the creation and characteristics of the Star Wars franchise, the allowance of the character growth and story shown feels original and not a marketing method, on part of Disney. A showing that Disney still wants to feel as family-friendly as possible, is that the dismemberment only occurs for non human enemies(The Beasts, monsters, etc). Even though that restriction is understandable in some way, still the combat feels as fresh as in a Star Wars game could be. The souls-like combat allows for many combinations of movements, while still not being an easy to learn combat style. You cannot just go swinging your sword like a frickin maniac without getting hit, or even dying if you get attacked by multiple enemies. Now, the world that the game provides I think, as a Star Wars fan is incredible. The planets shown are known by the most hardcore fans, and the little force echoes or the secrets give more info on the deep lore of each of the planets. The customization is a great way to allow the player to feel more like Cal, personalizing the Poncho, the suit color, and even the BD1 and The Mantis paint job. But the most important customization tool is the lightsaber. Every player has a totally different way that they want to have their lightsaber, in color, switches and many other characteristics that someone can change. Incredible, as Greez¬¥s plants. The last point that I want to say is that the story could be, if I'm not mistaken, canon, happening before the events of Episode 4, but after Episode 3, which could potentially make Cal come to live-action.

My last words...

"A really well written story, with a great combat and connection to the original material, showing that Disney isnt always so bad..."

It might have been a good game if it wasn't about a Jedi. The false pretense that you have a strong character, but can get absolutely mauled in a corner by Stormtroopers really played with my head. When I'm used to games like Jedi Academy giving me a fair representation of a Jedi and it's abilities, all the enemies in this universe/game are built to counter Jedi.

Enemies can chain-stun you repeatedly, and not give you an option to even stagger them once. You'll hit them with the wet noodle of a lightsaber, and they'll punch you in the face like it never happened. It didn't give much room for optional playstyles. I like to play aggressively, but I was forced to tumble-roll around the map like a circus clown to avoid unblockable attacks that were repeated over and over.

The story was interesting enough, but I felt like I was brute forcing my way through every section of the game. If they gave the player an unblockable attack like all the enemies have, or allowed enemies to stagger the way the player gets staggered over every hit, it would have been more enjoyable.

I give this game a 8 out of 10. I mostly play open world games, but I just could not resist a chance to play a good Star Wars game. The positives are I enjoyed the story line, and the graphics where really good also. The mechanics of the game were comfortable and smooth, and I really enjoyed the abilities you earned over time making your character become a "force" to deal with; you could noticeably feel your character improving over time after you had unlocked abilities. The negatives where there was no real loot system, and the few things you could loot where junk of no real use at all to your characters performance. The big negative for me was it's linear game play. I played A Plague Tale which is a liner game, but it's creators somehow managed to avoid it having a linear feel to it. The creators of Jedi: Fallen Order failed at this terribly. I felt like I was stuck in a hallway unable to turn right or left for 95% of the game. The world was just to small and presented very few (if any) exploring possibilities. I will recommend this game since it really was overall fun to play, but due to its claustrophobic feel and zero chance of having missed something worthy of exploration on the first play through, I do not see it being worthy of a second play through.

EA is ruled by a Sith Lord who endeavors to prevent me from rebuilding the Jedi Order.

It's an insidious plan, like all Sith's plans. EA grafted a broken EA launcher that requires an EA account, and doesn't work. I tried over and over, with multiple mails. EA just didn't want me to play the game I bought. I can only imagine the mad laughs the EA Sith Lord was having at my expense.

I was about to yield and refound the game, EA Sith Lord victorious.

Yet, there was a flaw in the Sith plan for Jedi Fallen order. There isn't just one executable, there is also another! By relinking steam to the executable "SwGame-Win64-Shipping.exe", I was able to flank EA's Evil third party launcher and play Jedi Fallen Order.

Upon launching, EA's abomination of a broken launcher pitifully asks to be installed. By standing fast, and following the force, I can push the X and close the abomination. The game finally launches. I shall rebuild the Jedi Order, despite EA Sith Lord best effort to prevent the Jedi from raising from the ashes!

EA Sith Lord planted many more traps. The unskippable cutscene at the start of the game can be foiled by renaming Content\Movies\GARBAGE_Default_Startup.mp4.

Post processing cannot be bypassed, leading to an ugly temporal aliasing. I'm still learning the ways of the Force to suppress this Sith Trap as well. It's a long tortuous path.

May the force be with you if you choose to oppose EA Sith Lord.

First lets just get this out of the way: Its a Sekiro clone. It has the exact same base gameplay and supporting mechanics. Though unexpectedly I ended up quite liking the game, despite not liking Sekiro. Still trying to figure that out.

Anyway, its a Star Wars game about being a Jedi (add it to the list) but unlike most jedi games its both significantly challenging, and feels quite satisfying when you do pull things off in a skillful manner. If they were going to pick anything to make a Sekiro clone in terms of gameplay, this was a really good choice for it. Force powers have tangible use in gameplay and can be quite helpful in combat with some opponents (particularly some Dark Troopers, force powers can turn an impossible encounter into a trivial one), and you can deflect blaster bolts as seen in the movies. Overall Respawn Entertainment (NOT EA they are a publisher, not a developer, get your facts straight FFS) nailed it in terms of gameplay.

In terms of story...Well it occurs in the events in between SW episodes 3 and 4. Aside from that, honestly, its nothing special. It wasn't bad, but not particularly good or outstanding either. Its typical star wars writing in other words.

So just be clear, if you buy this, buy it for the gameplay first and foremost. I don't particularly like that you need to use Origin to launcher the game, but there are ways around that for the persistent.

I like Star Wars but am not a die hard fan, and even I can appreciate what a huge fan service this game is. 

It's story rich, with great detail and superb voice and performance capture by known Hollywood actors. 
But it's also great fun, and really HARD on the hard setting (many games are still quite easy even in hard mode). You have tons of fast paced lightsaber action, parkour and climbing, huge slides and wall walking, big (and small) boss fights, and often fighting multiple enemies at once.

Every enemy and every boss requires a specific strategy, this isn't a button mashup kind of game. At the beginning, when facing stronger enemies on the harder game settings it can get a bit frustrating and you die a lot and fast (two mistakes and you're dead kind of fast). Timing is really critical and using the correct powers and skills at the right times, and difficulty scales with your progress so the game doesn't become easy in higher levels (but you don't die as quickly at least lol).

I'm really hooked and will definitely replay from the beginning in the future.

STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order is an incredible exploration, combat, puzzle, story rich and adventurous game, journeying into the Star Wars universe. Not only does it feature new and incredible locations, but also brings back locations from the films and shows, such as Kashyyyk and Dathomir. The story is very well written and executed, with the cast of voice actors doing an outstanding performance. Respawn really did a good job with this one. So much for EA claiming single player titles were dead.
The Story is by far the best for a recent Star Wars game, making the Battlefront II story look terrible compared to this. You play as Cal Kestis, a former Jedi in hiding on the planet Bracca, where even in the opening sequence of the game, Respawn added a whole motherlode of eye candy such as Tie Fighters, Probe Droids, Republic Star Destroyers and even a Sarlacc Pit! In the game you journey across the stars to find various artifacts to help you on your perilous quest, while also being repeatedly halted by various adversaries who have other plans for the fruit of all your efforts. A brilliant, well contained story that really knows how to entertain and please its audicence.
The Gameplay feels smooth and well refined, with important skills being unlocked throughout the story. These skills determine which areas of the map you can access, so if you get stuck somewhere it might just be because you haven't progressed through the story enough. Unlocked skills really change every fight and the boss fights really do feel like bosses. Highly recommended is unlocking more stim packs, as these are crucial for having a good experience and not dying all the time.
The Music is incredible, sounding just like it had come straight from John Williams himself, with some scores even coming from or being influenced from the films! Truly makes you feel in a Star Wars experience!.
Overall, STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order is another incredible game from an incredible studio. The achievements are all quite easy to achieve but require some research and guides, but don't take too long. The game also features a new game + mode where you can use cosmetics from a previous save but start the story over. A very fun and amazing game. Highly recommended!
STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order gets a 9/10.

Great presentation, but kinda tedious combat. The first annoying part about combat is not knowing what you don't know. In other words, there's a way to make this enemy less annoying to fight, but you haven't unlocked it yet, and you don't know that it exists.

The second part is when you realize that there's literally no point in fighting most enemies. Your health is limited between checkpoints by the number of stims you can carry, so it's to your advantage to run past everything and not fight it so you can save your stims for encounters that you're forced to have.

The third annoying part about combat is how reliant it is on the parry system. That means that most of the time you're just waiting the enemy to attack so you can parry and counter -- that is, if parrying can even lead to a counter. A lot of the time, a parry won't immediately lead to a punish, because their block meter hasn't been fully depleted. When that happens, it feels very anti-climactic and contrary to a nice battle flow because even though you've just countered, you can't do any follow-up attack.

You're also given force powers, but aside from a few obvious push-pull scenarios, it's not obvious what you'd actually do with them. If you want to watch someone on YouTube describe how to min-max the force powers for each individual enemy encounter, go right ahead. I'm sure there's an optimized formula or method for that. However, a better and more intuitive combat system would have let all force powers range between mildly and very effective depending on the scenario, rather than being some rock-paper-scissors type of effectiveness, or achieve nothing other than briefly interrupting the flow of battle at the cost of force with no benefit whatsoever.

So yeah, cool story, great graphics, mostly annoying combat.

A Single Player Masterpiece: Defying Critics and Embracing Excellence

Introduction:
In the vast landscape of gaming, few experiences rival the sheer joy of immersing oneself in a captivating single-player game. Among the countless titles available, one game stands out as a shining example of excellence, weaving an unforgettable narrative and delivering exhilarating combat. This review aims to shed light on the remarkable journey I embarked upon and address the misguided opinions that undermine its brilliance.

Captivating Storytelling:
One of the hallmarks of a remarkable single-player game is its ability to transport players into a richly developed world, enveloping them in an engaging story. The game in question masterfully accomplishes this feat, leaving players spellbound from start to finish. The narrative is expertly crafted, with well-rounded characters and intriguing plot twists that keep players eagerly pushing forward. I found myself emotionally invested in the protagonist's journey, experiencing a range of emotions that few games can elicit. The game's ability to weave a tale of such depth and complexity is a testament to the developers' dedication and skill.

Exhilarating Combat:
While an enthralling story lays the foundation, no single-player game is complete without satisfying gameplay mechanics. In this aspect, the game excels, delivering combat that is as breathtaking as it is satisfying. The fluidity of the controls allows players to effortlessly execute intricate moves, creating a seamless combat experience. The game strikes the perfect balance between challenge and reward, providing moments of intense action that test the player's skills while offering a sense of accomplishment. Each encounter is meticulously designed, encouraging strategic thinking and providing a plethora of options for dispatching foes. The combat system is a true work of art, showcasing the developers' commitment to delivering an exceptional gameplay experience.

Misguided Criticisms:
Unfortunately, no matter how exceptional a game may be, it is bound to face unwarranted criticism from a small fraction of players. It is essential to recognize that negative reviews often stem from a place of misunderstanding or personal bias rather than objective analysis. One common criticism revolves around the game's playtime, with some arguing it is too short. However, this viewpoint fails to consider the game's focus on quality over quantity. Each moment spent in this meticulously crafted world is packed with meaning and purpose, delivering a concentrated dose of entertainment. Judging a game solely based on playtime overlooks the immense value that can be derived from a carefully constructed experience.

Additionally, it is crucial to highlight that those who criticize without fully understanding the game's intricacies lack the credibility to undermine its excellence. By dismissing their ill-informed opinions, the developers can remain focused on the game's true audience‚Äîthe players who appreciate the artistry and dedication poured into every aspect of its creation.

Conclusion:
In the realm of single-player gaming, this particular game shines as a beacon of excellence, offering an unforgettable experience that captivates from beginning to end. Its superb storytelling and exhilarating combat mechanics set a new standard for the genre, leaving players in awe of its brilliance. While negative reviews may attempt to diminish its worth, it is vital to recognize the misguided nature of such criticisms. This game deserves to be celebrated and cherished by those who appreciate the profound impact that a single-player journey can have on one's gaming experience.

I'm not a big fan of the Star Wars universe, but I still decided to play this game. The impression of the game was mixed.

The level design in the game seemed interesting to me. Visually, it's not bad and has its moments, but it quickly becomes tedious. Probably because everything is tailored to the characters and the plot, which turned out to be quite predictable. Difficulty! Here is where I had a little issue. I changed the difficulty several times. On one hand, it's interesting to struggle in some boss battles, but on the other hand, it becomes tiresome to kill the same dummy enemies for the tenth time. And honestly, towards the end of the game, I started feeling bored. I stopped getting into the plot too much - I just wanted to finish it quickly and forget about it. There is a story and characters, of course, but they didn't really resonate with me.

You can buy it for 20% of its price, but not for the full price.
its Good

The last hack and slash Star Wars game I played before this was The Force Unleashed II and I was hoping for and expecting more of that. This game is not that. It's more adventure/exploration/puzzle with an actual story that makes more sense than the narrative of both TFU games. While I'm no fan of Disney these days I do appreciate a good canon, story-driven campaign in games. It's beautiful to look at and I think the story itself is decent and comprehensible. 

Now for the bad.
The controls are a little more awkward than I'm used to but I've gotten the hang of it. So that's not so bad.
Now, I know a lot of people like puzzles and I personally don't mind them. With that being said, some of the puzzles in this game can be a bit convoluted. 
My biggest gripe, but by no means the worst I've seen in any video game, would be some of the bosses. Specifically the "hidden" or "secret" bosses. They have some janky hit boxes and sometimes even get stuck in a loop of attacks that can't be blocked. Even this is inconsistent and doesn't always happen with even the same boss. For example, the Albino Wyyyschokk boss on Kashyyyk has an inconsistent hit box on it's attacks. One moment I'm dodging all of it's unblockable attacks and the next I'm killed by it when it's attack lands a couple feet in front of me and does not actually connect, meaning I should not have been hit. Another time I will be able to narrowly dodge with mere inches between us.
Lastly, this game has some performance issues like stuttering. They aren't too bad and eventually clear up on their own. 

All-in-all I think it's a good, solid Star Wars game worth checking out, especially if you are/were a fan of TFU I & II, despite being different. I do very much recommend it despite its few flaws.

Good game overall, but quite a few issues that hold it back. The combat is almost Souls-like but lacks the depth and complexity to really compare. It gets the basics done fine so combat isn't bad or annoying but it's not particularly enjoyable either. Enemies have cheesy unrealistic behaviour like instantly snapping towards your direction, which is especially noticeable when you Force Slow a giant frog and run circles around it and it spins like it's a compass and you're the whole planetary magnetic field. Not only is it silly, it also negatively impacts the gameplay experience somewhat because it means you can't use knowledge and skilful positioning to dodge attacks like in Souls games. This is just one of a few things that really separates this game from being a true Souls-like with good combat. 

To be fair, the combat does shine at times, particularly when facing the lightsaber-wielding bosses. They are well designed and difficult without being unfair, and the fights look great too. The game should have had more of that, rather than all the random wildlife which isn't anywhere near as interesting or fun to fight. And lore-wise it's just ridiculous a random sheep or bug can be an actual threatening opponent for a Jedi. 

Another issue is the revolting overabundance of "squeezing through small gaps" sections, which sometimes last upwards of 30 seconds, of just holding forwards and watching your character ever so slowly and painfully squeeze through. Just what the Souls-like genre was missing. To add insult to injury, those sections are often placed just after a checkpoint, meaning that dying forces you to endure the whole squishy ordeal all over again. Fun.

The environment design is especially fantastic. This is a modern Triple A game that actually looks the part. Facial models and animations are also top notch. This game has a ton of climbing and even puzzle sections so I would say it's actually much closer to Uncharted/Tomb Raider than any Souls game. There's also high octane set piece moments straight out of Uncharted and those are great. As a cinematic story driven single player experience, the game is good. But as a Souls-like, it misses the mark. Honestly, I think it should have dropped the Souls elements entirely and fully committed to being an Uncharted-esque game, which is what the game was better at doing. 

Overall, it's a good game and I'd give it a 6/10, but unfortunately the entire experience was ruined when I got jumpscared by an emoji and fell off my chair and banged my frigging knee elbow.

Main Story Completion time - 15 hours
100% Completion time - 32 hours
This review contains very minor spoilers

Definitely one of the better Star Wars games of the last decade. Strong recommendation for any Star Wars fans. Souls-like fans may enjoy the game but may also find the combat to be lacking.

Visually, the environments are beautiful and diverse. Most enemies are well designed and animated. Cal himself is a bit of a trainwreck, with a handful of goofy animations (running in particular is just awful) and the remainder of the main cast isn't much better (Cere's eyes look as though they are going to bulge out at any moment -- even in the trailers).

The soundtrack, as with almost every Star Wars product, is on par with the best. The main theme is beautiful, and the backing tracks thoughout the game are new and refreshing, while at the same time classic Star Wars.

The story is on the shorter end (you could definitely finish it up in 10 hours, but I spent a decent chunk of time exploring.) That being said, it's a well written and paced, with some non-offensive new additions to the canon. There are several compelling voice acting performances, and serviceable but predictable villains (seriously, you could probably guess their motivations within the first hour -- this isn't breaking any new ground narratively)

As for the most important factor, gameplay, it's fairly good. I played through the game on Jedi Grandmaster (the highest difficulty) and jumped back down to Jedi Master (the recommended) when completing the remaining achievements. Both modes offer responsive controls, satisfying parrying and dodging, and enemy attacks feel fair other than a few glaring exceptions. The game also puts a heavy emphasis on parkour and terrain scaling - most of it is forgiving and decent fun. Some collectibles require somewhat precise jumps that can be slightly annoying.

One definite complaint about the combat is the flashy special moves - most of them are entirely worthless because of long charge-up times for mediocre damage. Your basic heavy attack uses your force bar, which is a questionable choice as it almost feels like you're being punished by the developers for finding an opening for one. There are a few special moves (notably the move that allows you to swap saber stances) that do extremely high damage and will end up being what you spam to take down tankier enemies. Its disappointing not being able to mix in a number of different moves because your force bar is so limited throughout the game, and the consequence for missing is almost certain death on the highest difficulty.

That being said, the main boss fights are quite fun and decently challenging. The optional bosses are all reskins of normal wildlife you can encounter with amped health and damage, stuffed into small arenas to give them artificial difficulty - they aren't fun nor are they interesting.

As for the completionists out there, you will almost certainly need to use youtube videos showing you optimal paths if you don't want to spend 100 hours on this. Missing a single collectible is a huge pain as there is no fast travel in the game. There are also achievements that fall mostly to luck like the bounty hunter ones.

Good fun for one playthrough. 
The planets are really intricately designed, so they can be really tricky to navigate, and the map does not help. I would sometimes have to spend more time trying to find my way out of a level than progressing through the story. 
Story is good, and all of the character writing is great, and I really liked the casting.
Character customization is a little sparse, but this was something which was fixed in the sequel.
Combat feels like a slower (and clunkier) take on the Sekiro combat model. Fighting an enemy one-on-one feels really satisfying, especially once you have their attack timings down. Trying to fight multiple enemies at the same time felt overwhelming; they could overlap attacks, and your block recovery animation means you can only perfect block the first hit. 
Overall a positive experience, but I won't be going back to play through it again any time soon.
I am not usually a souls-like fan, but this game is a bit more forgiving than most of the souls-like genre, plus has a solid game loop.

I have been in a gaming slump for a few years, I'm going to be honest. Most of it has been just casual depression and not having any interests even with gaming. This year I started making some healthy life choices like quitting alcohol, getting on HRT for gender-affirming stuff, trying to spend more time outside. I have found myself surprised (though it's not unbelievable) that my interests like reading and gaming are also coming back. Having said this, [u] Jedi: Fallen Order [/u] was the first game I've picked up in quite a long while. I played it on the 2nd easiest difficulty and found the story rich and inviting for a welcome back into the gaming world. I know it's an older game, four years at the time of this review, but it was a welcome treasure in my life. Cannot wait to play the next one (as well as start conquering my playlist).

In a galaxy far, far away, a remarkable Star Wars game has arrived, and it has truly left me in awe. As a devoted fan of the franchise, I had high expectations, and I can confidently say that this game has exceeded them on multiple fronts.

From side quests and collectibles to customization options and hidden easter eggs, there's always something new to discover.
The gameplay mechanics are a perfect blend of excitement and challenge.
hi
I love this game

Great game overall. I am not a Star Wars fan but it was still an enjoyable ride. Gameplay feels very good and graphics are great considering that it is a bit older. The puzzles and climbing are not too difficult and some are actually fun. Story is well written and I cant wait to play the next part.

The one annoying thing was the map layout/minimap and the inability to fast travel.

The timing of the cinematic clips is one of the best parts of the game...right when you're annoyed that you have to go back through something you've already done, the game surprises you with more (of a great) story line. :)

Easily one of the best single player games I have played. I picked this up not knowing anything about it and I am very pleased to say that this game is a certified banger, almost akin to a masterpiece even. 

I completed my playthrough on Jedi Master difficulty and it feels like just the right amount of difficulty. You can kill and counter enemies but you can easily die if you get greedy. 
Amazing gameplay, a really good story and that sweet sweet Star Wars lore.
Great Game!

The story is highly enjoyable - average fans and die-hards should both enjoy the time period.

Visually, the game is nothing short of stunning. The devs clearly spent time meticulously crafting breathtaking environments that range from ancient temples to lush forests. Each location captures the essence of the Star Wars universe, drawing you into a world filled with awe-inspiring detail and captivating visuals.

While the gameplay in Jedi: Fallen Order is undeniably satisfying, it does come with its fair share of challenges. Combat requires precise timing and skillful execution, presenting a learning curve that may take some time to conquer. It's worth noting that certain encounters and enemy AI can feel unbalanced, resulting in occasional frustration. Nevertheless, the immense joy derived from executing fluid lightsaber attacks and counter.

The puzzle aspects of the game felt a bit half-baked for how many of them existed in the game - the sheer amount of times gameplay was interrupted to complete a mandatory force push/lift puzzle started to feel obnoxious. Instead, I wish that these were left out of the game in favor of more challenging movement puzzles.

In summary, Jedi: Fallen Order is a must-play experience for both avid Star Wars fans and action-adventure enthusiasts. Recommended at full price.

The gameplay in Jedi: Fallen Order strikes a satisfying balance between exploration, combat, and puzzle-solving. Players will traverse diverse and visually stunning environments, from lush forests to ancient temples and hostile industrial planets. The platforming elements, coupled with the Force abilities at Cal's disposal, offer a refreshing and dynamic experience. The lightsaber combat is another highlight, providing an authentic and challenging representation of wielding a Jedi weapon. As Cal progresses, he can unlock new skills and upgrades, enhancing his combat prowess and expanding his repertoire of Force powers.

One of my favorite Star Wars games, but the support between EA & Steam deck gives constant compatibility troubles. Play it on P5 instead.

I have somewhat fond memories of the few hours I put into the game back when I first purchased and played it. Unfortunately, I had a slightly underpowered GPU for my monitor's resolution at the time, so I shelved the game and decided to come back after an upgrade. Well, that upgrade has come and I remembered this game was in my library. So I install all 50-god-forsaken-GBs and go to launch the game.

"No," says the EA Desktop app. "There is an error on our end" which translates into I cannot play the singleplayer game on MY end.

I tried all sorts of troubleshooting suggestions online and finally found one that worked: Do not use Steam. Launch the game directly from its directory.

So I launch into the game and I am presented with a message that the game is best played on a controller. That's fine, I had one in my hand already. That was my plan the entire time. It would help if the buttons respond, though. I use the keyboard and mouse (and quickly realize why a controller is recommended as the menu is almost unusable with KB+M) to check my settings. I restart the game a couple of times and still the best I get is the my thumbstick moves around menus but none of my button presses register.

Off to the internet I go again and find few suggestions for this particular problem. Nothing works and all of the solutions seem to assume one is launching the game from Steam. I can't fault them for that assumption, it would be the natural course of playing a game purchased through Steam. The only suggestion sounded promising was to disconnect USB devices until maybe the game decided that the game controller was the game controller, but I was exhausted. I was defeated.

I have played 5 hours of the game. I remember it looking pretty good and playing fine. I would love to confirm if this is still the case. I would love to finish the game. Yet, I cannot. EA has decided that simply buying the game is not enough. I must install their insipid launcher. I must suffer through shoddy design decisions. I am a year or more passed being able to get a refund.

EA has won. They got my money. I have lost.

[h1]What I liked: [/h1]
[list]
 [*]More sekiro-like than souls-like
 [*] Great enemy variety, especially the purge troopers and bounty hunters
 [*] Cool worlds and levels/metroidvania
 [/list]

[h1]What I didn‚Äôt like: [/h1]
[list]
    [*]Star Wars reskin of popular games
   [*]Most exploration rewards are generic cosmetics
    [*]Combat is the weakest part
    [*]Technical issues
 [/list]
[h1]My Score: [/h1]
[b]C[/b]

[h1]Quick Summary [/h1]
There are two camps of people, those who have played Jedi Knight Series and those who have not, that will decide how much you will like this game. It‚Äôs now the second best Jedi videogame. The story is better than it should be given the publisher, Disney reboots, and AAA standards that I‚Äôve grown to know will always disappoint. Luckily the game is just good enough in taking the tropes of popular games and reskinning it to please Star Wars fans that want to pretend to be a Jedi one more time.

 [h1]More in depth: [/h1]
[list]
[*]The STORY WAS WAY BETTER THAN I THOUGHT WHEN COMPARED TO BOTH THE RECENT MOVIES, can‚Äôt go lower than rock bottom I guess and most AAA games, the theme of failure and forgiveness hits in a couple scenes. Wished they focused more on the relationships of Cal, Cere and Trilla, the interactions were so few and far between with a lot Cal being alone with boring ‚Äúaudio logs‚Äù that did world building stuff, but with so many and nothing of interest to me, at least it doesn‚Äôt get in the way. It was more personal with Cal and Cere, and would love to see the bond in a sequel and the cast return.  The story is more than passable when compared to the average game and it was published by EA, see EA let a developer do what they want and they will make a good game, so please don‚Äôt fuck this up like every other franchise. OVERALL THE CAST IS A WELCOME ADDITION AND WOULD LOVE TO SEE A SEQUEL EVOLVE THE CHEMISTRY FURTHER, INSTEAD OF BEING MOSTLY EXPOSITION OR MAGUFFIN. Star Wars is loved for the characters in the world, not the other way around. Also it acknowledges the prequels and uses some of it instead of ignoring it to make it better.  2 for 2 with Mandalorian as well

   [*]   The WORLD AND EXPLORATION has I think 5 or 6 planets to explore, they are mostly for exploring to get new powers and the weirdly purely cosmetics only secrets with the rare HP boosts and bosses. The worlds are populated with animal, environmental hazards, fun and interesting platforming, with some actually good puzzles that I didn‚Äôt expect seeing as the target audience is for. I would say that this is better than the action in this game from a design point with a lot more challenge and fun varied stuff to do. The robot companion BD-12 is as always with star wars pals, cute and got that charm.

[*] SPEAKING OF BOSSES the main ones are mainly pretty weak and feel again generic with mash buttons and they block waiting for some QTES in some of them, can we stop with that. The final boss is great and feels more like an actual fight, the bounty hunters are the standout for sure. They aren‚Äôt a huge variety in them as I found them all, but they feel fresh and fun to fight even if for the most part they aren‚Äôt a challenge, well I am a Jedi and they don‚Äôt use lightsabers. I would love to see this expanded and used as a template for how the bosses should go, just make them have more than one or two attacks and an actual challenge
[*]COMBAT IS OVERALL THE WEAKEST PART OF THE GAME FOR A COUPLE REASONS, FIRST THE GOOD. I like the variety of enemies, each one has something to mix up the formula and keep it fresh throughout the game, very similar issue I had with Control and is usually the case with AAA games. None are really challenging with most of them having just one attack or defense, like can‚Äôt be pushed, has heavy unblockable attacks, rapid fire guns and more that I would of loved to see pushed further for those wanting a challenge, with most enemies being placed in a manner that fights never required heavy planning. I do like that this follows the same design as Sekiro with parry and stance mechanics that I hope become a new norm in sword based games.

[*]NOW THE BAD PART OF THE COMBAT and this is coming from some that has played a fair bit of games including Jedi Academy, Kingdom Come Deliverance. Sekiro, Furi and now Ghostrunner, this game is a pale imitation for both fans wanting to feel like a Jedi and have meaningful swordplay. If you want to know why those are great and this isn‚Äôt, the reviews for each are below. I don‚Äôt think most people will disagree on the combat feeling like a reskin of just about any major Hack and Slash game like Assassins Creed, even the great God of War reboot, or the other standard combat system like the Batman series. So that points a picture on how the combat feels. So if you haven‚Äôt played any of the standout melee games I‚Äôve mentioned, this game will be better for you most likely. I get the game wants kids to play so you can‚Äôt chop humans up and they get around that with robots and animals being able to get slashed and boy does it make a MASSIVE DIFFERENCE IN FEEL. Also max difficulty doesn‚Äôt make the game that much better; I do like that each bump up makes the parry window less forgiving. Other than that it‚Äôs artificial stats.

[*]The FORCE POWERS being the staple of what makes a Jedi game standout look to Jedi Academy for how to do it perfectly. Here you do get a watered-down version with the sith ones gone and I can see that for story and character reasons. Most of the time I used them is for the metroidvania style exploration to push, pull and freeze puzzles to progress. This is fine as it breaks up the pacing of the game and might go into the realm at times of feeling like a Tomb raider vibe instead of A Jedi vibe, but it‚Äôs better at it than the game that are known for it, so kudos Respawn. Heavy attacks never felt like could be used it‚Äôs long timing and short windows. THE FORCE POWERS FOR ME CAN BE SUMMED UP IN USED ON CANNON FODDER TO CHEAPLY GET THE FEELING OF POWER INSTEAD OF EARNING IT BY USING THEM IN YOUR ARSENAL TO OVERCOME THE ODDS AND BECOME AN ACTUAL JEDI.

     [*]    TECHNICAL ISSUES AND PRAISE:  I had to reduce to 1080p with a GTX 1080, seems to be poorly optimized for stable above 60 fps at 1440p. Crashed twice, once during the final boss fight, has a lot of stutters that happen. It‚Äôs one big load at the boot of game. It does mask its loading very well and hope to see more games do this, by traveling in the ship instead of just a normal loading, and tight going through tight crawl spaces during gameplay, which is standard, but noticed it way more in this game than most. 
[/list]

STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order is a thrilling and immersive journey that captures the essence of the beloved Star Wars universe. From its captivating storyline to its exhilarating gameplay, this game delivers an unforgettable experience that will leave fans and newcomers alike in awe.

One of the standout features of Fallen Order is its compelling narrative. Set in the aftermath of Order 66, players assume the role of Cal Kestis, a young Jedi Padawan on a quest for survival and redemption. The story unfolds with masterful storytelling, featuring memorable characters, intense emotional moments, and unexpected plot twists that keep you engaged from start to finish. The game successfully captures the spirit of Star Wars, delving into themes of hope, friendship, and the eternal struggle between the light and dark sides of the Force.

The gameplay in Fallen Order is a perfect blend of exploration, combat, and puzzle-solving. As Cal, you navigate through intricately designed environments, utilizing your Force abilities and lightsaber skills to overcome obstacles and enemies. The combat system is satisfyingly challenging, requiring precise timing, strategy, and the effective use of defensive maneuvers and offensive combinations. The lightsaber battles are truly epic, allowing you to unleash your inner Jedi or Sith as you face formidable adversaries.

The attention to detail in Fallen Order is exceptional. The game's visuals are stunning, capturing the iconic Star Wars aesthetic with meticulous care. From the bustling cities to the lush jungles and ancient temples, each location is brimming with authenticity and immersive atmosphere. The sound design is equally impressive, with familiar blaster sounds, lightsaber hums, and the iconic musical score enhancing the overall experience.

Fallen Order's world-building is commendable. As you explore different planets and interact with various characters, you uncover the lore and history of the Star Wars universe. The game seamlessly weaves together elements from the films and expanded universe, creating a cohesive and richly detailed setting. Collectibles and hidden secrets further reward exploration, enticing you to delve deeper into the game's expansive universe.

Moreover, Fallen Order offers a sense of progression and character development. As you advance in the game, you unlock new abilities, upgrade your skills, and customize your lightsaber, empowering you to take on increasingly challenging encounters. This sense of growth and personalization adds depth and longevity to the overall experience.

Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order is a gaming masterpiece that flawlessly captures the essence of the Star Wars universe. With its stunning graphics, immersive gameplay, captivating storytelling, and exceptional acting, Respawn Entertainment has created an unforgettable experience that will leave fans and newcomers alike in awe.

Let's start with the graphics. From the moment you step foot into the galaxy far, far away, you're greeted with a level of visual fidelity that is truly breathtaking. The environments, whether it's the ancient forests of Kashyyyk or the bustling streets of Nar Shaddaa, are meticulously designed with incredible attention to detail. Each planet feels alive and unique, immersing you in its beauty and danger. The character models, especially the protagonist Cal Kestis and his companions, are rendered with remarkable realism, bringing them to life in a way that feels authentic and true to the Star Wars universe.

The gameplay of Jedi: Fallen Order is equally exceptional. As Cal Kestis, a young Jedi on a quest to rebuild the Jedi Order, you embark on a thrilling adventure filled with intense lightsaber combat, challenging puzzles, and exhilarating platforming. The lightsaber combat system is deeply satisfying, allowing for precise strikes, parries, and Force abilities that make you feel like a true Jedi. The platforming sections are well-crafted, requiring skill and agility to navigate treacherous landscapes and uncover hidden secrets. The inclusion of Metroidvania elements, where exploration and backtracking are rewarded with new abilities and upgrades, adds depth and replayability to the game.

One of the standout aspects of Jedi: Fallen Order is its captivating storytelling. The game's narrative is a gripping tale of redemption, discovery, and the fight against the dark forces that threaten the galaxy. The characters are well-developed and engaging, each with their own unique personalities and motivations. Cal's journey is filled with emotional moments and unexpected twists that keep you invested from start to finish. The story seamlessly weaves itself into the larger Star Wars lore, introducing new elements while staying true to the established canon.

The acting in Jedi: Fallen Order is top-notch. The voice performances, led by Cameron Monaghan as Cal Kestis, deliver a level of authenticity and emotional depth that enhances the overall experience. The interactions between characters feel natural, and the dialogue is well-written, immersing you further into the game's world. The cinematic cutscenes are beautifully crafted and showcase the talents of the actors, bringing pivotal moments to life with cinematic flair.

In terms of game mechanics, Jedi: Fallen Order shines in its balance of combat, exploration, and puzzle-solving. The skill tree system allows you to customize Cal's abilities to suit your preferred playstyle, offering a sense of progression and mastery. The integration of the Force powers into combat and puzzle-solving is seamless, providing a satisfying sense of empowerment and creativity. The level design is cleverly crafted, encouraging exploration and rewarding those who venture off the beaten path.

In conclusion, Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order is a triumph in every aspect. Its stunning graphics, immersive gameplay, engaging storytelling, and superb acting come together to create an unforgettable Star Wars adventure. Whether you're a die-hard fan or a newcomer to the franchise, this game will transport you to a galaxy far, far away and make you feel like a true Jedi. Respawn Entertainment has set a new standard for Star Wars games, and Jedi: Fallen Order stands as a testament to their passion and dedication to delivering an exceptional gaming experience.

Imagine a cross between dark souls and sekiro but then make it much less polished.

First of all, we have no fast travel system. this game has 'bonfires' all over the map and you have to walk your way towards them each time. what makes this so much worse is that you get new powers that allows you to further explore a map. Meaning if you remember a place you couldn't get to before there is no quick way to get there, you have to slog through all the entire level.

There are also parts of the map that just don't load the actually platforms and you just fall through. And these aren't even particularly difficult to get through. in one dungeon i wanted to drop down to the lower flow instead of running around the entire dungeon (See criticism above), but when I landed on the platform that was solid before, I fell through the level. There are also entire ships that you would think you could jump on, but you will just fall through. Thankfully this game doesn't send you to a bonfire when you fall, but what can happen is you fall through a platform trying to find secrets and you have to start the level over again, because for some reason there IS NO QUICK TRAVEL! ugh.

Whenever you open up the game you have to deal with about 90s of intro music and animations playing at max volume. Think of CIv 6, and how only after you reach t he menu do you volume settings kick in. There are also forced 'load times' between planets. The reason why a game like mass effect had long ship animations was to allow the game to load. I didn't install this game on an NVME SSD to have to wait through fake load times.

there are also some strange animation things going on. One of them is just cosmetic, when you open a container underwater the container rattles around even though your droid doesnt enter. Others are kind of game breaking. the first miniboss monster you fight (toad looking thing) can just completely break its AI after a jump attack. or sometimes it just flies off into the heavens.

The basic gameplay loop is pretty good and the exploration itself isn't bad but the issues come up too frequently and takes away from the enjoyment. since this game is pretty old now it is safe to say these issues will never get fixed overall an EA/10

[h1] My review of STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order‚Ñ¢ [/h1]

First of all, this is an [b] updated review[/b], with +50 hours, after the review I made in 2020. And [b]after[/b] playing STAR WARS Jedi: Survivor‚Ñ¢, so the opinion might not be ‚Äòfair‚Äô(?), but here I go.

[b] My PC specs: [/b]

‚Ä¢	Intel Core i7-11700F, 2.50GHz, 8 cores, 16 threads
‚Ä¢	RAM: 24GB
‚Ä¢	VRAM: 12GB
‚Ä¢	NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3060
‚Ä¢	SSD: 1TB

[b] My thoughts about STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order‚Ñ¢ [/b]

I love this game. When it first released, I was fascinated by everything on it. The story is well written, absorbing, entertaining, and all the characters are compelling. I remember craving for a game a la Tomb Raider (which I also love), where I could explore, collect things and get maps to 100%. This game delivered. Cal felt like a Lara Croft, but with a lightsaber.

The cinematics and the music are on point, and so is the action and gameplay*. The environments of each planet are beautiful on their own way, and having to unlock abilities to resolve puzzles makes the replayability of each planet a fun experience. The way it fits in the canon of the STAR WARS universe is even better. My only negative thought, and not about this game honestly, but everything EA:

[b] Requiring the EA App in order to play an EA game has to be the most absurd and infuriating thing I‚Äôve experienced in videogames. And not only EA does it, but it‚Äôs sincerely annoying. Stop. Please. [/b]


[b] Do I recommend STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order‚Ñ¢? [/b]

Yes, as a must, honestly. But also, please play it before its successor. Sounds like a stupid request, but the improvement in gameplay on the second one is so big that if you play this one after, you won‚Äôt have as much fun and you will even feel some things kinda‚Ä¶ rusty. Just be ready to have EA App installed, because that‚Äôs a dumb requirement you‚Äôll need to do.

[h1]STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order‚Ñ¢[/h1]
STAR WARS Jedi: Fallen Order‚Ñ¢ is Respawn's and EA's single-player game that, despite the little amount of faith from the publisher, has achieved great success in the world of Star Wars and games in general. The main character ( Cal Kestis ) is played by actor Cameron Monaghan, and the game itself features many voice actors we know from other Star Wars media, e.g. Dee Bradley Baker.
[h1]The Plot[/h1]
The main plot is survival in a galaxy overrun by the Empire, and as we are a Jedi Padawan, this will not be an easy task. The game will lead us through several iconic planets that we have seen in TV series and movies, and each of them will give us new environments, enemies, and plot threads. Over the course of the game, we'll fight Cal's traumatic past and his uncertainty about the future, allowing us to see some cool visions, and visit the Clone Wars era to regain our abilities in the Force, eventually transforming into a true Jedi Knight. The characters themselves are very well written, Cal is a really multi-layered character, and the great acting and dedication of the actor playing him really adds a lot. He's definitely one of the best characters in Star Wars, and I'd love to see him in live-action someday. As for our companions, they are interesting enough, not only visually different, but also have different views on the galaxy, given that each of them played a different role in the Clone Wars, which ended up changing their lives for rather worse. Moving on to our main enemies, which are the Inquisitors, their characters are cool, and even cooler if you read the comics about their whole institution. The very end of the game is a great climax, and a good excuse for a juicy cameo. The only downside to all of this is that the game's main antagonist is quite a frequent enemy, which makes our subsequent interactions with her less interesting, not to mention that the cutscenes are the only barrier that makes most of the game's characters even able to survive until the end credits.
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Still very solid, but here I start to have slight problems with the game. But first, the positives. I really liked the locations we visit, there is a good amount of them, they have many nooks and crannies to explore, different collectibles, and different enemies, and even though there aren't that many in the game, they are either stormtroopers or local animals, they are nicely modeled and original in their combat roles. Coming to the combat itself, I really enjoyed it, the game is well-balanced, it's not easy, but it's not impossibly hard either. And no, it's not a Dark Souls clone, the best example of this is that parrying is more important than rolling around like a lunatic. The developers really wanted to give us a lot of opportunities to approach different situations in different ways, using lightsaber powers and combat forms, and they managed it, every fight can be exciting, giving us a lot of freedom. Going to the lightsaber, it's fun to swing, it's fast, but you can also feel the power of its strikes. It's just a shame there's no dismemberment ( at least when we are talking about humans ). A nice detail are also the comments of the opponents, who will actively comment on their situation and what is happening around them. However, I also sense a large portion of ludonarrative dissonance. The point is that although it's not a Dark Souls clone, this game follows the same logic of combat and bonfires, which are meditation points in this game. What was explained and made sense in Dark Souls is not here. Why do stormtroopers magically respawn in the same places every time we meditate? Can the Emperor's new generation of stormtroopers reproduce like amoebas around building corners/caves every time we take a break? And why can't I cut through doors with my lightsaber like Qui-Gon Jinn in episode 1, does the Empire have such a big budget that they installed beskar doors specially in case one of the 200 living Jedi in the entire galaxy decides to show up at that random planet? And why when fighting opponents with a higher health bar, a cool lightsaber fight turns into a baseball bat swinging where you have to pound and pound this opponent endlessly as if he wasn't just getting slapped in the face with a sun-surface-temperature lightsaber? I know it's a game, and it had to be done that way, but it's a bit inconsistent with the concept. At least the bosses are cool. What's not cool though is parkour in my opinion, there's a bit too much of it, and it's not smooth enough for me to enjoy it, and combined with the rather annoying puzzles, this game quickly turns into Tomb Raider: Space Edition. Which isn't cool though, because it's a Star Wars game after all, and I personally want to fight swarms of enemies and mow them down with my lightsaber, and not use my brain that much for these 20h. Maybe I just don't like puzzles and jumping from wall to wall every 2 minutes ( probably because of my total lack of patience ).
[h1]Technical Matters[/h1]
Despite the very good graphics, the game is very stable, there is no problem with FPS, and it does not crash to the desktop. Bugs are rather non-existent. The music is obviously standard Star Wars music, so that's always a plus, as are the sound and visual effects.
[h1]Summary[/h1]
Although not perfect, it is certainly one of the best Star Wars games on the market. A game that wasn't as good as it could have been because of EA's lack of faith in singleplayer games. I'm glad, however, that this game showed their mistake, and that Cal will soon have a whole trilogy of games under his belt, where the potential of the universe will develop dramatically ( and I'm still keeping my fingers crossed for the live-action version, but looking at Disney, it would be a total Russian roulette when it comes to quality ).

It was a great experience.
