Sometimes i wished there were some ways to fast travel between save points, some other times i gotta give credits to the map design for linking the deepest end of the map back to the spaceship, so travelling back was not too frustrating.

- Dark Souls-like but easier: Souls-lite(?). No need to grind, loved it. Death was not too punishing, loved it too. Chests are for cosmetics only, no in-game currency, THE BEST.

- had some visual glitches during cutscenes. Cal was holding his lightsaber without his hand touching. Looked weird but nothing game breaking. Got pushed out of bound one time during the final boss fight though.

- a little bit of post game content. Not enough to make me want to start NG+.

Nothing amazing or super exciting here but Jedi Fallen Order is a good game overall. In all honestly it kind of feels like a poor man's Dark Souls meets a poor man's Uncharted; nothing here is really done better than either of those other two franchises. That being said Jedi Fallen Order is still objectively good. The gameplay and traversal and combat are all pretty good, the characters are enjoyable, the story is solid, there are great visuals and decent music and good bosses, etc. It's obvious that a lot of time was put into the game and it shows in general. Some of my frustrations with this game came from the absurd amount of backtracking, the unrewarding loot system/upgrades, and the constant reuse of a lot of enemies. I also think the beginning of the game was far too slow, but things pick up quickly in terms of variety and gameplay by the second planet. All in all I'd say this was a good game; I'd say get it on sale personally but it is still worth your time and money overall for sure, especially if you're a Star Wars fan.

And the thing, that I hate the most in this game is that, after finishing the main quest on some of the planets, you simply cannot return to your ship using the same path, that you used back when you just landed on the planet, so you will spend minutes returning back to finish the level. And another problem is, that exploration doesn't pay off, and I mean, that if you find a hidden area, it will have a crate with just a lightsaber customization thingies in most cases, and those custom mods for lightsaber don't do anything. So exploration is just pointless in this game. To be honest, I'm a bit disappointed, I expected more from this game, It's one of the few games that I didn't like in the last couple of years. Even the campaign of "Star Wars: Battlefront 2" was more fun for me to play.

Exploration and story were fun, combat was somewhat lackluster, but maybe thats on me because i thought it would be more souls like. Honestly, its just nice to have some really good star wars single player games.

[h1]Star Wars Return of the Jedi-sappointment. Hard to admit, but it really kinda sucks.[/h1]

For pretty much exactly 20 years now my favorite Star Wars games (and two of my all-time favorite games in general) have been Jedi Knight 2: Jedi Outcast and its successor Jedi Academy. Those two games have everything that a nearly perfect Star Wars game needs: A serviceable story with the distinct Star Wars atmosphere and some awesome cameos of Luke Skywalker, Lando Calrissian, Chewbacca and Boba Fett, appropriate presentation that faithfully follows the movies, varied and action-packed leveldesign and last but not least absolutely revolutionary lightsaber combat that was unmatched at that time and still holds up well today. Nevertheless, even the best games start to age at some point, so I had high hopes that after all those years Jedi Fallen Order would finally pick up the staff as a sort of spiritual successor to the old Jedi Knight games and be the new best Star Wars game for the next 20 years to come. But oh well, it seems that the Jedi Knight series continues to comfortably sit on its throne: Jedi Fallen Order completely failed to fulfill my expectations by a very long shot. 

I have exactly three positive things to say about this: First, the presentation is beyond any doubt. Grafics, sound, voice-acting and animations are great and the opening chapter really gets you pumped with its cinematic staging. Second, Cal Kestis and his little droid are likable guys. Cal reminds me a bit of a young Obi-Wan Kenobi and is a cool guy to play as. Finally, the numerous possibilities to customize your lightsaber are every Star Wars nerd's wet dream.

As soon as you get to the gameplay though, Jedi Fallen Order goes rapidly downhill. The game showed me first hand, why I have absolutely zero interest in Souls-like games: The combat is...meh. Again, the animations are top-notch and it is fun enough to throw Stormtroopers off ledges with force push, but all those boring, repetitive battles against all those generic animals and weird alien critters, with this combat system that i think is more of a glorified variation on quicktime events than anything else, is not exactly fun or engaging. It's rather annoying. If only the enemies wouldn't respawn everytime you meditate at a safe point, but oh well.

The biggest fault is the poor run-of-the-mill metroidvania concept, with it's confusing, irritating leveldesign and poorly copied Assassin's Creed parcour movement. All you do is stumbling around in those drab, lifeless, convoluted levels, opening chests that barely contain anything else than superficial cosmetics and then get lost or confused by one of the awfully designed puzzles. The leveldesign really killed the game for me. On Zeffo for example, the third planet you visit, I spent about close to two hours (including a peek into a walkthrough) just figuring out the proper way how to backtrack to my ship. Everything in those levels looks totally samey and the godawful map doesn't help jack-sh*t. Take this monotonous, bland and boring visual design of the environments plus the respawning enemies, add some more ridiculously annoying gameplay gimmicks (oh those slides, they make my blood boil) and voil√°, you've got yourself some mediocre wannabe-Metroidvania gameplay that just feels horribly wrong for a Star Wars game. It's really a shame, because on some very few occasions Jedi Fallen Order has some worthy Star Wars moments, for example when you arrive on Kashyyyk in the middle of a fight between the rebels and the empire and hijack an AT-AT to wreak havoc. What could have been if only the game had more of this and less of all the b*llsh*t I mentioned before?

Jedi Fallen Order just steals some elements from other successful titles like Dark Souls, Assassin's Creed, Tomb Raider, Uncharted and various Metroidvanias, slaps the Star Wars name on top and there you go. It does some things decent enough, but nothing really convincingly well. As a huge Star Wars fan who waited two decades for a proper Star Wars action-adventure with a focus on storytelling and lightsaber combat, it's a tough pill to swallow and really hard to admit, but Jedi Fallen Order is just one of those style-over-substance games, that is not really bad, but feels hollow and bland and is just downright boring and confusing for some long stretches. If only I had played this sooner, I really would've thought twice about pre-ordering Jedi Survivor Deluxe Edition for 90 g*dd*mn m*therf*cking Euros, but I was totally conviced, that it was simply impossible for this game to be anything else but absolutely great. I thought this was going to be on the very top of the Star Wars game food-chain, alongside games like Jedi Knight, X-Wing and Knights of the Old Republic. I was wrong. Very wrong.

So, if you have the same misguided expectations as I had, turn away from this game and never look back because:
This game is not about fighting breathtaking lightsaber duels against mighty sinister Sith Lords. It is not about evolving all the way from a measly Padawan to a powerful Jedi Knight, and it sure as sh*t is not about saving the galaxy from an unspeakably evil of epic proportions. 
It is about traveling back and forth between the same handful of completely lifeless planets in the most boring and drab corner of the Star Wars universe to collect f*uckin ponchos. 
_________________________________________________________________________________

STAR WARS JEDI FALLEN ORDER
Genre: Action-Adventure
Release: Q4 2019

After years of mediocre and even polemic Star Wars games (yes I am talking about loot boxes EA, after all these years I still remember it) finally Electronic Arts gave us a game that basically is what many of the Star Wars fans expect of a game set in the Star Wars universe, a story driven game. 

Fallen Order is a great third person action game that tells us the story of a Jedi Padawan that escaped the purge of Order 66 and is now on a journey to regain his powers and to rebuild the Jedi order. 

Visually it is a pretty nice game, the scenery is amazing and the characters as well. You will feel an immersed vibe because the whole game is full of action, full of intensity and very cinematic. The combat and movement mechanics are pretty great too and most of the areas and puzzles are cool to play with, the planets available to explore and where the story takes place are diverse, different and allow you a proper sense of exploration, since many times you will not be able to go from A to B because you did not unlock this power or that feature (you get the picture, normal game locking mechanics).

But the important thing to retain is that Fallen Order is without a doubt a great game and I fully recommend it! 
Quick last minute note that I believe that is relevant to many of you, if you do not wanna pay full price you can wishlist it and wait for a price drop, since it frequently appears on sale or you can subscribe to EA Play and enjoy it through there.

A good balanced between difficulty and story. The story mode was really cool and the sound, graphics are beautiful. The only downside is it requires an online connection and signing into EAs launcher.

This game is a cool cinematic experience, and it does a pretty good job of making you feel like you're in the Star Wars universe. I enjoyed the game, and it's worth getting on sale.

I do want to mention however that the 6th highest tag for this game is 'Open World', and I want to make sure you know that this game is NO WHERE CLOSE to an open world game. It's extremely linear. It appears to be open world with lots of options, but in reality it's essentially a 3D platformer. There are many invisible boundry's, death pits, and even land that you just fall straight through if you try to land on it(even land you have stood on earlier, but if you don't reach it using one of the few paths they have planned, then it doesn't 'load' in or something). So if you're interested in playing an 'Open World' Star Wars game, this is NOT it.

10/10

Typical modern AAA game produced for console.

The gameplay is made with controller in mind. If you like the typical "reaction" based gameplay where you have to press a button upon action of enemies, this is a game for you... for me it wasn't. 

Without liking the gameplay, the story and game world have to compensate to keep me immersed in the game. The story during the intro together with good world building did indeed a good job. Unfortunately, this only held up until the game left the linear section of the intro and released the player into an open world section (presumably the main part of the game).  Here, the story did not progress at all and simultaneously the world became extremely scarce. (Not a lot to search for, lots of running). I did not continue playing the game from here.

This is probably a game for console players with controllers, who generally like (re)action-based game mechanics like jump-and-run. It is not for people who like fps games or rpg.
